http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2014/oct/17/big-pharma-interest-rich-people-sick <p>The giant pharmaceutical company <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/glaxosmithkline" title="">GlaxoSmithKline</a> said yesterday that its work on a vaccine for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/ebola" title="">Ebola</a> will “come too late” to do anything about the current situation. Even now it is trying to compress trials that would normally take a decade into a year. The impression it gives is that it is working flat out, no holds barred. But hang on a moment. Ebola was discovered back in 1976. What has GlaxoSmithKline been doing since then? Answer: not much.</p> <p>A small clue to why can be found by looking at the stock price of Tekmira Pharmaceuticals, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/sep/22/ebola-treatment-us-canada-tekmira-drugs-authorize" title="">the Canadian-based drugs firm that some investors seem to think is leading the pack on Ebola research</a>. Tekmira shares rose a massive 180% from mid-July to October, with most of the share-price action coming when the virus jumped to Europe and the US.</p> <p>Ebola has been killing people in central and western Africa for at least 38 years – but it’s only when the virus becomes a threat to the developed world that there is seen to be a profit in it. I know it sounds cynical to say it flat out like that – but it sounds cynical because it is. What business case is there for developing drugs to save the lives of poor Africans when they don’t have the money to pay for them? Especially when there is so much more profit to be had in – for instance – giving rich white men erections. As a study in last year’s Lancet showed, of the 336 new drugs developed in the first decade of this century, only four of them were for what are known in jargon as neglected tropical diseases – three for malaria and one for diarrhoea.</p> <p>The point being this: the business model of market-driven big (or even medium-sized) pharma does not work well to address the challenges posed by a virus that ultimately has no respect for geography or bank balance. Some of the developed world’s early interest in Ebola was in whether it could be weaponised. It was said that the Russian biological weapons unit – Biopreparat – had turned Ebola into an aerosol spray.</p> <p>All of which is red meat for conspiracy theorists (like those who tell you that the patent for the Ebola virus is owned by the US government, which is true). But my suspicion is not about shady government actions but about basic capitalist economics. Isn’t it interesting that there is money about to ask scientists to turn a virus into a weapon, but not the money about to ask scientists to find a vaccine? And by the time there’s a market for a vaccine, it’s too late.</p> <p>What better example of what is commonly called market failure – that state of affairs in which market forces do not make for desirable outcomes. Here’s another example: remember Nelson Mandela having to take on the big pharmaceutical companies as thousands of dying South Africans were unable to afford Aids drugs. Apparently, the market-driven economics of health care do not have an answer to a virus that begins in a part of the world where there isn’t much money. And that is often where dangerous viruses begin. Which is precisely why market forces will not be able to save us.</p> <p>Indeed, on the contrary, market-driven healthcare is incentivised to keep us sick. For what profit is there in a healthy population? If everyone were healthy, it would be the job of the pharmaceutical companies to persuade us that we were not well, that certain things about us needed fixing, putting right (even if they didn’t).</p> <p>Its a bit like Friedrich Nietzsche’s criticism of the Christian priest: that the priest first has to poison us into imagining we are unwell – and thus in need of saving – before he can present himself as the cure, as salvation. There is no market for salvation in a sinless world. Of course, big pharma presents itself as evidence-based and scientific. Not at all like Nietzsche’s Christianity. But it’s not the science that calls the tune. It is the stock price. And the stock price goes up when rich people feel threatened.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/17/two-suspected-ebola-cases-spain-test-negative-disease <p>All four suspected Ebola cases admitted to hospitals in Spain on Thursday have tested negative for the virus in the initial rounds of tests, authorities said on Friday.</p> <p>On Thursday, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/spain-man-posible-ebola-case-madrid-hospital" title="">a passenger on an Air France flight arriving at Madrid’s airport</a> was taken to hospital after he reported a fever and began trembling during the flight. He had travelled from Lagos in Nigeria to Madrid via Paris. He was brought to Madrid’s Carlos III hospital, the designated centre for treating Ebola patients in the city.</p> <p>Another man, who had later travelled in the ambulance that carried Ebola patient Teresa Romero Ramos last week, was also admitted to the hospital after reporting a fever. Health authorities had been monitoring him after it emerged that seven patients were transported in the Romero Ramos ambulance before it was disinfected.</p> <p>On Friday morning, authorities said both the Air France traveller and the patient who had been in the ambulance had tested negative for Ebola in the first round of tests. Both remain in quarantine while authorities wait for the results of the second round of tests.</p> <p>A missionary, recently returned from Liberia, who was also admitted to the hospital on Thursday tested negative on Friday.</p> <p>Fifteen other patients are in isolation in the Carlos III hospital. None of them have shown any symptoms of Ebola to date.</p> <p>Three people have also been placed in quarantine in the Canary Islands. A Red Cross worker recently returned from treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone was sent to a hospital in Tenerife with a fever on Thursday and tested negative on Friday.</p> <p>Spain’s only patient with a confirmed case of Ebola, Teresa Romero Ramos, remains in stable but serious condition. The presence of Ebola in her blood continues to fall, health officials noted, but cautioned that it was too early to say she is out of danger.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/17/ebola-in-the-us-timeline <h2><strong>20 </strong>September</h2> <p>A Liberian man, Thomas Eric Duncan, arrives in Dallas to visit his family after flying from the Liberian capital Monrovia, via Brussels.</p> <h2>24 September</h2> <p>Duncan begins to feel unwell, according to his family.</p> <h2>25 September</h2> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/01/ebola-us-doctors-texas-liberia">Duncan’s first visit to an emergency room</a> since feeling unwell. Medical records <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/thomas-duncan-ebola-medical-records-high-fever">show he has a temperature of 103F (</a><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/thomas-duncan-ebola-medical-records-high-fever">39.4C</a><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/thomas-duncan-ebola-medical-records-high-fever">)</a> when he arrives at Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in Dallas. He is also suffering “severe” abdominal pains.</p> <h2><strong>26 September</strong></h2> <p>Duncan <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/01/ebola-case-diagnosed-us-officials-texas-virus">sent home from the hospital with a course of antibiotics</a> – an outcome that hospital chiefs later describe as a matter of “regret”. Edward Goodman, the infectious disease specialist at the hospital, later says the patient’s symptoms were not definitive when he was first seen. A nurse notes that Duncan had recently travelled to Africa. Texas Health Resources, which runs the hospital, initially says the nurse did not share information about Duncan’s travel history with doctors. It later retracts this statement.</p> <h2><strong>28 September</strong></h2> <p>Duncan returns to Texas Health Presbyterian in an ambulance <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/01/ebola-us-doctors-texas-liberia">and this time he is admitted</a>. He is suffering more abdominal pains, as well as diarrhoea and vomiting. His condition is described as “critical” and he is put in isolation in the hospital’s intensive care unit.</p> <h2><strong>28-30 September 2014 </strong></h2> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-hospital-sorry-ebola-case-errors">Staff work in the quarantine unit with their skin exposed</a>, according to the National Nurses United union. The hospital later insists that staff wore the appropriate personal protective equipment as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) at the time, including shoe covers and face shields. “When the CDC issued updates, as they did with leg covers, we followed their guidelines,” <a href="http://texashealth.org/news-alert.cfm?id=1629&amp;action=detail&amp;ref=1898">Texas Health Resources says in statement</a>.</p> <h2><strong>29 September</strong></h2> <p>Nina Pham, a 26-year-old nurse, treats Duncan for the first time. There are doubts about whether she was wearing protective clothing when she first came into contact with him. Later there are also reports of <a href="http://edition.cnn.com/2014/10/13/health/ebola-nurse-how-could-this-happen/index.html">“inconsistencies” about how she removed protective gear</a>. She is one of 76 healthcare workers thought to have come into contact with Duncan while at the hospital. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition">Pham enters Duncan’s intensive care unit often</a>, according to medical records. She later becomes the first person to be diagnosed with Ebola after contracting it in the US.</p> <h2><strong>30 September </strong></h2> <p>US officials announce the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/30/first-ebola-case-diagnosed-us">first case of Ebola to be diagnosed outside Africa</a> during the current outbreak. At this stage they do not reveal Duncan’s name but say the Ebola patient is being treated in Dallas.</p> <h2><strong>2 October</strong></h2> <p>Duncan’s girlfriend Louis Troh, and three other family members, are placed under quarantine until 19 October – the end of their 21-day incubation period.</p> <h2><strong>4 October </strong></h2> <p>Duncan is treated with the antiviral drug brincidofovir.</p> <h2><strong>7 October</strong></h2> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition">Pham cares for Duncan</a>.</p> <h2><strong>8 October </strong></h2> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-patient-dies-texas-thomas-eric-duncan">Duncan dies</a> in hospital after his condition worsens.</p> <h2><strong>12 October</strong></h2> <p>Pham is diagnosed with Ebola, two days after reporting a high fever. She is placed in an isolation unit within 90 minutes of driving herself to Texas Health Presbyterian hospital and presenting the symptoms.</p> <h2><strong>13 October </strong></h2> <p>Amber Vinson, a 29-year-old nurse who also treated Duncan at Texas Health Presbyterian, travels on a commercial flight from Cleveland to Dallas with a raised temperature.</p> <h2><strong>15 October</strong></h2> <p>Vinson becomes the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-texas-healthcare-worker-virus">second US health worker to be diagnosed with Ebola</a>, a day after being admitted to THP. She is transferred to a bio-containment unit in Atlanta. The National Nurses United union accuses THP of lax <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/dallas-nurses-accuse-hospital-sloppy-safety-ebola">safety procedures in Duncan’s treatment</a>. They say he was left in an open area of a Dallas emergency room for hours, and the nurses treating him worked for days without proper protective gear. President Barack Obama admits the US must be<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/obama-ebola-international-threat-european-leaders"> more aggressive in monitoring Ebola</a>.</p> <h2><strong>16 October</strong></h2> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-nurse-transferred-texas-maryland-special-unit">Pham is transferred from Dallas</a>, where she contracted the virus, to a special bio-containment unit in Maryland. Texas Health Resources <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-hospital-sorry-ebola-case-errors">apologises for initially failing to diagnose Duncan</a>, and for misinforming the public about how this happened.</p> <h2><strong>17 October</strong></h2> <p>Seventy-five staff members from Texas Health Presbyterian hospital, who are thought to have treated Duncan, are <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-healthcare-workers-ebola-public">urged to sign legal agreements stating they will avoid public transport</a>, not go to areas where large numbers of people congregate, and continue to be monitored twice a day for symptoms.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/17/public-health-ebola-virus-uk <p>Ebola panic is rife. Makeup artists at the BBC are said to be <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2793696/bbc-ban-guests-ebola-hit-countries-entering-buildings-terrified-staff-fear-catch-disease.html" title="">worried about touching the faces of interviewees from Guinea</a>, a <a href="http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/523145/Ebola-school-Ghana-exchange-trip-visit-postpone" title="">school cancelled the visit of a mother and child from Sierra Leone</a> , and rumours and conspiracy theories float through the air in a way that the Ebola virus cannot (it is categorically not airborne).</p> <p>Ask most people and they will probably think Ebola is about to arrive in the UK and is a threat. The first may be true – but it will be a handful of cases, at most – and the second is not. Ebola is not easy to catch. It is transmitted by an exchange of bodily fluids with somebody who is so sick they are vomiting, bleeding or excreting heavily. That puts health workers potentially at risk but very few of the rest of us, and the planned emergency response to any Ebola diagnosis – tracking down and monitoring every contact, just in case – will ensure the risks of spread are minimal.</p> <p>Ebola panic is a global development. It is hard to reassure people when unfounded scare stories are broadcast across the worldwide web. But in several ways this could have been better handled.</p> <p>1. <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/public-health-england" title="">Public Health England</a>, full of expertise on infectious diseases and keeping the public safe, does not have a high enough profile. It talks absolute sense and advises government and journalists, but its voice is not much heard by the general public – and nor do they know what it does. In fact, the expertise on infectious diseases resides in Colindale in north London, in what used to be called the Health Protection Agency, which maybe has a more resonant name when it comes to Ebola. Public Health England is responsible for obesity and smoking cessation and other health issues. It may be a problem that PHE has existed only for the last couple of years. It is not the go-to place for Ebola information for most of the general public.</p> <p>In the US, public health messages are dispensed by the surgeon general, and have been for a long time. Warnings in his name are plastered over cigarette packets. The top item on the surgeon general’s website is Facts about Ebola, with the one line underneath: “The risk of an Ebola outbreak in the US is very low.” It is a simple message, put out by a known authority, with more detail available for those who want to click onwards.</p> <p>2. Politicians have been part of the problem. Public Health England was not in favour of screening people returning from west Africa at ports and airports, and advised ministers so. You cannot detect Ebola virus until somebody has symptoms, which is usually about five days after infection but can be up to 21 days. So taking temperatures at Heathrow is a needle-in-a-haystack exercise. You will be lucky to find anybody who was well enough to board the flight but has become symptomatic on arrival in the UK.</p> <p>Keith Vaz, chair of the Commons home affairs select committee, was one of those who did not listen. Last Thursday, he <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/uk-screening-airports-ebola-symptoms" title="">called for screening</a> to increase public confidence, on the back of the US decision to screen. The defence secretary, Michael Fallon, had said there were no plans to screen and the chancellor, George Osborne, said they would screen only if they had medical advice that this was useful – but on Monday the health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, announced screening would go ahead. At best, the public gets a very confused message. More probably, this fuels the panic.</p> <p>Hunt has not weighed his words carefully on Ebola. The disease, he said this week, could reach the scale of the Aids epidemic. For Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea, and potentially other countries nearby, that is sadly true, although Nigeria and Senegal have tracked down all cases and stopped Ebola in its tracks within their own borders. But many readers of Hunt’s words will be thinking of the UK, the US and Europe. Scary.</p> <p>3. The media have not helped. Hunt’s words were, of course, blasted across the front page of the Times, and were prominent in the Telegraph, the Mail and elsewhere. But the sheer quantity of unsubstantiated and sometimes unchecked stories on Ebola are just as much of a problem. Because people are worried, Ebola stories on newspaper websites get huge numbers of hits. People are certainly looking for information. It is a disservice, however, to ramp up and run every minor scare.</p> <p>Maybe we need a trusted voice on Ebola and public health generally. Members of the <a href="https://www.rcplondon.ac.uk/" title="">Royal College of Physicians</a>, anxious about escalating obesity in the UK, urged that there should be an obesity champion and even suggested it could be a member of the royal family. Maybe not, but we need somebody on the public health side with a much higher profile, who must not then be gainsaid by politicians or railroaded by the press into measures that are not justified by any evidence.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/17/ebola-britain-david-cameron-ban-ki-moon <p>Britain has called on world leaders to “wake up” to the crisis posed by the Ebola outbreak and to follow the example of the UK, US and France in providing medical and financial support to countries in West Africa.</p> <p>As the UN secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, chided the international community for paying just $100,000 into his $1bn trust fund to fight Ebola, David Cameron called on other countries to “act in a similar way” to Britain, the US and France.</p> <p>The UK prime minister’s intervention is designed to step up pressure on other EU leaders to agree to increase their contributions to fighting Ebola at an EU summit in Brussels next week. It is felt that Germany could make a greater contribution of cash and medical resources while France has further to go in Guinea to match Britain’s efforts in Sierra Leone.</p> <p>The criticism from Britain came after Kofi Annan, the former UN secretary general, said he was “bitterly disappointed” with the response of the international community, which would have been different if the crisis had erupted in the west. Annan told BBC Newsnight: “If the crisis had hit some other region it probably would have been handled very differently. In fact, when you look at the evolution of the crisis, the international community really woke up when the disease got to America and Europe.”</p> <p>Ban Ki-Moon said on Thursday night that countries need to take part in a “huge and urgent global response” to Ebola. He said: “I believe that it is time that those other countries who really have the capacity provide financial support and other logistical support. This is quite serious. We need an urgent global response and support.”</p> <p>The UN secretary general expressed severe disappointment that only $100,000 has been sent by one country – Colombia – to his $1bn trust fund. A further $20m has been pledged but not received. A wider UN appeal has received $376m, about 38% of the amount the UN is seeking to raise for that appeal.</p> <p>Speaking at the EU-Asia summit in Milan, David Cameron said: “This is the biggest health problem facing our world in a generation. It’s very likely to affect a number of the countries that are here today. Britain in my view has been leading the way. The action we’re taking in Sierra Leone, where we are committing well over £100m, 750 troops, we are going to be training 800 members of health staff in Sierra Leone, providing 700 beds.</p> <p>“We are doing a huge amount and I think it’s time for other countries to look at their responsibilities and their resources and act in a similar way to what Britain is doing in Sierra Leone, America’s doing in Liberia, France is doing in Guinea. Other countries now need to step forward with the resources and the action Because taking action at source in west Africa, that is the best way to protect all of us here in Europe.”</p> <p>Justine Greening, the UK international development secretary, who said Britain had contributed £125m to Sierra Leone, endorsed the prime minister’s comments as she called on world leaders to “wake up” to the crisis. Britain is supporting Sierra Leone because of its historic ties to its former West African colony. The US and France are focusing on Liberia and Guinea because of their own historic ties to the countries.</p> <p>Greening told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme on BBC Radio 4: “I do think Ban Ki-moon is right to say that many more countries need to get involved. We had the World Bank annual meetings last week in Washington. I was there making those points. I had the chance to meet directly with Ban Ki-moon and we discussed the need for the international community to now step up to the plate.</p> <p>“It is simply not going to be a tenable approach to simply leave the UK to work with Sierra Leone, to leave the US to work with Liberia, France to work with Guinea and no other countries to get involved. It is fair to say there is now movement. Germany is starting to provide funding. It is quite right to say that the international community now needs to wake up to this crisis and start putting resources into working with the UK and the US in particular to help deliver our strategy which we believe will be successful. We do need resourcing.”</p> <p>The naval vessel Royal Fleet Auxiliary Argus, with 100 medical beds, will be leaving Falmouth for Sierra Leone on Friday. Capt David Eagles said the beds would not be used to treat Ebola victims in Sierra Leone. He told the Today programme: “Our hospital facility is not for the Ebola patients themselves, but it’s to provide reassurance to the UK military and civilian personnel operating in Sierra Leone in support of the DFID [Department for International Development] mission, that if they have a non-Ebola injury, they will have facilities identical to what they would find in a UK NHS hospital off the shore on UK sovereign territory.</p> <p>“We also have the ability to screen our personnel returning from duties ashore, so anyone who has been on shore in Sierra Leone will be screened and monitored on their return, and if anybody had inadvertently been in contact with an Ebola patient, we have a process in place that will see them isolated and returned ashore to the dedicated Ebola treatment units in very short order. I’m confident we have a safe system.</p> <p>“It would serve no purpose to bring Ebola patients out to the ship. The purpose of the DFID mission is to increase the number of Ebola treatment units and Ebola beds and training ashore in Sierra Leone, and as such we are supporting that mission rather than actually using the hospital for Ebola patients. To bring them on board a ship would lead to all manner of complications.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2014/oct/17/beat-ebola-outbreak-bureaucrats-bureaucracy <p>If I asked you to name the most important things we need in order to tackle the Ebola outbreak, I bet “bureaucrats” would come pretty far down your list. Doctors, nurses, beds, protective equipment, public information campaigns, diagnostic labs and many more would all spring to mind before the bureaucrat. But without bureaucrats and bureaucracy, we won’t beat Ebola.</p> <p>Bureaucracy has a bad name, conjuring images of pettiness and obstructionism and the rubber stamp permanently set to “declined”. It sounds slow, resistant to change, obsessed with procedure rather than progress. But my organisation, the <a href="http://www.africagovernance.org/africa" title="">Africa Governance Initiative</a> has teams working inside the governments at the centre of the Ebola crisis – Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea – and what they are seeing is that effective bureaucracy is central to ending Ebola. We’ve seen what our government colleagues are grappling with every day. So I want to make the case for the bureaucrat, even in emergency situations like the one in west Africa.</p> <p>I should say that by bureaucracy I don’t mean endless meetings and form-filling (although actually even they turn out to have their place). What I mean by a bureaucrat is a public servant who can oversee and manage something. And what I mean by bureaucracy is systems and processes to make decisions and coordinate actions. From our perspective on the government side of the Ebola response, I’ve seen three things that make me think bureaucracy matters.</p> <p>First, the response to Ebola is as much a coordination challenge as it is a medical one. There is a huge number of actors working on different aspects of Ebola. One official from the <a href="http://www.un.org/ebolaresponse/mission.shtml" title="">United Nations mission for Ebola emergency response</a> official recently told us that Ebola is the most complex emergency he’s ever seen. Without proper systems of coordination, like the Emergency Operations Centre in Sierra Leone or the Incident Management System in Liberia, there is a real danger of duplication, delay or muddle, ultimately leading to a less effective response and lives being lost. Effective bureaucracy – a clear hierarchy for decision-making and the sharing of information, for example – saves lives.</p> <p>Second, without decent systems, it’s hard to provide leadership to the fight against Ebola. At times of crises, political leaders need to take the reins. But they will struggle to do so without the right advice and information at their fingertips. So, for example, in Liberia, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf chairs a weekly meeting with the major players on the Ebola response – her key government officials, the United Nations, the US government and the Africa Union. That seems obvious, but it takes effective bureaucracy to oil the machinery of leadership, to make sure that the right meeting happens at the right time, with the right expertise and information available and systems to follow-up on decisions. Behind every great leader there is a great bureaucracy.</p> <p>Third, we will defeat Ebola with data before drugs. Without decent information on Ebola cases, it’s virtually impossible to manage the response, and decent information needs decent systems to collect it. That’s why my colleague <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1qbtHiEoi5w" title="">Victoria Parkinson’s work with the government</a> in Sierra Leone’s Ebola call centre is so important. We need to know how many cases of Ebola we have where, for two reasons: to send medical help where it is needed; and to plan the response, so we know how many beds and doctors are needed today and in the weeks ahead. The gathering of data, including form-filling (even if it’s done electronically), is central to the response effort.</p> <p>I have worked with the governments of Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea for a number of years now, and I know, with fast enough and big enough support from the international community, they will get Ebola under control. There will be many heroes in that story, the Liberian, Sierra Leonean and Guinean public servants who are working behind the scenes to organise things – the bureaucrats – should count among them.</p> <p><em>• Andy Ratcliffe is director of strategy and development at the </em><a href="https://twitter.com/tonyblair_agi" title=""><em>Africa Governance Initiative</em></a></p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/17/ebola-gambia-africa-tourism <p>Omar Jarju looks out across a row of empty sunbeds around the Djeliba hotel’s perfectly maintained pool, a few steps from the palm-fringed Kololi beach on the Gambia’s Atlantic coast. “Every day in my inbox I get emails from clients, who tell me they’ve been warned not to come,” he says, despondently. “They say ‘Omar do you have Ebola?’ and I say ‘Oh for God’s sake, no!’. Ebola is killing us, whether we have it or not.”</p> <p>This week is only the start of the Gambia’s tourist season but Jarju, manager at the Djeliba, says the hotel is only 47% full, compared with 67% last year. Headlines about the rapid spread of Ebola in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea are having a serious knock-on effect for other countries in the continent, according to the Gambia’s ministry of tourism. The number of tourists could be down by as much as 50-60% this season in the Gambia, according to Benjamin Roberts, the tourism minister.</p> <p>That could have devastating implications for a country with half of its population living <a href="http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/gambia_the/gambia_the_economy.html" title="">under the poverty line</a>. “When the international media talk about Ebola they say ‘West Africa’ – it’s bundled together as one area or even one country. So, even though the Gambia is Ebola free, operators are facing cancellations,” he says. “The people who are hit hardest are those at the bottom, the workers who rely on tourists for their livelihood and to feed their families.” The government has strategies in place to keep the country free of Ebola – and make sure people know it is a safe place to go, he says. The ministry is working with tour operators, and a video showing visitors arriving in the Gambia and their testimonies is expected on YouTube next week.</p> <p>Tourism accounts for about 16% of the Gambia’s GDP and directly employs 35,000 people with the same number again employed indirectly by the industry. It is the second biggest source of foreign currency in the nation – vital for the purchase of key imports such as rice. Recent years have hit the country hard, food crop pests and drought have led the UN to warn that <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/01/us-foundation-gambia-hunger-ebola-idUSKCN0HQ3KR20141001" title="">200,000 people among the 1.8m population need urgent food assistance</a>.</p> <p>Everyone is feeling the squeeze, under the blazing October sun that has succeeded the rains. Lugging a bag of bracelets, scarfs and trinkets along the beach, Kida Sanu, 35, explains that she supports herself, her sister and her four children. “I sell some trinkets, we get rice, school books. I don’t sell – we don’t have.” It is only the start of the tourist season but, even so, business is slow. “This year is very poor, there are very few tourists around – this time last year it was much busier,” she says. “It’s all this Ebola – but here is safe, tourists come, tourists go – no Ebola.”</p> <p>David Barry, 38 has been operating his juice stall, selling freshly squeezed orange, lime and baobab juice, for 15 years. He reckons there are only a quarter of the normal number of tourists for the time of year. “It’s only the start of the season, so I hope more will come,” he says. “I think the ones who come year after year will come again. They know how important it is to us, but it is the new ones I worry about. Maybe they will stay away.”</p> <p>The Gambian government insists that all possible measures to prevent an occurrence of Ebola in the country have been taken. Omar Sey, the health minister, explains that Ebola screening has been introduced at all borders, <a href="http://www.pura.gm/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=category&amp;id=5:latest-news&amp;layout=blog&amp;Itemid=58" title="">a 24-hour toll-free telephone helpline was open</a> and the public were being told how to recognise the signs of Ebola – through the training of local chiefs, radio stations, plays, posters, text messages and <a href="http://vimeo.com/108650573" title="">a social media campaign</a> under the hash tag #EbolaFreeGambia. “We are speaking to schools, the heads of every village, to elders and young people,” says Sey. “It is working, the message is getting across – we have the systems in place.”</p> <p>Ministers also note that Senegal, which controlled a possible outbreak of Ebola announced on 17 October and <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/ebola/14-october-2014/en/" title="">looks set to be declared free of Ebola by WHO</a>, surrounds Gambia, putting an extra border between the country and danger.</p> <p>Sanu, slinging her bag onto her back, hopes enough has been done. “If we get a case then yes, it is scary for tourism,” she says. “But also we will also be scared for ourselves.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/17/downing-street-ebola-panic-politics-of-fear-sars-bird-flu <p>No one can tell me if Ebola is the worst plague since, variously, Aids, Sars, BSE or the black death. All I hear is that it “might” be. I do not mind being told no one knows. But what do I make of a prime minister who emerges from his Cobra bunker and declares “a very serious threat to the UK”, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/obama-ebola-international-threat-european-leaders" title="">a US president who says</a> it is “spiralling out of control”, and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates" title="">a World Health Organisation that says</a> it is “the most severe health emergency seen in modern times … a potential threat of an unparalleled human catastrophe”?</p> <p>We have lost control of the language of proportion. The result is an outbreak of crying-wolf syndrome. David Cameron and his cabinet currently tell me to be scared witless by Ebola, an attack from Isis, a resurgent Russia and global warming (sometimes). In July, the prime minister said we face being <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/jul/02/cameron-superbugs-dark-ages-medicine" title="">“cast back into the dark ages of medicine”</a> because of a new strain of superbugs. This was capped two months later when Stephen Hawking declared that <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2746727/Maybe-shouldn-t-looking-quite-hard-God-particle-destroy-universe-warns-Stephen-Hawking.html" title="">“the God particle could destroy the universe”.</a> In small print it said this was “very unlikely”, but how unlikely is very?</p> <p>Is this all scientific drivel, or merely abuse of the sacred word “could”? We have no tools for assessing such threats. There is no help from the Office for National Statistics or Office for Budget Responsibility. Tim Harford of the BBC Radio 4 programme More or Less tries to keep his head above the sea of tosh. But the only sane response is total scepticism of the motives of those seeking to make us afraid.</p> <p>The real threat from Ebola, the subject of agonising coverage from Africa and panic measures from governments, is hard to assess. It has <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-28262541" title="">been around since the 1970s</a>. It was eventually contained each time, including in the Democratic Republic of Congo earlier this year. If governments really thought it so terrifying they would issue a temporary ban on air travel which, in the digital age, is almost all non-essential. But when fear is in the air and politicians want to seem in control, who can tell?</p> <p>The one sure pandemic is panic. In 1997 we were told that bird flu could kill 2 billion people worldwide. In 1999 European Union scientists wailed that the illness BSE/CJD <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/873026.stm" title="">could kill 500,000 people</a>. It peaked at <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs180/en/" title="">28 deaths in the UK</a> and is down to two a year. The Sars outbreak of 2003 was asserted by one expert as having <a href="http://www.infowars.com/swine-flu-hysteria-spreads-faster-than-actual-virus/" title="">“a 25% chance of killing tens of millions”</a>. The press headlined Sars as “a plague worse than Aids”. One Briton possibly died from Sars last year.</p> <p>The recent flus classed as H1N1 and H5N1 seemed to arrive as regularly as swallows in summer. All were eagerly labelled pandemics by scientists, apparently to unlock millions of pounds in government drugs purchases. In 2006, bird flu was declared “the first pandemic of the 21st century” (others not having come up to scratch). The WHO, penetrated by big pharma advisers, issued a statement that “one  in four Britons could die”. They did not.</p> <p>By 2009, flu scares were on autopilot. “This could really explode,” a BBC reporter wailed of the latest arrival. “It is here,” cried the London Evening Standard, with fear “spreading like a Mexican wave”. The Department of Health’s Sir Liam Donaldson famously declared that <a href="http://lvnch.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2009/07/21/the_swine_flu_bump_in_the_road_to_mecca" title="">“65,000 could die”</a>. Drugs companies such as Roche and GSK were showered with gold, with a staggering $2bn eventually being spent worldwide on Tamiflu. One of the few official bodies to call the scaremongering to account, the Council of Europe, called the hyping of the 2009 pandemic “one of the great medical scandals of the century”.</p> <p>Health scares are classics of the politics of fear. After a while they lose all force, except to distort medical priorities. Hundreds died of hospital-caught infections while ministers panicked over bird flu. But what are we to do? As with fear of terrorism, crime, poverty or common illness, we have to rely on authority to advise and warn us. When authority has a vested interest in alarmism, anarchy reigns. We are at the mercy of the lobbyist, the spin doctor and the headline writer.</p> <p>The lunacies of medical catastrophism are one thing. The political exploitation of personal insecurity is more serious. We can take an aspirin to ward off mad science disease but we cannot altogether dismiss a minister who claims to know our lives and livelihoods are at risk. I expect the police to guard me from danger without constantly telling me what the danger is. Why do politicians behave otherwise?</p> <p>The political scientist Louise Richardson wrote in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/2006/sep/09/shopping.politics2" title="">What Terrorists Want</a> that it is precisely what western politicians seem happiest to give them: they want to make us fear them. “By declaring war on terror,” she says, “far from denying al-Qaida its objectives we are conceding its objectives. That is why a war on terror can never be won.” It is a terminological admission of defeat.</p> <p>Fear is the dumbing down of politics. After 9/11, Americans were made very afraid of planes. They duly took to their cars and an extra <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/05/september-11-road-deaths" title="">1,500 died as a result</a>. Privately promoted catastrophe has always had a good press. Bookshops are crammed with titles such as The Long Emergency, The Population Bomb, Our Final Hour. The fact that Aids, predicted to slash by a third Africa’s population, has simply not done so, will no more dent the appeal of Armageddon than will the wilder claims of climate changers. The political psychologist Philip Tetlock famously gathered 28,000 predictions from scientists and other experts, then waited and found they were no better than random guesses.</p> <p>Perhaps the answer is to take a leaf from the Office for Budget Responsibility. The government should appoint a commission for the assessment of panics. Its job would be to test alarmist announcements against stringent statistical probability. If a budget can be independently audited and crime figures independently scrutinised, why not Downing Street scaremongering?</p> <p>What is the real risk of thousands dying of flu or being blown up by terrorists? Should we be very scared, seriously scared or scared out of our minds? What force should these words convey to the body politic?</p> <p>My commission would test for the abuse of words such as “could”, “might”, “up to”, as in “Isis terrorism could threaten up to a thousand lives”, or “superbugs could take us back to the dark ages”. The new press regulator, Ipso, would do likewise for that equal offender, the media. Penalties would be harsh, such as a year’s course in regression analysis and probability theory.</p> <p>A democracy must know what it should fear. Perhaps young people who did not know the cold war threat of nuclear annihilation are more susceptible to the phoney scaremongering of today. Either way, it lays them open to lobbyists and cynics. Freedom from fear is a human right. We pay politicians to guard us from terror by not terrifying us.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates <div id="block-54406304e4b0cd82a095fa0b" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-17T01:59:11.756+01:00">1.59am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Closing summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>We are ending our live coverage of Ebola for now. We’ll leave you with this <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/17/barack-obama-open-to-travel-bans-experts-ebola-nurse-ohio"><strong>full report from Dan Roberts on the latest from the White House</strong></a>, where the president has been briefing the press. And here’s a summary of the day’s developments:</p> <ul> <li>After meeting for two hours with top advisers Barack Obama has given a briefing at which he suggested he might <strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/17/barack-obama-open-to-travel-bans-experts-ebola-nurse-ohio">appoint a new senior official</a></strong> to oversee the response to Ebola, and said he was continuing to “push and ask our experts” about whether <strong>travel restrictions</strong>, which he had previously resisted, should be put in place for <strong>passengers from west African nations</strong>.</li> </ul> <ul> <li>Questions and controversy have continued to swirl over air travel by the second US nurse infected. Amber Vinson<strong><strong> <a <time datetime="2014-10-17T01:21:10.073+01:00">1.21am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>More from the White House where <strong>Dan Roberts</strong> has been covering the president’s briefing to reporters on the Ebola response:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Despite insisting earlier in the week that the various federal agencies responding to the crisis were co-ordinating well, the White House now acknowledges it may need an “Ebola tsar” to oversee the US response.</p> <p>“Not because these three haven’t been doing an outstanding job but [because] they are also responsible for a whole bunch of other stuff,” he explained. “After this initial surge of activity, we may have a more regular person.. to make sure we’re crossing all the t’s and dotting all the i’s”</p> <p>But the biggest political U-turn may come over the vexed question of travel restrictions on passengers arriving from countries in west Africa where Ebola is most common, something Republicans have been demanding the White House reconsider.</p> <p>“I don’t have a philosophical objection necessarily to a travel ban if that is what is going to keep the American people safe,” Obama told reporters. “The trouble is all the discussion I have had so far with experts in the field is that it is less effective than the measures were are already implementing.”</p> <p>“I continue to push and ask our experts whether we are doing what’s adequate to protect the American people, if they come back to me and say we need to do more then we will do it,” he added. “If it turns out I am getting different answers I will share that with the American people and we will not hesitate.”</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54405b24e4b02f15ae75780f" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-17T00:59:52.533+01:00">12.59am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">President Obama speaks about Ebola response</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Barack Obama has given a press briefing on the Ebola response</strong>. Here’s a quick take from Dan Roberts on what the president had to say:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Barack Obama has hinted at possible policy shifts in US efforts to contain Ebola, revealing he is considering fresh leadership to co-ordinate the federal response and is open to implementing travel bans if expert advice on its merits were to shift.</p> <p>Speaking to reporters at the White House after his second <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-544038fee4b0b858885afebf">two-hour meeting with advisers</a> in as many days, the president also said extra disease control specialists were being sent to Ohio amid fears that a second nurse infected with the disease may have been contagious for longer than originally suspected.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54404e7de4b0b858885afeca" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-17T00:36:11.474+01:00">12.36am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Texas healthcare workers deemed at risk of having contracted Ebola have been asked to sign voluntary agreements to stay away from the public</strong>, my colleagues Jon Swaine and Lauren Gambino report.</p> <p>After Dallas authorities decided not to declare a state of emergency, 75 staff members of Texas Health Presbyterian hospital were to be given a “binding legal document and order” that states they will avoid public transport, not go to areas where large numbers of people congregate, and continue to be monitored twice a day for symptoms, county judge Clay Jenkins said on Thursday.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Any of those involved in the care of Thomas Eric Duncan who refuse to sign the agreement would be subject to a legal control order, Jenkins told reporters after a meeting of the county commissioners court in downtown Dallas. “All the remedies of the law are available,” he said. However he said he believed this would not be necessary. “These are hometown healthcare heroes,” he said. “They’re not going to jail.”</p> <p>The healthcare workers will also have their home addresses flagged on the internal systems of emergency services, said Jenkins, adding that this would prompt first responders responding to calls from their houses to raise an alarm. The flags would disappear when they are no longer at risk of Ebola.</p> </blockquote> <p>In all more than 135 people – including the 75 healthcare workers, 48 other people who had contact with Duncan before he entered hospital, and a number of people Vinson encountered in Ohio – are being monitored for signs of Ebola.</p> <p>You can read<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-healthcare-workers-ebola-public"> the full report here</a>.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54404bcce4b0d81d4881b2e4" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T23:48:57.872+01:00">11.48pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">US medics will 'be involved in care of afflicted healthcare workers'</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>American medics will staff a US military-built hospital in Liberia to treat infected healthcare workers</strong> – a “centerpiece of US efforts in west Africa”, according to Reuters – but also a deviation from other officials’ statements.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Major General Darryl Williams, who is overseeing the US military response in west Africa, renewed assurances that there were no plans for American troops to treat Liberians infected by Ebola. </p> <p>But a team of 65 doctors and nurses from the US Public Health Service Commissioned Corps, which is part of the Department of Health and Human Services, will staff a 25-bed hospital built by the military. </p> <p>“They will actually be involved in the care and feeding of healthcare workers who have been inflicted with the Ebola virus,” Williams said in a teleconference from Liberia. </p> </blockquote> <p><strong>The general’s remarks highlight subtle distinctions and apparent contradictions – or confusion – on the part of top defense and health officials. </strong>Another general, David Rodriguez, had earlier said that troops would only work with Ebola samples during testing, “clarifying” a statement that a handful American troops would have direct contact with potential Ebola patients. (You can <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/07/ebola-us-troops-direct-contact-potential-sufferers-liberia">read that story here</a>.)</p> <p>Moreover, earlier today the director of the CDC said that the Defense Department had told him there were no plans for military personnel to actively treat Ebla patients. </p> <p>Major General Williams’ remarks apparently contradict these statements. He admitted there was risk, saying: “I would not say there’s no risk. But there is risk that can be tampered down if you take the appropriate discipline and use the protocols,” he said. </p> <p>About the handful of specialists testing samples, Williams said: “That’s probably the closest it comes [for the US military] to the Ebola virus chain.” </p> <p>The apparent distinction Williams makes is that the US medics report to the US Department of Health and Human Services – and not the military, technically.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54404475e4b0cd82a095f9fe" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T23:22:52.439+01:00">11.22pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Passenger luggage and the Air France aircraft in Madrid will be disinfected</strong>, Ashifa Kassam<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/spain-man-posible-ebola-case-madrid-hospital"> reports for the Guardian from Madrid</a>.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The passenger, who showed signs of shaking on board the flight, had travelled from Lagos, Nigeria, to Madrid via Paris. After the plane staff informed ground crews of the situation, the plane was parked in a special area of the airport and the other 155 passengers were allowed to leave the flight as normal, said Air France. Health authorities took note of their details and advised them to contact the Carlos III Hospital if they show any signs of a fever.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time Africa.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: HARRISON MCCLARY/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-544038fee4b0b858885afebf" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:36:56.409+01:00">10.36pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>President Obama has just begun another meeting with top members of his administration, </strong>including Lisa Monaco, the Homeland Security chief who is in charge of coordinating various agencies’ Ebola protocols.</p> <p>According to a White House pool report, the meeting will also include Sylvia Burwell, secretary of Health and Human Services; Denis McDonough, White House chief of staff; Susan Rice, national security advisor; and Dr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.</p> <p>The Guardian’s Washington bureau chief Dan Roberts says it looks like Obama may speak briefly afterward.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5440344fe4b0cd82a095f9f4" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:30:22.771+01:00">10.30pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>In the UK, prime minister David Cameron convened a meeting of Cobra, the government’s emergency response committee. <strong>The group was told by Britain’s chief medical officer that the risk of Ebola to the UK remains low</strong>, a spokesman said.</p> <p>Per the spokesman:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“There was a discussion over the need for the international community to do much more to support the fight against the disease in the region,” the spokesman said.</p> <p>“This included greater co-ordination of the international effort, an increase in the amount of spending and more support for international workers who were, or who were considering, working in the region. The prime minister set out that he wanted to make progress on these issues at the European Council next week. </p> </blockquote> <p>Downing Street also said there are “detailed plans for protecting the UK against Ebola” in place, including screening “up and running across all Heathrow terminals, and [soon in] Gatwick and St Pancras”.</p> <p>In Sierra Leone, where more than 100 British army personnel have landed, work is being done to build six new treatment facilities, train staff, improve existing centers, and support the government.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-544033d0e4b0cd82a095f9f3" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:19:35.723+01:00">10.19pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The Ebola epidemic may not end until the world has a vaccine,</strong> according to one of the scientists who discovered the virus. Sarah Boseley, the Guardian’s health editor, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-vaccine-peter-piot-west-africa-epidemic">has more from Professor Peter Piot’s talk in Oxford</a> earlier Thursday:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Piot said it would not have been difficult to contain the outbreak if those on the ground and the UN had acted promptly earlier this year. “Something that is easy to control got completely out of hand,” said Piot, who was part of a team that identified the causes of the first outbreak of Ebola in Zaire, now the Democratic Republic of Congo, in 1976 and helped bring it to an end.</p> </blockquote> <p>Three vaccines are being fast-tracked through early safety trials in in the UK, US and in unaffected Mali. Healthcare workers – who are at highest risk of being infected and over 200 of whom have died – could be offered a vaccination before Christmas, but the only proof that a vaccine is acceptable would be a significant drop in the number of deaths among vaccinated people on the frontline.</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="2af0201e697e1c4cdc88d0dc2919cc256dffb259"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413494181804/1a906efc-0142-4778-8aec-04fa538ac179-280x420.jpeg" alt="Peter Piot." width="280" height="420" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Peter Piot.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: DENIS BALIBOUSE/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Piot compared the epidemic to war, saying the world too often says “‘never again’ and then we forget about it.” </p> <p>“It could lead to major destabilisation of societies and also political destabilisation,” said Piot. “It is going to come at a very high cost. Just as Sars a decade ago only killed 700, but the economic impact was tens of billions of dollars.”</p> <p>Piot, like US healthcare researcher Dr Anthony Fauci, said he thought the prospects for an effective vaccine were good, and that the candidates had shown good results in animal trials.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:24:50.474+01:00">at 10.24pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-544023d7e4b02f15ae7577e9" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:58:59.444+01:00">9.58pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Nina Pham has released a statement through Texas Presbyterian Hospital,</strong> in part about her imminent transfer to the special NIH center in Maryland.</p> <p>The hospital says the decision was made “in consultation with Mr Pham and her family”, and that the nurse’s condition remains good. The statement reads, in part:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>With many of the medical professionals who would normally staff the intensive care unit sidelined for continuous monitoring, it is in the best interest of Nina, hospital employees, nurses, physicians and the community to give the hospital an opportunity to prepare for whatever comes next.<br /></p> </blockquote> <p>Pham says she’s “so thankful for the outpouring of love and support from friends and family, my coworkers and complete strangers. … I appreciate everything that my coworkers have done to care for me at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas. I believe in my talented coworkers.”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54402ed8e4b02f15ae7577ee" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time from west Africa have a visible, if lonely, supporter.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="cf55f12ed21e404a143d81657154c0f7272551e8"> <img MLADEN ANTONOV/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54402953e4b0b858885afeb8" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:36:50.592+01:00">9.36pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Obama authorizes call-up of national guard</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>President Obama has signed an executive order that allows for reserve military forces to be called up to bolster the US presence in west Africa, if necessary</p> <p>In a letter sent to Speaker of the House John Boehner, Obama writes that he authorizes defense chiefs to order reserve troops “to active duty to augment the active forces … providing humanitarian assistance and consequence management related to the Ebola virus disease outbreak in the west Africa region”.<br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="bea6b7b615bdacb22c6d484f599ecdd097b29fb7"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413491801439/cce00815-6eaf-42b6-abee-fcba438c2d47-280x420.jpeg" alt="President Barack Obama." width="280" height="420" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">President Barack Obama.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: UPI /Landov / Barcroft Media/UPI /Landov / Barcroft Media</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>“The authorities that have been invoked will ensure the Department of Defense can properly sustain the military operations required in this effort.”<br /></p> <p>In the order itself, Obama writes “I hereby determine it is necessary to augment the active armed forces of the United States for the effective conduct of Operation United Assistance”, the name of the west Africa support mission. </p> <p><strong>Bureaucratic language translated:</strong> Obama authorizes the right to call up the US national guard.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:24:55.942+01:00">at 10.24pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-544024e5e4b02f15ae7577ea" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:08:45.226+01:00">9.08pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>In Dallas, the Guardian’s Jon Swaine says a vote has “gone a bit weird” </strong>after convening to decide whether or not to declare a state of emergency.</p> <p>Jon says there’s “a strange dance going on. The Dallas County judge and commissioners are saying they don’t need a state of emergency regarding Ebola. The mayor seems to stands to agree.”</p> <p>“Seems instead, Dallas hospital staffers who encountered Ebola patients will be asked to<strong> sign an agreement that they’ll stay away from the public.”</strong></p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/jonswaine/statuses/522835983146823680">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Emergency meeting of Dallas court of county commissioners to consider declaring a state of emergency over Ebola <a href="http://t.co/Frhndpofvg">pic.twitter.com/Frhndpofvg</a></p>&mdash; Jon Swaine (@jonswaine) <a href="https://twitter.com/jonswaine/status/522835983146823680">October 16, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54402106e4b0d81d4881b2c4" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:00:11.295+01:00">9.00pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>A fourth person in Spain is being tested for Ebola</strong>, agencies report, adding the detail that a feverish passenger started shaking before their Air France flight was grounded.</p> <p>The new case is in the Canary Islands, where two people were admitted to a hospital for “precautionary monitoring”. According to the AP, a Red Cross health worker, who recently worked with Ebola patients in Sierra Leone, was hospitalized with a fever in Tenerife, officials said. Two roommates, who showed no symptoms, were placed in hospital isolation as a precaution.</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="5e4ac96fe5af17b212c259cf659aebf81e7b131b"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413489498216/9e87ec7b-ede0-420b-868a-473469205bc1-460x276.jpeg" alt="A paramedic drives an ambulance in a protective suit while leaving the Carlos III Hospital in Madrid, Spain." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">An ambulance leaving the Carlos III Hospital in Madrid.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Daniel Ochoa de Olza/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The Air France passenger, Reuters reports, had originally travelled from Nigeria before taking a connecting flight, and developed tremors on a flight from Paris. The plane was evacuated and isolated, and the passenger taken to Madrid’s Carlos III hospital.</p> <p>The other two people being monitored are a priest who recently traveled in west Africa and one of 68 “low risk” people who came into contact with sick nurse Teresa Romero.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:58:23.981+01:00">at 9.58pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54401f03e4b0d81d4881b2c2" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T20:44:02.757+01:00">8.44pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>A UN trust fund aiming for $1bn to fight Ebola has only $100,000 in the bank, </strong>secretary general Ban Ki-moon said Thursday. The fund was set up about a month ago.</p> <p>Ban asked the world to provide the money “to get ahead of the curve and meet our target of reducing the rate of transmission by 1 December,” agencies reports.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>As of Thursday, just $100,000 was paid into the fund, by Colombia, although $365m had been committed. Much of the pledged amount was donated directly to UN agencies and nonprofits working on the ground in the three worst affected countries of Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, according to UN records.</p> </blockquote> <p>According to AP, the UN leader said dozens of countries “are showing their solidarity,” singling out the US, Britain, France, Canada and Germany. But he said it’s time that countries that have “the capacity” which he didn’t identify provide support. </p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T20:44:09.949+01:00">at 8.44pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5440194ee4b02f15ae7577e2" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time developments:</p> <ul> <li><strong><strong>US <a clamored for travel bans at a hearing on Ebola </a>and questioned health agency leaders</strong></strong>, including director of the CDC Tom Frieden, who defended his agency’s response and said would be ready to deploy expert teams “within hours” if needed.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>The first nurse to fall ill, Nina Pham, </strong><a acknowledged failings in the response to the arrival of the virus in the US.</strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong> The CDC is trying to contact people who flew on a commercial flight with Vinson while she had a low fever just a day before she tested positive.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong>The WHO said <a href="http:">it expects global Ebola cases to surpass 9,000 this week</a></strong></strong>, that a drop of cases in Liberia was “encouraging”, and that a team of experts are going to Mali and Ivory Coast to help secure borders.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong>British army medics <a
