in west Africa</a></strong></strong>, where they will coordinate with government and international teams.<br /></li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong>Several suspected new cases have been reported in Europe</strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong>. Spanish authorities <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-543fd87de4b080f839252198">grounded a plane after one of the passengers reported a fever</a>, and one of the people who being monitored for contact with an infected nurse has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-543fd87de4b080f839252198">also been taken to the hospital</a>. Healthcare workers <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-543fdc8ce4b0cd82a095f965">in France and Denmark</a> are also being tested, as well as two students rom Guinea-Bissau who reported high temperatures in Russia. </li> </ul> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54401815e4b0d81d4881b2bf" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T20:15:01.735+01:00">8.15pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Despite the clamor from Washington leaders to impose travel bans, the Obama administration is still debating whether to change its policy, my colleague Dan Roberts reports from the capital.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>FAA administrator Michael Huerta said to reporters “We are now working together and assessing this on a daily basis. CDC’s determination is that a travel ban in and of itself doesn’t address the challenges that we have here.” “But”, he added, “this is something that we continue to monitor.”</p> <p>Asked if he had discussed a ban with the White House, Frieden refused to rule it out. “We have had discussions on the issue of travel to and from West Africa,” he told the hearing. “From the CDC’s perspective we will consider anything that will increase the safety of Americans.</p> <p>Existing screening measures at JFK airport in New York have led to 8 passengers undergoing further tests since they were introduced on October 11 and similar systems were put in place at Dulles, Newark and O’Hare airports on Thursday.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/RobertsDan/statuses/522827018858016768">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Ebola hearing Republicans hold presser to reinforce travel ban calls but refuse to say if Congress should be recalled <a href="http://t.co/pCvsBqtCRG">pic.twitter.com/pCvsBqtCRG</a></p>&mdash; Dan Roberts (@RobertsDan) <a href="https://twitter.com/RobertsDan/status/522827018858016768">October 16, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54401393e4b0cd82a095f9d6" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:56:12.028+01:00">7.56pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>A congressperson excoriates Texas Presbyterian again and asks Frieden to comment – he says he agrees completely about the need for better training but <strong>“the CDC can’t be everywhere”.</strong></p> <p>Finally, chairman Tim Murphy says that he appreciates Dr Varga’s “honesty, and saying that we made mistakes.” He says that the other witnesses didn’t say as much, which he finds “disturbing”.</p> <p>He says people will always make mistakes or perhaps not be entirely honest, and that guards like “the buddy system” for removing gear would help ensure that protocols are followed.</p> <p>He calls for a travel ban from infected countries, better guards domestically; and he calls for immediate training of healthcare workers, including a review of gear; identify and designate specific medical centers equipped for Ebola; accelerate development and trials of all “promising” vaccines and treatments; and he calls for coordination with Congress in confronting Ebola in west Africa.</p> <p>After a few procedural comments the hearing adjourns, clocking in at almost three hours of testimony and questions.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-544012e8e4b0b858885afeae" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:48:52.096+01:00">7.48pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>More about Dallas</strong> – where the Guardian’s Jon Swaine is reporting on an imminent vote on whether to declare a state of emergency. From Jon:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>John Wiley Price, the commissioner for district three, told the Guardian that the situation was putting a strain on the county’s funds. </p> <p>“This is still evolving and the only way we can get reimbursed as a county is to make this declaration,” he said. “We escrowed a million dollars last week and we are already north of that. As we continue with clean-ups, surveillance and containment, we need to be able to pay for it.”</p> <p>Speaking shortly before the commissioners meeting, Price said the Dallas hospital at the centre of the crisis had bungled its response. “It wasn’t handled appropriately and as a result we are all suffering,” he said. </p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54401237e4b0cd82a095f9d3" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:47:38.715+01:00">7.47pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>“I can’t speak for the White House … we’ve discussed the issue of travel,”</strong> is all Frieden will say to the peroration of Representative Scalise, of Louisiana, on travel bans.</p> <p>The congressman says the US should at least suspend visas then. </p> <p>Frieden: “The CDC does not issue visas …”</p> <p>Scalise: “Do you have a high level of confidence that our US troops … up to 3,000 troops are going to be sent over by president Obama … do you have confidence that they’re protected?”</p> <p>Frieden says it’s not “zero risk” but “they’re not participating in high risk [activities].”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:14:02.297+01:00">at 9.14pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54401136e4b0b858885afead" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:43:27.826+01:00">7.43pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>“There will not be an outbreak here barring a mutation,”</strong> Frieden tells the representative from North Carolina, Renee Ellmers.</p> <p>He reassures her: “We are confident it is not airborne. These nurses were working with someone who was very ill. There was lots of vomiting, lots of hazardous material.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="dd10d8ad528c8f18a640f80ce563df8a4dd1f621"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413485002053/dac62bf7-1d21-4475-b652-ce833af9d344-460x276.jpeg" alt="Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Director Dr. Tom Frieden." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Director Dr. Tom Frieden.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Pablo Martinez Monsivais/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54400ed8e4b0cd82a095f9d1" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:37:17.565+01:00">7.37pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Asked about the CDC’s authority to help hospitals prepare, Frieden says the US has “a federalist system.” <strong>Of the CDC, he says “we are not a regulatory agency.”</strong></p> <p>He says there are one of the important lessons the CDC has learned so far: “To prevent it at the source. If we had had the basic public health system in these three countries a year ago, this would be over.”</p> <p>Representative Long, of Missouri, asks basic questions after saying that he does not like how people refer to Nina Pham and Amber Vinson as “nurse one and nurse two”. Then he asks about contagion.<br /></p> <p>Frieden: “Direct contact from someone who is ill and showing symptoms, or from contact with a corpse.”</p> <p>Long: “Do you need a fever to be contagious?”</p> <p>Frieden says a sick person needs to be showing symptoms. Asked again, Frieden says: “Late in the disease when people are deathly ill, they may not have fever, but they probably wouldn’t be able to woalk at that point.”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54400e15e4b0b858885afeab" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:30:13.354+01:00">7.30pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Frieden tells the representatives that speed is the key to success in west Africa, </strong>particularly Liberia. He also confirms what Representative Matheson of Utah says about the importance of stopping the outbreak in west Africa, adding that it improves Americans’ safety.</p> <p>Asked about funding, Frieden diplomatically thanks Congress for having approved Defense Department funding and resources for the CDC.</p> <p><strong>“The US navy has a pilot test in development, we’re currently testing that in parts of west Africa</strong>. … We’re working with a number of commercial manufacturers as well.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:42:10.013+01:00">at 7.42pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54400ca6e4b0b858885afeaa" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:24:15.249+01:00">7.24pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>In Dallas, county authorities will vote Thursday afternoon on whether to declare a state of emergency</strong>, my colleague Jon Swaine reports.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Four commissioners and the county judge are scheduled to meet at 2pm to consider “extraordinary measures” necessary because Dallas “has the potential to suffer widespread or severe damage, injury, loss or threat of life resulting from the Ebola virus,” according to a proposal obtained in advance by the Guardian.</p> <p>Passing the proposal would activate the county’s emergency management plan and a request that Texas governor Rick Perry also declare a state of emergency. This would pave the way for state or federal funds to be transferred to Dallas to help pay for dealing with the crisis.</p> </blockquote> <p>The state of emergency would give the county judge, Clay Jenkins, wide-ranging authority <a href="http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/GV/htm/GV.418.htm">under state law</a> to control the movement of people into, out of and within the county if he chose. It would also allow him to “order the evacuation of all or part of the population from a stricken or threatened area” if this was deemed necessary.</p> <p>Dr Elba Garcia, the commissioner for district four of Dallas county, plans to vote in favour of the measure, her chief of staff, Brooks Love, told Jon, who is reporting from Dallas.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54400ba9e4b0cd82a095f9ca" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:20:58.863+01:00">7.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Yarmuth, of Kentucky, asks about diagnostics and offers a skeptical take on the media representation of the infections.</p> <p>Freiden answers about testing first: “A<strong>t this point we don’t have a test before someone shows symptoms</strong> … the test is for the virus itself. We can’t even find tiny amounts of it in people’s bodies until they get sick. There’s a lot of research being done to try to diagnose and treat and prevent better.”</p> <p>But Freiden says it’s important the media reports it extensively so that the plain facts can get across. </p> <p>He concedes that “some of the coverage, I think many would agree, exaggerate the potential risks, or may confuse people. But there really is a lot we know about Ebola. CDC has a whole branch … working on ebola and similar infections. We have stopped every outbreak of Ebola except the current outbreak in west Africa. … We welcome the attention; it would be important at times to put it in perspective.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:14:23.169+01:00">at 9.14pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54400af1e4b0b858885afea8" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:16:43.653+01:00">7.16pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Griffith, of Virginia, asks how much we really know about Ebola and past outbreaks, including about how it’s spread. <strong>He expounds on the matter of dogs, and whether they have antibodies that fight the virus.</strong></p> <p>Freiden says that “although we’re still learning about every organism we study, we have a lot of information about Ebola. We’ve looked at the issue of exposure to animals … we don’t know of any transmission to dogs [but because] we don’t know we’ve quarantined a dog.”</p> <p>Griffith: <strong>“Don’t you think we ought to at least restrict travel to dogs?”</strong></p> <p>Freiden looks surprised. “We’ll follow up.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="b4e25959ba5ad376d38a1c2ac584859d3693806d"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413487035766/f934268d-1a6d-456c-87aa-f6a4faafdf89-460x276.jpeg" alt="Friden, Fauci and other witnesses testifying before Congress." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Friden, Fauci and other witnesses testifying before Congress.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: JONATHAN ERNST/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:14:38.356+01:00">at 9.14pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5440098de4b0b858885afea6" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:11:05.252+01:00">7.11pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Welch asks a number of questions that get the standard answers from Frieden:</p> <p>“People travel, and people will be getting in. … We’ll look at any proposal that would improve the safety of Americans.”</p> <p>The congressman takes it back to the question of funding and suggests that “Congress revisit its priorities” and make sure that NIH, CDC and HHS have sufficient funding for infrastructure and medical support around the country. Murphy, the chairman, says that he’s arranged to have a hearing on that topic in the near future.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-544008fde4b0d81d4881b2b2" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:07:48.855+01:00">7.07pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Welch asks about the nature of Ebola and how, practically, hospitals should deal with the CDC and consider and diagnose the virus.</p> <p>“It’s a severe disease, it’s not as contagious as some other diseases … but any infection of a healthcare worker is unacceptable.” He says that every hospital should be able to communicate with the CDC about cases, and that the agency has received hundreds of calls. In the event of a diagnosis, he says that a team will go to the hospital and consider it as a case by case basis.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5440079ae4b0d81d4881b2b0" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T19:05:39.901+01:00">7.05pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Gardner, of Colorado, says that 100-150 people are coming to the US from west Africa each month, and asks Wagner about the logistics of screening travelers.</p> <p>Gardner: “Would we be checking their temperatures?”</p> <p>Wagner: “We will not be checking their temperatures, or asking them to fill out a contact sheet.”</p> <p>Gardner: Wagner: “So we will not be checking the temperatures of 2,000-2,500 people?”</p> <p>“They’re going to arrive at hundreds of different airports throughout the United States.”</p> <p>Wagner: “There are no commercial flights coming directly into the United States from those three areas.”</p> <p>Gardner asks about flights through Europe, and by way of repeating “hundreds of flights, 94% screening,” implies an uncertain level of readiness.</p> <p>Freiden: “The single most important thing for them to do is for them to ask where they’ve been for the past 21 days, and whether they’ve been in west Africa. … By all means get a flue shot, and for healthcare workers, whenever anyone comes in with a fever or other symptoms, get a travel history.</p> <p>Gardner goes back to harping on the number of flights, personnel and equipment moving to and fro from the US, directly and indirectly. Freiden defends the greater benefit of travel information over the marginal benefit of rerouting travelers en route to the US.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54400741e4b0b858885afea3" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:59:49.347+01:00">6.59pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Fauci says the world’s response has not been commensurate to the rate of the epidemic.</strong></p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="dda1210c3284f87f6ea379153f429a5aef505fcd"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413487097142/32f03cc1-f367-4c7b-8950-4e5b47b3ec8b-460x276.jpeg" alt="Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease, testifies." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease, testifies.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: JIM LO SCALZO/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Fauci says: “if you have a raging epidemic, to be quite honest with you Ms Castor, I cannot predict when that will be” that a vaccine or effective treatments begin to make a difference.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:57:18.676+01:00">at 9.57pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54400695e4b0d81d4881b2af" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:58:10.722+01:00">6.58pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Castor, of Florida, gets into the question about research for treatments and vaccines – and begins with a shot at Republicans over last year’s government shutdown.</p> <p>“Dr Fauci can you explain to us why government support is so important to developing a vaccine?”</p> <p>Fauci says it’s not in the interests of the pharmaceutical companies to develop treatments for a disease of Ebola’s nature, since not many people have it. “We were sturggling for years to get pharmaceutical partners. We were doing the research … and now we do have pharmaceutical partners [so we’ve made progress] … The research is on this end, and you have to push it so that [there’s less risk to companies].<strong> Companies don’t like to take risks.”</strong></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:15:16.157+01:00">at 9.15pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54400537e4b02f15ae7577c4" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:54:59.074+01:00">6.54pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>A representative (his name obscured) asks whether Varga and Texas officials have determined where safety breaches occurred in the exposure cases of Pham and Vinson.</p> <p>“We’ve confirmed that Nina, through her care with Mr Duncan, was wearing protective patient equipment through the whole period of time of the diagnosis confirmed. The level of equipment was elevated to the full hazmat style. We don’t know at this particular juncture what the source or cause to the exposure of Nina was.”</p> <p>The representative turns to Frieden and asks whether CDC guidelines “mirror international standards”, which he says are being followed.</p> <p>“There’s no single right answer. Our current guidelines are consistentn with recommendations from the World Health Organization.”</p> <p>The represntative says “some consistency is what we need.”</p> <p>Moving on – “on the issue of elevated temperature: is it 101, 99.5, 103.6? I think there’s some issue here. … Mr Duncan came for the first time to the hospita, his temperature was 100.1, within 24 hours of course it was 103! When mom and dad are out there when their child has flu season … “ He asks what parents and Americans should be worried about with regard to fevers and symptoms.</p> <p>“Parents should not be concenred unless you’re living in west Africa or your child has had exposure to Ebola. Right now in the US it’s just [these three healthcare workers and those being monitored]. We’re always going to have an extra margin of safety for our screening.”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54400412e4b0d81d4881b2aa" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:48:31.325+01:00">6.48pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Schiakowsky, of Illinois, asks <strong>“how come the nurses in Dallas weren’t protected, and how do we make sure that everyone can be?”</strong></p> <p>“Those first days were before his diagnosis was known. He suspected, but the tests had not yet been drawn.”</p> <p>Schiakowsky yields briefly to DeGette, who interjects with a bit of outrage: “He presented with Ebola symptoms, he came to the emergency room … saying he had come from Africa. I believe that CDC protocol says workers should be wearing protective gear even before diagnosis. … I hope that if a person shows up vomiting [and with diarrhea] then you wouldn’t say ‘The lab results aren’t back’ but [that you would] treat him as if he had Ebola.”</p> <p>Back to Schiakowsky’s question, Frieden says that the CDC tells doctors to “think Ebola” first, and that “the day the diagnosis was confirmed we sent a team to Texas.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:15:32.340+01:00">at 9.15pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54400271e4b0d81d4881b2a8" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:44:30.991+01:00">6.44pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Frieden is now asked about whether the two Ebola patients are being moved because staff fears about the virus.</p> <p>Frieden says that the hospital faces the challenge of having to monitor some 50 healthcare workers, and that “we felt it would be more prudent” for the CDC and NIH to take over treatment of the two ill nurses.</p> <p>The representative now asks him about proper protective gear – about shoe protection and exposed skin, particularly. He pulls out a picture of a fully-covered man in west Africa: “This is your picture, in west Africa, with goggles [etc] and you’re about to be doused with a near toxic dose of chlorine?”</p> <p>Frieden: “Yes”</p> <p>“And that’s why you can’t have skin expose – it’s impossible to do the disinfection. … What kind of stockpile of this kind of personal protective equipment do you have?” </p> <p>He asks whether supplies are ready to get quickly to whomever needs them, and the Human and Health Services assistant secretary says there are no shortages and things seem ready.</p> <p>The congressman turns back to Frieden: “What did you think … patient zero was going to look like?”</p> <p>“Our goal has been to get hospitals ready. The specific type of personal protective equipment to be used [is more complicated question]… There is no one right answer. The use of different types of personal protective equipment is obviously something we’re looking at very closely right now in Dallas.”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-544001f0e4b0cd82a095f9b7" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:37:00.217+01:00">6.37pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Braley asks John Wagner about the pros and cons of travel bans with regard to border security.</strong></p> <p>Wagner says through airline data, authorities can track the travel history of passengers and that he “agrees with the experts, it’s easier to manage” that information and contact and track people of interest.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="67d9fd92da2e58755e5777e079c9bcf8a636735c"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413487176045/0cfff513-5829-4b34-8797-b59e7a723f69-460x276.jpeg" alt="Robin Robinson, director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority in the HHS Office, Luciana Borio, assistant commissioner for counterterrorism policy at the FDA, and John Wagner, acting assistant commissioner in CBP. " width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Robin Robinson, director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority in the HHS Office, Luciana Borio, assistant commissioner for counterterrorism policy at the FDA, and John Wagner, acting assistant commissioner in CBP.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: NICHOLAS KAMM/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T20:19:42.033+01:00">at 8.19pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-544000d8e4b02f15ae7577bb" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:34:18.553+01:00">6.34pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Braley, of Iowa, is asking about how health officials are adapting to the crisis: “Are you familiar with the concept of sentinel event reporting? Has CDC done an analysis of what happened at Texas Presbyterian? Have there been any recommendations on changing, updating [guidelines and plans]?”</p> <p><strong>“Twenty of the top disease </strong><strong>detectives” are on the job, </strong>Frieden says, before getting into what the CDC is trying to improve.</p> <p>“First is the prompt diagnosis of anyone who has fever or shows symptoms and has traveled to west Africa.”</p> <p>“The second is contact tracing and monitoring – [the contacts of Thomas Duncan have] their temperature taken, every day, for the 21 days. We’re now looking at the contacts of the two healthcare workers.”<br /></p> <p>“The third area is effective isolation and we’re looking very closely at what might have happened with these two exposures.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:16:35.691+01:00">at 9.16pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fff8ce4b0b858885afe9c" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:30:48.288+01:00">6.30pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Blackburn, of Tennessee,<strong> starts talking at length about the border with Mexico,</strong> apparently misunderstanding Dr Frieden’s “porous border” phrase as meaning the southern US border – rather than the borders of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.</p> <p>Frieden clarifies his point. John Wagner, of US border patrol, is cut off as he tries to answer how the southern border is at all relevant to the Ebola crisis.</p> <p>Blackburn moves on to the dangers of medical waste, asking whether the CDC is providing </p> <p>Frieden: “We’ve worked very closely with the Department of Transportation as well as the commercial waste companies.”</p> <p>Blackburn: “So we have an added danger of removing and moving waste.”</p> <p>Frieden: “We have detailed guidelines for the disposal of medical waste from the care of Ebola patients.”</p> <p>Blackburn: “Are American troops going to come into contact with Ebola patients [in Africa]”</p> <p>Frieden: “As I understand it from the Department of Defense, their plans [do not include] any care of Ebola patients. … The Department of Defense is trying very hard to avoid the possibility of soldiers coming into contact [with anyone showing symptoms, as well”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:16:54.304+01:00">at 9.16pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fff27e4b0d81d4881b2a1" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:25:23.068+01:00">6.25pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Waxman asks Dr Fauci whether he agrees, which the latter does.</p> <p>“It’s certianly understandable that someone might come to the conclusion that the best approach would be to seal off the border of those controls. … But we know what we’re dealing with. [If we were to close airports] there would be this big web of things that we don’t know what we’re dealing with.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="16a5e9058e933b2b5fd239c38476c9b2cbdddeaa"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413490658693/c1b6049a-02db-4cc2-9ec8-b84bb9d01b01-460x276.jpeg" alt="National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Director  Dr. Anthony Fauci, right, talks with CDC Director Dr. Tom Frieden." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Director Dr. Anthony Fauci, right, talks with CDC Director Dr. Tom Frieden.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Pablo Martinez Monsivais/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:17:45.762+01:00">at 9.17pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ffe7ce4b02f15ae7577b7" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:23:42.909+01:00">6.23pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Representative Waxman defends the CDC</strong>, pointing out that they don’t have the authority to impose anything on hospitals across the US but can only provide guidance and assistance. He says Frieden and other officials are tasked with dealing with “a fluid situation” and also trying to forestall panic.</p> <p>“So we have to make sure we monitor healthcare workers … so the question has been raised, what about all these people coming in from Africa?”</p> <p>He gestures with a map of airline traffic flows from Africa, making the point that it’s easy to catch layovers to the US from airports around the world. In effect<strong> Waxman is reinforcing Frieden’s earlier argument:</strong> airports as control points are far more useful than trying to block the “porous borders” around the world.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T21:18:17.541+01:00">at 9.18pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ffd35e4b0b858885afe99" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:20:34.502+01:00">6.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative Upton is asking about how people could contract the disease, be asymptomatic, and then manifest Ebola here in the US.</p> <p>Upton: “Does the president have the legal authority to impose a travel ban, is that correct?”</p> <p>Frieden: “I don’t have the legal expertise to answer that question.”</p> <p>From what he’s seen, Upton says, the president does have that power. Upton now asks about travel restrictions imposed by other countries, which Frieden says are in some cases “in flux”.</p> <p>Finally, he asks “why can’t we move toward a similar ban … especially knowing that … this is not a fail-safe system that’s been put into place?”</p> <p>Frieden: “Right now we know who’s coming in. If we try to eliminate [air travel] … we won’t be able to check them for fever when they leave, when they arrive, we won’t be able to check for a detailed history. We wouldn’t be able to impose quarantine … we wouldn’t be able to identify and trace contacts – email history, phone history [etc]. … We wouldn’t be able to impose controlled motion …”</p> <p>Upton: “If we have a system in place that requires any airline passenger coming in from overseas that we can’t look at one’s travel history and say ‘No, you’re not coming here.’ … Until the situation is resolved in Africa.”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ffca9e4b0b858885afe98" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:15:13.291+01:00">6.15pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>They go back and forth about how Vinson boarded a plane with a fever.</p> <p>DeGette: “She was told by your agency that she can board your plane?”</p> <p>Frieden: “I do not know exactly what was said, but she did contact our agency and she did board the plane … People who are in what’s called controlled movement, should not board commercial airlines.”</p> <p>DeGette: “And that’s people who’ve had contact with these patients.”</p> <p>Frieden: “The guidelines say people who were not protected [by appropriate equipment] should not, but that people [who were can].”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ffbeae4b0cd82a095f9aa" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:12:38.241+01:00">6.12pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Representative DeGette is asking Dr Varga about what happened with Thomas Eric Duncan in Texas, running through much of what he just said.</p> <p>“Because Ebola is highly contagious, the protective gear that [health workers] have to wear has to cover them completely, correct?”</p> <p>She gestures with a New York Times graphic and asks what workers should have been wearing before Ebola was diagnosed. Frieden says it depends on whether a patient has diarrhea and vomiting, then additional covering is recommended.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ffa81e4b0d81d4881b298" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:09:27.038+01:00">6.09pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">US representatives question health officials</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Representative Murphy is now interrogating Dr Frieden about travel restrictions </strong>and how it happened that Amber Vinson flew from Cleveland to Dallas.</p> <p>Frieden <strong>says he was not involved in the CDC conversation that did not bar Vinson from flying</strong>, and maintains that his goal “is to protect Americans”. Only when pressed about travel bans does he say the CDC would be willing to adapt if that’s truly necessary.</p> <p>Dr Fauci tells Murphy that secure plans are in place to move Nina Pham to Bethesda, and that “Our total right now is two beds, she will occupy one of them.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:45:58.277+01:00">at 10.45pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ff6cde4b0b858885afe90" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:03:45.273+01:00">6.03pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Back in Washington,</strong> Dr Luciana Borio, assistant commissioner for counterterrorism policy and actinv chief scientist of the FDA, and John Wagner, of US Customs and Border Protection, have both testified about US readiness.</p> <p>Borio goes through FDA plans to test and supply treatments, and Wagner talks about the preparedness at airports and among border security, stressing good communication about what to look for.</p> <p>Dr Daniel Varga, a Texas health official, describes, in depth and without shying from the errors, the timeline of treatment for Duncan, Pham and Vinson – until the chairman asks him to conclude to preserve time.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ff825e4b0d81d4881b296" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T18:01:03.620+01:00">6.01pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Seven people in north-east Ohio have entered voluntary quarantine</strong> – despite having no symptoms – after confirmed contact with Amber Vinson, the second Texas nurse who tested positive for Ebola.</p> <p>CNN broke the story with word from Ohio Department of Health spokesman Jay Carey, who said that the people are monitoring themselves for fever or symptoms.</p> <p>In what may be an excess of caution, two schools have closed in Ohio, because someone who works there “traveled home from Dallas on Frontier Airlines Tuesday on a different flight, but perhaps the same aircraft” as Vinson, the school district said in a statement. In Texas schools closed as well, because two students were on Frontier flight 1143 with Vinson.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ff5bce4b0d81d4881b28d" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:47:29.841+01:00">5.47pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Spain is testing a third person for Ebola today </strong>– Reuters reports, saying he was a religious missionary recently in Liberia.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A Spanish missionary who worked in Africa has been taken to hospital in Madrid with symptoms of Ebola, a hospital source said on Thursday.</p> <p>The priest had been in Liberia and had been in contact there with people infected with Ebola, El Mundo newspaper reported, adding he was hospitalized on Thursday after developing a fever of over 37.6 (99.68) degrees Celsius.</p> <p>He was in the same religious order as two other Spanish priests who were repatriated from west Africa in recent weeks with the disease, and who later died in Madrid, the newspaper said.</p> </blockquote> <p>The Spanish government confirmed the third person’s testing in a statement.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ff3e0e4b02f15ae7577a1" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:39:11.748+01:00">5.39pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>He says that all the therapeutics tried so far are experimental – and emphasizes “We <em>do not know</em>” whether they’re having an effect, or what that effect might be.</p> <p>He runs down the list of treatments attempted so far, and says “We are in phase one trials” for a vaccine, and that the US military in collaboration with the NIH is working on a vaccine as well. </p> <p>Fauci says the trials in animals have been “favorable” so far, but that it is one of the highest priorities is making sure any such treatment is safe and would not create more harm than good.</p> <p>Finally<strong>, he confirms the report about the first Texas Ebola patient:</strong> “This evening tonight we will be admitting to the clinical studies unit at the NIH Nina Pham, otherwise known as ‘nurse number one’, where we will be giving her state of the art care.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:39:31.397+01:00">at 5.39pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ff351e4b0d81d4881b287" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time Diseases, is now describing some of the science behind Ebola, saying that it’s difficult to confront the virus because it’s highly lethal and infective on contact with bodily fluids, and because there is no cure.</p> <p>Fauci describes NIAID’s roles as one of diagnostics and research, with an endgame in “vaccines and therapeutics” . <br /></p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ff2ace4b0d81d4881b285" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:32:41.047+01:00">5.32pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>He says that the CDC fields calls from healthcare professionals and anyone who fears they have symptoms, and that only one of those calls – “one call too many” – turned out to be positive: Thomas Eric Duncan.</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="507ad11d78be859fdb3c03aafdb2539b24cc050b"> <img ERNST/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Frieden also says that the CDC has teams ready to be deployed anywhere in the country “within hours”.</p> <p>He now demonstrates with some documents, saying that he is ready to explain in full how the CDC traces contacts of infected patients. <strong>“There are no shortcuts. … We’re always open to new ideas.”</strong></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:58:16.229+01:00">at 10.58pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ff1c9e4b02f15ae75779f" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:30:30.331+01:00">5.30pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Dr Tom Frieden, director of the CDC, takes the floor:</strong></p> <p>He goes through is credentials and almost 25 years of experience researching communicable diseases.</p> <p>“Ebola is not new, even if it is new to the United States … We know how to control Ebola, even in this period, even in Lagos, Nigeria. We do this by [isolating, treating] and tracing contacts.”</p> <p>“To protect the United States we have to stop it at its source. There is a lot of fear about Ebola, and <strong>I’ll tell you as director of the CDC, that I fear it will spread more in Africa. </strong>Our top priority, our focus, is to work 24/7 to protect Americans. We protect Americans from threats, and in the case of Ebola we do that through a system of multiple levels.” </p> <p>“We have helped each of the infected countries to use exit screening. We identified 72 people with fever, none of them … boarded a plane. … Recently we added another level of [screening] at the US. … We’ve also increase awareness among physicians in the US to think Ebola, to look for anyone who has fevers or symptoms of infection and has been to Africa in the past 21 days.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:13:16.787+01:00">at 10.13pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543feec4e4b0cd82a095f98f" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:25:03.520+01:00">5.25pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Back in DC at the hearing, Fred Upton, a Republican from Michigan, tells the medical officials that he’s going to “hold your feet to the fire” to make sure that proper safeguards are implemented immediately.</p> <p>He too suggests travel bans to and from west Africa, although he does say that the US must work to confront the outbreak there.</p> <p>Simon Waxman, a Democrat from California, ridicules the idea of a ban, pointing out that people can easily fly “to Brussels” and then into the US. He goes after Republicans who backed the government shutdown in 2013 and says: “We have our share of responsibility of funding the infrastructure … we shouldn’t leave ourselves vulnerable to these irrational budget cuts.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:25:14.568+01:00">at 5.25pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div </p>   <h2 class="block-title">First infected nurse to move to Maryland</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Nina Pham will be airlifted to the National Institutes of Health outside Washington</strong>, according to Reuters, the Associated Press and local Dallas NBC News.</p> <p>Pham, the first nurse to be diagnosed with Ebola after treating a Liberian man at Texas Presbyterian Hospital, will go to an isolation unit in Bethesda, Maryland, according to a Dallas and federal officials cited by AP and NBC News, respectively.</p>  <figure class="element element-image </strong>Diana DeGette of Colorado says.</p> <p>She says we need to find out why Texas Presbyterian Hospital was not prepared, and says that Americans should be concerned about the appearance of Ebola protocols of thermal scanning and questions at airports as “troubling” and says that passengers can mask symptoms of a fever.</p> <p>He calls for the administration just to ask Congress to get things id="block-543fec36e4b0cd82a095f985" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T17:07:42.718+01:00">5.07pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">House hearing on Ebola begins</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The House of Representatives hearing on Ebola has begun</strong>, with chairman Tim Murphy, of Pennsylvania, kicking off:</p> <p>“We must be clear-eyed … and ensure not one additional case is contracted in the United States … The stakes in this battle couldn’t be higher. The cases in west Africa are doubling every three weeks. [At this point] the numbers are still on the side of the virus.”</p> <p>He says that we have to acknowledge that “mistakes have been made” and the US must move on while also rectifying mistakes, such as making sure that all hospitals with isolation wards can handle Ebola cases.</p> <p>He hints at questions to come for the CDC, such as “Why was the CDC slow to deploy first response teams? Why [weren’t guidelines] better communicated?”</p> <p>Finally, Murphy suggests stricter travel restrictions – like bans – and says that self-reporting at airports is a “demonstrated failure”&gt;</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T22:41:59.826+01:00">at 10.41pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fe7d6e4b080f8392521ae" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T16:55:50.622+01:00">4.55pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Dan also flags some interesting points from prepared testimony, including <strong>updates on the mission to develop an Ebola vaccine</strong><strong>, and a </strong><strong>disturbing detail of mismanagement at Texas Presbyterian</strong> Hospital in Dallas.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>In <a href="http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF02/20141016/102718/HHRG-113-IF02-Wstate-VargaD-20141016.pdf ">pre-submitted evidenc</a>e, Dr Daniel Varga, the chief clinical officer at the Dallas hospital that first treated cases in the US, revealed how the temperature of the first patient Eric Duncan had spiked to 103 degree fahrenheit during his first visit to the emergency department, yet he was still sent home.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>About experimental drugs and production capabilities</strong>, Anthony Fauci, Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) <a href="http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF02/20141016/102718/HHRG-113-IF02-Wstate-FauciA-20141016.pdf">warned that they were still some distance</a> from widespread trials.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“While NIAID is an active participant in the global effort to address the public health emergency occurring in west Africa, it is important to recognize that we are still in the early stages of understanding how infection with the Ebola virus can be treated and prevented,” he said.</p> <p>“As we continue to expedite research while enforcing high safety and efficacy standards, the implementation of the public health measures already known to contain prior Ebola virus outbreaks and the implementation of treatment strategies such as fluid and electrolyte replacement are essential to preventing additional infections, treating those already infected, protecting health care providers, and ultimately bringing this epidemic to an end.”</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fe6e8e4b04a4f580016d9" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T16:46:30.982+01:00">4.46pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>A congressional hearing of the US House of Representatives is due to begin at 12pm ET</strong>, and my colleague in Washington, Dan Roberts, briefs us on what to expect:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>In<a href="http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF02/20141016/102718/HHRG-113-IF02-Wstate-FriedenT-20141016.pdf"> prepared testimony</a> ahead of a hearing of a House of Representatives oversight committee, Thomas Frieden, director of the CDC, pointed to the temporary re-emergence of the disease in Nigeria as a sign of what happens if contact tracing protocols are not fully followed.<br /></p> <p>“It’s like fighting a forest fire: leave behind one burning ember, one case undetected, and the epidemic could re-ignite.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Frieden points to “meticulous work” in Nigeria as a model to emulate – noting “that the outbreak appears to have been extinguished there.” He does warn, however, that even with 10 CDC staff and highly trained Nigerian epidemiologists, one missed case caused a cluster of others in Port Harcourt.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T16:54:57.914+01:00">at 4.54pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fdeb5e4b080f83925219b" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T16:37:08.056+01:00">4.37pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a summary of the latest developments:</p> <ul> <li><strong>US congressmen will question CDC director Dr Tom </strong><strong>Frieden</strong><strong><strong><strong> over the handling of Ebola cases</strong>,</strong></strong> after a second nurse tested positive for the virus in Texas. Frieden has said the CDC should have acted faster and been more engaged.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta">The second nurse, Amber Vinson, arrived at a special bio-containment unit in Atlanta</a>, as officials acknowledged failings in the response to the arrival of the virus in the US.</strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong></strong> The CDC is trying to contact people who flew on a commercial flight with Vinson while she had a low fever just a day before she tested positive.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>The WHO said <a href="http://">it expects global Ebola cases to surpass 9,000 this week</a></strong>, that a drop of cases in Liberia was “encouraging”, and that a team of experts are going to Mali and Ivory Coast to help secure borders. </li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>British army medics <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-543f7bd6e4b0ebfb2a1bf334">landed in west Africa</a></strong>, where they will coordinate with government and international teams.<br /></li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong><strong><strong>Several suspected new cases have been reported in Europe</strong></strong></strong></strong>. Spanish authorities <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-543fd87de4b080f839252198">grounded a plane after one of the passengers reported a fever</a>, and one of the people who being monitored for contact with an infected nurse has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-543fd87de4b080f839252198">also been taken to the hospital</a>. We do the same thing, wipe down the seat pockets, empty out the pockets,” says Luke-Anthony, who lives in the Bronx and has two small children. “If there are blankets, we put ‘em in bags. Vacuum, mop.” <br /></p> <p>“Food, wet napkins, sanitary wipes, dirty Pampers. It’s disgusting,” Luke-Anthony says. “Sometimes we find dirty needles.”</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="dc6468063e003b8947701610beb5060acacdee5c"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413472578810/098cc29b-b45d-404e-b57d-ac187444f58f-460x276.jpeg" alt="JFK airport in New York." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">JFK airport in New York.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: EDUARDO MUNOZ/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Last week workers at New York’s LaGuardia airport walked off the job for a day to protest poor preparation. As one told the Guardian:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>They expect us, that if a little bit of feces stays on the toilet, that we remove it with our hands because [if not] they will say that bathroom is dirty. And I refuse to do it because I think it’s disgusting and I don’t have the appropriate attire, and because I don’t know what that person has.</p> <p>“We come in contact with a lot of stuff that is dangerous for our health and obviously they don’t give us the appropriate tools to work with.”</p> </blockquote> <p>You can read the full piece <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/airline-cabin-cleaners-strike-over-ebola-fears-at-laguardia-airport">here</a>. <br /></p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fdc8ce4b0cd82a095f965" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T16:03:38.502+01:00">4.03pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>A nurse with a high fever in has been rushed to a hospital in France</strong>, Reuters and <a href="http://www.thelocal.fr/20141016/french-nurse-suspected-of-having-ebola">local French media repor</a>t, where she will be evaluated. France has had two false alarms in recent weeks, and one infected humanitarian worker has recovered there.</p> <p>Reuters says the woman being tested today was taken under high security to the Begin de Saint-Mande military hospital outside Paris.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The woman had been in regular contact with a French volunteer nurse working with humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders who contracted Ebola in Liberia and was repatriated to France last month. </p> <p>That nurse, the first French national to be infected with the disease, received an experimental treatment for the virus and subsequently recovered. </p> </blockquote> <p>Reuters could not confirm the report, however, with the French Health Ministry, which has a policy of not commenting until tests are completed.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fdaf4e4b0449bb15336ce" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:53:54.051+01:00">3.53pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Screening for Ebola will begin today at four US airports</strong>, following New York’s JFK airport, which began checks on Saturday.</p> <p>Each of the airports – O’Hare in Chicago, Newark airport, Washington DC’s Dulles and Atlanta’s international – is a major international hub for airliners. </p> <p>Teams equipped with thermal guns will take the temperatures of travellers from Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea and ask questions about their possible exposure to the virus as they enter the US.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="2abcf452ea37dbc87f130fcad385d144ae4f9451"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413471338342/1430c591-9466-4ba8-be45-f0fd1c23b3be-460x276.jpeg" alt="A thermal camera system monitors the body heat of passengers arriving from abroad to check for possible infections." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A thermal camera system monitors the body heat of passengers arriving from abroad to check for possible infections.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: BYUN YEONG-WOOK/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Dr Martin Cetron, a director at the CDC, said in a Saturday briefing that despite any number of checks at airports: “No matter how many procedures are put into place, we can’t get the risk to zero.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:56:07.029+01:00">at 3.56pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fd87de4b080f839252198" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:46:36.827+01:00">3.46pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Test results for a person with a fever in Spain will come in this afternoon</strong>, after a Spanish health official confirmed.</p> <p>The official, Fernando Simon, also says that one of the people being monitored for having had contact with an infected nurse, is being evaluated:</p> <p>“One of [the 68 people being monitored] has developed fever this morning. She was immediately told to remain at home and will be immediately transferred to the Carlos III Hospital. The appropriate protocol has been put in place very quickly because the case has been detected in a very timely manner and we understand that we will have results by this afternoon or this evening of the first Ebola test.”</p> <p>About the Teresa Romero, the nurse who contracted the disease:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“The patient is in stable condition, the viral load seems to be down, which means that a priori, the immunity system of the patient is being able to control the infection – which is a positive sign.”</p> <p>We have information that the infection of the organs that had been affected during the infection also are improving. But as always with a disease like this, we have to be cautious until the last moment and although there are clear signs of hope, we should continue to be cautious and maintain moderation when giving information about her condition.”</p> </blockquote> <p>So far 15 people, including Romero’s husband and hospital staff who came into contact withe her, are under observation in an isolated ward, and none have shown symptoms. <strong>Today’s developments mean two people with fevers are being tested</strong>, one of whom is known to have contacted Romero, who remains in serious condition.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T16:20:56.971+01:00">at 4.20pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fd679e4b080f839252193" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:34:10.937+01:00">3.34pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>One last major point from the WHO: it plans to send teams to test Ebola preparedness in at Mali and Ivory Coast’s borders. </p> <p>Mali borders Guinea, and Ivory Coast borders both Guinea and Liberia – the latter of which has been particularly hard hit by the outbreak. In August Ivory Coast <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-28913253">closed its land borders with both countries</a>, despite the WHO’s counsel that the measure is counter-productive. Per Reuters:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A team of around 10 will leave for Mali on Sunday and another team will leave for Ivory Coast within days, Nuttall said, adding that Ivory Coast had checkpoints to monitor people coming across the border and had already done a simulation exercise to test its response.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:38:24.602+01:00">at 3.38pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fd1e3e4b0cd82a095f951" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:18:31.252+01:00">3.18pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here are the main points from the WHO briefing:</p> <ul> <li>The number of Ebola cases is set to exceed 9,000 by the end of this week, and the number of deaths will soon exceed 4,500.</li> <li>The number of new cases is doubling every four weeks. Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone remain the worst hit. </li> <li>There has been an “encouraging” drop in the number of cases in the Lofa district of Liberia. The WHO said it was hopeful that the decrease was the result of community engaging paying off, but cautioned that it was too early to tell.</li> <li>The WHO is to focus attention of 15 African countries to stop the disease spreading. They are: Ivory Coast, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/guinea">Guinea</a> Bissau, Mali, Senegal, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Gambia, Ghana, Mauritania, Nigeria, South Sudan, Togo. They have to be “better prepared” the WHO warned. <br /></li> </ul> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fcf76e4b0449bb15336bb" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:05:18.826+01:00">3.05pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>This is what Nutall said about pickups and ambulances: <br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We have enough evidence now to know that the best ambulance is not a closed ambulance it’s pickup. Why is better to have pickup? The driver is protected. The [infected] person can be put in the back and therefore you limit the manipulation of the person.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="c01877fa08874fdab15fbbdde9b9c88d9507bda5"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413468292132/e5a3d7d8-da23-4aa1-895b-b79a800194b6-460x276.jpeg" alt="Health workers load a body infected with Ebola virus onto a pickup truck  in Monrovia, capital of Liberia." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Health workers load a body infected with Ebola virus onto a pickup truck in Monrovia, capital of Liberia.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Xinhua /Landov / Barcroft Media/Xinhua /Landov / Barcroft Media</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fcb67e4b080f839252186" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T14:45:39.052+01:00">2.45pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Nuttall named the 15 countries (corrected from the figure of 14 she mentioned earlier) where the WHO is trying to stop the disease spreading. They are: Ivory Coast, Guinea Bissau, Mali, Senegal, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Gambia, Ghana, Mauritania, Nigeria, South Sudan, Togo.</p> <p>These priority countries either have land borders with affected countries or they have high travel and trade with the worst hit countries. </p> <p>She said: “The objective is to stop the transmission from occurring in these countries. They may have a case but after one case we don’t want more cases.” These countries need to be “better prepared” Nuttall said. <br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:09:59.102+01:00">at 3.09pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fcafde4b0cd82a095f944" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T14:42:36.820+01:00">2.42pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a transcript of the first part of Nuttall’s statement, including the “encouraging” drop in cases in one district of Liberia.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>This week we will cross 9,000 cases of Ebola and 4,500 deaths. The outbreak continues to hit health workers hard. So far 427 health care workers have been infected with Ebola and 236 have died. </p> <p>Our data shows cases are doubling every four weeks. The disease is still widespread in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, and there is persistent transmission of the virus. </p> <p>An increase in new Ebola cases in Guinea is being driven by a spike in confirmed and suspected cases in the capital Conakry, and the nearby district of Coyah.</p> <p>In Liberia problems with data gathering makes it hard to draw any firm conclusions. There is significant under-reporting of cases from the capital Monrovia. But it is also worth mentioning that in Lofa district appears to have a decrease in the number of cases. This is encouraging since this area was hit hard early on, but we need a concerted effort to sustain this drop. Remember we have seen drops before and have then seen another increases in the number of cases.</p> <p>WHO has had a strong community engagement in the area of Lofa in Liberia, and we are hopeful that this work is paying off. Time will tell. </p> <p>In Sierra Leone, intense transmission is still occurring in the capital Freetown and surrounding districts. </p> <p>It will take months before this outbreak is stopped. In the meantime we need to make sure it doesn’t spread to other countries. <br /></p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fc617e4b0449bb15336a3" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T14:21:49.940+01:00">2.21pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a recording of Nuttall’s update on the WHO’s latest Ebola assessment.</p>  <figure class="element element-audio" data-canonical-url="https://audioboom.com/boos/2568282-who-update-on-the-ebola-outbreak"> <iframe width="460" height="154" src="http://audioboom.com/boos/2568282-who-update-on-the-ebola-outbreak/embed/v3?eid=AQAAAGLGP1RaMCcA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fc4e3e4b0449bb15336a2" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T14:16:16.073+01:00">2.16pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Nuttall points out that pick up trucks are better than ambulances for transporting patients because they provide better protection for drivers. <br /></p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fc43ee4b080f83925217c" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T14:13:48.512+01:00">2.13pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Nuttal says the WHO is focusing on 14 countries to stop the disease spreading.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/WHO/statuses/522736413457285120">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Dr Nuttall: For <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Ebola?src=hash">#Ebola</a> preparedness plan, 14 countries are our top priority (land borders w/ affected countries or high travel trade routes)</p>&mdash; </p>   <h2 class="block-title">WHO: 9,000 cases by the end of the week</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>The World Health Organisation predicts that the number of cases will exceed 9,000 by the end of the week, and that the number of deaths from the disease will soon pass 4,500.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/WHO/statuses/522734347196309504">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Dr Isabelle Nuttall: This week we will cross 9,000 <a </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fc200e4b01d51bd0b0554" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T14:03:23.403+01:00">2.03pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a summary of the latest developments:</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-hospital-sorry-ebola-case-errors"><strong><strong>The operator of the Texan hospital in which two nurses contracted Ebola has apologised for initially failing to diagnose the patient who infected them. </strong></strong></a>Dr Daniel Varga, chief clinical officer at Texas Health Resources, conceded that errors were made by Presbyterian hospital in Dallas, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/thomas-duncan-ebola-medical-records-high-fever">which sent Thomas Eric Duncan</a> home after he complained of a fever and abdominal pain after arriving from his native Liberia last month.<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta"><strong><strong><br /></strong></strong></a></li> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates#block-543f95ede4b03829d13c20f7"><strong>But Texas Health Resources rebutted health union criticisms of the way staff were protected.</strong></a> It said it followed federal guidelines and responded to nurses concerns about skin being exposed. <br /></li> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta"><strong><strong>The second nurse diagnosed with Ebola in Texas was transferred from Dallas to a special bio-containment unit in Atlanta, as officials acknowledged failings in the response to the arrival of the virus in the US.</strong></strong></a> The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also said that the 29-year-old nurse, Amber Vinson, flew on a commercial flight from Cleveland, Ohio to Dallas with a low-grade temperature a day before she was diagnosed.</li> <li><strong>Several suspected new cases have been reported in Europe</strong>. Spanish authorities isolated an Air France plane at Madrid’s airport and activated emergency health procedures after one of the passengers was reported to have a fever. Tests are also being carried out on a health worker in Denmark. And two students who travelled from Guinea-Bissau are being treated in an isolation unit in a Russian hospital after reporting a high temperature. </li> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/16/ebola-outbreak-texas-hospital-apologises-over-infections-as-uk-army-medics-travel-to-sierra-leone-live-updates"><strong>The UN’s new high commissioner for human rights Zeid Raad al-Hussein has drawn comparison between the Ebola outbreak and the Islamic State.</strong></a> He described them as “twin plagues” which have been neglected and misread by the international community. <br /></li> <li><strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/obama-ebola-international-threat-european-leaders">Barack Obama has promised a “much more aggressive” monitoring of Ebola cases in the US and confirmed plans to send a “Swat team” of experts to any hospital that reported an infection.</a></strong></strong>The president also cancelled a trip to Rhode Island and New York on Thursday to focus on his administration’s response to domestic cases of Ebola.</li> </ul> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T15:28:27.221+01:00">at 3.28pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543fbca1e4b03829d13c213b" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time emergency health procedures after one of the passengers was reported to have a fever.</p> <p>A Spanish Airport Authority spokeswoman said the passenger jet had arrived in Madrid from Paris. She said the plane was taken to a special area of the airport complex and the passengers were being kept on board. <br /></p> <p>A health ministry spokeswoman said they were treating it as a suspected case of Ebola.<br /> <br /> The private Europa Press news agency said there were 183 passengers on the plane.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" He was airlifted out of Sierra Leone in September but later made a full recovery. Doctors are confident he is now free of all five strains of the virus</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543fb3b7e4b01d51bd0b0540" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T13:10:57.065+01:00">1.10pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The Ministry of Health in <a href="https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=365256273651221&amp;id=281064805403702">Sierra Leone has announced that Ebola has now reached every district of the country</a>. </p> <p><br />It noted two Ebola cases in the Koinadugu district, in Sierra Leone’s far north. military use only, was initially developed by AMMS. </p> <p>The company is preparing for clinical trials in Africa and could test the drug on African Ebola patients, said Huo. </p> <p>No Chinese nationals have been infected. <br /> <br /> There are about a million Chinese nationals living in Africa, with some 10,000 in the countries most affected by Ebola, which are Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia. <br /> JK-05 has not been used on humans, although Sihuan says it has proven effective in tests on mice. </p> <p>Its development lags some way behind US-developed ZMapp and TKM-Ebola, which have been tested on monkeys and used on Ebola patients. </p> <p>However, analysts said the drug’s similarities to Japanese influenza drug Favipiravir is an encouraging sign. </p> <p>Japanese firm
