datetime="2014-10-16T11:18:22.642+01:00">11.18am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Texas Health Resources rebuts union criticism</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Texas Health Resources [THR], the company that runs the Presbyterian hospital in Dallas where two nurses contracted the virus, has taken issue with union criticisms of the way it treated Thomas Eric Duncan, who died last week.</p> <p>After <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-hospital-sorry-ebola-case-errors">apologising for its initial failings</a> in Duncan’s treatment, <a href="http://texashealth.org/news-alert.cfm?id=1629&amp;action=detail&amp;ref=1898">THR issued a detailed rebuttal of criticism</a> by the National Nurses United union. </p> <p>The union seized on medical records suggesting that staff worked in the quarantine unit with their skin exposed during the three days between when the patient was admitted and when he was diagnosed.</p> <p>Here are the key points of the company’s rebuttal. <br /></p> <ul> <li>Hospital staff treating Duncan wore protective equipment as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] at the time. </li> <li>At no time did Duncan’s specimens leak or spill.<br /></li> <li>During Duncan’s second hospital visit his specimens were triple-bagged, placed in a container, and placed into a closed transport container and hand-carried to a lab.<br /></li> <li>Nurses who treated Duncan initially wore shoe covers and face shields. When CDC guidance was updated they also wore leg covers.<br /></li> <li>When the CDC recommended that nurses wear isolation suits, nurses pointed out that the skin on their necks was exposed. The CDC recommended that they pinch and tape the necks of the gown. The hospital ordered hoods to allay nurses fears. <br /></li> <li>The hospital went “above and beyond” CDC recommendations on the handling of hazardous waste. Waste was well-contained in accordance with standards, and it was located in safe and containable locations.</li> <li>It admitted that some protective suits were too large and that it has since ordered smaller sizes. <br /></li> </ul>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="c142b43b78a3cf7a2cff212a22e33db1df9f701b"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413454643549/5671c95f-4fd8-4ebe-b47a-df34b296b123-460x336.jpeg" alt="Students wearing personal protective equipment participate in a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) training session" width="460" height="336" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Students wearing personal protective equipment participate in a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) training session</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: ERIK S. LESSER/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T11:51:34.866+01:00">at 11.51am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543f8947e4b03829d13c20d7" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T10:42:28.326+01:00">10.42am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Two students from <a href="http://rt.com/news/196404-russia-africans-hospital-ebola/">Guinea-Bissau have been taken to hospital in the Russian town of Oryol</a>, to check for Ebola, RT reports. <br /></p> <p>They arrived in the country at Moscow’s Domodedovo Airport and travelled to Oryol by bus, it said.<br /></p> <p>The students, Monteyro Bolde Iyury (20) and Santoush Monteyro Ayuk Lidish (23) are being kept in an isolation unit. Both are reported to have had a fever, but their temperature levels have since returned to normal. <br /></p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543f84e9e4b0ebfb2a1bf340" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T10:42:28.326+01:00">10.42am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Ebola survivors are meeting in Kenema, one of the centres of the Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone, to share their experience of the disease and learn how to deal with its psychological aftermath.</p> <p>The event is organised by the Sierra Leone government with the help of <a href="http://www.unicef.org.uk/">Unicef</a>.<br /></p> <p>Alhaji Moijue Kaikai, minister of social welfare, said the survivors “give hope” to others still fighting the the disease. He said: “We need to accept survivors and welcome them back to our families and our communities.”</p> <p>The survivors will hear from experts on how to deal with trauma and stigmatisation. <br /></p> <p>People who have been exposed to, and survived Ebola, are often shunned by their communities, Unicef warned. It found that 96% of households in Sierra Leone reported some discriminatory attitudes toward people with suspected or confirmed Ebola. <br /></p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543f7bd6e4b0ebfb2a1bf334" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-16T10:42:28.326+01:00">10.42am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Welcome to our live coverage of the spread of the Ebola virus and the global efforts to tackle it.</p> <p>The World Health Organisation is due to give another Ebola briefing (at 2pm BST) as the total <a href="http://www.trust.org/item/20141015232548-vudg2/">number of people killed in the outbreak nears 4,500</a>. </p> <p>In the US the Texas hospital where a patient died and two nurses became infected has apologised for its mistakes.</p> <p>In Britain David Cameron will chair another meeting of the government’s emergency Cobra committee to discuss further action to stop Ebola spreading. And <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-crisis-british-army-medics-arrive-sierra-leone">British Army medics are due to arrive in Sierra Leone</a> where they will operate a treatment centre specifically for healthcare workers. <br /></p> <p>Here are the other latest key developments:</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta"><strong>The second nurse diagnosed with Ebola in Texas was transferred from Dallas to a special bio-containment unit in Atlanta, as officials acknowledged failings in the response to the arrival of the virus in the US.</strong></a> The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also said that the 29-year-old nurse, Amber Vinson, flew on a commercial flight from Cleveland, Ohio to Dallas with a low-grade temperature a day before she was diagnosed. </li> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-hospital-sorry-ebola-case-errors"><strong>The operator of the Texan hospital in which two nurses contracted Ebola has apologised for initially failing to diagnose the patient who infected them. </strong></a>Dr Daniel Varga, chief clinical officer at Texas Health Resources, conceded that errors were made by Presbyterian hospital in Dallas, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/thomas-duncan-ebola-medical-records-high-fever">which sent Thomas Eric Duncan</a> home after he complained of a fever and abdominal pain after arriving from his native Liberia last month.</li> <li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/obama-ebola-international-threat-european-leaders">Barack Obama has promised a “much more aggressive” monitoring of Ebola cases in the US and confirmed plans to send a “Swat team” of experts to any hospital that reported an infection.</a> </strong>The president also cancelled a trip to Rhode Island and New York on Thursday to focus on his administration’s response to domestic cases of Ebola.</li> </ul>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="65eb68da015ad5b49ade062c24979f977aa8e613"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413448297021/71008890-e05d-4625-976e-4a2e66c3fd1a-280x420.jpeg" alt="Will Pooley" width="280" height="420" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Will Pooley</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: WILL OLIVER / POOL/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/british-nurse-ebola-survivor-sierra-leone-return"><strong>Will Pooley, the British nurse who survived Ebola after contracting the disease in Sierra Leone, is heading back to the African country to join the exhausted frontline workers battling to treat patients with the virus.</strong></a> “There is still a lot of work to do out there and I am in the same or better position than when I chose to go out before,” he said.</li> <li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/uk-landlords-refuse-house-student-sierra-leone-ebola-fears">British landlords have refused to house student from Sierra Leone over Ebola fears.</a> </strong>Radio presenter Amara Bangura, 35, from the capital Freetown, said he was refused lodgings by two separate landlords who had been happy to rent him accommodation in Norwich until they saw his passport and found out he was from one of the worst-hit Ebola hotspots.</li> </ul> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T11:50:33.296+01:00">at 11.50am BST</time></p>  </div>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/texas-healthcare-workers-ebola-public <p>Healthcare workers deemed to be at risk of contracting Ebola after dealing with a patient who died from the virus in Texas are being asked to sign voluntary agreements to stay away from the public, after Dallas authorities decided against declaring a state of emergency.<br /></p> <p>Seventy-five staff members from Texas Health Presbyterian hospital are being given a “binding legal document and order” that states they will avoid public transport, not go to areas where large numbers of people congregate, and continue to be monitored twice a day for symptoms, county judge Clay Jenkins said on Thursday.</p> <p>Any of those involved in the care of Thomas Eric Duncan who refuse to sign the agreement would be subject to a legal control order, Jenkins told reporters after a meeting of the county commissioners court in downtown Dallas. “All the remedies of the law are available,” he said. However he said he believed this would not be necessary. “These are hometown healthcare heroes,” he said. “They’re not going to jail.”</p> <p>It was unclear how long the agreements would be in force. After first suggesting that all 75 healthcare workers had approved them, Jenkins conceded that the wording had only just been finalised, and that some of the 75 may have learned of it from watching broadcasts of the commissioners meeting. “This is clearly not the way I wanted it to go,” he said.</p> <p>The healthcare workers will also have their home addresses flagged on the internal systems of emergency services, said Jenkins, adding that this would prompt first responders responding to calls from their houses to raise an alarm. The flags would disappear when they are no longer at risk of Ebola.</p> <p>The new measure was implemented amid sharp criticism over Amber Vinson, the second nurse to be diagnosed with Ebola after treating Duncan, being permitted to take commercial flights between Texas and Ohio despite already experiencing a fever. Vinson, 29, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-nurse-transferred-texas-maryland-special-unit">has been transferred to a facility in Atlanta</a> for treatment. Nina Pham, the first nurse to be diagnosed, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta">is being treated in Maryland</a>.</p> <p>In all, more than 135 people – including the 75 healthcare workers, 48 other people who had contact with Duncan before he entered hospital, and a number of people Vinson encountered in Ohio – are being monitored for signs of Ebola.</p> <p>Jenkins announced the voluntary agreements after surprising the audience for the commissioners meeting by saying that he would not be declaring a state of emergency because of Ebola. A proposal for him to declare such an emergency was the sole stated reason for convening Thursday’s emergency meeting.</p> <p>The proposal, published in advance awaiting Jenkins’s signature, called for “extraordinary measures” necessary because Dallas “has the potential to suffer widespread or severe damage, injury, loss or threat of life resulting from the Ebola virus.” However, the motion was abruptly ignored and Jenkins announced the meeting had become “a public discussion”.</p> <p>“At this point we don’t feel that it’s necessary to take extraordinary powers, because we were able to do everything through our partnership with the city of Dallas, the state of Texas and the federal government,” Jenkins said afterwards.</p> <p>Jenkins, who as county judge is the highest-ranking elected official in Dallas county, indicated that the decision had been taken following consultations with other officials including Rick Perry, the Republican governor of Texas, who returned from a visit to Europe to help deal with the situation.</p> <p>Referring to the wide-ranging powers that he would have been handed to control the movement of people into, out of and within the county, and to evacuate Dallas if necessary, Jenkins said: “That’s not what America is about. I don’t want those powers vested in me, and neither does Governor Perry.”</p> <p>Jenkins chided the operators of the hospital for failing to prevent infections among its staff. He said he would begin working from inside the hospital in a unified command structure alongside Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) officials.</p> <p>“The buck has to stop with somebody, so the buck will stop with me,” said Jenkins, amid ongoing complaints that no one figure has emerged to lead Dallas’ response to the virus.</p> <p>Zachary Thompson, the county’s health director, told the meeting that the voluntary agreements with the healthcare workers must “give the cities a comfort level that the 75 are contained”, adding: “We need to be clear and transparent to the public that we don’t hear a new number”.</p> <p>Two of the four county commissioners signalled to the Guardian just hours before the meeting that they were in favour of the emergency declaration, which they said would also have made it easier for the county to obtain state and federal funding for its response to the crisis.</p> <p>“This is still evolving and the only way we can get reimbursed as a county is to make this declaration,” said John Wiley Price, the commissioner for district three, who promptly backtracked once the meeting had begun following delays while the commissioners held discussions backstage.</p> <p>“I think it’s important that we be reimbursed but that can’t be my focus right now,” said Jenkins. “Public safety has to be priority number one”.</p> <p>District four commissioner Dr Elba Garcia, whose chief of staff said before the meeting that she, too, wanted a state of emergency declared, said from the stage: “At this point I agree with Commissioner Price that the emergency declaration is a tool in the toolbox. I’m going to be very honest with you: I was ready to vote for it. But I think we should put it back in the toolbox.”</p> <p>Both Dr Theresa Daniel and Mike Cantrell, the other two county commissioners, along with Mike Rawlings, the mayor of Dallas, said from the stage that they agreed with the decision not to declare an emergency. Asked afterwards why the emergency meeting had been convened at all, Jenkins told reporters: “You’ll have to ask the commissioners.”</p>

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-republicans-pressure-ebola-travel-bans-west-africa <p>Republicans are stepping up pressure for travel bans on passengers arriving from Ebola-stricken countries in west Africa, calling for a vote on quarantine measures in the House of Representatives as the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) acknowledged it was assessing the question “on a day-to-day” basis.<br /></p> <p>The White House and senior US health officials continue to insist such measures would be counter-productive because they would hamper efforts to control the Ebola epidemic at its source, but the growing clamour from critics in Congress means the issue is becoming a major political battleground in Washington.</p> <p>During the <a href="http://energycommerce.house.gov/hearing/examining-us-public-health-response-ebola-outbreak">first hearing</a> into the administration’s handling of the crisis in Washington on Thursday, a succession of Republican congressmen joined the House speaker, John Boehner, in calling on the administration to urgently review its opposition to tighter travel restrictions.</p> <p>Michael Burgess, a Texas Republican and doctor of obstetrics and gynaecology who is the vice-chair of the subcommittee that held the hearing, said it was time for the full commerce committee to propose a vote on quarantine measures in the House.</p> <p>Such a vote is highly unlikely to force the administration’s hand unless there is overwhelming support in the Senate as well, but the call for it points to the growing politicisation of the Ebola threat in the run-up to next month’s midterm elections.</p> <p>“This should not be represented as an all-or-none choice,” said the subcommittee chair, Tim Murphy, a Pennsylvania Republican. “We can and will create the means to transport whatever supplies and goods are needed in Africa to win this deadly battle. http://www.theguardian.com/money/us-money-blog/2014/oct/16/ebola-nurses-walk-off-job <p>Cyndi Krahne is a nurse. Since <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/ebola">the first Ebola patient died in the US</a>, she has not worn her work shoes in the car. When she gets home, she follows a careful ritual in her garage: taking off her scrubs, stepping gingerly out of her shoes. She carefully wraps them in plastic and puts them in an out-of-the-way place where they won’t touch anything. The shoes and the scrubs never make it into the house.</p> <p>In a week when <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/money/us-money-blog/2014/oct/16/apples-iphone-and-the-iconic-consumer-designs-that-never-change">Dallas is considering declaring itself an Ebola disaster zone</a>, nurses are nervous. <br /></p> <p>Krahne has five children. “I am concerned. I don’t want them exposed,” she says. She’s seen infectious diseases before in the 10 years she has worked at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center Santa Rosa, California. She’s been careful – but never this diligent. <br /></p> <p>Fear is the reason for her conscientiousness. Krahne says she doesn’t feel safe at work. She is still without training or protective equipment. Krahne’s confidence is wavering that her workplace is as dedicated to her safety and well-being as she is. <br /></p> <p>“We haven’t received any education, nor do we have proper personal protective equipment to care for patients with Ebola,” she says. “Because we pushed the issue, we are beginning to get leaflets and they say there are a couple days of training that’s recommended, it’s not mandatory. Speaking for my facility, I personally have not received any notification of training and neither have my coworkers.”</p> <p>A lot of workers who have to come into contact with Ebola share her concerns. Their worries about potential exposure continue to grow, especially among those working on the front lines like nurses and airplane cleaners, who worry that they are not being properly equipped to deal with the situation. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/dallas-nurses-accuse-hospital-sloppy-safety-ebola">A leader of National Nurses United revealed that</a> nurses are forced to improvise dangerously at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital; some used medical tape to secure the openings of their gowns to prevent exposure. Airport employees are, in some cases, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/airline-cabin-cleaners-strike-over-ebola-fears-at-laguardia-airport">walking off the job</a>. <br /></p> <p>The Nurses Union has previously raised concerns over preparedness of hospitals when it comes to treating potential Ebola patients. <a href="http://www.nationalnursesunited.org/press/entry/national-nurse-survey-shows-hospitals-still-not-prepared-for-us-ebola/">Before the Dallas Ebola incidents, the union released a survey of 700 nurses</a> that found that 80% of them had received no communication from their hospital regarding any policy dealing with potential patients infected by Ebola and 87% were provided no education on the disease with the opportunity to ask questions. A third of them said that their hospital did not have sufficient supplies of personal protective equipment like face shields and impermeable gowns. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="104ac1361ec4b65be37732dd3a77f78035dce4ed"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413462832508/d4d38789-07d6-47fb-ad70-53fbe7ce447c-460x276.jpeg" alt="US Money nurses ebola " width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Four out of five nurses say their hospitals have yet to communicate with them about treating potential Ebola patients. </span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: National Nurses United</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>“The employers in these cases assume that individuals will make supreme sacrifices in the course of employment. And they do make significant sacrifices, but if it’s life or flight, many workers choose flight,” says Michael LeRoy, <a href="http://www.law.illinois.edu/faculty/profile/michaelleroy">a professor of labor and employment relations at the University of Illinois.</a></p> <p>This week, two US nurses were diagnosed with Ebola in Dallas after having been part of the 77-member team that took care of Thomas Eric Duncan, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-patient-dies-texas-thomas-eric-duncan">the first person in America to die in the recent Ebola outbreak</a>. <br /></p> <p>Officially, US leaders including President Barack Obama and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) chief Tom Frieden have gone to lengths to reassure the American public that their risk of contracting the disease is low. Obama said he “shook hands with, hugged and kissed” nurses working with Ebola patients at Emory University hospital in Atlanta. <br /></p> <p>Yet even Frieden appeared to concede the fears about Ebola are not entirely unfounded. “It’s scary and getting it right is really important because the stakes are so high,” Frieden <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-texas-healthcare-worker-virus">said at a press conference</a> about Nina Pham, the first nurse to contract the disease in the US.</p> <p>The law is thin on protecting people from workplace hazards having to do with infectious diseases. Workers’ rights are limited outside of demanding more training and better equipment. <br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="8871720027eab2e5581f7277b5c1d62d457e03a0"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413413107848/6f2139e0-8e23-4167-921e-2b1ce84370d5-460x307.jpeg" alt="US Money Obama Ebola " width="460" height="307" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Obama and Health and Human Services secretary Sylvia Burwell, speak to the media about Ebola.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Jacquelyn Martin/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The CDC has issued guidance that tells workers what their protections are, but it’s voluntary and not enforceable. <br /></p> <p>The Occupational Safety Health Act of 1970 – better known as OSHA – outlines employers’ responsibilities in maintaining a safe and healthy workplace, but Ebola is not something the law’s provisions on blood-borne pathogens could have predicted. <br /></p> <p>“We think of OSHA standards as the minimum wage of safety and health. Employers can do better if they want,” says Mark Catlin, occupational health and safety director for the Service Employees International Union, or SEIU. <br /></p> <p>The result: unions like the SEIU are stepping in to let workers who may be exposed to Ebola know their rights.<br /></p> <p>The California Nurse’s Association has held press conferences. The SEIU held a training session at a Clarion Hotel across the road from LaGuardia airport in New York. </p> <p>“[The training] wasn’t meant to replace the training that those employers of those airport workers need to do,” explains Catlin, SEIU’s occupational health and safety director. “It was done because we heard that the workers weren’t getting training or having knowledge about what was expected and what was in the CDC guidance that applied to their work and to them.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="f4bc2b471e7d755fe4aec572d1ea6e6f9e39133f"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413413409089/a46b3102-cc77-49b3-b0ed-36c8f4a8dfd1-460x307.jpeg" alt="US Money La Guardia ebola" width="460" height="307" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A protester holds up a sign during a one-day strike by airline cabin cleaners demanding more protection in the fight against Ebola.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Carlo Allegri/Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Power in Numbers</h2> <p>If conditions are bad enough, or the equipment inadequate enough, nurses could walk off the job – a tactic highly discouraged by unions but which remains within the realm of possibility. </p> <p>Workers who are members of the SEIU or the National Nurses Association can recruit these organizations to lobby with their employers on their behalf. What’s more, if workers walk off the job as a united front, instead of doing it as an individual act of protest, there is less likelihood of disciplinary action from their employers.</p> <p>“Workers in this country have a limited right to refuse dangerous work under federal OSHA. In certain circumstances, they aren’t supposed to outright refuse to work, they refuse to do the specific task that they deem to be dangerous,” explains Catlin. <br /></p> <p>“It’s not a very strong right. We urge workers to work through their union because a lot of time workers who refuse the dangerous work can lose their jobs and not get them back. “</p> <p>There are ways to get around this, says LeRoy, the Illinois University law professor. Rather than show up for work, employees who are afraid to come to work could call in sick and start using up their sick days.</p> <p>“It’s always an individual’s prerogative whether they are going to go to work,” says Katharine Parker, partner at the law firm <a href="http://www.proskauer.com/">Proskauer</a>, adding that some workers might be risking disciplinary action if they don’t show up or don’t give enough notices.</p> <p>“If the employer is not following what the CDC is saying, then the employee should raise that as a concern. Most employers will want to engage in a dialogue to address those concerns. Employers want to have a safe workplace, and so do employees.”</p> <p>Calling in sick to avoid work could also result in disciplinary action, or even termination. In some states, if a manager has a reasonable suspicion that the employee is not actually sick, they can ask him or her to produce a doctor’s note, says Parker.</p> <p>While nurses are fearful for their personal safety, they are also concerned with the safety of their communities and their patients, says Krahne. </p> <p>“There may be some nurses who don’t want to come to work, but overall – nurses, we take care of people,” she insists. “We go into situations where other people would never go and so the majority of us are going to be there for our patients.” <br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="b9df6cdbddfa1afde1b6440da06feb652b029ce0"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413480334281/292a45a3-c6ca-4c26-b691-7233ad99746e-460x328.jpeg" alt="Bentley" width="460" height="328" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Bentley, the one-year-old King Charles Spaniel belonging to Nina Pham, the nurse who contracted Ebola. </span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>The fear factor</h2> <p>Yet first responders also have families and fear for their safety. “The fear factor is the number-one employment-related matter that first responders don’t pay attention to,” says LeRoy. </p> <p> LeRoy points to simulation of a three-day smallpox attack in Oklahoma City just before 9/11 that found that 20% of of healthcare workers would fail to report to work due to a fear of contamination. <br /></p> <p>By discounting the fear factor in circumstances such as these, those in charge of planning often underestimate absenteeism that might occur if there is a wider outbreak.</p> <p>“Employers who have employees reasonably anticipated to come into contact with blood or pathogens have to document that they have solicited input from frontline workers in identifying, evaluating and implementing appropriate work practice controls,” says Parker.</p> <p>It is this dialogue between executives and workers that many workers say has been missing in the current handling of the situation. </p> <p>“Managers and supervisors need to listen better to front line responders. The front line responder is a subject matter expert and even if their science isn’t as good as the planners’, the fact of the matter is if they don’t feel comfortable doing their job, they are simply going to refuse doing their job,” says LeRoy. “It’s critical and it’s simple: there has to be bottom up listening instead of top down direction. It has to be a two way communication flow.”</p> <p>Specifically, the hospitals and employers should focus on the most elementary things like more masks, more training, more education and more upfront talking about work refusal. </p> <p>“Those hard talks never took place in those simulations and planners learned from that,” LeRoy says, adding quickly, “Or they claimed to. Whether that’s been put in practice or not, I don’t know.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-vaccine-peter-piot-west-africa-epidemic <p>The Ebola epidemic, which is out of control in three countries and directly threatening 15 others, may not end until the world has a vaccine against the disease, according to one of the scientists who discovered the virus.</p> <p>Professor Peter Piot, director of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said it would not have been difficult to contain the outbreak if those on the ground and the UN had acted promptly earlier this year. “Something that is easy to control got completely out of hand,” said Piot, who was part of a team that identified the causes of the first outbreak of Ebola in Zaire, now the Democratic Republic of Congo, in 1976 and helped bring it to an end.</p> <p>The scale of the epidemic in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea means that isolation, care and tracing and monitoring contacts, which have worked before, will not halt the spread. “It may be that we have to wait for a vaccine to stop the epidemic,” he said.</p> <p>On Thursday night, a Downing Street spokesman said a meeting of the government’s emergency response committee, Cobra, was told the chief medical officer still believed the risk to the UK remained low.</p> <p>“There was a discussion over the need for the international community to do much more to support the fight against the disease in the region,” the spokesman said. “This included greater coordination of the international effort, an increase in the amount of spending and more support for international workers who were, or who were considering, working in the region. The prime minister set out that he wanted to make progress on these issues at the European council next week.”</p> <p>Dr Tom Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), in evidence to Congress, said he was confident the outbreak would be checked in the US, but stressed the need to halt the raging west African epidemic.</p> <p>“There are no shortcuts in the control of Ebola and it is not easy to control it. To protect the United States we need to stop it at its source,” he said.</p> <p>“One of the things I fear about Ebola is that it could spread more widely in Africa. If this were to happen it could become a threat to our health system and the healthcare we give for a long time to come.”</p> <p>There are three vaccines now being fast-tracked through early safety trials in volunteers in the UK, the US and in unaffected Mali to ensure that they do no harm. The results should be available by the end of November or start of December. If they are acceptable, it is likely that healthcare workers – who are at highest risk of being infected and over 200 of whom have died – will be offered a vaccination before Christmas. But the only proof that any of them works will be if there is a significant drop in the number of deaths among vaccinated people on the front line.</p> <p>“If the epidemic is not going to be stopped in these three countries, it will definitely spread to adjacent countries such as Ivory Coast, Guinea Bissau and Mali,” said Piot.</p> <p>He was speaking at a seminar in Oxford as the World Health Organisation (WHO) warned that 15 countries, neighbouring or trading with those where the epidemic is raging, were at risk. They are Ivory Coast, Guinea Bissau, Mali, Senegal, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Gambia, Ghana, Mauritania, Nigeria, South Sudan and Togo. Nigeria and Senegal have both succeeded in halting an outbreak. Nonetheless, Dr Isabelle Nuttall of the WHO said all needed to be better prepared. “The objective is to stop the transmission from occurring in these countries. They may have a case but after one case we don’t want more cases,” she said at a briefing.</p> <p>By the end of the week, she predicted, the number of cases will have risen to over 9,000, with more than 4,500 deaths.</p> <p>“It could lead to major destabilisation of societies and also political destabilisation,” said Piot. “It is going to come at a very high cost. Some countries are very vulnerable. The economic impact is already enormous – just as Sars a decade ago only killed 700, but the economic impact was tens of billions of dollars.</p> <p>“My concern is that, as so often after a war or crisis, we say never again and then we forget about it.”</p> <p>Piot said he thought the prospects for an effective vaccine were good. The three candidates had shown good results in animal trials. Piot is chairing a WHO scientific committee on Ebola, looking at who to vaccinate and how and at what dose. He said he was optimistic, but the manufacturers would have to boost their production capacity and massive vaccination campaigns would have to be organised.</p> <p>In written testimony to the House of Representatives, however, Anthony Fauci, Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), was cautious about the progress being made on drugs and vaccines. “While NIAID is an active participant in the global effort to address the public health emergency occurring in west Africa, it is important to recognise that we are still in the early stages of understanding how infection with the Ebola virus can be treated and prevented,” he said.</p> <p>The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) warned that around 120,000 women could die in childbirth within the next year in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea because of the breakdown of healthcare and fears of contracting Ebola in hospital. It estimates that 800,000 women will give birth in the next 12 months, of whom 120,000 may suffer complications and need lifesaving emergency care.</p> <p>“The reality is that pregnant women are facing a double threat – dying from Ebola and from pregnancy or childbirth, due to the devastating impact of Ebola on health workers and health systems,” said UNFPA executive director, Dr Babatunde Osotimehin.</p> <p>• This article was amended on 17 October 2014 to change the word “with” to “without” in the caption.<br /></p>

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-nurse-transferred-texas-maryland-special-unit <p>One of two healthcare workers diagnosed with Ebola in the US is being transferred from the Texas facility where she contracted the virus to a special bio-containment unit in Maryland a day after her colleague was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta">taken to a similar facility in Atlanta</a>. </p> <p>Nina Pham, the first person to contract Ebola in the US, is expected to be transferred on Thursday from Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in Dallas to a National Institutes of Health (NIH) isolation unit in Bethesda, Maryland, the agency confirmed in a statement. </p> <p>“She will receive state-of-the-art care in this high-level containment facility, which is one of a small number of such facilities in the United States,” the NIH said. “The unit staff is trained in strict infection control practices optimized to prevent spread of potentially transmissible agents such as Ebola.” </p> <p>The NIH facility has one of four biocontainment units in the country.</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--supporting" data-media-id="9a16184bc9a0830b11d0b1e0392cb76366f3b9a5"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413481429172/c599d408-c3d0-4d0c-95e1-40561b415be0-bestSizeAvailable.png" alt="Map of biocontainment level 4 facilities in the US" width="460" height="457" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption"> </span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>“I’m so thankful for the outpouring of love and support from friends and family, my coworkers and complete strangers,” Pham said in a statement released by the hospital.</p> <p>“I feel very blessed, and have gained strength from their support. We’re going to have to call you back,’” she said.</p> <p>Aguirre’s interview aired hours after the hospital hit back at <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/dallas-nurses-accuse-hospital-sloppy-safety-ebola">similar allegations made by National Nurses United</a>, the country’s largest nurses’ union. The hospital categorically rejected most of the claims the union made, apparently on behalf of anonymous healthcare workers at Texas Health Presbyterian, about the hospital not protecting its staff after Duncan was diagnosed, saying it was always in step with CDC protocol. </p>
http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2014/oct/16/ebola-crisis-a-heroic-chris-brown-shares-his-views-with-the-world <p>Lost in Showbiz likes to think of itself as a paragon of modesty and shy understatement. It would never seek to self-aggrandise by claiming that it exerts a vast influence over the world of celebrity, that the famous hang on its every word, looking to it for guidance much as they would a guru or oracle, regarding its pronouncements as wisdom, spun from the purest gold, there to be acted upon with alacrity.</p> <p>But sometimes, it does wonder. Last week, Lost in Showbiz found itself forced to berate the world’s celebrities for their woefully inadequate response to the Ebola outbreak. It noted sorrowfully that, to date, hardly anyone from the glittering showbiz firmament had done or said anything idiotic. Apparently forgetting themselves – and the vital role they’re supposed to play in any crisis – they had chosen to make a sober black and white fundraising video. No word, alas, as to whether he meant that it was the judgment of God upon an over-populated world or a crisis engineered by shadowy operatives of The Man – just the suggestion that “shit is getting crazy” – but let’s not pick nits here. Let us instead offer profound thanks that at least one celebrity has started doing their job properly, and hope that others follow his lead and buck their ideas up.</p> <p>Indeed, the only drawback to the situation was that, 9,500 retweets later, Brown suggested he was going to “shut up”. Lost in Showbiz can only clasp its head in its hands. No, Chris Brown! Don’t shut up! At the moment, you’re our only hope! Indeed, at risk of abusing its position as your guru or oracle – its pronouncements of purest spun gold to be acted upon with alacrity – Lost in Showbiz commands you to say more stupid things! Have you any thoughts on the advance of Islamic State?</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/16/ebola-congress-hearing-cdc-director <p>The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has warned that Ebola is like a “forest fire” that can reignite at any point if all embers are not extinguished, as politicians in Washington prepared to criticise initial mistakes made in responding to its spread in the US.<br /></p> <p>In <a href="http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF02/20141016/102718/HHRG-113-IF02-Wstate-FriedenT-20141016.pdf">prepared testimony</a> ahead of a hearing of a House of Representatives oversight committee, Thomas Frieden pointed to the temporary re-emergence of the disease in Nigeria as a sign of what happens if contact tracing protocols are not fully followed.</p> <p>“It will take meticulous work and we cannot take short cuts,” he said. “It’s like fighting a forest fire: leave behind one burning ember, one case undetected, and the epidemic could reignite.”<br /></p> <p>“In response to the case in Nigeria, 10 CDC staff and 40 top CDC-trained Nigerian epidemiologists rapidly deployed, identified, and followed 1,000 contacts for 21 days,” added Frieden. “Even with these resources, one case was missed, which resulted in a new cluster of cases in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. However, due to the meticulous work done in Nigeria, no new cases have been identified, and the outbreak appears to have been extinguished there.”</p> <p>The danger of mistakes is expected to be underlined by the congressmen on the House commerce committee, whose oversight branch is holding the first hearings on the US response on Thursday.</p> <p>“We cannot afford to look back and say we could have done more,” said the full committee chairman, Fred Upton, in<a href="http://energycommerce.house.gov/press-release/committee-continues-oversight-ebola-outbreak#sthash.rz25NWcd.dpuf"> a statement ahead of the hearing</a>. “The Ebola outbreak is a global public health issue that demands an all-hands-on-deck response.</p> <p>Other witnesses included Daniel Varga, the chief clinical officer at the Dallas hospital that first treated cases in the US, whose remote testimony included an apology for its handling of the incident.</p> <p><a href="http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF02/20141016/102718/HHRG-113-IF02-Wstate-VargaD-20141016.pdf">In pre-submitted evidence</a>, he revealed how the temperature of the first patient Eric Duncan had spiked to 103F during his first visit to the emergency department, yet he was still sent home.</p> <p>Other <a href="http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF02/20141016/102718/HHRG-113-IF02-Wstate-FauciA-20141016.pdf">witness testimony </a>submitted by the National Institutes of Health described the lengths that drug companies were now going to in order to find a cure or vaccine for Ebola, but Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) warned that they were still some distance from producing sufficient quantities for widespread trials.</p> <p>“While NIAID is an active participant in the global effort to address the public health emergency occurring in west Africa, it is important to recognise that we are still in the early stages of understanding how infection with the Ebola virus can be treated and prevented,” he said.</p> <p>“As we continue to expedite research while enforcing high safety and efficacy standards, the implementation of the public health measures already known to contain prior Ebola virus outbreaks and the implementation of treatment strategies such as fluid and electrolyte replacement are essential to preventing additional infections, treating those already infected, protecting healthcare providers, and ultimately bringing this epidemic to an end.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/16/ebola-text-messaging-combat-outbreak <p>Text messaging is playing a vital role in Sierra Leone’s fight against Ebola as more people use their mobile phones to send information about food security to aid agencies and to receive free public health alerts.</p> <p>The Word Food Programme (WFP) last month started <a href="http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/WFP%20mVAM%20Special%20Ebola%20Bulletin%20%231%20-%20Sierra%20Leone,%20September%202014.pdf" title="">a new drive to reach Sierra Leoneans by text message</a> in an effort to source information about household food security. Ebola is ravaging rural economies, agricultural activities and markets in west Africa and straining food supplies, <a href="http://www.fao.org/emergencies/fao-in-action/stories/stories-detail/en/c/253935/" title="">according to the Food and Agricultural Organisation</a>.</p> <p>More than 850 people have responded to a survey about food supplies in Sierra Leone, the WFP revealed. The survey quizzed people on the prices they are paying for food and livestock as well as their strategies for coping with stretched food supplies. “Over 80% of respondents in the east report consuming less expensive food, while three quarters report reducing the number of meals and limiting portion sizes,” the WFP said.</p> <p>Jean-Martin Bauer, a food security analyst at the WFP, said: “This is a good source to get a quick update on information, but of course there’s a lot more going on than just mobile services in terms of food security assessments in those three countries.</p> <p>“We are doing these surveys in Guinea and Liberia as well. Our idea is not to do a one-off; this is a system that we’re setting up. We know that Ebola is a dynamic phenomenon and it’s changed a lot in the past few months and we need to be able to track its impact on household food security.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-7805c68a-b163-43c6-9596-57e38c96382b"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413473499927/111dab59-263f-493b-8831-3208e680cbea-460x276.jpeg" alt="BBC information service" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">The BBC is utilising a range of mediums to convey information about Ebola to people in countries affected by the virus.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: PR</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Bauer said that monthly rounds of mobile-phone surveys about food security are planned in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. “As Ebola changes, we need to be able to have an update so that we can adjust our response,” he said.</p> <p>But the WFP cautioned that SMS surveys do not reach everyone in Sierra Leone, which in 2012 had a <a href="http://www.gsma.com/publicpolicy/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/SSA_FullReport_v6.1_clean.pdf" title="">mobile penetration rate of only 48%</a> (pdf), according to the GSM Association.</p> <p><a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-29573964" title="">On Thursday, the BBC started sending text alerts</a>, short audio clips and low-resolution photos to people threatened by Ebola. The material was delivered through WhatsApp, a free text-messaging service.</p> <p>The BBC said that, within four hours of launching the service, more than 1,000 people had signed up for its Ebola alerts, which are available in English and French.</p> <p>Peter Horrocks, director of the BBC’s World Service, said: “The BBC is trusted by millions of people in the affected countries, so we are stepping up our efforts to reach people with timely information, whether they’re listening to the radio, watching TV or using chat apps. We’re committed to playing our part and will continue looking at new ways to reach audiences, for example by developing programmes in local vernacular languages.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/16/morocco-africa-cup-of-nations-ebola-withdraw <p>The venue for next year’s Africa Cup of Nations finals is in major doubt after the proposed hosts, Morocco, reiterated its fears over the Ebola outbreak on the continent.</p> <p>The Confederation of African Football (Caf) received a letter from the Moroccan government last week asking for the tournament to be called off and had <a href="http://www.cafonline.com/en-US/NewsCenter/News/NewsDetails?id=D1lozWSZ8RJEFgm6iR31DA%3D%3D" title="">agreed to discuss the plans</a> at the next executive committee meeting on 2 November. But given the current Ebola situation we don’t think such a feast can take place as expected.</p> <p>“We are talking about the Africa Cup of Nations where we are expecting between 200,000 and 400,000, even one million spectators to converge in Morocco. I don’t think there is any state or any country that has the necessary capabilities to monitor, check and control the current Ebola situation when faced with these numbers.</p> <p>“This is our real problem. We don’t have a problem with visiting teams, we have a problem with visitors.”</p> <p>Ouzzine added: “If there are fears about the loss of funding and financial commitments, we can always find solutions to these issues – but today is not the day to discuss these things.</p> <p>“We will discuss these things when we meet with Caf – and we might even debate other options. But I beg you, what’s the significance of the financial losses compared to human losses? A human being is priceless. I can tell you that we will reach a definite decision during our meeting with our brothers from Caf.”</p> <p>The 2013 hosts South Africa are now tipped to take over after reports that the country’s Football Association was already in negotiations with Caf, although Sudan and Egypt have also expressed an interest in hosting the tournament.</p> <p>Ghana’s sports minister, Mahama Ayariga, confirmed they are also considering a request from Caf to take over hosting duties.</p> <p>“The Confederation of African Football has officially asked Ghana to consider hosting the 2015 African Cup of Nations if Morocco drops its bid to host the tournament. http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/16/west-ebola-response-black-patient <p>Thomas Eric Duncan, the first person to die of Ebola in the United States, was not the right kind of victim for the west: he wasn’t <a href="http://www.drudgereportarchives.com/data/2014/10/14/20141014_140931.htm">a pretty young woman smiling in sunglasses</a> as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/texas-ebola-nurse-dog">a Cavalier King Charles spaniel named Bentley</a> licks her cheek; he didn’t have a young, <a href="http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/health/Ebola-Patient-Dr-Kent-Brantly-to-Leave-Hospital-Thursday-272102161.html">benevolent doctor’s face</a> that looks “appropriate” <a href="https://twitter.com/sierra_n_salone/status/502795675428347904">plastered on newspapers</a>; he wasn’t a kindly older nurse who told reporters how <a href="http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ebola-survivor-nancy-writebol-recovery-20140903-story.html">God had spared her</a>. He wasn’t the kind of person to whom primetime news specials would dedicate 20 minutes and glorify with quotes from loved ones about his kind spirit or ceaseless determination to overcome an unfair affliction.<br /><br />Thomas Eric Duncan was black, he was poor, and he was African.<br /><br />A Dallas hospital turned away the <a href="http://time.com/3502174/ebola-thomas-eric-duncan-liberian-bodies-treatment/">uninsured Liberian immigrant</a> after an initial exam concluded he suffered only from a “<a href="http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/10/01/353029054/hospital-official-ebola-patients-travel-not-relayed-to-doctors">low-grade viral disease</a>”, and the media turned him into the unsympathetic, undeserving face of a contagion with which the west is frantically grappling.</p> <p>He – and the West Africans to whom he is tied by both birth and cause of death – have become nothing more than disease vectors responsible for infecting innocent <a href="http://www.vox.com/2014/10/15/6981157/a-second-health-worker-in-dallas-tests-positive-for-ebola">western health workers</a>, tarnishing pristine nations by importing the blemish of an African scourge. And yet, American citizenship alone does not sanitize the blight of blackness; Amber Joy Vinson, the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta">second healthcare worker diagnosed with the virus</a>, is already being met with <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/ebola-virus-outbreak/dallas-ebola-nurse-amber-vinson-should-not-have-traveled-cdc-n226551">scrutiny</a> as Nina Pham’s quarantined dog receives an <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/dallas-officials-vow-to-care-for-ebola-patient-nina-phams-dog/">outpouring of support</a>.</p> <p>Ebola now functions in popular discourse as a not-so-subtle, almost completely rhetorical stand-in for any combination of “African-ness”, “blackness”, “foreign-ness” and “infestation” – a <a href="http://www.who.int/csr/disease/ebola/faq-ebola/en/">nebulous but powerful threat</a>, poised to ruin the perceived purity of western borders and bodies. Dead African bodies are the nameless placeholders for (<a href="http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/15/health/ebola-fears/index.html">unwarranted</a>, <a href="http://jezebel.com/from-miasma-to-ebola-the-history-of-racist-moral-panic-1645711030">racist</a>) “<a href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/10/15/parents-ebola-panic-is-taking-over-my-clinic.html">panic</a>”, a conversation topic too heavy for the dinner table yet light enough for supermarket aisles.</p> <p>To date, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/07/31/world/africa/ebola-virus-outbreak-qa.html#outside-africa">fewer than 20 cases of Ebola have been treated outside West Africa</a> in the current outbreak. Meanwhile, in West Africa itself – mostly in Sierra Leone, Guinea, Liberia, and Nigeria – the death toll has <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-29615452">risen to nearly 4,500</a>. Girls and women in the region, tasked with the <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/2014/08/14/3e08d0c8-2312-11e4-8593-da634b334390_story.html">gendered social responsibility of caring for sick family members</a>, are dying at a rate that eclipses their male counterparts. Liberia is <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/mojo/2014/10/liberia-ebola-going-need-lot-more-bodybags">perilously under-resourced</a> to deal with the outbreak, and the United States has perhaps ominously committed only <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2014/09/us-military-liberia-fight-ebola">military personnel</a> there. “If this epidemic of Ebola rages out of control in West Africa,” <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/obama-ebola-international-threat-european-leaders">Barack Obama said on Wednesday evening</a>, “it will spread in an age of frequent travel and the kind of constant interactions that people have across borders.”</p> <p>But we will still write off the <a href="https://twitter.com/AP/status/519192473529516032">“Africa patient”</a> who infected a hospital in Spain and not bother with silly things like geographic specificity. We will breathe a sigh of relief when we remember that the <a href="http://online.wsj.com/articles/missionary-doctor-infected-with-ebola-dies-in-madrid-1407835487">Spanish priest infected in Liberia</a> was afforded access to an <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/14/health/ebola-vaccine-drugs-faq/">experimental drug</a> though West Africans were not; after he died, we wondered aloud whether Africans even deserve Christianity.</p> <p>We will <a href="https://twitter.com/dabeard/status/517790857869537280">tweet</a> about how much more terrifying Ebola is than <a href="https://twitter.com/janinegibson/status/519957204573904897">black-eyed ghost children</a>. We will make sure to specify that <a href="http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-ebola-cases-20141010-story.html">alcohol, not Ebola</a>, killed a British man in Macedonia. We will suggest that Ebola is so common among West Africans – even the ones who make it to New York City – that it might as well be <a href="http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2014/10/nigerian_independence_day_parade_2014_cloudy_with_a_chance_of_ebola.php">part of the weather forecast</a>. We will not mention that <a href="http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/4769ca32-52c4-11e4-a236-00144feab7de.html#axzz3GE6x5kE6">Nigeria hasn’t had a live case in six weeks</a>.</p> <p>We will try to hide our fear behind jokes with dying black bodies as their punchlines. We will “<a href="https://twitter.com/DRUDGE/status/522350000106635264">self-quarantine</a>”. We will dedicate <a href="http://www.reddit.com/r/Jokes/comments/2ig1pw/good_jokes_about_ebola_will_most_likely_go_viral/">Reddit threads</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/EbolaJokesDaily">Twitter accounts</a> to our Ebola “jokes”. We will giggle at our <a href="http://knowyourmeme.com/memes/events/2014-ebola-outbreak">Ebola memes</a>. We will suggest that perhaps Ebola is really just the <a href="http://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/what-is-ebola">Isis of biological agents</a>.</p> <p>And when this is all over, we will move on and find a new reason to weaponize black suffering to account for our unshakeable fear. There will always be a new emergency, a new threat, a new reason that <a href="http://www.blackcommentator.com/54/54_guest_immigrants_pf.html">black bodies cannot be allowed to infiltrate the borders</a> of nations that our blood and sweat have built. Black death is remarkable only to the extent that its perpetrator could also affect citizens more deserving of sympathy, of news coverage and of life.</p> <p>We are comfortable with viruses that ravage entire communities, so long as <a href="http://mic.com/articles/100618/one-powerful-illustration-shows-exactly-what-s-wrong-with-media-coverage-of-ebola">those communities do not look like the ones we believe are deserving of health</a>. Black bodies exist only on the receiving end of apocalyptic fanfare like airport screenings designed to weed out Ebola carriers (with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/ebola-screenings-heathrow-airport-mixed-response">dubious success</a>) or <a href="http://www.propublica.org/article/deadly-force-in-black-and-white">excessive, deadly force from police</a> that claim to protect and serve all people. Africa exists only in <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2014/08/25/othering-ebola-and-the-history-and-politics-of-pointing-at-immigrants-as-potential-disease-vectors/">stark contrast</a> to the civilized west, where disease and disorder must be contained to preserve health and hierarchy.</p> <p>To be black – African or otherwise – is to be born into a world that anticipates your death with bated breath (or <a href="http://www.truth-out.org/news/item/26797-the-death-penalty-missouri-and-the-continued-devaluing-of-black-life">botched execution</a> cocktail, or <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2014/10/to-raise-love-and-lose-a-black-child/381189/">vigilante bullet</a>, or <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/tuskegee/timeline.htm">syphilis needle</a>). It is to occupy a position of <a href="http://www.yorku.ca/intent/issue5/articles/jaredsexton.php">social death</a>, to exist in a liminal space that guarantees neither rights nor recognition under the law. It is to be a perpetual contaminant in the body of the western world.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta <p>The second nurse diagnosed with Ebola in Texas was transferred from Dallas to a special bio-containment unit in Atlanta, officials announced on Wednesday, as they acknowledged failings in the response to the arrival of the virus in the US.</p> <p>The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also said that the 29-year-old nurse, Amber Vinson, flew on a commercial flight from Cleveland, Ohio to Dallas with a low-grade temperature a day before she was diagnosed. While in Ohio, she also reportedly travelled from Cleveland to Akron. </p> <p>Concerns about the US response to the crisis intensified on Wednesday night when it was reported that Vinson told the CDC that she had a slight fever before she boarded the flight but was not told to stay put. </p> <p>Citing a federal source, CNN reported that the nurse said she had a temperature of 99.5F (37.5C) before boarding the flight on 13 October. But since that was below the CDC’s temperature threshold of 100.4F, “she was not told not to fly”. </p> <p>Vinson is the second healthcare worker to have contracted Ebola at Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/dallas">Dallas</a>, which treated <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/thomas-eric-duncan-liberia-ebola-war-texas-family-obituary">Thomas Eric Duncan</a>, a Liberian who was the first patient in the US to be diagnosed with Ebola. Another nurse, 26-year-old Nina Pham, was diagnosed at the weekend. Both had cared for Duncan, who died in an isolation ward on 8 October.</p> <p>Vinson was transferred to Emory University Hospital in Atlanta by air ambulance on Wednesday night and will be treated in a special isolation unit. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="7dc39241aebbc23506664eb046436703de75b244"> <img who were aboard Vinson’s return flight to Dallas - Frontier Airlines flight 1143 from Cleveland, Ohio. But Frieden said he believed the risk to passengers was low because Vinson’s symptoms did not present themselves until the following day.</p> <p>The US secretary of health and human services, Sylvia Burwell, said that Vinson will be transported to Emory University hospital in Atlanta, which has successfully treated two Ebola patients and is caring for a third, an unidentified American doctor who contracted the disease while working in west Africa.</p> <p>Before Duncan’s diagnosis, all Ebola patients in the US were treated in special bio-containment units in Atlanta and Omaha.</p> <p>President Barack Obama was briefed by the relevant members of his cabinet about the country’s Ebola response on Wednesday afternoon. He cancelled visits to Rhode Island and New York planned for Thursday in order to concentrate on the Ebola outbreak.</p> <p>“I am absolutely confident that we can prevent a serious outbreak of the disease here in the United States, but it becomes more difficult to do so if this epidemic of Ebola rages out of control in West Africa,” <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/obama-ebola-international-threat-european-leaders">he told reporters.</a></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-8b610dee-6208-45ef-9391-4240e0771949"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/16/1413437302073/a2147824-3a08-4a1b-9a74-d3aa368c1234-460x276.jpeg" alt="Ebola in Texas" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Members of Dallas Fire-Rescue Haz Mat Unit prepare to decontaminate common areas near the apartment of a second healthcare worker who has tested positive for Ebola.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Sana Syed/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Texas governor Rick Perry, who is cutting short a trip to Europe to deal with the unfolding situation in Dallas, said in a statement on Wednesday: “This is the first time that our nation has had to deal with a threat such as this. Everyone working on this challenge - from the medical professionals at the bedside to the public health officials addressing containment of the infection - is working to end the threat posed by this disease.”<br /></p> <p>According to Frieden, the two nurses who contracted Ebola in Dallas had “extensive” contact with Duncan in the days before he was diagnosed, when he was extremely ill, excreting large quantities of highly contagious body fluids. <br /></p> <p>“Our investigation increasingly suggests that the first several days before the patient was diagnosed appear to be the highest-risk period,” Frieden said.</p> <p>Information from medical records suggested that the team of healthcare workers who treated Duncan had exposed skin while working in the quarantine unit during the three-day window between when he was admitted and when he was diagnosed.<br /></p> <p>“Were protocols breached? The nurses say there were no protocols,” said National Nurses United co-president Deborah Burger in a call with reporters Wednesday.</p> <p>Burger said nurses who work at Texas Health Presbyterian reported that Duncan was not immediately placed in isolation upon his arrival at the hospital on 28 September. They said Duncan, who at that point was very ill, was left for several hours in an area where other patients were present. </p> <p>Burger also said the union was told the nurses who initially treated Duncan wore only generic gowns, three pairs of gloves and surgical masks, and were not given surgical booties. They had the option to wear a full-face mask, but one was not initially required.</p> <p>The nurses said they were eventually given better gowns, but the garments still exposed their necks, part of their heads and their scrubs from the knees down. To protect the exposed parts of their body, the nurses said, they were instructed to wrap medical tape around their necks. It is not clear what healthcare workers treating patients suspected or confirmed to have Ebola in Dallas are currently required to wear.</p> <p>In a letter addressed to Obama, the union asked him to take executive action to keep nurses and all healthcare workers safe. They’re asking that every healthcare worker be required to wear a Hazmat suit when treating an Ebola patient, and for hospitals where they are being treated to be compelled to meet the same standards of care as the nation’s special bio-containment centers. </p> <p>The 77 healthcare workers who worked in the quarantine room with Duncan or handled samples of his blood were initially instructed to monitor themselves for symptoms, Frieden said. After Pham was diagnosed, the healthcare workers were placed under more aggressive monitoring, which requires a twice daily temperature check by a public health official. At that point, Vinson had already left Texas and traveled to Ohio. </p> <p>Frieden said three people who may have made direct contact with Vinson have been identified and are being actively monitored. Officials are also monitoring one person who may have made direct contact with Pham, as well as her dog.<br /></p> <p>Pham was in “improved condition” Wednesday, according to Frieden, while Vinson was “ill but clinically stable”.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/obama-ebola-international-threat-european-leaders <p>Barack Obama has warned of Ebola spreading globally if more is not done to stop the epidemic raging out of control in west Africa, as he urged the US public not to lose sight of the importance of focusing on tackling the disease at its source.</p> <p>As pressure grows on the White House to explain failures to prevent <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta">a second case of transmission</a> within the US, the president announced a “rapid response Swat team” from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) would aim to respond to any further infections within 24 hours “to take local hospitals step by step through what needs to be done”.</p> <p>The president also cancelled a trip to Rhode Island and New York on Thursday to focus on his administration’s response to domestic cases of Ebola, the White House said late on Wednesday. </p> <p>“I am absolutely confident that we can prevent a serious outbreak of the disease here in the United States, but it becomes more difficult to do so if this epidemic of Ebola rages out of control in west Africa. If it does, then it will spread globally in an age of frequent travel and the kind of constant interactions that people have across borders,” he told reporters after an emergency two-hour meeting of his cabinet.<br /></p> <p>The administration is under growing political pressure over its handling of the crisis after the CDC admitted “shortcomings” in its initial response to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition">first confirmed US case in Dallas</a>, admitting it should have done more to ensure the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/dallas-nurses-accuse-hospital-sloppy-safety-ebola">hospital was following infection-control protocols</a>. An infection of a second health worker was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta">confirmed</a> on Wednesday.<br /></p> <p>On Wednesday, Obama stressed that though protecting healthcare workers was a top priority, the risks of transmission should not be overstated:<br /></p> <p> “I want to use myself as an example so people have a sense of the science here. I shook hands with, hugged and kissed – not the doctors – but a couple of the nurses at Emory because of the valiant work that they did in treating one of the patients. They followed the protocols, they knew what they were doing and I felt perfectly safe doing so. This is not a situation like the flu where the risks of a rapid spread of the disease are imminent.”</p> <p>Earlier, the president declared Ebola a “threat to international security” in a video conference with European leaders.<br /></p> <p>Speaking with leaders in the UK, France, Germany and Italy shortly after the case was confirmed on Wednesday, the US president said they all urgently needed to marshal extra finances and personnel to “bend the curve of the epidemic” in west Africa.<br /></p> <p>But the White House rejected growing calls for greater restrictions on passengers travelling from the region, insisting travel bans were “not on the table” at present and would prove counter-productive by hampering local aid efforts.<br /></p> <p>The House speaker, John Boehner, <a href="http://www.speaker.gov/press-release/boehner-travel-ban-should-be-considered-president-ebola-crisis-worsens">urged the president </a>to review that policy on Wednesday. “A temporary ban on travel to the United States from countries afflicted with the virus is something that the president should absolutely consider along with any other appropriate actions as doubts about the security of our air travel systems grow,” he said.</p> <p>The White House spokesman, Josh Earnest, resisted calls for a single “Ebola czar” to be placed in charge of the federal response on Wednesday, claiming “people should be encouraged that the government is demonstrating a tenacious adaptive response [to Ebola]” among a range of federal agencies.<br /></p> <p>“We have designated very clear lines of responsibility in terms of which agencies are responsible for which aspects of this response,” he added.</p> <p>Nonetheless, political criticism is expected to grow on Thursday when a committee of the House of Representatives convenes the first public hearing into recent developments.</p> <p>Republican Tim Murphy, chairman of the oversight and investigations subcommittee, said “so far traveller self-reported screening procedures and hospital infection control measures have been demonstrated failures” in a statement issued ahead of Thursday’s testimony from the CDC director, Tom Frieden.</p> <p>White House officials acknowledge failures in the initial response and said a “very concerned” Obama had cancelled travel plans and convened an urgent meeting with cabinet members on Wednesday to make sure federal agencies were properly coordinated.</p> <p>“It is unacceptable that even one healthcare worker was exposed to this virus while they were providing medical treatment to this patient. So that is an indication that there were shortcomings,” Earnest told reporters in a White House press briefing dominated by the crisis.</p> <p>However, he rejected suggestions that the multiple transmissions among health workers in Dallas constituted an “outbreak” of the disease, insisting that the risk of the disease spreading in the general public in the US remained “extremely unlikely”.</p> <p>In Texas, officials were preparing to transfer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-nurse-transferred-atlanta">the second nurse diagnosed with Ebola</a> to a special bio-containment unit in Atlanta, hours after it was revealed that she had travelled on a commercial flight to Ohio with a low-grade temperature before she was diagnosed. </p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates <div id="block-543eeefbe4b0cd82a095f869" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T23:17:36.205+01:00">11.17pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>We’re going to wrap our coverage of the Ebola cases in the US, Africa and Europe today with a summary of the major developments.</p> <ul> <li><strong>President Barack Obama said <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543eec3ee4b0ebfb2a1bf2e1">the US must respond much more aggressively</a> </strong>to prepare at home and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543eec3ee4b0ebfb2a1bf2e1">confront the outbreak abroad</a>. At least 69 people, including eight health workers, are believed to have been infected, and 49 have died.</p> <p>Health experts think the initial cases in each outbreak got it from eating or handling Ebola-infected animals, then spread it person-to-person. The exact source in nature has not been proved but the leading suspect is a certain type of fruit bat.</p> <p>The virus is different from the Zaire strain causing the larger epidemic in West Africa, suggesting that a separate source in nature seeded each outbreak.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543eeccae4b01d51bd0b048d" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:54:17.350+01:00">10.54pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>“The bottom line to the American public is that the dangers of contracting Ebola … is very low. in the United States, then we could have future problems.”</p> <p>“In the meantime I want everyone thinking about and praying about the [workers] who have gotten sick … we are going to be doing
