datetime="2014-10-15T22:22:55.210+01:00">at 10.22pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543edd89e4b0cd82a095f84b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:15:00.929+01:00">10.15pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>A bit of brighter news about the dog of Nina Pham, an Ebola patient in Dallas. The pup is “looking good and happy” at a decommissioned naval air base while his owner is treated, city officials say.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-f9bb5978-e493-462a-a4a7-5542be411bea"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413406153511/0366bbbd-6814-4bbc-ba7d-b3dc7831a090-460x276.jpeg" alt="ebola dog dallas" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Bentley the dog being transported in Dallas.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: HANDOUT/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Bentley has been given comfortable bedding, toys and room to run around at the former residence of the executive officer at the decommissioned Hensley Field, city spokeswoman Sana Syed said.</p> <p>The dog, like humans who may have come into contact with Pham, will be monitored for 21 days, and officials have so far shown no will to follow the path of Spanish authorities, who euthanized a dog belonging to a nursing assistant with Ebola. Authorities, a decision that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/09/excalibur-ebola-dog-conspiracy-theories"> caused an uproar</a>.</p> <p>The CDC says there have been no reports of pets spreading Ebola to people or other animals.</p> <p>My colleagues have gathered<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/texas-ebola-nurse-dog"> more details about Bentley here.</a></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:27:41.438+01:00">at 10.27pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543edb32e4b0ebfb2a1bf2cc" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:03:28.086+01:00">10.03pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Accounts from west Africa tell of fear, panic and hunger, as men and women in Sierra Leone send their stories <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41">sent to the Guardian</a>.</p> <p><a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41/1196042">John F Sillah</a> tells of the last unaffected region in Sierra Leone: “Two suspected Ebola cases have been reported in Fagoya, a village in the Nieni chiefdom of the Koinadugu District. This village allegedly became affected through a man who had travelled there from Kono. Many people in Kabala are now very worried. The District was the only previously unaffected region in Sierra Leone.”</p> <p>Hunger and poverty are compounding the pressures of Ebola, according to <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41/1195563">Moses Kortu</a>, who says “Ebola has destroyed the community.”</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>In this part of the country, students are not able to listen to the radio; most of them don’t own radios. This is farming time, parents are looking for food- how will they tell their children to listen when there is no food at home. Generally, children in this community are not benefiting from lessons via the radio.</p> <p>The issue of hunger is still a real concern in Koindu; there is no food at home. Banks are only open Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 9am-1pm which is causing problems – people need their money. Ebola has destroyed the community.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="2d900300e5447da947434f9fb6b3be41edb93557"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413406061477/f0d987ba-7d7f-43cb-8d39-5d38cae28375-460x276.jpeg" alt="Two children recovering from Ebola virus wait at a treatment centre in the Hastings area of Freetown, Sierra Leone." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Two children recovering from Ebola virus wait at a treatment centre in the Hastings area of Freetown, Sierra Leone.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Michael Duff/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41/1195868">Mariama Jalloh </a> describes “panic in Koinadugu”, Sierra Leone: “There is panic in Koinadugu right now due to two persons suspected of Ebola. They are from Nieni chiefdom but according to the information I have gathered, these two people came from Kono … and now the district has decided that no one should travel in and out of the Nieni chiefdom until the results come out.”</p> <p>If you have a story to share you can <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41">send it to Guardian Witness here</a>.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ed29ee4b0cd82a095f832" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T21:45:13.459+01:00">9.45pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>A British nurse who survived Ebola is heading back to Sierra Leone to rejoin the frontline of health workers,</strong> my colleague Lisa O’Carroll (<a href="https://twitter.com/lisaocarroll">@lisaocarroll</a>) reports.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Will Pooley confirmed his plans as he spoke to potential volunteers at the department of health on Wednesday. “There is still a lot of work to do out there and I am in the same or better position than when I chose to go out before,” he said.</p> <p>“It does not seem likely that I will contract it again but it will still be the same question in my mind as it was the first times. It was an easy decision at that time and it is the same now.</p> <p>Of his friends and family who have already seen the trauma he went through after contracting the illness, he said: “They are always going to be worried. They are very supportive.</p> <p>“I know my mum and dad are worried but they support me because they know this is something I have to do. My potential immunity is very reassuring for them, or at least it should be, and I will be returning in a more organised fashion than when I was out there originally.”</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-490920aa-b04d-43f7-b618-58d24349602a"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413405000178/01385ba7-2471-45ef-9160-bb04a7a09bf3-460x276.jpeg" alt="British Ebola survivor and nurse Will Pooley." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">British Ebola survivor and nurse Will Pooley.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: WILL OLIVER / POOL/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Pooley said he has made a “100% recovery”. “My exposure, as with everyone’s exposure, was an accident. It is something that everyone will be thinking about – all the volunteers who are here tonight but it is about vigilance really and being cautious. You must never let any complacency creep in.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:25:47.547+01:00">at 10.25pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ebb39e4b03829d13c2037" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T21:26:26.029+01:00">9.26pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>An ambitious plan to contain and push back the epidemic in west Africa in two months</strong> is guiding UN policy, explains the Guardian’s health editor Sarah Boseley (<a href="https://twitter.com/sarahboseley">@sarahboseley</a>).</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The 70/70/60 plan aims to isolate, treat and care for 70% of Ebola patients and safely bury 70% of the dead within 60 days. At a briefing on Tuesday, Dr Bruce Aylward, WHO Assistant Director-General, said that by the start of December, they expected up to 10,000 cases a week, a tenfold increase. If they could meet the targets, he said, they might be able to “bend the curve” and try to get the numbers to fall.</p> <p>“I worry that we risk making their challenge worse. We are not at common purpose, and we must get to common purpose very, very quickly,” he said.</p> <p>“There is no question the strategies work. The question is how much carnage and human misery there will be between now and then, and that depends on if we get to common purpose - 70/70/60.”</p> </blockquote> <p>The WHO also committed to getting 600 people in 45 districts across the three countries in 60 days “to find the cases, ensure the programmes are safe, and ensure we have the evidence we need to get this finished.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="874dc569e16611a7cea61bb3e52b5f7b23e872bc"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413405186595/41d4b6a0-228b-4f63-8e34-eb4bc33c7ca4-460x276.jpeg" alt="Red Cross members workers each other before in Monrovia, Liberia. ebola" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Red Cross members workers each other before in Monrovia, Liberia.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Anadolu Agency/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Sarah also reports that health officials called for substantial and immediate financial help. Dr David Nabarro, the UN Secretary General’s special envoy on Ebola, said: “This is in a moment where there must be no postponement of financing decisions and no postponement of action because we haven’t agreed on things. As everybody has said so far, the time is the key variable.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:24:46.842+01:00">at 10.24pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ed515e4b01d51bd0b046a" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T21:20:23.466+01:00">9.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>An American being treated for Ebola at Emory says he is recovering,</strong> Reuters reports.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The patient, who has not been identified, was working in Sierra Leone when he tested positive for the disease and was evacuated to the United States on a private chartered flight. <br /></p> <p>“I want to share the news that I am recovering from this disease, and that I anticipate being discharged very soon, free from the Ebola virus and able to return safely to my family and to my community,” the patient said. </p> <p>“I want the public to know that although Ebola is a serious, complex disease, it is possible to recover and return to a healthy life,” the patient said. </p> </blockquote> <p>The patient, being treated since 9 September, has said he wants to keep his identity secret for now.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-42a71ded-aaa6-4c2c-ada2-25f0d80604b1"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413404121893/7954b7d9-ee04-4fac-9e6a-19254a20e51f-460x276.jpeg" alt="emory university ebola" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">An isolation unit at Emory University in Atlanta.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: HANDOUT/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ea69be4b0ebfb2a1bf28b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T21:03:45.509+01:00">9.03pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The international effort to contain and stop the virus has brought nine Ebola patients to Europe, three of whom to Germany – but <strong>some medical organizations say Germany should do more</strong>, my colleague Philip Oltermann reports.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A working group at Leopoldina, the German national academy of sciences, on Wednesday called for Germany to accelerate its effort to develop experimental vaccines and medicines for clinical application.<br /></p> <p>“Germany already has very good expertise in this field, particularly with the research going on,” said Leopoldina president Jörg Hacker.</p> </blockquote> <p>Hacker argues that the discovery and development of vaccines should not be solely driven by the market economy, and he told the Guardian that recent progress in the field of Aids research had shown that governments could drive progress via public-private partnerships or medical foundations.</p> <p><strong>But he said the cost of treating patients with Ebola is “extremely high”</strong>, amounting to around €10,000 plus additional medicine costs. Moreover, patients’ own health insurers (including the UN) have covered the expenses so far, rather than Germany.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ecd6ce4b0ebfb2a1bf2b1" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:49:58.633+01:00">8.49pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a summary of today’s key events so far:</p> <ul> <li><strong><strong><strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e469be4b01d51bd0b0384">A second health worker has contracted Ebola</a> after having treated a man who died from the virus there</strong></strong></strong></strong>. She has been named as Amber Vinson and will be <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543ea6bfe4b0ebfb2a1bf28c">airlifted to Emory hospital in Atlanta</a>, near the Centers for Disease Control. </li> </ul> <ul> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e9568e4b0cd82a095f7e6"><strong><strong>Vinson flew just a day before reporting a fever </strong></strong></a><strong><strong>and testing positive, </strong></strong>though crew members say she showed no symptoms during the flight. The CDC is trying to reach all 132 people who were on board Frontier Airlines flight 1143, which flew from Cleveland to Dallas-Fort Worth on 13 October.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>The White House said </strong><strong><strong><a href="http://">“there are likely to be more cases,”</a> </strong></strong>and said that the safety breaches that led to infections in Texas were “unacceptable”, but resisted the idea of an “Ebola tsar”. President Barack Obama will speaker after <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e9c9ae4b03829d13c2016">an emergency m</a><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e9c9ae4b03829d13c2016">eeting</a>, and also spoke by<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e563be4b03829d13c1f85"> video conference </a>with EU leaders.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543eb229e4b03829d13c2030">Nearly 4,500 people have died from the virus</a> since the outbreak began</strong> in west Africa, the WHO said in a statement, adding that the estimated death rate is now 70% and it’s likely that many deaths go unreported.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong><strong><strong>Staff at Presbyterian Hospital <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e70ace4b0cd82a095f79e">allege chaotic scenes and poor safety protocols</a></strong></strong></strong></strong> in dealing with infected patients. A nurses union says the hospital let hazardous waste “pile to the ceiling”, and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543ecb4de4b01d51bd0b045b">threatened to picket</a> over poor preparations.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong><strong><strong>UN agencies describe increasingly awful situations in west African nations</strong></strong></strong></strong>, with the crisis affecting other areas, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e7a13e4b0ebfb2a1bf230">for example families’ ability to heal themselves</a>.</li> </ul> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T21:13:00.278+01:00">at 9.13pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ecb4de4b01d51bd0b045b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:34:23.353+01:00">8.34pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>National Nurses United, the union and professional organization for US healthcare workers, just held a conference call for thousands of nurses to discuss Ebola.</p> <p>Vox’s Sarah Kliff tweets what may be the biggest news from the call:</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/sarahkliff/statuses/522466007890554880">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Wow: in a conference call happening now, nurse’s biggest union says they’re considering hospital pickets if preparation doesn’t improve.</p>&mdash; Sarah Kliff (@sarahkliff) <a href="https://twitter.com/sarahkliff/status/522466007890554880">October 15, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <p>Dallas local news meanwhile has yet another allegation from nurses about the lack of protocol at Texas Presbyterian Hospital.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/abenadove/statuses/522465210846949377">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Dallas hospital nurses DID NOT wear protective personal equipment for several days, until diagnosis confirmed. <a href="http://t.co/24oSPbWiFU">http://t.co/24oSPbWiFU</a></p>&mdash; Dove (@abenadove) <a href="https://twitter.com/abenadove/status/522465210846949377">October 15, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ec935e4b0cd82a095f829" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:27:42.982+01:00">8.27pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>“There’s a multi-layered screening protocol in place,”</strong> Earnest says, to prevent Ebola-positive people from boarding flights to the US. </p> <p>He says controls abroad and by border patrol officers in the US are part of a system to stop the virus from entering the country (again).</p> <p><strong>Earnest directs reporters to the CDC for leadership </strong>on how to handle the crisis:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“It’s the CDC’s responsibility to communicate with hospitals and healthcare professionals about the proper protocols … there’s also a protocol the CDC has in place for [treating] patients with Ebola. The CDC is reviewing those protocols. And we are concerned about making sure that the CDC is offering clear guidance about what those protocols should be.”</p> </blockquote> <p>But he refuses to say that Texas Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas did anything wrong: “There was, uh, something unacceptable occurred.”</p> <p>And shortly after that the briefing is over, and Earnest leaves to attend the president’s meeting.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ec739e4b01d51bd0b0458" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:18:46.667+01:00">8.18pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">White House: more cases are 'likely'</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>“<strong>There are likely to be more cases of Ebola,” Earnest says, </strong>before adopting the future tense, rather than the conditional:</p> <p>“When those cases present themselves, [the president wants to ensure] that our [workers] will be able to [handle it] and to ensure the safety of the greater public.”</p> <p>The next question hits on the problem of leadership: “So there’s not one person in charge…? Besides the president.”</p> <p>Earnest strenuously clarifies that Lisa Monaco is coordinating activities of agencies, who are themselves determining those activities, and that she’s not involved with ground operations, per se.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T21:02:29.020+01:00">at 9.02pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ec57de4b0cd82a095f828" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:11:50.729+01:00">8.11pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Asked about preventing people who’ve contacted Ebola patients from getting on commercial flights, <strong>Earnest says that the CDC bears most of that responsibility.</strong></p> <p>Pressed about the powers necessary to keep Ebola off airplanes, Earnest repeats his earlier comment about setting up protocols; he doesn’t say anything about the administration’s ability to enforce any rules.</p> <p>“The president is concerned that healthcare professionals are getting clear guidance from the Centers for Disease Control … he wants them to be cognizant that there could be other Ebola patients across the country, about how to handle [one such patient] should they present themselves … the president is convening this meeting to make sure the response is commensurate.”</p> <p>He then reminds the press pool about the American healthcare workers who contracted the virus in Africa and recovered upon return to the US, without incident or further infections – “at other healthcare facilities”.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:12:45.489+01:00">at 8.12pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ec438e4b0cd82a095f825" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:04:51.542+01:00">8.04pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>“The stakes are high,” Earnest says, after something of a dodge to a question about Obama’s video conference with EU leaders and UK prime minister David Cameron.</p> <p>Earnest says the president urged EU leaders to make a bigger commitment in west Africa, but that he won’t remark about their conversation before a readout comes from the White House later today. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="f934e550415943e8f62f566409b00200a707cb58"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413399883921/ca1e0651-4de2-4321-81cb-ad4ed7edb589-460x276.jpeg" alt="White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ec37ce4b0cd82a095f824" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T20:00:02.928+01:00">8.00pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Earnest gets asked about fear and the failings of healthcare workers protocol: “Everyone on that plane is now being contacted – that creates at least a low level of alarm … do you understand how that could create [fear]?”</p> <p>“We have a modern medical infrastructure in place – that again has not been flawless … people should take solace in the fact that we know exactly how Ebola is transmitted. … This is a deadly graphic disease.”</p> <p>He hits his talking points again: the investigation to determine how healthcare workers were infected; tracing contacts of the infected; adapting better, more secure protocols; and treatment of those patients.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ec263e4b03829d13c203f" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T19:54:49.723+01:00">7.54pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Earnest says a travel ban from west African countries is “not on the table”.</strong><br /></p> <p> “The only way for us to stop this outbreak … is to stop this outbreak at the source. So we are mobilizing significant resources … to the region,” referring to the US military work in west Africa to support medical work and infrastructure.</p> <p>“This is a deadly, terrible disease and it is wreacking havoc in west Africa … it is genuinely tragic. At the same time because of the way that virus is transmitted, because of [the quality of medical serices] in this country,” that risk is extremely low, he says.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ec123e4b03829d13c203d" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T19:52:11.354+01:00">7.52pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Earnest goes to pains to differentiate the situation in west Africa from the US infections in Dallas.</strong></p> <p>“[Dallas] is wholly different than the situation we see in west Africa, where we see people in the same household passing the virus from one to another … or burial practices, where individuals are contracting the virus [from handling] corpses.”</p> <p>A reporter interrogates him a bit about how it was possible that Presbyterian hospital’s conditions allowed for workers to contract the virus, and about the government’s response.</p> <p>“Dr Frieden [the CDC director] has said that it’s unacceptable that even one healthcare worker has been exposed to this virus while providing treatment to this patient. That is an indiciation that there were shortcomings. … This under investigation, and that investigation will now expand to this second healthcare worker.”</p> <p>“What you are seeing from the federal government is the kind of tenacious response that reflects changing circumstances. Dr Frieden indicated that he would send a whole team of experts earlier this week after [seeing] that they should’ve been there sooner – what you’re seeing in Texas is [a changing response to reflect that].”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-16T16:50:00.239+01:00">at 4.50pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ebfeee4b0cd82a095f820" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T19:46:51.969+01:00">7.46pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Earnest is cagey about the idea of an “Ebola tsar”</strong> – he says that Monaco is in charge of coordinating agencies in the US but that, because the situation is “dynamic”, the organization of powers could change.</p> <p>Asked about how the second patient boarded a commercial flight, Earnest launches into a talk about protocols, saying that the CDC and administration is working on “advice to medical professionals across the country about the protocols to ensure that healthcare workers remain safe”.</p> <p>Earnest says that “contract tracing of the two workers that have contracted the virus” has begun, explaining that authorities are “tracing the contacts that these individuals have had after they got sick”.</p> <p><strong>He emphasizes that “risks are low”, </strong>and<strong> </strong>asked whether an Ebola epidemic is still “very unlikely” in the United States, he says “it is true, it’s guided by the science, that’s what our experts say. … The only way an individual can get Ebola is by coming into close contact with the fluids of an individual that is showing the symptoms of Ebola.”</p> <p>“How the transmission of [the healthcare workers with infected fluids] occurred remains under investigation.”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543ebe8ce4b0cd82a095f81f" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time reporters</strong>, and dives right into questions. He says that the president is convening a meeting at 3.30pm ET and will deliver remarks afterward.</p> <p>From the pool: “Can you give us any more details on the meeting?”</p> <p>He’ll be meeting with “members of his team who are responsible for responding to the Ebola situation … he wants to make sure that all the needed resources of the federal government are being deployed.”</p>  <figure and responsibilities: in Africa US forces from Department of Defense, Homeland Security, the CDC and health agencies are all involved.</p> <p>He says “There are clear lines of responsibilities in place … and Lisa Monaco, secretary of the department of homeland security [is in charge] of integrating the response.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time Ebola outbreaks and their consequences.</strong></p> <p>The council’s <a href="http://newyork-un.mae.lu/en/News/Security-Council-Press-Statement-on-Ebola">press statement </a>says the virus threatens international security, and that all UN countries and organizations should “accelerate and dramatically expand the provision of resources.”</p> <p>The head of the UN mission for Ebola response, Anthony Banbury, on Tuesday said that should the world fail to meet goals by 1 December, everyone will “face an entirely unprecedented situation for which we don’t have a plan.”</p> <p>You can read <p><strong>“The first several days before the patient was diagnosed appear to be the highest risk period,”</strong> the director of the CDC has said.</p> <p>My colleague Lauren Gambino (<a The WHO puts the death rate in the outbreak at 70%; it had previously hovered near 50%. The</p> <p>“It is clear … that the situation in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone is deteriorating, with widespread and persistent transmission of [Ebola],” the report notes, emphasizing that huge numbers of cases and deaths may be unreported.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/martinenserink/statuses/522444668257464320">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>.<a href="https://twitter.com/WHO">@WHO</a>&#39;s latest <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Ebola?src=hash">#Ebola</a> report makes it very clear that the official numbers ar far removed from reality.   <a href="http://t.co/vxxkI1wqPZ">http://t.co/vxxkI1wqPZ</a></p>&mdash; Martin Enserink (@martinenserink) <a href="https://twitter.com/martinenserink/status/522444668257464320">October 15, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543eb08ae4b01d51bd0b044a" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T18:42:39.858+01:00">6.42pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Amber Vinson is ill but “clinically stable”,</strong> according to Tom Frieden, the CDC director. </p> <p>He said infected nurses had extensive contact with Thomas Eric Duncan during the most infectious stage of the virus. He also clarified the timeline, and his comments about her flight: </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The patient had traveled to Ohio before it was known that the first healthcare worker was ill. At that point that patient as well as the rest of the healthcare team were undergoing self-monitoring. </p> <p>The second healthcare worker reported no symptoms and no fever. However, because at that point she was in a group of individuals known to have exposure to Ebola, she should not have traveled on a commercial flight.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Ohio’s health department is tracing whom Vinson may’ve contacted while she was in the state, and whether she may have had any symptoms before or during her flight from Cleveland back to Texas.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543eae81e4b03829d13c202e" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T18:31:01.267+01:00">6.31pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong><strong>Vinson should never have boarded a commercial plane, </strong></strong>Frieden says, per my colleague Lauren Gambino (<a href="https://twitter.com/LGamGam">@lgamgam</a>).</p> <p>He says she should not have flown after having been exposed to extremely infectious, late-stage Ebola – which she knew. He says the CDC is using “extra margins of safety” by contacting passengers and crew on board Frontier flight 1143, and in dealing with the second patient.</p> <p>Frieden also says hospital staff may have put on too many layers of protective gear while caring for Duncan in the early days of his treatment.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" patient to be airlifted to Emory</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>One of the healthcare workers to contract Ebola will be transported to Emory University Hospital in Atlanta, </strong>Tom Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has told reporters.</p> <p>A patient will be taken for treatment at CDC’s state-of-the-art base, where two Americans recovered from the virus earlier this year. </p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T18:13:16.633+01:00">at 6.13pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543ea2e1e4b01d51bd0b0433" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T17:47:35.383+01:00">5.47pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a summary of today’s key events so far:</p> <ul> <li><strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e469be4b01d51bd0b0384">A second health worker has contracted Ebola</a> after having treated a man who died from the virus there</strong></strong>, officials have said. She has been named as Amber Vinson and is being treated in isolation at Texas Presbyterian Hospital. Crews have cleaned her apartment, where she reportedly lived alone.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e9568e4b0cd82a095f7e6"><strong>Vinson flew just a day before reporting a fever </strong></a><strong>and testing positive, </strong>though crew members say she showed no symptoms during the flight. The CDC is trying to reach all 132 people who were on board Frontier Airlines flight 1143, which flew from Cleveland to Dallas-Fort Worth on 13 October.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong>A <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e675be4b0ebfb2a1bf20a">series of reports</a> from staff at Presbyterian Hospital <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e70ace4b0cd82a095f79e">allege chaotic scenes and poor safety protocols</a></strong></strong> in dealing with infected patients. A nurses union says the hospital let hazardous waste “pile to the ceiling”.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e62d9e4b03829d13c1fa2">More Ebola cases were “a very real possibility</a>, according to Dallas judge Clay Jenkins, </strong></strong>and the city’s mayor said the situation “may get worse before it gets better, but it will get better”.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong>The overwhelming majority of cases continue to be seen in west Africa</strong></strong>, with the UN’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e47e8e4b0cd82a095f73a">World Health Organisation warning that we could soon see 10,000 new cases a week</a>.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong><strong>UN agencies describe increasingly awful situations in west African nations</strong></strong>, with the crisis affecting other areas, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e7a13e4b0ebfb2a1bf230">for example families’ ability to heal themselves</a>.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>President Barack Obama cancelled plans to arrange <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e9c9ae4b03829d13c2016">an emergency m</a></strong><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e9c9ae4b03829d13c2016">eeting at the White House</a></strong>. He is due to speak later this afternoon ET, and also held <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e563be4b03829d13c1f85">a video conference </a>with EU leaders to discuss the crisis. </li> </ul> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T18:33:09.304+01:00">at 6.33pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e98a2e4b03829d13c2006" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T17:37:41.262+01:00">5.37pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The second case may help determine how nurses were infected, </strong>which would allow the hospital to correct a control breach and prevent spread, the AP reports. </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>For example, if both health workers were involved in drawing Duncan’s blood, placing an intravenous line or suctioning mucus when Duncan was on a breathing machine, that would be recognized as a particularly high-risk activity. It also might reveal which body fluids pose the greatest risk.</p> <p>Nina Pham, the first person to contract the disease as she cared for Duncan was in Duncan’s room often, from the day he was placed in intensive care until the day before he died.</p> </blockquote> <p>The hospital now plans to limit the number of healthcare workers who care for Ebola patients so they “can become more familiar and more systematic in how they put on and take off protective equipment, and they can become more comfortable in a healthy way with providing care in the isolation unit”.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e97e2e4b01d51bd0b041d" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T17:26:24.722+01:00">5.26pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The situation in Dallas “may get worse before it gets better, but it will get better”, </strong>Mayor Mike Rawlings has said, as officials both call for calm and signal that the end is not quite in sight.</p> <p>Dallas County health and human services director Zachary Thompson has told residents “don’t be surprised” to see more cases in the coming days, but has called for area residents to remain calm in an <a href="http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/health/2014/10/15/second-dallas-hospital-worker-diagnosed-ebola/17290677/">interview with local new</a>s.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“I’ve got to remind Dallas County residents: Let’s not get into the fear factor and panic,” he said. “It should be contained within the healthcare workers, and hopefully we don’t see any more cases, but don’t be surprised.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Dallas County judge Clay Jenkins said the 48 people who had contact outside the hospital with the first patient, Thomas Eric Duncan, are still healthy and without symptoms. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="e6cf59f2d5796362ec3b8c2e7114d5c855ad4b45"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413398146221/11d78acb-2fc3-4eda-a61b-57e065dcee28-460x276.jpeg" alt="Dr Daniel Varga, Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins, and Mayor Mike Rawlings." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Dr Daniel Varga, Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins, and Mayor Mike Rawlings.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: David Woo/David Woo/Dallas Morning News/Corbis</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At the hospital, 76 people could have been exposed to Duncan and are being monitored for fever and other symptoms. With the addition of the 132 people on board Frontier flight 1143, more than 250 people may have come into contact with one of the three people to have tested positive for the virus in the US.</p> <p>Executive president of Texas Health Resources Dr Daniel Varga said Presbyterian hospital has an isolation unit set up which can handle up to three patients. A new area has also been opened to screen patients for Ebola.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T19:35:52.037+01:00">at 7.35pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e9c9ae4b03829d13c2016" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T17:13:06.355+01:00">5.13pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>President Obama has postponed travel to campaign rallies for an emergency Ebola meeting at the White House</strong>, my colleague Dan Roberts reports.</p> <p>Obama will also speak this afternoon after the meeting. Dan copies in a statement from the White House press secretary:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Late this afternoon, the president will convene a meeting at the White House of cabinet agencies coordinating the government’s response to the Ebola outbreak. There will be a pool spray at the conclusion of that meeting, where the president will deliver brief remarks. We will have more details on the participants and timing of the meeting as soon as they are available.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e96e0e4b0cd82a095f7e9" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:50:54.692+01:00">4.50pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The second infected healthcare worker has been named as Amber Vinson</strong> by family members to local media. Dallas <a href="http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/health/2014/10/15/second-dallas-hospital-worker-diagnosed-ebola/17290677/">local news WFAA</a> has more details from the mayor’s press conference, and has spoken with relatives:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Family members say 29-year-old nurse Amber Vinson has joined nurse Nina Pham in isolation at Texas Presbyterian Hospital. Martha Schuler, the mother of Vinson’s former stepfather, confirmed her identity Wednesday morning.</p> <p>During a press conference Wednesday morning, Mayor Mike Rawlings confirmed that Vinson lives alone without pets at The Green in the Village Apartments, in the 6000 block of Village Bend near Skillman, just north of Lovers Lane.</p> </blockquote> <p>Police were at Vinson’s apartment complex early this morning and notified people in the area. About Pham, Presbyterian Hospital said her condition had improved and that her dog is also doing well.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T17:22:26.256+01:00">at 5.22pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e9568e4b0cd82a095f7e6" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:45:51.811+01:00">4.45pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The CDC and Frontier Airlines have released statements about their attempt to contact passengers on flight 1143.</strong></p> <p> Both statements reiterate: “the healthcare worker exhibited no symptoms of illness while on flight 1143, according to the crew”. The CDC statement reads in part:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Because of the proximity in time between the evening flight and first report of illness the following morning, CDC is reaching out to passengers who flew on Frontier Airlines flight 1143 Cleveland to Dallas/Fort Worth 13 October. </p> <p>CDC is asking all 132 passengers on Frontier Airlines flight 1143 Cleveland to Dallas/Fort Worth on October 13 (the flight route was Cleveland to Dallas Fort Worth and landed at 8.16pm CT) to call 1 800-CDC INFO <a href="tel:%281%20800%20232-4636">(1 800 232-4636</a>). After 1pm ET, public health professionals will begin interviewing passengers about the flight, answering their questions, and arranging follow up. Individuals who are determined to be at any potential risk will be actively monitored.</p> <p>The healthcare worker exhibited no signs or symptoms of illness while on flight 1143, according to the crew. </p> </blockquote> <p>Frontier Airlines statement follows a similar line, saying the company cleaned the aircraft as usual:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>At approximately 1am MT on 15 October, Frontier was notified by the CDC that a customer traveling on Frontier Airlines flight 1143 Cleveland to Dallas/Fort Worth on 13 October has since tested positive for the Ebola virus. </p> <p>The flight landed in Dallas/Fort Worth at 8.16pm local and remained overnight at the airport having completed its flying for the day at which point the aircraft received a thorough cleaning per our normal procedures which is consistent with CDC guidelines prior to returning to service the next day. It was also cleaned again in Cleveland last night. Previously the customer had traveled from Dallas Fort Worth to Cleveland on Frontier flight 1142 on 10 October.</p> <p>The safety and security of our customers and employees is our primary concern. Frontier will continue to work closely with CDC and other governmental agencies to ensure proper protocols and procedures are being followed.” </p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e92d1e4b01d51bd0b0415" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:33:30.393+01:00">4.33pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Second patient was on a flight before fever</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The CDC is trying to contact passengers who shared a flight with an infected health worker, </strong>Reuters snaps.</p> <p>The second healthcare worker was on flight number 1143, flying 13 October from Cleveland to Dallas-Fort Worth, just before reporting a fever a day later.</p> <p>The CDC says that she showed no symptoms during the flight, quoting a crew member, but asks all 132 who were on board to call a hotline: <a href="tel:+18002324636">1.800.232.4636</a>, which can be called after 1pm ET.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:36:04.799+01:00">at 4.36pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e9148e4b03829d13c1ff2" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:28:41.656+01:00">4.28pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>“We feel like a pariah nation,” </strong>an NGO worker in Sierra Leone tells my colleague Sam Jones, in a piece excerpted earlier in the blog.</p> <p>Sierra Leone has been wracked by Ebola cases, with public services pressed for resources and officials stranded around and outside the country. There have been some 2,700 cases of the virus in the country, and nearly 900 deaths.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="adbe314fe219769fae0348d16a2eb9a24744a2d9"> <img datetime="2014-10-15T16:28:48.532+01:00">at 4.28pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e8cd3e4b01d51bd0b0400" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:15:43.195+01:00">4.15pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>The president of Sierra Leone says containing the virus will require drastic laboratory improvements</strong>, my colleague Lisa O’Carroll (<a href="https://twitter.com/lisaocarroll">@lisaocarroll</a>) relays.</p> <p>Ernest Bai Koroma has said Ebola test results need to be turned around within four hours, and told a delegation from the Italian-run Emergency Hospital in Freetown the the country is in urgent need laboratories.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We need these facilities today as there is no time to waste.”</p> <p> “If we can increase our capacity of handling over 500 samples a day, it will be helpful to handle the pressure. Forty-eight hours is not good, as some will get infected while waiting. We should maintain the four hours and work on improving it further.”</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="e7c670b7ab52f6a99bcc0fbbca9545e4e1e44b74"> <img <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:25:57.879+01:00">at 10.25pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e8a0ce4b01d51bd0b03fa" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:01:59.436+01:00">4.01pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>EU countries may screen airport travellers for Ebola</strong>, Reuters reports, which would follow actions by<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/ebola-screening-confusion-heathhrow-airport-measures"> the UK and US</a>.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The European Commission, the bloc’s executive body, says it is still weighing up the effectiveness of entry screening, given that travellers are screened on departure from the affected areas and have a low probability of developing infectious symptoms between leaving an African airport and arriving in Europe. </p> <p>An EU official said one key element of entry screening could be informing arriving passengers of what to do if they later fell ill – notably telling them not to turn up without warning at hospital after developing symptoms of Ebola.</p> </blockquote> <p>Health ministers will meet Thursday in Brussels to discuss whether the bloc ought to have more uniform screenings. </p> <p>The effectiveness of<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/01/ebola-prevention-thermal-scanner-effective-placebo"> screenings has been questioned by experts</a>, as my colleague Jessica Glenza wrote about earlier this month.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e86c1e4b03829d13c1fe2" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T15:44:34.018+01:00">3.44pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>CDC guidelines for protective gear could be more careful and guarded yet,</strong> according to CNN’s Sanjay Gupta. </p> <p>Gupta notes that the recommended gear leaves skin exposed, that there’s no “buddy system” for healthcare workers to ensure that colleagues are careful, and that there should likely be more about cleaning your hands. He says that in Guinea, he and healthcare workers would dip their hands in buckets of bleach. </p> <p>You can watch him try and critique the guidelines here; CDC guidelines are only recommendations, and not standard practice in all US hospitals.</p>  <figure class="element element-embed" data-alt="CNN Ebola CDC protocol">  <iframe width="460" height="234" src="http://www.cnn.com/video/api/embed.html#/video/health/2014/10/14/sgmd-gupta-ebola-suit-demo.cnn" frameborder="0"></iframe> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e80bfe4b0ebfb2a1bf243" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T15:23:17.078+01:00">3.23pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a summary of today’s key events so far:</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e469be4b01d51bd0b0384"><strong>Another health worker at the Dallas hospital where a man died from Ebola has contracted the virus</strong></a>, officials have said. The person has not been identified yet.</li> <li><strong>A <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e675be4b0ebfb2a1bf20a">series of reports</a> from staff at the Texas Health Presbyterian hospital <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e70ace4b0cd82a095f79e">allege chaotic scenes and poor safety protocols</a></strong> in dealing with infected patients.</li> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e62d9e4b03829d13c1fa2"><strong>At a press conference the Dallas judge, Clay Jenkins, said more Ebola cases were “a very real possibility”</strong></a>.</li> <li><strong>The overwhelming majority of cases continue to be seen in West Africa</strong>, with the UN’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e47e8e4b0cd82a095f73a">World Health Organisation warning that we could soon see 10,000 new cases a week</a>.</li> <li><strong>UN agencies describe increasingly awful situations in West African nations</strong>, with the crisis affecting other areas, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e7a13e4b0ebfb2a1bf230">for example families’ ability to heal themselves</a>.<br /></li> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e563be4b03829d13c1f85"><strong>Around 4pm UK time Barack Obama is due to hold a video conference about Ebola with David Cameron and three other EU leaders</strong></a>.</li> </ul> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T15:40:40.152+01:00">at 3.40pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e7a13e4b0ebfb2a1bf230" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:51:12.393+01:00">2.51pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Sam Jones </strong>also sends these heartbreaking details from the UN’s <strong>World Food Programme</strong> about the devastating impact of the Ebola outbreak on some families:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>According to John Crisci, the World Food Programme’s emergency co-ordinator in Sierra Leone, the spread of Ebola is making it harder for people to feed their families.<br /><br />“The average Sierra Leonean family spends anything from 60% to 70% of their income on food and with this crisis, families in highly infected hotspots such as Kenema and Kailahun have lost one of the breadwinners in the family either to Ebola or to unemployment.”<br /><br />In some areas, says Crisci, families are now spending 80-90% of their income on food and adopting what the WFP calls “severe food coping strategies”: when food becomes the predominant concern, people stop buying medicines, clothes and hygiene products.<br /><br />With unemployment rising in towns and the countryside as people lose jobs in banks, hotels and restaurants, farmers stop tending their lands and plantation employees shun work that involves large groups, mothers and fathers are beginning to limit what they eat.<br /><br />“Parents in some areas are now eating one meal a day to try to give two meals to their children,” says Crisci. “When both parents were working and had a steady income, they’d be having three meals a day.”<br /><br />In response, the WFP is conducting a “no-regrets operation”, opting to bring in and then withdraw excess resources rather than risk failing those in need. <br /><br />Dry rations of rice, beans, salt, vegetable oil and supercereals for children - supplemented by onions, stock cubes, tea and toothpaste from the Sierra Leonean government - are being delivered to families whose houses have been locked down by the military and police in the hope of halting Ebola’s spread.<br /><br />“The biggest challenge in this operation is that it’s forever-evolving,” says Crisci. “The number of areas in the country that are being isolated continues to grow. We’re always moving quickly behind the target but we’re now trying to beat it.”<br /><br />With the food pipeline beginning to open up and the WFP bringing in large shipments this month and next, Crisci believes it will have the capacity to respond to the needs of up to 600,000 people.<br /><br />But he does not underestimate the scale of the emergency. Last week, while on an assessment mission to a village 45 miles from Freetown that had been placed in isolation, he came across a quarantined house guarded by soldiers.<br /><br />“Behind them on the patio, covered with a coloured cotton sheet were two sisters, probably about two and nine years old. One was face up and one was face down. Their mother was there on the patio, keeping a distance of couple of metres. She was looking over at them and you could see that she was desperate and hopeless. Her hands were tied and she couldn’t do anything to comfort them. She kept on looking out at the road hoping that the ambulance was coming any time. We intervened heavily but unfortunately one of the little girls passed away. The other sister is in a treatment centre now in Port Loko and we hear the chances are slim.<br /><br /> “If it had been a kid who had broken their leg or bumped their head, we’d have thrown them in the WFP car and run to the hospital; we do it all the time. But in a case like this, we couldn’t do anything. We try to change the world, we try to assist millions of people but here there were these two children just lying there and none of us could do anything except pull every contact we had to get the ministry of health to intervene. You feel like you’re doing a big thing and then you see the two children and their mother. It broke my heart.”</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e7697e4b01d51bd0b03d5" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:30:17.788+01:00">2.30pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>My colleague <strong>Sam Jones</strong> sends this about the wider social effect of the outbreak in Sierra Leone:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Ebola’s impact on Sierra Leone goes far beyond swamped clinics and closed schools, according to Simitie Lavaly, the executive director at AdvocAid, an NGO that works with women and their children in detention in Sierra Leone.<br /><br />“Very few lawyers are going to court because it’s not worth their while financially and there are not many judges because a lot of them are stranded outside the country because they went abroad for the high court summer recess. The flights were cancelled and they can’t come back. <br /></p> <p>“The few magistrates who are now sitting don’t hear more than 10 cases a day because the emergency public health declarations say there should not be large gatherings. If you have more cases, you have more people. Before, they’d hear 30 cases a day. Now they’re adjourning cases and they’ve also restricted litigants: it has to be your case and you can’t come with lots of friends and witnesses to support you. Lots of the male prisoners are not in good health and some lawyers are worried about coming across them in the corridors.”<br /><br />Lavaly says the situation in prisons is also becoming increasingly difficult as people’s cases are adjourned. With visits from family suspended, it is left to the NGOs to bring baby food to mothers detained with young children, and to top up the prisons’ ever-dwindling supplies of chlorine, buckets and gloves.<br /><br />“We also bring in a bit of cassava for people, because a lot of time they complain that the don’t have enough food,” says Lavaly. “And God forbid, if you get Ebola, your immune system needs the food – not to mention oral rehydration solution. Even without Ebola, there are a lot of malnourished prisoners.”<br /><br />While it applauds the efforts of those judges and magistrates still managing to do their jobs, AdvocAid wants the police to relieve some of the pressure by dealing with minor offences in the police station rather than clogging up the courts.<br /><br />But what it most needed, argues Lavaly, is neither a fast-tracked legal process nor a judicial airdrop, but international help in bringing a swift end to the crisis.<br /><br />“Many of us lived through the war,” she says. “It feels like we are back in that time again, but only it is worse. Then, we could see our enemy but now the enemy is unknown and could be a loved one or close associate. Then, the international community and relatives overseas were sympathetic to our plight and readily gave financial and moral support. Now we feel like a pariah nation, closed from the outside world and with not much sympathy for our plight as no one wants to contract Ebola from us.”<br /></p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e766ae4b03829d13c1fca" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:28:49.254+01:00">2.28pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a photo of the Dallas apartment block where the second healthcare worker to contract Ebola lived. Their home is currently being decontaminated.<br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="a1f3cc1160830f75d3d0b063905d275ad6a507b7"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413379687964/97ddecfc-6337-4fa7-b9ec-796d3fdcbac2-460x276.jpeg" alt="Dallas Police patrol the entrance to The Village Bend East apartments, home to the second healthcare worker who tested positive for Ebola." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Dallas Police patrol the entrance to The Village Bend East apartments, home to the second healthcare worker who tested positive for Ebola.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Brandon Wade/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e7419e4b0cd82a095f7a9" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:21:56.519+01:00">2.21pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>My colleague <strong>Ben Quinn</strong> sends this about the Sierra Leonean population in the UK:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The UK is home to one of the largest Sierra Leonean diasporas outside of Africa – some 16,972 people born in the country were living in Britain at the 2001 census – and they’re certainly getting involved in helping relatives in their homeland.<br /><br />I’ve been speaking to Londoner Memuna Janneh, who grew up in Sierra Leone, about the charity she has set up to channel resources there (see the audio below). <br /><br />Her Charity, <a href="http://www.lunchboxgift.com/"> Lunchbox</a>, has already supplied thousands of meals to people living in a number of communities. Its next goal is to raise £50,000 to supply 50,000 meals to those in hospital in Sierra Leone’s western region, including patients, nurses, doctors, drivers and others.<br /><br />She talks also about the strong sense of community among the Sierra Leone diaspora in the UK.<br /><br />“Everybody who is on the front line should at least be able to get meal,” she said.<br />“The idea is that we free up the Ministry of Health and Sanitisation so that they don’t have to worry about that part of the struggle. This is a very complex situation and we are all battling to get things going.”<br /><br />The campaign - Lunch Is On Me - launches this Saturday. People are going to be asked to take photographs of their lunch, make a donation to the value of their lunch, post a photograph online and perhaps nominate three other people to do the same.</p> </blockquote> <p>You can <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/oct/09/ebola-response-diaspora-sierra-leone">read more about the role of Sierra Leone’s grassroots diaspora here</a>.<br /></p>  <figure class="element element-audio" data-canonical-url="https://audioboom.com/boos/2564648-memuna-janneh-talks-about-her-charity-lunchbox"> <iframe width="460" height="154" src="http://audioboom.com/boos/2564648-memuna-janneh-talks-about-her-charity-lunchbox/embed/v3?eid=AQAAAD10PlQoIicA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:22:56.049+01:00">at 2.22pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e7368e4b0ebfb2a1bf223" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:18:10.911+01:00">2.18pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a photo of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/15/ebola-second-texas-healthcare-worker-tests-positive-as-world-grapples-with-outbreak-live-updates#block-543e62d9e4b03829d13c1fa2">press Otero/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e70ace4b0cd82a095f79e" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:06:53.995+01:00">2.06pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The Associated Press has more on the accusations by nurses at the Texas Health Presbyterian hospital of lax safety protocol in the handling of Thomas Eric Duncan’s Ebola case. The nurses allege that:</p> <p>• Duncan was kept in a non-isolated area of the emergency department for several hours, potentially exposing up to seven other patients to Ebola.<br /></p> <p>• Patients who may have been exposed to Duncan were kept in isolation only for a day before being moved to areas where there were other patients.</p> <p>• Nurses treating Duncan were also caring for other patients in the hospital.</p> <p>• Preparation for Ebola at the hospital amounted to little more than an optional seminar for staff.</p> <p>• In the face of constantly shifting guidelines, nurses were allowed to follow whichever ones they chose.</p> <p>• Basic principles of infection control were violated by both the hospital’s Infectious Disease Department and CDC officials, the nurses said, with no one picking up hazardous waste “as it piled to the ceiling”.</p> <p>We have launched a version of this story and you can read it <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/dallas-nurses-accuse-hospital-sloppy-safety-ebola">here</a>.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T17:33:30.971+01:00">at 5.33pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e6a29e4b0ebfb2a1bf211" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T13:38:01.708+01:00">1.38pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Ashifa Kassam</strong> in Madrid sends me this on Spain’s latest response to the crisis:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Spanish health authorities have begun rolling out a series of improvements after repeated complaints of inadequate training by those on the frontline of fighting Ebola in Spain. </p> <p>Officials said they would begin offering specialised training courses to health workers on Wednesday. Earlier this week they promised training to anyone who might come in contact with Ebola, from doctors to firefighters, and said they would enlist the help of groups such as Doctors Without Borders in developing the training. </p> <p>After experts from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control raised concerns about the layout of Madrid’s designated hospital for treating Ebola, emergency renovations have begun at the Carlos III Hospital. The tiny change rooms, which sparked concerns over infections when health workers are taking off the protective suits, are being expanded. Video cameras have been installed to catch any slip-ups in protocol. </p> <p>The improvements come after <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-spanish-health-workers-poor-training-virus">months of lobbying by health workers</a>. In July, more than 100 nurses brought a complaint before a judge over their “lack of training and knowledge regarding Ebola protocols.” The virus was spreading in Africa, and the nurses worried it would only be a matter of time before it reached Spain. For many of them, training had simply been a 10- or 20-minute demonstration, said the unions representing health workers. </p> <p>Their worries turned out to be well-found when one month later, the Spanish government decided to repatriate a 75-year-old Ebola patient from Liberia. A second patient was brought in September from Sierra Leone. Both men died days after arriving in Madrid. </p> <p>After a nurse who attended to both patients <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/06/nurse-spain-tests-positive-ebola">became the first known person to contact Ebola outside of west Africa</a> last week, health workers again began lobbying for better training and equipment to fight the virus. </p> <p> Teresa Romero Ramos remains in stable but serious condition. Another 15 people remain in quarantine in the Carlos III Hospital, none of whom have shown any symptoms of Ebola to-date.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e675be4b0ebfb2a1bf20a" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T13:26:43.705+01:00">1.26pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">'Chaotic scenes' described at Dallas hospital</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>The <a href="http://www.dallasnews.com/news/metro/20141015-in-statement-nurses-at-presbyterian-dallas-describe-confused-response-to-ebola-case.ece"><strong>Dallas Morning News</strong> reports</a> that staff at the Texas Health Presbyterian hospital have described chaotic scenes when Thomas Eric Duncan was brought in with Ebola:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p> Nurses at the Dallas hospital where a Liberian man died of Ebola described a confused and chaotic response to his arrival in the emergency room, alleging in a statement on Tuesday that he languished for hours in a room with other patients and that hospital authorities resisted isolating him.</p> <p>In addition, they said, the nurses tending him had flimsy protective gear and no proper training from hospital administrators.</p> <p>The allegations, made under unusual circumstances, provided the first detailed portrait of Thomas Eric Duncan’s second trip to the emergency room, where he arrived by ambulance days after doctors had sent him home with a fever, a headache, abdominal pain and a prescription for antibiotics.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:13:18.368+01:00">at 2.13pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e62d9e4b03829d13c1fa2" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T13:20:42.433+01:00">1.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Dallas press conference</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>City officials in Dallas have been holding a press conference about the new Ebola case. I missed the start of the comments by the city’s judge, <strong>Clay</strong> <strong>Jenkins</strong>, but according to local reporters (see tweet below) they are preparing for more possible cases. He said of new cases:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>It’s a very real possibility.</p> </blockquote> <p>Also speaking was <strong>Dr Daniel Varga</strong>, chief clinical officer of Texas Health Resources, who spoke about whether more could have been done to prevent health workers contracting the virus. He said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We are a hospital that maybe could have done things differently, with the benefit of hindsight today.</p> </blockquote> <p>The city’s mayor, <strong>Mike Rawlings</strong>, said the apartment and car of the second health worker to get the virus were being decontaminated today. The person, who has still not been named, lives alone and does not have any pets, he said. In all, he said, 48 people who were known to have come into contact with Thomas Eric Duncan, the Ebola patient who died, are being monitored. Rawlings said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The only way we are going to beat this is person by person, moment by<br /> moment, detail by detail … we want to minimise rumours<br /> and maximise facts. We want to deal with facts not fear.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/WFAAalexa/statuses/522358043132956673">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Judge Clay Jenkins says the city is preparing contingencies for more cases of Ebola.  &quot;It&#39;s a very real possibility&quot;.</p>&mdash; Alexa Conomos (@WFAAalexa) <a href="https://twitter.com/WFAAalexa/status/522358043132956673">October 15, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T17:32:12.082+01:00">at 5.32pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e60b7e4b03829d13c1f9b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T12:57:50.806+01:00">12.57pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/11/world/africa/doctors-without-borders-evolves-as-it-forms-the-vanguard-in-ebola-fight-.html"><strong>New York Times</strong> has a fascinating piece</a> about how the medical charity MSF (Doctors Without Borders), has been at the forefront of trying to combat the outbreak in west Africa. Here’s a taster:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>When the <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/e/ebola/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier">Ebola</a> virus began relentlessly spreading in <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/news/international/countriesandterritories/sierraleone/index.html?inline=nyt-geo">Sierra Leone</a> months ago, government officials made an urgent plea to <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/organizations/d/doctors_without_borders/index.html?inline=nyt-org">Doctors Without Borders</a>, all that appeared to stand between the country and chaos.</p> <p>“They asked us to be everywhere,” recalled Walter Lorenzi, the medical charity’s former coordinator in Sierra Leone. “They didn’t know what to do.”</p> <p>Not long after, the group opened a treatment center in Kailahun, in eastern Sierra Leone, that was hacked out of the bush in just 12 days. Before opening another center three weeks ago in the southern city of Bo, the organization ran three shifts of workers, 24 hours a day, when daily rain and equipment breakdowns delayed construction.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T13:59:13.338+01:00">at 1.59pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e5d94e4b0ebfb2a1bf1f4" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T12:51:38.448+01:00">12.51pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Max Miller</strong> sends me this on British companies currently seeing a rush in sales of protective medical equipment.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Sales of disease protection items have spiked in the wake of the Ebola outbreak in west Africa, according to one British firm which sells the equipment online.</p> <p>As many as 10,000 protective suits, 5,000 Ebola kits, and 25,000 hand gel units have been sold in the last three months by <a href="http://www.spservices.co.uk/">SP Services</a>, who are based in London.</p> <p>While the overwhelming majority of sales have been to groups working in west Africa, the company has been fielding inquiries from concerned members of the public.</p> <p>Steve Bray, managing director of SP Services said: “We have told those members of the public who have rang up that they do not need to buy anything.”</p> <p>He added of the firm’s business in general: “Over the last two weeks both orders and enquiries have gone up. This weekend in particular has seen an increase.”</p> <p>SP Services’ Ebola protection kits include a bio-mask, a clinical waste bag, and a pair of safety goggles, amongst other gear.</p> <p>Sales have also spiked at <a href="http://survivalgear.co.uk">survivalgear.co.uk</a>, a UK based company who sell protective gear directly to the public online. </p> <p>Stuart Hurd, the owner, said: “There has been an increase in sales and general traffic to our website, maybe 50-60% more than usual. A lot of it coincided with the cases in Dallas and Spain.” </p> <p>He continued: “We have sold the same amount of NBC (Nuclear, Biological, Chemical) suits in the last couple of weeks as we did in the last year.”</p> <p>They are planning on bringing out an Ebola specific kit in the near future. </p> <p>Other companies have also been selling items specifically for Ebola protection, with protective suits available on eBay, and WHO-recommended medical face masks cropping up on Amazon.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time
