In <strong>USA Today</strong>, <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/10/14/ebola-spreads-easily-hospitals/17247157/">Peter Hotez, dean of the National School of Tropical Medicine in Houston, explains</a>.</p> <p>Ebola, he says, is unusual because the virus replicates very rapidly as the disease becomes more advanced. When people are first infected they are not contagious because levels of the virus in blood are too low to spread the infection.</p> <p>However, as it develops – and as intensive care nurses get involved – the risk of infection goes up as the virus replicates. Hotez said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>So by the time you are in the end stages of your illness, your liver and your spleen and your kidneys are just teeming with billions of viral particles.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e50bae4b0cd82a095f74b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T11:50:35.796+01:00">11.50am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>This <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/ng-interactive/2014/aug/13/ebola-outbreaks-interactive-map">useful interactive map</a> tracks every outbreak of Ebola from 1976 to this year.<br /></p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e505ce4b0cd82a095f749" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T11:46:58.878+01:00">11.46am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>My colleague in Berlin, <strong>Philip Oltermann</strong>, sends this update:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The body of the Sudanese Ebola victim who died in a German clinic on Monday night has been burnt to stop further spreading of the disease.<br /></p> <p>Authorities at the clinic in Leipzig took the step to burn the remains of the UN worker, who was a Muslim, even though cremation is not permissible in Islam.<br /></p> <p>The head of Germany’s central councils of Muslims in Germany told Bild newspaper: “In principle, cremation is not permissible for Muslims. But when the situation requires that the man is burnt, then the protection of the wider population is more important.”</p> <p>The 56-year-old man had been flown into Germany from Liberia last Thursday, but had succumbed to the disease on Monday night.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e4d8ae4b0ebfb2a1bf1c8" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T11:39:25.552+01:00">11.39am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Returning to the cases in Texas, the US’s <strong>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</strong> (CDC) has conceded that a quicker response to Thomas Eric Duncan’s diagnosis might have prevented the two healthcare workers catching the disease, my <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition">colleague <strong>Lauren Gambino </strong></a>(<a href="https://twitter.com/LGamGam">@lgamgam</a>) <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition">reported last night</a>.</p> <p>The CDC director, Tom Frieden, said the agency should have sent a larger team to Dallas:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>That might have prevented this infection. Ebola is unfamiliar. It’s scary and getting it right is really important because the stakes are so high.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>Nina Pham</strong>, the nurse who treated Duncan and contracted the virus, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/dallas-nurse-ebola-transfusion-kent-brantly">received blood plasma</a> from an American, Dr Kent Brantley, who recovered from Ebola earlier this year. In a statement released by the hospital she said she is “doing well”.<br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T22:24:05.336+01:00">at 10.24pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e4c21e4b0ebfb2a1bf1c7" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T11:30:51.080+01:00">11.30am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Today is the UN-organised <strong>Global Handwashing Day</strong>, marking a simple yet hugely effective public health measure which has a particular resonance at the moment.</p> <p> <strong>Sanjay Wijesekera</strong>, from the UN children’s charity <strong>Unicef</strong>, said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Handwashing with soap is one of the cheapest, most effective ‘vaccines’ against viral diseases, from the seasonal flu, to the common cold.</p> <p>Our teams on the ground in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea are stressing the importance of handwashing as part of a raft of measures that are needed to halt the spread of Ebola. It is not a magic bullet, but it is a means of additional defence which is cheap and readily available.<br /></p> <p>It is clear there is no simple fix, and it is going to take a massive international effort to stem the tide of this disease. But it is crucial to get the word out on what measures can be taken now in the hardest hit areas, even as additional help continues to arrive from the outside. Handwashing is one of those measures.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T13:51:54.834+01:00">at 1.51pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div leaders' conference call scheduled for 4pm BST</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Amid a fast-moving global response to the crisis, <strong>Barack Obama</strong> will discuss the outbreak with David Cameron and other EU leaders in a video conference call on Wednesday afternoon. Our <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/david-cameron-ebola-crisis-barack-obama-eu-leaders">story on the subject</a> says:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>It is understood that the leaders will discuss what further action can be taken to help stop the spread of the virus in west Africa.</p> <p>They will also discuss the steps that are being taken to screen air passengers arriving in Europe and the EU from west Africa.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T14:28:06.003+01:00">at 2.28pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543e47e8e4b0cd82a095f73a" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T11:17:43.565+01:00">11.17am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>On Tuesday the <strong>World Health Organisation</strong> <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/who-new-ebola-cases-world-health-organisation">warned that the outbreak could see 10,000 new cases a week within two months</a>.</p> <p>Dr Bruce Aylward, the WHO assistant director-general, said the number of new cases was likely to be between 5,000 and 10,000 a week by early December. While official figures show 4,447 deaths from 8,914 reported cases, Aylward said many deaths are not recorded officially, and it seemed only 30% of people were surviving, particularly in the hardest hit countries of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543e469be4b01d51bd0b0384" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-15T11:17:43.565+01:00">11.17am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Second US healthcare worker tests positive for Ebola</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>The rapid global spread of the Ebola outbreak has been reinforced with the news that <strong>a second Texas healthcare worker has tested positive for the virus </strong>after having treated the first patient in the US to be diagnosed with the illness.</p> <p>The worker, as yet unnamed, helped to care for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/thomas-eric-duncan-liberia-ebola-war-texas-family-obituary">Thomas Eric Duncan</a>, a Liberian man who contracted the disease before arriving in the US and dying at the Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in Dallas last Wednesday. The worker was immediately isolated after reporting a fever on Tuesday, the department of state health services says.</p> <p>A nurse, 26-year-old Nina Pham, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition">became the first person infected with Ebola in the US</a> while caring for Duncan during much of his 11 days in the hospital. </p> <p>But while the spread to the US has created headlines, this is, of course, a global issue, with the crisis centred in west Africa, where virtually all the deaths so far recorded have taken place.<br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-15T16:39:47.231+01:00">at 4.39pm BST</time></p>  </div>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/15/ebola-outbreak-central-africa-contained <p>As the world has rightly focused on the response to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/ebola" title="">terrible outbreak of Ebola in West Africa</a>, and the new cases in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/07/ebola-europe-unavoidable-who-spain" title="">Europe</a> and the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/01/ebola-us-risks-response-first-case" title="">US</a>, another unrelated Ebola outbreak has taken place in the Equateur province of the Democratic Republic of Congo. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/25/ebola-outbreak-congo-confirms-disease-cases" title="">It began in August</a> in the village of Ikanamongo and, as with all other outbreaks, was triggered when the Ebola virus crossed the species barrier between animals and humans and infected one person before spreading to others.</p> <p>It is thought that the first person to contract the virus in Ikanamongo was a woman, infected while butchering wild game to cook for a family meal. The outbreak caused around 70 infections and 43 deaths. But, unlike in West Africa, the last known case occurred around three weeks ago and the outbreak will likely soon be declared fully contained by the World Health Organisation.</p> <p>In today’s globalised world, it is almost certain there will be more Ebola cases reaching Europe and the US – despite the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/ebola-screenings-heathrow-airport-mixed-response" title="">airport screening</a> programme launched this week in several countries. Given this, and the fact that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/who-new-ebola-cases-world-health-organisation" title="">current estimates predict the rate of infection will rise</a> to 10,000 cases per week by December, it is vital that the lessons of how to defeat Ebola are learned quickly.</p> <p>Once the DRC outbreak was reported to health officials in Kinshasa, the response was rapid – a team that had contained numerous outbreaks in the past was brought in. It was headed by Jean-Jacques Muyembe, a professor of microbiology and now director of the DRC National Institute of Biomedical Research, who was the first medic to arrive in Yambuku when the first known outbreak occurred in 1976.</p> <p>His team has contained more than 10 outbreaks in the country and, with others in countries such as Uganda, has demonstrated that a rapid and robust response can stop rural outbreaks before they spread to major urban areas and across international borders. In fact, in 1995 the DRC team prevented a potential outbreak in Kinshasa, the capital city with a population of 9 million, when a patient from an <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00037078.htm" title="">outbreak in Kikwit</a>, five hours away by road, made his way to a hospital there.</p> <p>It was at Kikwit that the three basic public health strategies to prevent Ebola outbreaks were tested and proven. They are: rapid identification and isolation of those with the Ebola infection in controlled health facilities where workers are protected; tracing everyone who has been in contact with an infected person and monitoring their temperature for 21 days, with those who develop the Ebola fever isolated at a health facility; and helping local people understand how to protect themselves while providing safe patient transport and burial, and working with village chiefs and elders to help quell rumours about the origins of disease.</p> <p>So what has gone wrong in the current tragic outbreak in West Africa? First, by the time the rural infection was reported it had spread to several communities and the initial response was not robust enough to contain it. Now, urban areas are affected, where community organisation is less structured and effective, and where trust in government is low because of recent civil conflict. At the same time, the health system has collapsed in several areas where health workers have been infected, making it a challenge to ensure patients are isolated from their families.</p> <p>Rumours about what has caused the outbreaks and what is done at healthcare facilities always accompany rural outbreaks, and these have been amplified in urban areas where the virus is now spreading. At the same time, with greater population density and mobility in the cities, tracing contacts and monitoring their temperature has been difficult.</p> <p>It is essential that as many lives as possible are saved while attempts to stop the outbreak are under way. Fluid replacement for those who are sick is essential, orally if possible, then intravenously to keep patients alive so that their immune systems can work to defeat the virus. This alone will be lifesaving in some. At the same time, clinical trials of the candidate vaccines and medicines that have been developed in North America and elsewhere must now be studied in humans.</p> <p>New and innovative ways are already being found to compensate for the weakened public health systems in the three most affected countries. In Sierra Leone, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/19/sierra-leone-three-day-shutdown-ebola-outbreak" title="">people were confined to their homes</a> for a three-day period and information about Ebola was given to more than 70% of the households in outbreak areas. This was controversial: would there be facilities to isolate patients who were identified; would there be burial teams to carry away the dead? But it was accomplished without the dire consequences predicted by many outside the country.</p> <p>Other innovations might include using mobile phones to trace contacts or help people with fever understand where they can report for diagnosis. Another might be modifying community care centres so they can be used for Ebola patients – especially important in providing diagnosis, treatment and isolation of patients whose numbers have surpassed available hospital beds. Muyembe and his teams in the DRC have given protective materials to rural families who insist on keeping patients at home – monitored daily by the outbreak control teams. Though the effectiveness of this method is now being assessed, where it was used rural outbreaks have been successfully contained within months.</p> <p>Support from international partners is rapidly increasing in West Africa – goodwill is abundant – and this is essential for success, even though President Obama declared this week that the world “<a href="http://www.reuters.com/video/2014/10/14/obama-world-is-not-doing-enough-to-conta?videoId=346569829" title="">is not doing enough</a>” to combat the disease. But it is important to remember the lessons from Haiti after the 2010 earthquake. When a major cholera outbreak occurred, the international response was generous, but <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/dec/28/haiti-cholera-earthquake-aid-agencies-failure" title="">much of the coordination was ineffective</a>, resulting in duplication of effort, while gaps in the essential response remained.</p> <p>Despite the early lack of coordination in West Africa, and despite declarations that this outbreak is more difficult to contain because of poverty, recent civil disturbance and war, there is no time for excuses. With support from the UN, government efforts must be strengthened. The errors made in Haiti must not now recur in West Africa, where every day lives continue to be lost.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/texas-ebola-nurse-dog <p>While his owner, Nina Pham, remains hospitalised with Ebola, a one-year-old King Charles spaniel named Bentley has been temporarily moved to a decommissioned naval air base in Dallas, city officials said. </p> <p>Bentley has been given comfortable bedding, toys and plenty of room to run around at the former residence of the executive officer at the decommissioned Hensley Field, the city spokeswoman, Sana Syed, said on Tuesday. </p> <p>Bentley was moved on Monday from Pham’s apartment to his new home, where he will be monitored for 21 days. Syed has been providing updates <a href="https://twitter.com/dallaspiosana">via social media</a> on Bentley’s care after Dallas’s Mayor Mike Rawlings vowed to do everything in their power to care for the Texas nurse’s beloved pet.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="6d30249d177f3eaa6a28122c61734df9d1e3d49f"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/15/1413399441175/28bdd4d1-d4e6-445c-8332-8345043f6812-460x276.jpeg" alt="ebola dog" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Bentley is removed from Nina Pham’s home.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/dallaspiosana/statuses/522212079705411585">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Dr. Beckam -vet who cared for Bentley tonight. She hugged him and took good care of him. <a href="https://twitter.com/1500Marilla">@1500Marilla</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/DallasShelter">@DallasShelter</a> <a href="http://t.co/UNFc7tawz3">pic.twitter.com/UNFc7tawz3</a></p>&mdash; Sana Syed (@dallaspiosana) <a href="https://twitter.com/dallaspiosana/status/522212079705411585">October 15, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <p>The Dallas animal shelter, which is caring for Bentley, <a href="https://twitter.com/DallasShelter/status/522414639892951040">said on Wednesday</a> he was “bright and alert … Looking good and happy to see us.” </p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/dallaspiosana/statuses/522065774525952000">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Best part of my job? Authorities were concerned the dog might be harboring the virus.</p> <p>The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says there have been no reports of pets spreading Ebola to people or other animals.</p> <p><em>The Associated Press contributed to this report.</em></p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/uk-landlords-refuse-house-student-sierra-leone-ebola-fears <p>A radio presenter from Sierra Leone who had been broadcasting a myth-busting show about Ebola in his home country was refused accommodation when he arrived to study at the University of East Anglia this month because landlords feared he may have brought the killer virus with him.</p> <p>Amara Bangura, 35, from the capital Freetown, has told the BBC he was refused lodgings by two separate landlords who had been happy to rent him accommodation in Norwich until they saw his passport and found out he was from one of the worst-hit Ebola hotspots.</p> <p>The broadcaster, who had used his weekly radio show in Sierra Leone to dispel myths about the disease, said he was devastated to be turned down.</p> <p>“It’s very unreasonable,” he told the BBC. “And if you think everybody coming from Sierra Leone is affected, then that’s just completely unfair.”</p> <p>One of the landlords reportedly told him in a refusal letter: “Under normal circumstance[s] your profile would be a great profile to be one of our lodgers.</p> <p>“However, given that the world is about to probably experience an Ebola epidemic, we have decided not to accept anyone that has been anywhere near the outbreak within the last two months, or is likely to visit those areas in the near future.”</p> <p>Bangura has now found a place to stay and has given a presentation on the Ebola outbreak in Africa to students at the university.</p> <p>A senior officer at the UEA students’ union said the landlords’ behaviour was “absolutely disgusting”.</p> <p>Holly Staynor, welfare, community and diversity officer at the union, said: “There is no way we should be discriminating against any students.”</p> <p>Bangura’s show is networked to 35 stations across the west African country through BBC Media Action, and aims to educate, inform and warn listeners about the disease.</p> <p>He told the Guardian last week: “You have to deal with the issues of myth, you have to deal with the issues of religion, you have to answer questions about prevention and how to stay safe”.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/15/ebola-funds-disease-outpaces-aid <p>Governments have pledged millions of dollars of aid, volunteer medics are signing up to work on the frontline and individuals are digging into their pockets to address what the World Health Organisation (WHO) calls “unquestionably the most severe acute public health emergency in modern times”. But with death tolls relentlessly rising, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-outbreak-response-breakdown-key-funding-pledges">the biggest donors</a> are increasingly calling on other countries to step up.</p> <p>While there has, so far, been no “naming and shaming” of countries deemed to be dragging their feet, President Barack Obama reiterated on Tuesday that “the world as a whole is not doing enough”.</p> <p>The UN has said it will cost just under $1bn to tackle Ebola over the next six months. On Wednesday, the WHO said $257m had been received, or 26% of what the UN says is needed, with another $162m pledged.</p> <p><a href="https://extranet.who.int/ebola/#/resources">The WHO estimates that it alone will need $260m</a>. It still has a $93m shortfall. One of the greatest challenges, said WHO communications officer Fadela Chaib, is to get treatment centres fully operational and bring in more health workers.</p> <p>“WHO is working closely with governments and partners at the highest level to recruit teams and deploy resources and equipment. But the response is slow. We need 3.3m items of high-quality personal protective equipment and training provision of Ebola treatment centres,” Chaib said. Many countries have provided health workers, including Cuba – with 165 workers sent to Sierra Leone – China, Canada, Russia and Uganda.</p>  <figure class="element element-embed" data-alt="Ebola funding per citizen chart">  <iframe src="http://cf.datawrapper.de/6APr9/2/" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" webkitallowfullscreen="webkitallowfullscreen" mozallowfullscreen="mozallowfullscreen" oallowfullscreen="oallowfullscreen" msallowfullscreen="msallowfullscreen" width="460" height="400"></iframe> </figure>  <p>Marcus Manuel, a senior research associate at the Overseas Development Institute (ODI), said initially some G7 countries had seen the Ebola crisis as mainly a problem for countries with historical links to the west African region.</p> <p>“There is an issue of burden-sharing within the G7. That partly reflects long-term historical links that the US has with Liberia and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/crew-british-hospital-ship-sierra-leone-ebola-mission">the UK with Sierra Leone</a> … Now we are seeing that others are realising that this is a global emergency,” he said.</p> <p>One of the unique characteristics of this global emergency is how quickly Ebola is spreading, meaning that estimates of what aid – funds, personnel, equipment – is needed are being outpaced by the spread of the disease, which has already killed about 4,500 people in west Africa. On Tuesday, Dr Bruce Aylward, the WHO’s assistant director general, said the number of new cases was likely to be 5,000-10,000 a week by early December.</p> <p>To illustrate the scale of the needs and the rapidity at which they are changing, Manuel pointed out that British and American plans to build treatment centres in west Africa were unlikely to deliver new beds until mid-December at the earliest. And even then, the total would probably only be about 3,000 beds.</p> <p>“The issue is not just about money,” Manuel said. “The cases keep growing … original estimates quickly run out of time … That’s what’s overwhelming people at the moment. Each person is infecting another two people. That’s the challenge. The numbers don’t add up.”</p> <p>The US and the UK have led the calls for other nations to step forward.</p> <p>“Many countries are already contributing, but the scale of needs is dramatic,” the US secretary of state, John Kerry, said last week. “The US has contributed $113m to the UN response. Smaller countries have stepped up to the plate – some quite remarkably. Some smaller countries are contributing way above their per capita population. But the fact is more countries can and must step up to make their contributions felt … There are not enough countries to make the difference to be able to deal with this crisis. We need more nations – every nation has an ability to do something on this challenge.”</p> <p>Samantha Power, the US ambassador to the UN, has praised Cuba and Timor-Leste for “punching far above their weight” with their contributions to the global response.</p> <p>“According to the UN’s financial tracking service, only 24 countries have pledged $1m or more to the efforts,” Power told the general assembly last week.</p> <p>The <a href="http://fts.unocha.org/reports/daily/ocha_R10_E16506_asof___1410150300.pdf">UN financial tracking service</a> (pdf) lists funding pledges from countries, philanthropic associations and international bodies such as UN agencies. Notable absentees from the list include Saudi Arabia and Turkey. The Organisation of Islamic Cooperation and Islamic Development Bank are organising a conference on 5 November in Jeddah.</p> <p>Manuel said another issue was that pledges did not always translate into hard cash. There is also concern that amid the plethora of pledges, some funds may be recycled money.</p> <p>The head of the <a href="http://www.afdb.org/en/">African Development Bank</a>, Donald Kaberuka, said on Saturday that <a href="http://news.yahoo.com/ebola-funds-not-repackaged-aid-africa-bank-chief-072224137--business.html">he was worried some donors were repackaging aid money</a>, funnelling it away from other areas in the three countries at the centre for the epidemic.</p> <p>Kaberuka said moving funds from already allocated development projects in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone was unhelpful in the long term and would make their rebuilding harder. He said new money was needed, and criticised the international response as too little, too late.</p> <p>Individuals are also digging into their pockets. Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Dr Priscilla Chan, are donating $25m to the <a href="http://www.cdcfoundation.org/">CDC Foundation</a>, a private non-profit organisation gathering donations for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.</p> <p>Africa’s richest man, the Nigerian Aliko Dangote, provided about $900,000 to help Nigeria contain the disease, according to the UN list.</p> <p>Across the world, people are also offering to use their medical skills to treat people. The global campaigning organisation Avaaz said on Wednesday that more than 360 doctors, nurses and medical workers were among about 2,000 people who answered its call for qualified volunteers to fight Ebola in west Africa.</p> <p>“This is a stunning outpouring of courage and humanity. But it’s not just admirable, it’s necessary. To overcome Ebola and much more, we need to build a world of care and bravery without borders,” said Ricken Patel, executive director of Avaaz.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/oct/15/ebola-crisis-liberia-peace-building-conflict-pen-pen <p>The Liberian government responded slowly to the Ebola crisis, asking the international community to do <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/06/ebola-liberia-health-funds-africa-summit">what some have argued</a> it should have done itself. Now, there are indicators that the government is dependent on the goodwill of the international community for both manpower and basic supplies.<br /></p> <p>As a result, the most frustrated and marginalised citizens have taken to the streets. In late July, residents in Montserrado county <a href="http://allafrica.com/stories/201408051258.html">blocked a major highway</a>, demanding that the government remove three dead bodies from their community. Distressed citizens have <a href="http://www.npr.org/blogs/goatsandsoda/2014/08/15/340401807/radio-in-liberia-seems-like-its-all-ebola-all-the-time">called in to radio shows</a>, telling how they were forced to sleep in the streets while <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/09/liberia-ebola-bodies_n_5664559.html">waiting for authorities to remove dead bodies</a> from their homes. The government responded by <a href="http://allafrica.com/stories/201409011222.html">implementing a 9pm-6am curfew</a> to prevent people from coming out at night to throw out bodies or secretly bury their dead. The curfew <a href="http://www.voanews.com/content/liberia-modifies-ebola-curfew-hours-lifts-another-quarantine/2443351.html">has been lifted to a degree</a> but many still question the logic behind it. </p> <p>But local organisations have taken matters into their own hands and are engaging in awareness activities to reach out to populations in Monrovia and beyond. One successful local initiative is the <a href="http://buildingpeaceforum.com/2014/09/peacebuilding-with-local-citizens/">Pen-Pen Peace Network</a> which, since the outbreak, has expanded its role from post-civil war peacebuilding to fighting Ebola at the community level. So far, the network has built hand-washing and sanitising stations for citizens, communicated information about Ebola prevention through loudspeakers, and distributed 3,000 factsheets throughout communities.</p> <p>The inclusion of pen-pen (motorcycle taxi) drivers in the fight against Ebola is just the most recent step forward in the drivers’ integration into civilian life since the end of the Liberian civil war. As the country engaged in post-war processes, funds were provided to ex-combatants to disarm and many of them <a href="http://edition.cnn.com/2013/10/07/world/africa/easy-riders-liberia-bikers/">used these funds to buy motorcycles</a> (pen-pens). </p> <p>Although pen-pen drivers have become valued service providers, they are also often perceived as outcasts. Some have been hired by criminal entities to engage in illicit activity, or by political parties to intimidate and harass opponents during elections. These factors motivated the <a href="http://www.cla.purdue.edu/ppp/">Purdue Peace Project</a> (PPP) to work with pen-pen drivers and community members who regularly interact with them. The Pen-Pen Peace Network was created as an opportunity for drivers, police, the ministry of transport, customers, and community members to talk with each other and develop peace-building strategies.</p> <p>Most recently, the Pen-Pen Peace Network has launched a public awareness campaign in communities within Monrovia to educate citizens about Ebola. Liberia’s ministry of health and social welfare has trained and employed pen-pen drivers to disseminate information on virus transmission and prevention, to encourage safe practices among citizens and fellow drivers, and to attempt to reduce the continued risk of civil unrest against aid workers. The drivers’ ability to speak local dialects helps to address the concerns of distressed citizens. </p> <p>There is evidence to suggest that Pen-Pen Peace Network’s initial post-war peace-building efforts <a href="http://www.cla.purdue.edu/ppp/documents/EbolaCampaignExecutiveSummary%2010.7.14.pdf">have been accepted</a> by community members and this appears to have carried over into their Ebola awareness campaign. Preliminary analysis by the Purdue Peace Project suggests Liberians listen to the drivers’ messages because they are everyday citizens.</p> <p>There are other initiatives addressing Ebola-related violence in Liberia. The <a href="http://lern.ushahidi.com/">Early Warning and Early Response Working Group</a>, a network of local civil society organisations, governments and United Nations representatives, recently launched a campaign in four hard-to-reach counties. The <a href="http://www.irex.org/">International Research &amp; Exchanges Board</a> (IREX) is working to help civil society and media groups organise forums to discuss issues around the Ebola crisis, while urging constructive engagement with the government. </p> <p>Challenges still exist, however, especially in addressing communities outside of Monrovia. There is no clear government support to empower health workers and social mobilisation committees to carry out community-driven response activities beyond the capital. Unless the fight against the spread of Ebola is expanded beyond Monrovia and is fully decentralised to county, district, and community levels, and adequate support is provided to caregivers and health practitioners, many more people will die.</p> <p>This is a sad reality, but initiatives like the Pen-Pen Peace Network drive home the message that local citizens can be effective peacebuilders. The government and its partners should take keen note of this and consider identifying, strengthening, and supporting community-led structures, especially in counties not yet affected by the virus.<br /></p> <p><em>Nat Walker is Liberia correspondent for <a href="http://www.insightonconflict.org/">Insight on Conflict</a>. Stacey Connaughton is director of <a href="http://www.cla.purdue.edu/ppp/">The Purdue Peace Project</a>. Kai Kuang is a teaching assistant at Purdue Liberal Arts. Follow <a href="https://twitter.com/PurduePeaceProj">@PurduePeaceProj</a> on Twitter. </em><br /></p> <p><em>This article draws on two blogs posts from </em><em><a href="http://buildingpeaceforum.com/2014/09/fighting-the-spread-of-ebola-in-a-weak-and-poor-governance-structure-a-liberian-peacebuilders-perspective/">Latest Insight</a></em><em> and <a href="http://buildingpeaceforum.com/2014/09/peacebuilding-with-local-citizens/">Building Peace</a> magazine. <br /></em></p> <p><strong><strong><strong><strong>Read more stories like this:</strong></strong></strong></strong></p> <p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/oct/09/ebola-response-diaspora-sierra-leone">Ebola: the story of the Sierra Leone diaspora response that no one is telling</a><br /><br />• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jul/31/1993-genocide-burundi-peace-new-generation">Killers to healers: training Burundi’s youth to choose peace</a> <br /><br />• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/sep/29/media-and-communications-the-first-line-of-defence-against-ebola">Media and communications: the first line of defence against Ebola</a><br /><br />• Advertisement feature: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/malaria-consortium-partner-zone/2014/aug/28/harmonisation-improving-support-for-malaria-control">Harmonisation: improving support for malaria control</a></p> <p><strong><strong><strong><strong><a href="https://register.theguardian.com/global-development/">Join our community</a> of development professionals and humanitarians. http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/ebola-epidemic-2014-timeline <h2><strong>28 December 2013</strong> </h2> <p>A <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/23/ebola-outbreak-blamed-on-fruit-bats-africa">two-year-old child</a>, identified only as Emile, dies of an unidentified haemorraghic fever in the town of Guéckédou in Guinea, followed by his mother, sister and grandmother. Mourners at the grandmother’s funeral, together with a healthcare worker, carry the virus to nearby villages. </p> <h2><strong>22 March 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>Guinea reports that the fever has been confirmed as Ebola, and has already killed 59 people. There are already concerns that it may have spread to neighbouring Sierra Leone.</p> <h2><strong>28 March 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>Two Ebola cases are reported in Liberia among people who have been to Guinea.</p> <h2><strong>26 May 2014 <br /></strong></h2> <p>Ebola has reached Sierra Leone, the World Health Organization (WHO) confirms. Four months later, an increasingly desperate government will <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/sep/21/ebola-lockdown-ends-sierra-leone">bar people from leaving their homes</a> for three days in a bid to halt the spread of the virus.</p> <h2><strong>20 July 2014</strong> <br /></h2> <p>Liberian government employee <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/25/first-case-ebola-lagos-nigeria">Patrick Sawyer arrives in the 21-million-strong city of Lagos</a> in Nigeria and collapses, having flown from Liberia with a lay-over in Togo. He dies of Ebola five days later, sparking concerns about the ease with which the virus might jump borders. </p> <h2><strong>27 July 2014</strong></h2> <p>Liberia shuts down most of its border crossings. <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-28560507">Dr Sheik Umar Khan</a>, who played a pioneering role in Sierra Leone’s response to the virus, dies two days later after becoming infected.</p> <h2><strong>8 August 2014</strong></h2> <p>The WHO declares Ebola an <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/08/who-ebola-outbreak-international-public-health-emergency">“international health emergency”</a>. Four days later, the death toll exceeds 1,000.</p> <h2><strong>12 August 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>After some debate, the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/12/world-health-organisation-allow-unlicensed-ebola-drugs-west-africa">WHO gives its cautious blessing </a>to the use of experimental drugs to treat Ebola. The fact that there were no approved drugs available points to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/oct/05/ebola-america-range-big-pharma">the lack of financial incentive </a>to develop such interventions previously. </p> <h2><strong>22 August 2014</strong> <br /></h2> <p>A doctor in Nigeria’s oil hub Port Harcourt dies of Ebola, the second death on Nigerian soil. Fears rise for how quickly the virus may spread in Africa’s most populous country, but Nigeria goes on to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2014/oct/07/nigeria-ebola-experience-teach-world">demonstrate apparent success</a> in containing it.</p> <h2><strong>24 August 2014</strong> <br /></h2> <p>British volunteer nurse <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/25/family-ebola-patient-william-pooley-doctors-uk-government">William Pooley is flown back to the UK</a> for emergency treatment after contracting Ebola while helping treat patients in Sierra Leone. Pooley,29, goes on to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/sep/09/william-pooley-ebola-sierra-leone-outbreak-epidemic">make a full recovery.</a> </p> <h2><strong>26 August 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>The health ministry of the Democratic Republic of Congo informs the WHO of an outbreak of Ebola which is later confirmed to be a different strain to that affecting west Africa.</p> <h2><strong>27 August 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>Médecins Sans Frontières calls the international response to Ebola “irresponsible” and “slow and derisory”, saying health services in the affected countries needed to be bolstered with operational support rather than politicians’ empty promises</p> <h2> <strong>29 August 2014</strong> <br /></h2> <p>Senegal becomes the fifth country to be hit by Ebola, while riots break out in neighbouring Guinea over rumours that health workers are deliberately transmitting the virus to locals.</p> <h2><strong>5 September 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>With the pace of the epidemic accelerating, WHO figures suggest that 2,100 people have died from a total of around 4,000 who are thought to have been infected.</p> <h2><strong>16 September 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>Barack Obama announces that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/sep/16/obama-to-announce-ebola-force-of-3000-us-military-personnel">the US will send 3,000 troops</a> to west Africa to build Ebola treatment centres and establish a military coordination centre. The epidemic, Obama says, is “spiralling out of control”. </p> <h2><strong>26 September 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>WHO puts the death toll at 3,091 of 6,574 suspected cases. Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone remain the hardest-hit countries, with Nigeria and Senegal faring better.</p> <h2><strong>29 September 2014 </strong><br /></h2> <p>Thomas Duncan, who flew from Monrovia to Dallas via Brussels and Washington, becomes <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/05/ebola-cdc-thomas-frieden-confident-large-number-cases">the first person to be diagnosed with Ebola while on US soil</a>, and dies just over a week later. Two healthcare workers who treated Duncan go on to test positive for Ebola, with nurse Nina Pham becoming <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition">the first person to contract Ebola while within the US</a>.</p> <h2><strong>7 October 2014</strong> <br /></h2> <p>A Spanish nurse becomes <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/06/nurse-spain-tests-positive-ebola">the first person to contract the virus outside west Africa</a>. Madrid-based Teresa Romero Ramos had been treating a Spanish priest who was flown home after contracting Ebola in Sierra Leone. The diagnosis <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/07/ebola-crisis-substandard-equipment-nurse-positive-spain">raises concerns over Europe’s state of readiness</a> to deal with the virus. </p> <h2>9 October 2014</h2> <p>The UK announces that it will introduce <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/uk-screening-airports-ebola-symptoms">temperature screening for passengers</a> arriving at Gatwick and Heathrow airports from west Africa. In the US, New York’s JFK airport starts <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/11/ebola-crisis-new-york-jfk-airport-passenger-screening">enhanced Ebola screenings</a> on 11 October.</p> <h2>14 October 2014</h2> <p>WHO announces that the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/who-new-ebola-cases-world-health-organisation">fatality rate from Ebola has reached 70%</a>, with the total number of deaths so far topping 4,447.</p> <h2><br /></h2>
http://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/ng-interactive/2014/oct/15/visualised-how-ebola-compares-to-other-infectious-diseases <figure class="element element-embed" data-canonical-url="http://infobeautiful2.s3.amazonaws.com/940_Microbescope.png" data-alt="Visualised: how Ebola compares to other infectious diseases">  <iframe frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="0" marginwidth="0" allowfullscreen width="100%" height="636" src="http://infobeautiful2.s3.amazonaws.com/svg_microbescope.svg"></iframe> <figcaption><em>by David McCandless @ <a href="http://www.informationisbeautiful.net/">Information is Beautiful<br></a><br></em><em>Data: <a href="http://bit.ly/KIB_Microbescope">http://bit.ly/KIB_Microbescope <br></a></em><em><br></em><em>Sources: Centres for Disease Control, World Health Organisation, CIDRAP, Public Health Agency of Canada, studies. </em><em><br><br> <br></em></figcaption> </figure>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/15/david-cameron-ebola-crisis-barack-obama-eu-leaders <p>David Cameron is to take part in a video conference call on Wednesday afternoon with Barack Obama and EU leaders to discuss the growing Ebola crisis amid warnings that the outbreak could grow to 10,000 new cases a week within two months.</p> <p>As the death toll from the virus reached 4,447 people, nearly all of them in west Africa, Downing Street confirmed that the prime minister would join a conference call with Obama and the leaders of France, Germany and Italy.</p> <p>It is understood that the leaders will discuss what further action can be taken to help stop the spread of the virus in west Africa.</p> <p>They will also discuss the steps that are being taken to screen air passengers arriving in Europe and the EU from west Africa.</p> <p>The news of the conference call came after Dr Bruce Aylward, assistant director-general of the World Health Organisation (WHO), told a news conference in Geneva that the number of new cases was likely to be between 5,000 and 10,000 a week by early December.</p> <p>Aylward told a news conference in Geneva on Tuesday that the number of new cases was likely to be between 5,000 and 10,000 a week by early December.</p> <p>WHO’s regular updates show that deaths have resulted from 4,447 of the 8,914 reported cases, but Aylward said that any assumption that the death rate was 50% would be wrong. He put the death rate at 70% because many deaths are not reported or recorded officially.</p> <p>Where detailed investigations have been carried out, it was clear that only 30% of people were surviving, he said, adding that the figure was almost exactly the same in the three hardest hit countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. “This is a high-mortality disease in any circumstances but particularly in these places,” said Aylward, adding that it was not the WHO’s job to judge how different countries responded to the Ebola outbreak.</p> <p>The grim forecast came as the first returning passengers from west Africa to Heathrow airport were asked to undergo temperature checks and questionnaires about their contacts with Ebola patients. The £9m screening exercise has been criticised by some experts, who say it will not pick up those who have the virus but are not yet symptomatic.</p> <p>In the US, it emerged that a nurse who contracted Ebola has been given a blood transfusion from Dr Kent Brantly, who has recovered from the disease. The nurse, Nina Pham, was infected while caring for Thomas Duncan, who was taken ill on a visit from Liberia and died in Texas Health Presbyterian hospital, Dallas.</p> <p>Brantly has donated blood for three Ebola patients, including Pham. “He’s a doctor. That’s what he’s there to do. That’s his heart,” said Jeremy Blume, a spokesman for the non-profit medical mission group Samaritan’s Purse, which Brantly was working for in Liberia. The WHO said plasma from people who had overcome Ebola, which contains antibodies against the virus, should be tried as a treatment, but it is hard to use outside the sophisticated healthcare settings of the west.</p> <p>The US president said on Tuesday night that the “world is not doing enough” to combat the disease, and that “everybody’s going to have to do more than they are doing right now”. Obama said he wants to make sure lessons learned from Pham’s case are applied to health centres around the US.</p> <p>The UN Mission for Ebola Emergency Response, newly set up to coordinate the fight against the disease, has set targets to isolate 70% of suspected cases in west Africa and safely bury 70% of the dead within the next 60 days – described as the 70-70-60 plan.</p> <p>It is a tough target, said Aylward, but if it takes 90 days rather than 60, “a lot more people will die who shouldn’t and we will need that much more capacity on the ground to manage the caseload”.</p> <p>As the numbers continue to rise, the need for beds and health personnel to treat the sick will increase – and there is a serious shortage of trained and experienced people to lead the effort, according to Aylward.</p> <p>Good training programmes are being put in place, particularly by the UK and the US, “but there is still the challenge of getting internationals on the ground who have expertise – in Ebola ideally”.</p> <p>For the past four weeks, about 1,000 new infections a week – including suspected, confirmed and probable cases – have come to light. Aylward said the WHO was concerned about the continued spread, especially in the capital cities of Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia – Freetown, Conakry and Monrovia.</p> <p>“The virus is still moving geographically and escalating in the capitals,” he said. Large treatment centres are taking a long time to build and staff and those that exist are full. A new strategy, which the UK is supporting in Sierra Leone, is to set up a lot of community care units with a handful of beds, where people can stay and get basic care rather than endangering their families at home, while waiting for a treatment centre bed.</p> <p>The units will also help people arriving with fever because they have malaria. At the moment, they are not being treated or are afraid to go to hospital.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/nina-pham-ebola-texas-nurse-well-hospital-condition <p>The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is establishing an Ebola response team that will be immediately dispatched to any hospital with a confirmed case of the disease.</p> <p>At a press briefing on Tuesday, CDC director Tom Frieden conceded that the agency should have sent a larger team to Dallas when Thomas Eric Duncan, a Liberian man who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-patient-dies-texas-thomas-eric-duncan">contracted the disease</a> before arriving in the US, tested positive for Ebola two weeks ago. Duncan died in hospital last Wednesday.</p> <p>“That might have prevented this infection,” Frieden said. “Ebola is unfamiliar. It’s scary and getting it right is really important because the stakes are so high,” he added.</p> <p>Frieden said investigators have still not identified the apparent breach in protocol that led to Nina Pham, a nurse who cared for Duncan, contracting the virus. Healthcare workers wore gowns, gloves, masks and face shields when treating Duncan.<br /></p> <p>Regardless, Frieden said enhanced safety measures are already being implemented in Dallas, including the addition of a round-the-clock site manager to help enforce infection control procedures. Two nurses from Emory University hospital in Atlanta, home to one of the nation’s four bio-containment units, were sent to Dallas where they will train hospital staff.</p> <p>The CDC is also recommending that hospitals limit the number of staff involved in an Ebola’s patients care. Pham, 26, was one of 76 healthcare workers at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital who may have come into contact with Duncan or his blood while he was being treated. Pham entered Duncan’s intensive care unit often, and cared for Duncan a day before he died last week, according to medical records.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="67e1b4e1f2a872b4304cdd436308ab9fddd47e42"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/14/1413306575178/345eb2f2-3048-4dea-92ce-4d9c81dfa664-bestSizeAvailable.jpeg" alt="This 2010 photo provided of Nina Pham, 26, who became the first person to contract the disease within the United States. " width="450" height="270" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">This 2010 photo provided of Nina Pham, 26, who became the first person to contract the disease within the United States.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Members of the medical team that treated Duncan were instructed to self-monitor for 21 days, the disease’s incubation period. Pham was admitted to hospital and placed in isolation on Saturday <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/texan-healthcare-worker-ebola-thomas-duncan-us">after reporting a slight fever</a>, the hospital said. The following day, the CDC confirmed that she had tested positive for Ebola. </p> <p>Pham, who has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/dallas-nurse-ebola-transfusion-kent-brantly">received blood plasma</a> from an American, Dr Kent Brantley, who recovered from Ebola earlier this year, said she is “doing well” in a statement released by the hospital on Tuesday.</p> <p>“I’m doing well and want to thank everyone for their kind wishes and prayers,” Pham said. “I am blessed by the support of family and friends and am blessed to be cared for by the best team of doctors and nurses in the world here at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas.”</p> <p>A man who had contact with Pham before she became symptomatic is being “actively monitored” by health officials, as is her dog, Texas health commissioner David Lakey said on Tuesday.</p> <p>The 48 people who are believed to have had varying degrees of contact with Duncan are all still being monitored for symptoms. Frieden said they’ve passed the riskiest period of their 21-day incubation, and an infection at this point would be “unusual”.</p> <p>The deepening Ebola crisis in west Africa has claimed the lives of more than 4,000 people. </p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/14/ebola-not-another-dustin-hoffman-germ-thriller <p>I must confess: I was initially concerned that I am perhaps not sufficiently qualified to weigh in on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/who-new-ebola-cases-world-health-organisation" title="">our planet’s current Ebola panic</a>, seeing as I am neither a doctor nor a nurse nor a scientist of any kind nor an African fruit bat nor Dustin Hoffman.</p> <p>But then I discovered that singer and odious woman-puncher Chris Brown had recently offered his opinion on the matter (he thinks “this Ebola epidemic is a form of population control”, which is technically true, I guess, though not in the intentional, cosmic way I suspect he means); and so has bleating conspiracy theorist Dinesh D’Souza, who called Obama’s African roots <a href="https://www.facebook.com/DSouzaDinesh/photos/a.279556495404346.96395.216709768355686/968061683220487/?type=1" title="">a “more dangerous infection” than the virus itself</a>; and so has psychiatrist and large animatronic thumb Keith Ablow, who alleged that President Obama <a href="http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2014/10/09/ebola-outbreak-why-obama-is-allowing-ebolaphobia-to-spread/" title="">“may literally believe we should suffer along with less fortunate nations … allowing illegal immigrants and, potentially, even diseases to flow through”</a> – and I realised that I am more qualified to comment than at least three famous idiots who have already inflicted their opinions on millions and millions of people. After all, I read <a href="http://bookshop.theguardian.com/hot-zone.html" title="">The Hot Zone</a> when I was 14. I bet Chris Brown <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2014/apr/04/my-guilty-pleasure-outbreak" title="">hasn’t even seen Outbreak</a>. And you call yourself an armchair epidemiologist, sir. The gall.</p> <p>And anyway, there is one area in which I am eminently, objectively pedigreed to comment – relative to famous idiots or not – and that is in my capacity as a human being living in a culture where panic is marketed as both disposable entertainment and a way of life.</p> <p>Realistically, something will wipe us out eventually, though it probably won’t be Ebola. We’re hurtling toward a wall, even if we can’t see what it’s made of or when we’ll hit. Again, I’m not a doctor (so <em>please</em> stop emailing me pictures of your weird toe), but I’m a fairly educated, competent adult and I hate the way we talk about this stuff – like it’s simultaneously the end of the world and just another fun Dustin Hoffman germ-thriller. It’s a dead end. You can’t fix the apocalypse, and there’s no reason to fix fun.</p> <p>Somehow, in America at least, we seem to be taking Ebola both too seriously and not seriously enough. Rightwing xenophobes rage about closing the borders and impeaching #OBOLA (heads up, white Americans: if anyone has a track record of deliberately introducing devastating diseases to the North American continent in order to wipe out the population, it’s not half-Kenyan lawyers), while the rest of us titter proprietarily over <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/09/ebola-africa-paying-price-progress-at-risk" title="">the gory doom that we know will almost certainly never touch us</a>; meanwhile, we’ve skimped on funding infectious disease research ever since the 90s Ebola scare lost its lurid lustre, and healthcare workers are paying the price. <a href="http://www.wired.com/2014/10/ebola-ic-research/" title="">As Wired reported on Monday</a>: “If there were more infection-prevention research, the nurse in Dallas (and probably the one in Spain, who may have contaminated herself doffing her gear) might not have become infected.” Not only that, but Francis Collins, director of the National Institutes of Health, says that, if it wasn’t for funding cuts, <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/12/ebola-vaccine_n_5974148.html" title="">we would probably have an Ebola vaccine by now</a>.</p> <p>Sooo … do we learn from that? Are we going to invest in medical equipment that protects doctors and nurses from contamination? Procedures that minimise human error? Education campaigns about the dangers of antibiotic-resistant bacteria? Or even, um, a functioning healthcare system? Anything constructive? Nah, said John McCain on Sunday. Instead, he suggested, Obama should appoint an Ebola tsar to assuage Americans’ superficial, borderline recreational anxieties about a disease that mainly affects people in west Africa living in extreme poverty without access to clean water and modern medical facilities, along with the underfunded, understaffed medical personnel desperately battling the epidemic. Not to mention the fact that the Obama administration almost certainly has not just appointed officials but entire agencies to contain Ebola in the US (if I learned anything from Outbreak, Rene Russo is also on the case), and that McCain’s party hates tsars, government oversight in general and probably Rene Russo, too.</p> <p>Perhaps John McCain and his cohort ought to invest in a Get a Grip tsar.</p> <p>Or, if he’s genuinely interested in prolonging and enhancing the lives of his constituents, he should advocate for an Influenza tsar, or a Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococci tsar, or a Living Wage tsar, or a Forgive My Medical Bills/Student Loans tsar, or a Tell the Police to Stop Murdering Black People tsar. Any of those would be more useful, in the scheme of things. Not that Ebola doesn’t deserve attention – it absolutely does, and fast (and my deepest condolences to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/11/bintu-sannoh-ebola-sierra-leone-eyewitness" title="">every single person who’s been affected</a>) – but it deserves attention centred on west Africa, and not the kind of attention that deliberately whips the public into a panic so that their panic can be used as a political bargaining chip by elderly iguanas while the problems that <a href="http://theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/12/ebola-sierra-leone-fighting-war-against-unseen-virus" title="">cause and perpetuate the disease go unaddressed</a>.</p> <p>I will retract my iguana comment when John McCain starts agitating for a Global Clean Water tsar.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/ebola-screening-confusion-heathhrow-airport-measures <p>Passengers travelling to the UK from west Africa say they were not given automatic medical checks for Ebola, forcing Downing Street to defend its new screening regime on the first day of operation at Heathrow.</p> <p>Labour urged Jeremy Hunt, the health secretary, to get a grip on the situation after there was confusion among travellers and officials about whether it was voluntary for people entering the UK from the worst affected regions to undergo temperature tests and medical checks.</p> <p>On Monday, Hunt told MPs that border officials would have to rely to some extent on people noticing posters about Ebola in airports and presenting themselves to the authorities if they thought they were at risk.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-1125a9a8-7d47-4459-9692-eee5731bc976"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/14/1413312146588/58737e24-6fc2-4d9e-9903-8aad86b461b6-460x276.jpeg" alt="Port of entry Ebola health assessment form" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Port of entry Ebola health assessment form. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2014/oct/14/ebola">See the full version here</a> </span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Katharine Duncan</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>This appeared to be the case at Heathrow’s Terminal 1, where some travellers expressed bemusement and even shock at the relatively low key nature of the measures, which will cost about £9m over the next six months.</p> <p>A Sierra Leonean journalist who travelled via Brussels from Monrovia, Liberia, said passport control staff only realised where he had come from when he volunteered the information. Sorious Samura said: “I could have just come throughout without any screening. That is how scary it is.</p> <p>“Our flight was met by an airport official saying we might be screened. He even shook our hands. That’s something nobody does now in Liberia and infected countries – you have to learn not to.</p> <p>“Most of the people who had been on our flight from Liberia to Brussels didn’t go into the screening room, they just seemed to go through to customs and presumably out of the airport. I only filled in the questionnaire and went through the screening because I felt a sense of responsibility, having seen the effect of Ebola where I’ve been.”</p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2014/oct/14/ebola-checks-optional-london-heathrow-airport-video"                        data-show-ads="true"                data-video-id="2175445"                data-video-name="'Why are Ebola checks optional at London's Heathrow airport?' – video"                data-video-provider="ITN"                data-video-poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/10/14/1413297433099/London-Heathrow-Airport-017.jpg"> <video data-media-id="gu-video-449721193" class="gu-video" controls="controls" poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/10/14/1413297420962/London-Heathrow-Airport-007.jpg"> <source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2014/10/14/141014ebolascreening-16x9.mp4"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2014/10/14/141014ebolascreening/141014ebolascreening.m3u8"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2014/10/14/141014ebolascreening_3gpLg16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2014/10/14/141014ebolascreening_3gpSml16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2014/10/14/141014ebolascreening.webm"></source> </video> </figure>  <p>Among others arriving at Heathrow was ReGina Jane Jere, who travels frequently between Africa and her home in London. She said she had noticed little discernible difference during her arrival – apart from the presence of a sign.</p> <p>“I wasn’t stopped. I wasn’t asked any questions. I wasn’t asked where I had come from,” said Jere, who had travelled from Gambia via Dakar and Brussels.</p> <p>“There was a hand sanitiser as you walk in and I did use it, and there is a sign which is not highly visible which says ‘medical check’, which I have not seen before, so at least there is a sign. I travelled to [the capital of Gambia] Banjul on Friday and as I walked into the airport terminal everyone was actually screened and somehow I felt really quite comfortable that I was screened and I was going into a country that was doing that.”</p> <p>Public Health England said passengers on indirect flights from Liberia, Guinea or Sierra Leone – the three west African countries at the centre of the outbreak – would be automatically flagged at passport control. They would then be escorted to a screening area, where their temperature would be taken and they would fill out forms asking if they had had contact with any Ebola patients, experienced any symptoms of the disease or visited a traditional healer or hospital.</p> <p>Dr Paul Cosford, director for health protection and medical director of Public Health England, said that screening would not be compulsory, but he expected passengers would agree to it for the sake of their own health.</p> <p>“If they are not cooperative in coming for screening, it is an issue Border Force colleagues will look at,” said Cosford.</p> <p>“There is public health legislation so we can take steps if we believe somebody is a risk to the public’s health and that can lead to them being treated in hospital for the public’s safety.”</p> <p>However, David Cameron’s official spokesman appeared to contradict the idea that screening was not compulsory when pressed on whether the system was doing enough to catch passengers who are potentially at risk of the virus.</p> <p>“They are required to go through the screening process,” he said. “We are taking what I would describe as a robust and proportionate approach to this, based on the very latest medical advice we get.”</p> <p>Speaking on LBC 97.3 radio, Cameron later acknowledged that the screening would “never be perfect” and “we won’t catch everybody”.</p> <p>Labour said it was worrying that just 24 hours after Hunt’s statement to the House of Commons there was confusion over the new screening programme.</p> <p>“The fact that nobody in government seems to know whether the screening is voluntary or not will not build public confidence in the government’s handling of this situation. The government urgently needs to clarify its policy on screening to reassure the public that it has a grip.”</p> <p>Dan O’Mahoney, chief of staff of the Border Force, said there were fewer than 1,000 passengers a month coming into the UK from the three countries.</p> <p>“The vast majority come through Heathrow,” he said. “We don’t anticipate it will require additional staff. The numbers for Border Force are pretty modest.”</p>  <figure class="element element-embed" >  <iframe class="fenced" srcdoc="&lt;html&gt;&lt;head&gt;&lt;/head&gt;&lt;body&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://static.guim.co.uk/ni/1413311752320/Ebolia_stats_1510WEB.svg&quot;style=&quot;width:100%;&quot;&gt;&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;"></iframe> </figure>  <p>Ships that arrive from west Africa will have travelled for more than 21 days before landing in the UK, so anybody incubating the virus would have become ill on board and the authorities would be alerted.</p> <p>In Brussels, where the only direct flights from Sierra Leone to Europe arrive, there is no screening as the government says it has confidence in the screening done before passengers board.</p> <p>However, on Monday it introduced new measures at Brussels airport which means any baggage showing any sign of liquids or food must be destroyed.</p> <p>“We do not want to take the risk, so if we see any fluid in baggage coming from west Africa we destroy it. We are rigorously applying the rule,” said a spokeswoman.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/14/kei-kamara-ebola-sierra-leone-wolves <p>The Sierra Leone striker Kei Kamara believes the Ebola outbreak in his homeland jettisoned his chance of signing for Wolves. http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/14/crew-british-hospital-ship-sierra-leone-ebola-mission <p>A naval ship with a 100-bed medical complex and loaded with helicopters, landing craft, tonnes of emergency supplies and almost 400 personnel is preparing to head for Sierra Leone to help tackle the Ebola crisis.</p> <p><a href="http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/our-organisation/the-fighting-arms/royal-fleet-auxiliary/casualty-ship/rfa-argus" title="">Royal Fleet Auxiliary Argus</a>, a vast hospital and support vessel, will sail from Falmouth in Cornwall to west Africa and act as a forward base for army medics, engineers, soldiers and aid experts who will build and operate medical centres, train local doctors and nurses and transport vital supplies.</p>  <figure class="element element-embed" data-alt="he deck of UK naval vessel RFA Argus">  <iframe class="fenced" srcdoc="&lt;html&gt;&lt;head&gt;&lt;/head&gt;&lt;body&gt;&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot; lang=&quot;en&quot;&gt;&lt;p&gt;The deck of UK naval vessel RFA Argus, bound for Sierra Leone to help with Ebola crisis. &lt;a href=&quot;https://t.co/lK5P28bxTL&quot;&gt;https://t.co/lK5P28bxTL&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&amp;mdash; steven morris (@stevenmorris20) &lt;a href=&quot;https://twitter.com/stevenmorris20/status/522004599981752320&quot;&gt;October 14, 2014&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;script async src=&quot;//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js&quot; charset=&quot;utf-8&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;"></iframe> </figure>  <p>By the end of next month 750 British troops will be operating in Sierra Leone. With troops continuing to withdraw from Afghanistan it will be the largest overseas deployment of UK forces anywhere in the world.</p> <p>During a visit to the 28,000-tonne RFA Argus the defence secretary, Michael Fallon, described the ship, which first saw action during the Falklands conflict, as a “warhorse” embarking on a vital humanitarian mission.</p> <p>Fallon said British efforts in west Africa would help save lives there but also stop Ebola spreading through other parts of the continent, Europe and the UK. “She will be at the frontline defending Britain against the disease,” he said.</p> <p>“We’re doing more than any other country, certainly much more than in Europe. We’re putting a huge effort into this.”</p> <p>While Fallon spoke on the flight deck of the 175-metre-long ship, military and civilian staff (85 of the 140-strong ship’s crew are non-military) loaded supplies, weaponry and equipment – including protective suits – on the ship ahead of her departure at high tide on Friday.</p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gf0dfgFzUbw"                                                                                > <iframe width="460" height="259" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gf0dfgFzUbw?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> <figcaption>Captain David Eagles, commanding officer of RFA Argus.</figcaption> </figure>  <p>The ship’s commanding officer Captain David Eagles, a veteran of conflicts in the Middle East and the Balkans, accepted there was an “unknown quantity” to this mission. “It is worrying to the crew and their families but I’m confident we can achieve what we’ve been tasked to do and bring all our people safely home to their families.”</p> <p>Argus has varied roles. First, she will transport personnel and hardware, including more than 50 vehicles along with tonnes of bottled water and ration packs. The voyage, which includes a stop-off in Gibraltar to pick up more gear, will take about a week.</p> <p>When in theatre, she will act as a base for three Royal Navy Merlin helicopters, which will be used in surveillance work and to move equipment and people around. Anti-submarine warfare equipment is being stripped out of the aircraft to provide more space. The ship has its own mini air traffic control centre, Flyco.</p> <p>Argus will also become a giant landing stage for powerful boats operated by 80 Royal Marines, who will provide the security for the British operation.</p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QLqu-NcYNaE"                                                                                > <iframe width="460" height="259" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QLqu-NcYNaE?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> <figcaption>Lieutenant Colonel Rich Cantrill on the role of the Royal Marines in Sierra Leone.</figcaption> </figure>  <p>Finally the ship, which has the same sort of facilities available as at an NHS hospital, will provide medical cover to British personnel – military and civilian – who might suffer injury or illness while working in Sierra Leone.</p> <p>About 80 medical staff will be on board, including surgeons, consultants, radiographers, anaesthetists and nurses. Some will go on shore to help with the training; others will remain on Argus.</p> <p>What the ship will not do is treat anyone who contracts Ebola. Every time a marine or medic goes on shore, he or she will be asked to fill in a questionnaire about contacts with local people. If they have had contact, their temperature will be taken twice a day and if there are concerns that they have Ebola they will be evacuated to a British-run facility onshore.</p> <p>The idea is to keep the ship a safe, sterile environment from which the UK’s efforts can be coordinated locally.</p> <p>on Tuesday 120 members of the ship’s company gathered in the canteen to hear a 90-minute briefing on Ebola.</p> <p>Dr Ruth Howlett-Shipley, the Royal Navy’s public health consultant, told them: “We are doing everything we can to make sure that you go out safely and come back safely.” Among the questions she faced was: “If I sit next to a marine at breakfast, who shook hands with an infected person, will I contract Ebola?”</p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zF_gnG_d2zk"                                                                                > <iframe width="460" height="259" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zF_gnG_d2zk?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> <figcaption>Surgeon Lieutenant Dan Hawkins on his role aboard RFA Argus</figcaption> </figure>  <p>Surgeon Lieutenant Dan Hawkins, the medical officer for Argus, said: “There’s always concerns when you deploy and with the nature of where we’re going to there are added concerns and considerations but the crew are very much looking forward to going.”</p> <p>Conditions on board will vary. Some of the men in the so-called austere accommodation will sleep in 27-person dormitories; others share smaller cabins. Some will leave the vessel on missions but those who have no operational reason to head for shore will stay on board for the whole of a two- or three-month tour. They have Sky Sports and a ration of two cans of beer a day.</p> <p>It will not be a short trip – Argus has been told to prepare for six months away. Captain Eagles said the crew, medics and troops were used to working in trying conditions. “It will be quite tough but I think people will understand. I think people are going to be quite busy.”</p>
