id="block-543bb6c9e4b0fd64f752f96f" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T12:31:31.451+01:00">12.31pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">SNP says debate proposals are 'utterly unacceptable'</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Angus Robertson</strong>, the SNP’s leader at Westminster, has put out a statement on behalf of his party about the proposal from broadcasters for televised leaders’ debates. He says the plans are “utterly unacceptable”.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>These proposals will be utterly unacceptable to any democrat.</p> <p>What the London-based broadcasters’ are proposing fails in their duty to their viewers in Scotland, and simply doesn’t reflect the reality of politics across the UK today.</p> <p>The broadcasters have the cheek to say that their proposed format factors in ‘changes in the political landscape’ to justify including Ukip - entirely ignoring the fact that the SNP are now by far the third largest political party in the UK.</p> <p>Current Westminster voting intentions put the SNP in the lead in Scotland, and it is clearly wrong that the leader of the third biggest political party in the UK should be shut out of these network debates.</p> <p>Yet they are proposing to include Ukip, despite the fact the SNP won six seats at the last general election to Ukip’s none - and with the SNP at 40 per cent in Scotland for the general election, to Ukip’s 4 per cent.</p> <p>Despite the experience of the referendum campaign, the network broadcasters have once again forgotten their responsibility to Scotland. The BBC in particular as Scotland’s public service broadcaster should hang their heads in shame - under their proposals, the Tories and Labour would be included in four debates, the Lib Dems three, and the SNP just one. That is simply unfair to Scotland’s electorate.</p> <p>This looks like yet another cosy Westminster carve-up, and we need to know what discussions the broadcasters have had with the other parties, and why there has been absolutely no discussion with the SNP.</p> <p>These proposals are clearly inappropriate for Scotland, and cannot stand.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="a7c0a78fe9891fba58c93f6b912190c9c4939217"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/13/1413199848471/497e094f-deb8-46a3-8098-1fc81231d0d6-460x276.jpeg" alt="Angus Robertson" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Angus Robertson</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Michael Stephens/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543bb040e4b0fd64f752f964" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T12:19:44.850+01:00">12.19pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Number 10 lobby briefing - Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here are the key points from the Number 10 lobby briefing.</p> <ul> <li><strong>The prime minister’s spokesman refused to say how David Cameron would respond to the proposal from the broadcasters for televised leaders’s debates. </strong>Dismissing the story as “broadcasters talking about broadcasting”, he said the prime minister’s views were well known. </li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Number 10 confirmed that, if the Commons does vote in favour of tonight’s motion saying the government should recognise the state of Palestine, it will ignore it. </strong>Government ministers were under orders to abstain, the spokesman said. Asked why the government did not support recognising Palestinian statehood now, the spokesman said:<br /></li> </ul> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We think what we should be doing is everything that we can that is supportive of a successful and sustainable outcome based on a two-state solution.</p> </blockquote> <ul> <li><strong>Downing Street rejected Boris Johnson’s claim that promising to get net migration below 100,000 was a “great deception”. </strong>The spokesman said that migration from outside the European Economic Area was at its lowest level for 20 years. The spokesman also refused to endorse Johnson’s proposal for quotas on migration from existing EU member states. However, the spokesman also declined invitations to say anything critical of Johnson.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>The government’s Scotland command paper will be published at 2.30pm.</strong></li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Number 10 confirmed that Cameron was not expected to open the Commons debate on Scotland this week.</strong> Asked if this could be seen as a dereliction of duty, the spokesman stressed all he had done to campaign for Scotland to stay in the UK.</li> </ul> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-13T13:02:18.682+01:00">at 1.02pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543bae7fe4b0468f1ec5ca67" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T11:57:25.379+01:00">11.57am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>I’m back from the lobby briefing. I’ll post a summary shortly.</p> <p>In the meantime, here’s a bit more on the televised leaders’ debate proposal. </p> <p><strong>Natalie Bennett</strong>, the Green party leader, said the proposal from the broadcasters to exclude her party showed how out of touch they were. In a statement she said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>With these statements the broadcasters are demonstrating just how out of touch they are with the public mood, and how ridiculously they cling to the idea that the future of politics looks like the past. </p> <p>It is clear from votes and polls that the public are fed up with the three business-as-usual parties and are looking around for alternatives. That is also demonstrated by the soaring membership of the Green parties of England and Wales and Scotland, now exceeding 27,000. Those members, the fast-growing numbers of likely Green voters (matching Lib Dems numbers), and the majority who back Green policies like bringing the railways back into public hands and the living wage for all workers would be seriously shortchanged by debates from which we were excluded.</p> </blockquote> <p>And it is worth recalling that this is not the only televised leaders’s debate proposal on the table. As we announced earlier this year, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/15/guardian-telegraph-youtube-launch-bid-2015-election-leaders-debate">there is also a Guardian/Telegraph/YouTube plan to hold a debate. </a>Here’s an extract from the story written at the time. </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A proposal for a party leaders’ 2015 election debate to be staged on the internet is being launched by a unique alliance of YouTube, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/theguardian">the Guardian</a>, and the Telegraph.</p> <p>The initiative for a debate broadcast through YouTube would break the monopoly of existing broadcasters and allow innovative forms of audience participation for the political parties. The proposal, using the hashtag <a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23onlinedebate&amp;src=typd">#onlinedebate</a>, has been in preparation for months and was sent to the main party leaders on Thursday following informal talks with politicians.</p> <p>The cross-platform collaboration would put an online debate before the vast majority of the UK’s 55 million internet users, and would be aimed at engaging a younger and more interactive audience.</p> <p>A live feed could be embedded on any media site and be carried by any broadcasters on traditional TV and radio.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543b9ed1e4b0fd64f752f937" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:57:29.890+01:00">10.57am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Leaders' debate proposal - snap analysis</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Leaders’ debate proposal - snap analysis: </strong>As Peter Kellner argues (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2014/oct/13/jeremy-hunts-commons-statement-on-ebola-politics-live-blog#block-543b99e1e4b0fd64f752f932">see 10.37am</a>), the broadcasters’ proposal for televised leaders’ debates quite cleverly accommodates the need to include Ukip, without giving them equal billing to Labour and the Conservatives. But will it ever happen? Or has the Lib Dem statement just killed it off?</p> <p>First, these debates are not inevitable. Although you hear people say that they have become an established part of the election landscape, and that it would be democratically unthinkable not to have them, that is not the case. In the US, the first presidential debate was held in 1960, but the next one did not happen until 1976. It is relatively easy for a party, while pretending to be in favour of a debate in principle, to refuse to sign up to the details. Labour did this in 1997.</p> <p>Second, David Cameron may say he favours a debate, but it is hard to see how it would be in his interests. The main beneficiary from these proposed debates would probably be Nigel Farage. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/17/lynton-crosby-veto-leaders-debates-cameron">That is why Lynton Crosby is opposed</a>. (And one thing we’ve learned from the party conference season is that, what Crosby wants in Tory politics, he normally gets.)</p> <p>Third, the proposal does not accommodate Cameron’s main objection to debates. He has said he is in favour, but that he does not like they way they dominate the campaign. He has suggested debates should take place before the short campaign starts. But these three debates would all take place in April, the month before polling day.</p> <p>Fourth, Nick Clegg’s decision to reject the proposed format may give Cameron some cover. If one leader alone were to reject the proposed format, conceivably they could be “empty chaired” by the broadcasters (although I have not had time to check whether broadcasting law would allow this). But if two parties boycott the debates, they will be meaningless. Ed Miliband won’t want to debate Nigel Farage on his own.</p> <p>So, will they happen? It’s too early to know, but I think it would be unwise to put money on it.</p> <p>I’m off to the lobby briefing now.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-13T11:42:30.339+01:00">at 11.42am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543b9e66e4b0cd82a095f46f" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:42:33.457+01:00">10.42am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The Labour blogger Hopi Sen thinks Nick Clegg should be grateful not to be included in one debate.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/hopisen/statuses/521594483184795648">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Also, I don&#39;t know why the LibDems want Clegg in all the debates. It&#39;s not like increased Clegg-visibility helps them.</p>&mdash; Hopi Sen (@hopisen) <a href="https://twitter.com/hopisen/status/521594483184795648">October 13, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543b9e10e4b042a246208313" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:40:49.667+01:00">10.40am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>This helps to explain why the other party leaders might be reluctant to debate Nigel Farage.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/LadPolitics/statuses/521595741530517504">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Nigel Farage is 2/1 favourite to win any 4-way leaders&#39; Jenny Jones (@GreenJennyJones) <a href="https://twitter.com/GreenJennyJones/status/521587772369285122">October 13, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543b99e1e4b0fd64f752f932" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:37:52.206+01:00">10.37am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Peter Kellner</strong>, the YouGov president, told BBC News a few minutes ago that he thought the broadcasters’ proposal was “very, very smart”. The key question was whether David Cameron would accept it, he said. (He was speaking before the Lib Dems put out their statement - see <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2014/oct/13/jeremy-hunts-commons-statement-on-ebola-politics-live-blog#block-543b9ba2e4b042a24620830f">10.32am.)</a></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Cameron’s internal advice from Lynton Crosby, his strategic adviser, is to try and not take part in any debates at all because, if you give Nigel Farage an opening, that might [be counter-productive] and also Ed Miliband is sufficiently unpopular at the moment that the last thing David Cameron would want is to be seen on equal terms.</p> <p>But that said, this is very, very smart. The last time we had three debates with the same cast of leaders. Since then the Liberal Democrats have done so badly, whether you look at opinion polls, or local elections, byelections or the European elections in May, it would be reasonable to say they don’t deserve the same ranking as last time. At the same time, Ukip have been top in the European elections, they are ahead of the Liberal Democrats in the polls, they now have their first elected MP in Westminster - I think it would seem to normal voters out there that it would be very, very odd to exclude Nigel Farage altogether.</p> </blockquote> <p>Kellner said he hoped that, if one leader refused to take part, the broadcaster would “empty chair” him.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>What I hope the broadcasters will say to [the party leaders] is: ‘This is our joint proposal, if one of you leaders doesn’t like it, tough, we will, if necessary, empty chair you’.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-13T11:32:21.352+01:00">at 11.32am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543b9ba2e4b042a24620830f" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:32:01.690+01:00">10.32am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Lib Dems reject the broadcasters' proposal, saying they should not be excluded from first debate</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>The Lib Dems have said they would not accept being left out of one of the debates. This is from a party spokesman:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The Liberal Democrats have long argued that the debates last time round were of huge benefit to our democratic process and engaged millions of voters.</p> <p>The Liberal Democrats therefore welcome the fact that the broadcasters are seeking to make progress to ensure that the debates happen again in 2015.</p> <p> The Liberal Democrats, like the Labour party, have publicly said that we would be prepared to sign up to the same 3-3-3 system we had in 2010 [ie, three debates, with the three Conservative, Labour and Lib Dem leaders]</p> <p>We do not accept the proposal that the Liberal Democrats, as a party of government, should be prevented from defending our record in one of the TV debates.</p> <p>That is the case we will make strongly in the negotiations that will now take place and we urge the other parties to join us around the negotiating table without excuse or delay.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-13T11:30:14.927+01:00">at 11.30am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543b9990e4b042a24620830c" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:22:11.248+01:00">10.22am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Farage says Ukip should be included in second debate too</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Nigel Farage says the proposal is better than he expected, but that he would expect Ukip to be included in more than one debate.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/Nigel_Farage/statuses/521590234992357376">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Decision is better than it could have been. It is going to wait before it decides whether to accept or reject it.</p> <p>A spokesman said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We note the request and we will respond accordingly.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-13T11:33:07.702+01:00">at 11.33am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543b9523e4b0fd64f752f92a" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:03:45.053+01:00">10.03am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Broadcasters propose joint plan for televised leaders' debates</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-29595529">The BBC, ITV, Channel 4 News and Sky have announced a joint proposal for televised leaders’ debates at the election</a></p> <p>Here is what they are proposing.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>• One head-to-head debate between the two leaders who could become prime minister – Conservative and Labour. This debate will be co-produced by Sky News and Channel 4 and chaired by Jeremy Paxman. Kay Burley will introduce the programme and present the post-debate analysis. The whole programme will be carried live on Sky and Channel 4 and their digital platforms, as well as having a major presence across social media.</p> <p>• One debate between the Conservative, Labour and Liberal Democrat leaders. This debate will be produced by the BBC and presented by David Dimbleby. It will be broadcast on BBC One with extensive live coverage on other BBC TV and radio networks and online.</p> <p>• One debate between the Conservative, Labour, Liberal Democrat and Ukip leaders. This debate will be produced and broadcast by ITV. Chaired by Julie Etchingham, it will air on ITV’s main channel and online.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-13T11:44:19.865+01:00">at 11.44am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543b91ffe4b042a246208306" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T10:01:07.352+01:00">10.01am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Labour MP Graham Stringer says Miliband's team is 'hopeless'</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Ed Miliband isn’t the first Labour leader to turn on the radio to hear himself being denounced by the Labour MP <strong>Graham Stringer</strong>, but that doesn’t mean that he will be happy about the experience. Stringer was at it again on the Today programme this morning. Here are the key points he made.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Stringer said Miliband’s team was “hopeless”.</strong><br /></li> </ul> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>There is a problem that applies to Ed and the people round him that the Labour Party have recruited and appointed too many people who have very little experience of the world. They have been assistants to MPs, bag carriers for ministers, they’ve come through the system, they’ve been parachuted into seats where they’ve got no roots. It’s meant there’s been a disconnect with parts of the party - particularly the leadership - and what’s really happening in many of the communities we hope to represent ...</p> <p>We have to improve the people around Ed. I would sack quite a lot of the people. I think the team is hopeless around him. They’re giving him very bad advice. The shadow cabinet are individually all decent, hard-working people; collectively, they don’t have the breadth of experience that Ed needs for advice.</p> </blockquote> <ul> <li><strong>He said the party was out of touch with voters’ concerns in Heywood and Middleton.</strong><br /></li> </ul> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>In the Heywood and Middleton by-election it was the line coming from the leadership that this was about the health service. You only had to knock on three or four doors in Middleton or Heywood to find that what people were talking about was immigration. You can’t hope to win elections if you don’t talk about what the people are talking about. We have a problem on both communications and credibility. People have to believe what we say and at the moment they simply don’t do that.</p> </blockquote> <ul> <li><strong>He said Miliband was unpopular with voters.</strong><br /></li> </ul> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>If you go on the doorstep, Ed isn’t an asset to us. I don’t think that’s even a controversial thing to say, rather sadly. They think he doesn’t understand the problems they are suffering. </p> </blockquote> <p>Stringer was on the Today programme with another Labour MP, <strong>Yasmin Qureshi</strong>, who said she disagreed with his analysis.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>I think that to suggest that Ed’s team is responsible for the difficulties in Heywood and Middleton, I think you’re wrong. I think what we have to remember [is] that in Heywood and Middleton the Labour vote actually went up and I think that’s really important. The Labour vote did not collapse and therefore to say that the Labour party is completely disconnected to voters and don’t understand their concerns, it is wrong.</p> </blockquote> <p>I’ve taken some of the quotes from<a href="http://www.politicshome.com"> PoliticsHome.</a></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="6325b63d21e23fd2a697b4a15248c05f3d8a74d4"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/13/1413190848742/61d9cdac-4fc8-4729-b7c5-06f09be48f8c-460x276.jpeg" alt="Graham Stringer" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Graham Stringer</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: CHRISTOPHER THOMOND/Christopher Thomond</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543b8c91e4b042a2462082fe" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T09:46:47.727+01:00">9.46am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Jeremy Hunt's morning interviews - Summary</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>As I mentioned earlier, Jeremy Hunt has been giving a round of interviews this morning. They were largely about today’s strike by NHS hospital staff and midwives. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/live/2014/oct/13/nhs-hospital-staff-midwives-strike-over-pay-live-updates">My colleague Peter Walker is writing a separate live blog about that strike, </a>and he has covered what Hunt has said about pay.</p> <p>But here are the other key points that emerged from the interviews.</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/13/uk-must-ready-ebola-outbreak-worsen-jeremy-hunt"><strong>Hunt said the global Ebola outbreak would get “a lot worse” and that Britain had to be prepared for this.</strong></a></li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>He rejected suggestions that screening for Ebola at airports was ineffective.</strong><br /></li> </ul> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>I think there are a lot of misunderstandings and that’s why it’s very important that we get the right training in place, put in place the right procedures. The main purpose of the airport screening that we are introducing is not actually to identify people who have Ebola, have the symptoms right now because most of them would have been prevented form flying by the checks that you have already in the airports at those countries. </p> <p>The main purpose is to identify higher risk people because the virus incubates for 21 days and we need to make sure that anyone that is higher risk – we know their contact details, we are able to stay in touch with them, monitor their temperature on a daily basis so that if they do develop the symptoms we can get to them quickly. And that is better for them, that massively increases their chance of survival, but is also much safer for the public. </p> </blockquote> <ul> <li><strong>He defended the government’s controversial Health Act which reorganised the NHS.</strong> This came when he was asked about <a href="http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/politics/article4234883.ece">a story in today’s Times (paywall) saying senior Tories now think the Act was their biggest mistake. </a>Here’s an extract from the story. </li> </ul> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>David Cameron did not understand the controversial reforms and George Osborne regrets not preventing what Downing Street officials call a “huge strategic error”, it can be revealed.</p> <p>One senior cabinet minister told <em>The Times</em>: “We’ve made three mistakes that I regret, the first being restructuring the NHS. The rest are minor.” </p> <p> The prime minister and the chancellor both failed to realise the explosive extent of plans drawn up by Andrew Lansley, when he was the health secretary, which one insider described as “unintelligible gobbledegook”. </p> <p> An ally of Mr Osborne said: “George kicks himself for not having spotted it and stopped it. He had the opportunity then and he didn’t take it.” </p> </blockquote> <p>Asked about this, Hunt said he would not comment on the views attributed to Tory figures in the article. But he said that the NHS was now doing an extra 1m operations a year, and that this was only possible because of the savings obtained by bureaucrat posts axed as a result of the reforms. Asked about George Osborne’s views, Hunt replied: </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>I think if you talked to George Osborne, he would say exactly the same thing. The officially verified figures show that those reforms are saving the NHS more than £1bn a year. That is paying for a lot of doctors and nurses. </p> </blockquote> <ul> <li><strong>Hunt said he would not be taking the proposed 9% pay increase for MPs.</strong><br /></li> </ul> <p>I’ve taken some of the quotes from <a href="http://www.politicshome.com">PoliticsHome.</a></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="4b1ef519fbe47aeefcf231fc8055c7fa13e55063"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/13/1413189990807/4fa5117c-ff8a-4395-ae20-30ad84188ade-460x276.jpeg" alt="Jeremy Hunt" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Jeremy Hunt</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: ELM/Rex Features/ELM/Rex Features</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543b89a6e4b042a2462082f8" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T09:23:25.205+01:00">9.23am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">OBR boss says income tax revenues likely to be disappointing</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Robert Chote</strong>, chair of the Office of Budget Responsibility, had some bad news for George Osborne on the Today programme this morning. He said income tax receipts were likely to be disappointing this year because wage growth was so low.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Fewer pence of revenue [are] coming in for every pound of wages and salaries that’s generated in the labour market and that’s one of the reasons why the receipts have come in weaker. Now, from the perspective of the public finances, that’s not particularly good news. The chancellor of the exchequer gets more bang for his buck if wages and salaries rise as a result of people’s earnings going up than if employment goes up – and that’s basically because if earnings go up you’re taking more people into higher income tax brackets, whereas if employment is going up you’re perhaps bringing more people in at the bottom.</p> <p>This continued story of earnings growing less rapidly than expected and employment growing more rapidly than expected does perhaps suggest that we are more likely to be disappointed than to overachieve on income tax receipts this year.</p> </blockquote> <p>One factor was the increase in self-employment, he said.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Quite a lot of the employment growth we’ve seen relatively recently has been self-employed people. And the evidence suggests that more of those than we expected have come in on relatively low incomes. So, for example, Revenues and Customs, the tax department, suggest that the proportion of self-employed people who are reporting incomes below the tax-free personal allowance has gone up from about 20% immediately prior to the crisis to about 35%.</p> </blockquote> <p>Later <strong>Danny Alexander</strong>, the chief secretary to the Treasury, told the programme that the problem with tax revenues that Chote highlighted could be related to the government’s success at tackling youth unemployment.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>One of the things we are seeing in the UK is a very large fall in youth unemployment. Young people at the start of their careers tend to earn significantly below the median income. That doesn’t mean that those are low-quality jobs. It does mean that those are people who are able to start out in life in the workplace, which is something that is hugely important.</p> </blockquote> <p>I’ve taken the quotes from<a href="http://www.politicshome.com"> PoliticsHome </a>and the Press Association.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="fec4c0c685eea545c1dc68de4206ad2b107b6ac1"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/13/1413188595984/b31da222-e536-4dc6-ae65-cef5700d8bb9-460x276.jpeg" alt="Robert Chote" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Robert Chote</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Lewis Whyld/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-543b8110e4b0468f1ec5ca1e" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-13T09:05:26.863+01:00">9.05am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The first day when the Commons comes back after a recess is always busy and this afternoon there will be at least two important statements in the chamber. <strong>Jeremy Hunt</strong>, the health secretary, will tell MPs what is being done to prepare Britain for an Ebola outbreak. http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/13/liberia-ebola-health-workers-strike <p>Liberia’s efforts to contain Ebola suffered a further blow on Monday after health workers demanding increased danger money for looking after patients with the disease began their threatened walkout.</p> <p>The National Health Workers Association of Liberia (NHWAL) ignored government pleas to refrain from striking and urged its members to stay off work after midnight on Monday. The call to strike was for nurses, medical assistants, lab technicians and other health workers, but did not include doctors.</p> <p>The NHWAL chairman, Joseph Tamba, said the call had been “massively” followed, adding: “Health workers across the country have downed tools as we asked them to do.”</p> <p><a href="http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Liberia-health-workers-strike-over-Ebola" title="">According to one unconfirmed report</a>, industrial action by those looking after sick people may already have resulted in deaths.</p> <p>In the capital Monrovia, where staff at Island Clinic, the largest government-run Ebola facility, have been on a “go-slow” for three days, a patient quoted on local radio described scenes of desolation with sick people deserted by staff.</p> <p>“We are at the Ebola treatment unit and no one is taking care of us,” the unnamed man said. “Last night several patients died. Those who can walk are trying to escape by climbing over the fence.”</p> <p>Liberia has banned reporters from Ebola clinics, making the claim impossible to verify.</p> <p>Healthcare workers are on the frontline of the worst outbreak on record of Ebola, which spreads through contact with bodily fluids, with 95 killed in Liberia alone, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). The west African outbreak has so far killed more than 4,000 people – at least 2,300 of them in Liberia.</p> <p>George Williams, the NHWAL’s secretary general, acknowledged that the strike would undermine the progress being made against Ebola in Liberia, but said he was confident the public would understand the reasons for their action.</p> <p>“The problem is the government. The public should get angry with the government, not with us,” he said.</p> <p>“The public is aware that health workers are dying because they are not protected. Nobody is supposed to die while protecting lives. We have been calling on the government to give us protective gear but they are not doing so.”</p> <p>According to the association, the walkout will involve “every hospital and every health centre including Ebola treatment units”. Although the NHWAL has more than 10,000 members, Liberia’s health ministry says only about 1,000 of those are employed at sites receiving Ebola patients. It has also denied the association’s claims that the government had failed to engage with health workers’ demands.</p> <p>Some health workers chose not to strike. Gobee Logan, a doctor at a government hospital in Tubmanburg, 40 miles (60km) from Monrovia, told the Associated Press that some nurses had turned up for work on Monday.</p> <p>With salaries said to be as low as £155 ($250) a month, calls are mounting for pay to reflect the risk of dealing with Ebola, for which there is no vaccine or widely available treatment.</p> <p>Last week, Liberia’s president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, told a World Bank crisis meeting there was an urgent need for “compensation to healthcare workers who, for fear of the risk involved, have refused or are reluctant to return to work”.</p> <p>On Monday, the WHO described the Ebola crisis out break as “unquestionably the most severe acute public health emergency in modern times”.</p> <p>Its director general, Margaret Chan, said the number of new cases in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone was rising exponentially, adding: “The world is ill-prepared to respond to any severe, sustained and threatening public health emergency.”</p> <p>In a statement to a regional health conference in the Philippine capital Manila, she said: “I have never seen a health event threaten the very survival of societies and governments in already very poor countries. I have never seen an infectious disease contribute so strongly to potential state failure.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/13/spain-ebola-repatriations-nurse <p>Spain’s foreign affairs minister has defended the government’s decision to repatriate two Spanish nationals with Ebola, despite a nurse who treated them becoming the first person to contract the virus outside of west Africa.</p> <p>“The government did what it had to do,” José Manuel García-Margallo told El País newspaper. “The duty of a state is to protect its citizens – and even more so when they are in difficult circumstances far from Spain. All the developed countries who have had this problem have done the same.”</p> <p>The two missionaries, Miguel Pajares, 75, and Manuel García Viejo, 69, died in August and September, days after being evacuated to Madrid for treatment. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/07/ebola-crisis-substandard-equipment-nurse-positive-spain">Spanish nurse Teresa Romero Ramos tested positive for the Ebola virus</a> shortly after. She remains in a stable but serious condition.</p> <p>García-Margallo argued that far from hurting Spain’s image, the Ebola case would show the world the strength of the Spanish healthcare system. “In the face of an event that can happen in any country, Spanish society has demonstrated its solidarity, and in the long run we will see that our healthcare system is among the world’s best.”</p> <p>On Sunday, Fernando Simón, of Spain’s health ministry, said the presence of the virus in Romero Ramos’s blood <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/spanish-ebola-nurse-shows-signs-improvement">appeared to be diminishing</a>. “We have high hopes that the infection is under control,” he said. None of them have shown symptoms of the virus.</p>  <figure class="element element-embed" data-alt="Global Ebola outbreaks">  <iframe class="fenced" srcdoc="&lt;html&gt;&lt;head&gt;&lt;/head&gt;&lt;body&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://static.guim.co.uk/ni/1413212395898/Ebola_Outbreaks_WEB141014.svg&quot;style=&quot;width:100%;&quot;&gt;&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;"></iframe> </figure>  <p>Last week, in a phone interview from her hospital bed, Romero Ramos told El País that she might have touched her face with her gloves while removing her protective suit. The matter was brought before court by workers’ unions, who argue that the Spanish health authorities violated labour laws by failing to provide adequate protection and training for its employees.</p> <p>Amelia Batanero, a nurse who underwent training to treat Ebola patients at the Carlos III, told the Guardian: “We haven’t learned how to use these suits, we don’t know the protocol on how to treat Ebola.”</p> <p>The news that a healthcare worker in Dallas has also contracted the Ebola virus prompted comparisons on Monday between the differing response in each country to the infected health workers.</p> <p>Despite the fact this was the US authorities’ <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/us-ebola-diagnosis-cdc-chief-deeply-concerning">second case of Ebola</a> – after the death of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/texan-healthcare-worker-ebola-thomas-duncan-us">Thomas Eric Duncan</a> in Dallas this month – and had been riddled with missteps, the Spanish media used the news to take aim at their government’s slow response.</p> <p>Romero Ramos contacted health authorities several times over the course of nearly a week before she was tested for Ebola, while the unnamed US healthcare worker was put in quarantine less than 90 minutes after she arrived at a hospital complaining of a slight fever.</p> <p>Many of Romero Ramos’s neighbours learned of the diagnosis through the media, in contrast to the US where authorities contacted the patient’s neighbours to explain the situation. And while a global protest failed to prevent health authorities in Spain from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/07/threat-to-dog-spanish-nurse-ebola-sparks-online-petition">putting down Romero Ramos’s dog, Excálibur</a>, US authorities facing a similar situation have promise to save the healthcare worker’s dog.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/13/uk-must-ready-ebola-outbreak-worsen-jeremy-hunt <p>Britain must be prepared for the Ebola outbreak to worsen, the health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, has said as he prepares to outline the next steps he intends to take to prevent an outbreak in the UK.</p> <p>Hunt said he would give the latest estimate of the number of cases likely to emerge in the UK in the next three months, when he made a statement in the Commons later on Monday.</p> <p>He told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme: “It is a question of being prepared; at present the number of [global] cases is doubling every three to four weeks. But we need to make sure that everyone gets the training, everyone is reassured about what they need to do to stay safe.”</p> <p>As part of the country’s strategy to deal with the virus, calls to the case of the disease</a>, in a Texas hospital worker who was in contact with Thomas Eric Duncan, who died from the virus on Wednesday.</p> <p>Hunt said the UK had “robust and well-tested systems” for 111.</p> <p>“Now all call handlers on the NHS 111 service are asking anyone reporting potential symptoms of Ebola, such as respiratory problems, high temperatures, or diarrhoea and vomiting, about their recent travel history, so appropriate help can be given to people who might be at higher risk of having come into contact with the virus.</p> <p>“If the person with symptoms has recently been to west Africa and is at high risk of having been in contact with Ebola, 111 will immediately refer them to local emergency services for assessment by ambulance personnel with appropriate protective equipment.”</p> <p>The UK’s chief medical officer, Sally Davies, said the country should expect a handful of Ebola cases in the coming months and that a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/11/ebola-crisis-uk-readiness-virus-assessed-nationwide-exercise">major exercise to test the country’s readiness</a> for such cases proved plans were robust.</p> <p>Enhanced screening for the virus at major airports and terminals are part of the government’s contingency plan against Ebola.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/13/cairns-nurse-in-ebola-scare-urges-volunteers-to-fight-virus-in-west-africa <p>The nurse at the centre of the Australian Ebola scare has urged other health professionals to travel to West Africa to help fight the virus.<br /></p> <p>Sue Ellen Kovack, 57, was released from Cairns hospital on Monday after returning a second negative result for the virus. Kovack returned from treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone last Tuesday and was taken to hospital on Thursday after developing a low-grade fever, sparking fears she could have brought the virus to Australia.</p> <p>The federal government has given $18m to fight Ebola, which has killed more than 4,000 people, but has said it will not send aid workers to West Africa <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/ebola-crisis-australia-wont-send-doctors-into-harms-way-abbott">for fear of putting Australian lives at risk</a>.</p> <p>In her first public statement since being admitted to hospital Kovack urged Australians to donate to the Red Cross to send more help to West Africa.</p> <p>“It has been so inspiring and it has really kept me going in the past few days to know there’s growing public support for action to help people affected by Ebola in West Africa,” she said.</p> <p>“Most importantly to me, I’m sending a message to my fellow medical professionals who are thinking about heading over to treat the sick and work at bringing Ebola under control: please, please do it.”</p> <p>Kovack said the support she had received from around the world had made the past week “quite emotional”.</p> <p>“The past few days have been a worrying and taxing time and it has meant I’ve not had much time to fully process the challenges I had in West Africa, treating people sick with Ebola, seeing people die and helping to control this dreadful virus,” she said.</p> <p>The Public Health Association of Australia (PHAA) is sending a letter to Tony Abbott, signed by health professors, urging more direct help for countries affected by Ebola.</p> <p>“The best means of protecting Australia and other high-income countries is for robust control efforts at the source of the outbreak,” the letter says.</p> <p>“The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is a global health catastrophe which threatens future economic prosperity, regional political stability and human health globally. It is in our national interest to ensure the epidemic is contained.”</p> <p>The letter was circulated to health professors on Friday afternoon and gained 30 signatures within two hours, PHAA chief executive Michael Moore said.</p> <p>He said the association had purposefully restricted the letter to health professors as they did not want to turn it into a petition.</p> <p>“These are the people who understand the risks, people with serious expertise in this area believe it is important and appropriate for Australia to send health professionals over there,” Moore told Guardian Australia.</p> <p>Moore said non-government organisations in west Africa needed personnel and facilities. He said only 10-20% of Ebola patients were being treated in treatment centres and that number needed to rise to about 70% to stop the virus spreading more quickly.</p> <p>He said while Abbott had valid concerns about the safety of Australian health workers, the logistics could be worked out.</p> <p>“Evacuation of any of our people who contract Ebola is of course the concern and it’s a sensible concern the prime minister has raised, but we’re not beyond being able to organise with the United Kingdom, the United States, Norway, France, other countries who have evacuation systems in place to be able to work with them to deal with this sort of situation,” Moore said.</p> <p>He said Australia had evacuation plans in place with allies for soldiers seriously injured in the Middle East conflicts and could make similar arrangements in West Africa.</p> <p>Asked why Australia seemed more willing to intervene in military conflicts than health crises, Moore said: “It’s politically great to be seen to be strong [by intervening militarily], Maggie Thatcher showed that, but this is a crisis we don’t seem to be strong on.”</p> <p>“If you look at it from a selfish perspective, people seem to be thinking why are we worrying? It’s just Africa’.”</p> <p>The PHAA will circulate the letter until Tuesday and send it to the prime minister on Wednesday.</p> <p>Moore said he was “disappointed” one of the people he had sent the letter to had leaked it to the media before the prime minister had seen it.</p> <p>“I feel it’s impolite,” he said.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/ebola-healthcare-workers-alive-africa <p>Health workers on the Ebola frontline are and always have been <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/-sp-ebola-west-africa-health-workers" title="">at the highest risk of contracting the disease</a>. Ebola becomes more contagious the sicker patients get. By the time they are in the care of doctors and nurses, patients have become a serious danger to the lives of those treating, washing and attempting to rehydrate them.</p> <p>But in countries such as the US and Spain, which have sophisticated healthcare systems and well-equipped hospitals, healthcare workers should be safe. It is shocking that workers in Spain and now Texas have contracted Ebola from patients they were treating.</p> <p>As Médecins sans Frontières has proved, it is possible to keep health workers safe even in the difficult setting of west Africa, where an isolation ward can be no more than an area behind a canvas tent flap. The vital elements are vigilance and strict adherence to the rules.</p> <p>The Texas health worker was reportedly wearing full protective gear – gown, gloves, mask and shield – while providing care for the patient who later died. Either that equipment failed or correct procedures were not followed.</p> <p>Dr Tom Frieden, head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, suggested on Sunday that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/texan-healthcare-worker-ebola-thomas-duncan-us" title="">there had been a breach in protocol,</a> saying that one focus of the investigation will be the possibility that the health worker took off protective gear incorrectly.</p> <p>Personal protective suits keep the virus off the body but removing them safely is a skill in itself. It is possible to transfer the virus from the outside of the suit on to the hands. From there it takes a moment’s thoughtlessness to touch the face. The virus enters the body through eyes, nose or mouth or any abrasion on the skin.</p> <p>In Africa it is so much harder to be safe. The suits are hot, there are not enough available, and doctors and nurses are hard-pressed because there are too few of them to cope with the soaring number of cases. In Liberia there was a critical health worker shortage even before Ebola broke out. Fear over dangerous working conditions was as strong a motivation for recent strikes as very low pay. The government in June doubled the pay of nurses because of the hazard, but was told by the World Bank to rescind the offer, which would have busted the health budget.</p> <p>Better conditions for health workers in Africa are vital. That is going to have to involve increasing their number and improving training. There will still be, for a while, a shortage of experienced people to supervise and ensure procedures are followed. West Africa needs a great deal of help from the west.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/texan-healthcare-worker-ebola-thomas-duncan-us <p>A Texas healthcare worker who provided care for Thomas Eric Duncan, the first patient to be given a diagnosis of Ebola in the US, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-patient-dies-texas-thomas-eric-duncan">who died on Wednesday</a>, has tested positive for the deadly virus.</p> <p>At a Sunday morning press conference at the hospital, it was confirmed that a close contact of the healthcare worker – who officials said was wearing full protective gear when he or she made contact with Duncan – has also been placed, “proactively”, in isolation. The new case is the first person-to-person transmission of the disease in the US.</p> <p>Dr Tom Frieden, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), said the diagnosis of the healthcare worker showed there had been a clear breach of safety protocol at the hospital.</p> <p>“We’re deeply concerned about this new development,” Frieden said on CBS. “I think the fact that we don’t know of a breach in protocol is concerning because clearly there was a breach in protocol. We have the ability to prevent the spread of Ebola by caring safely for patients.”</p> <p>The worker was reported to be in stable condition in isolation at the Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in Dallas. The hospital is no longer taking any other emergency patients.<br /></p> <p>Frieden told CBS the worker had treated Duncan multiple times after the Liberian man was diagnosed, and said that all those who had treated Duncan were now considered to be potentially exposed. <br /></p> <p>At a subsequent media briefing, Frieden said the healthcare worker had not been able to identify a breach in protocol during his or her contact with Duncan. He also said the healthcare worker is not one of 48 people who have been being monitored because of contact with Duncan.</p> <p>Healthcare workers treating Duncan were to follow CDC protocol that included wearing protective gear. Among the things CDC will investigate, Frieden said, is how the workers took off that gear – because removing it incorrectly can lead to a contamination.</p> <p>At the hospital press conference, Dallas County judge Clay Jenkins said the healthcare worker was a “heroic person who provided care for Mr Duncan” but did not release his or her name. News of the second diagnosis broke overnight, after a preliminary blood test on the healthcare worker, who had reported a low-grade fever on Friday night.<br /></p> <p>On Sunday morning Dr Dan Varga, of Texas Health Presbyterian hospital, said the worker had been “following a self-monitoring regimen prescribed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention” (CDC) and that “the entire process from the patient’s self-monitoring to the admission to isolation took less than 90 minutes”.<br /></p> <p>He added: “The patient’s condition is stable. In addition, a close contact has also been proactively placed in isolation. The caregiver and the family have requested total privacy, so we can’t discuss any more details of the situation.”</p> <p>Dr Varga said the hospital was now not taking any other emergency patients. Answering questions, he said the healthcare worker had been wearing full protective gear and following all CDC guidelines when he or she made contact with Duncan.</p> <p>Mike Rawlings, the mayor of Dallas, addressed likely public fears brought about by the second case. He said: “We heard about this around midnight and have been working throughout the morning to make sure the citizens of Dallas are safe when they wake up. I believe I can say they are.”</p> <p>Rawlings detailed protective measures taken by the city, including the Dallas fire and rescue haz-mat team “clearing up and decontaminating any of the open areas of an apartment complex” and “standing by to make sure nobody enters that apartment complex”.</p> <p>“Furthermore,” he said, “we have knocked on every door in that block and talked to every person who came to the door to explain what has happened and what we have done.”</p> <p>Rawlings said there was believed to be a pet inside the apartment of the healthcare worker now in isolation. He said the pet was not believed to show any signs of Ebola, and that authorities would take care of it. This week in Spain,<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/excalibur-spanish-ebola-patient-dog-euthanised"> a dog owned by an Ebola patient was euthanised</a>.</p> <p>A neighbour, Cliff Lawson, 57, told Reuters he was woken at 6am by two Dallas police officers, who told him “don’t panic”. </p> <p>“I went back to bed after that. There’s nothing you can do about it. You can’t wrap your house in bubble wrap,” Lawson said. </p> <p>A hospital statement detailed the steps taken by the hospital since the admission of Duncan, on 28 September, on his second visit.</p> <p>“We have known that further cases of Ebola are a possibility among those who were in contact with Mr Duncan before he passed away last week,” the statement said. “The system of monitoring, quarantine and isolation was established to protect those who cared for Mr Duncan as well as the community at large by identifying any potential ebola cases as early as possible and getting those individuals into treatment immediately.” <br /></p> <p>Duncan travelled from Liberia to the US on 19 September to join his girlfriend, Louise Troh, the mother of his son, Karsiah. After falling ill a few days later, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/thomas-duncan-ebola-medical-records-high-fever">Duncan was initially sent home from hospital</a>, despite telling a nurse he had recently travelled from west Africa. He was taken by ambulance to Texas Health Presbyterian on 28 September, where he was admitted and placed in isolation.</p> <p>He was confirmed to have Ebola two days later.</p> <p>It is believed Duncan contracted the disease while helping take his landlord’s 19-year-old daughter to an Ebola treatment ward in Monrovia. He did not declare that he had been in contact with Ebola when he completed a pre-flight questionnaire at Monrovia airport before travelling to the US.</p> <p>On Wednesday, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/us-airports-ebola-screenings-west-africa">the White House announced that passengers travelling from west Africa will face additional Ebola screenings at five US airports</a>, amid mounting concern that not enough controls were in place to prevent the deadly disease from entering the US.</p> <p>The current outbreak of Ebola has killed more than 4,000 people in west Africa.</p> <p>In his opening remarks on Sunday, judge Jenkins sought to calm public fears. He said: “I want to stress an important fact. You cannot contract Ebola other than from bodily fluids of a symptomatic Ebola victim. You cannot contract Ebola by walking by people in the street or from contacts who are not symptomatic. There is nothing about this case that changes that basic premise of science. <br /></p> <p>“And so it’s important that while this is obviously bad news, it is not news that should bring about panic. We have a strategy to monitor this and we will go to that strategy to keep the community safe.”</p> <p>The hospital said it was “triple-checking our full compliance with updated CDC guidelines. We are also continuing to monitor all staff who had some relation to Mr. Duncan’s care even if they are not assumed to be at significant risk of infection”.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/ebola-boris-johnson-uk-london <p>Boris Johnson has said there is little doubt a case of Ebola will come to the UK and this will most probably be in London.</p> <p>The London mayor also admitted health checks at UK airports were a “far from perfect solution” and cautioned the government against seeming to “promise stuff that doesn’t really make any sense”.</p> <p>As the outbreak continues to spread across west Africa, Johnson suggested the best thing the UK could do was to be prepared for a new case of the virus when it happens.</p> <p>“I have little doubt that eventually there will be a case of Ebola in this country and probably this city,” he told the BBC’s the Andrew Marr Show. “All I can tell you is that to the best of my knowledge … we have fantastic preparations in London for this. What you need to do is make sure people coming from the affected countries are properly screened, properly tested when they leave. They shouldn’t be allowed to leave if they have been in contact with people in one of the affected areas. Sierra Leone is a country with which Britain has very deep and long historic links, Liberia the same thing is true of America, Guinea has French connections.</p> <p>“We need the EU and those three countries in particular to champion the effort inside these countries in west Africa … This is absolutely critical because this is a threat to all of us, it needs to be contained in west Africa. People are very frightened there. There is danger of significant migration in the region and wider than that and that is why containment is so important.”</p> <p>He added that the reaction of the world to crises such as Ebola was “almost always behind the curve, too slow”, but that the international community was now doing the right thing of by rapidly increasing aid efforts in Africa.</p> <p>Labour criticised Johnson for raising the possibility of a UK Ebola outbreak and failing to provide solid reassurances.</p> <p>Luciana Berger, the party’s public health spokeswoman, said: “People don’t want to see politicians on TV speculating about an Ebola outbreak, before passing the buck. After the past week they want reassurance that robust preparations are being made. Boris Johnson should focus on explaining what plans are in place.”</p>
