http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/ebola-crisis-online-courses-alison-knowledge-gap <p>Amos Gardy is lucky. Thanks to an online course he took last month, he has educated himself about Ebola and has been busy spreading that knowledge through his community in Monrovia, Liberia.</p> <p>Gardy, who has two sons, works for an NGO and runs a youth organisation in Monrovia. He undertook his study through <a href="http://alison.com/" title="">Advance Learning Interactive Systems Online (Alison)</a>, a Massive Open Online Course (Mooc) provider that launched an Ebola learning programme in August as the outbreak raced through towns and cities across west Africa.</p> <p>“It was a very great help because I had no knowledge of Ebola,” Gardy said in a phone interview from Monrovia. “Ebola has taken so many lives in our country. I learned how Ebola travels and how you can catch it.”</p> <p>He owns a laptop and has access to the internet, which gives him an acute sense of responsibility.</p> <p>“Not everybody has the opportunity to do the course,” said Gardy. “It’s just a few who have the internet. Those of us who can, we take our responsibility and go into the communities to educate people … The chain continues so gradually people will be aware of how to avoid the virus.”</p> <p>Alison was set up in 2007 by Mike Feerick, an Irish social entrepreneur. It allows all learning, assessment, testing and verification to be accessed by anyone, anywhere for free.</p> <p>As of December 2013, it had 2.5 million learners with 200,000 new users signing up every month. About 250,000 users are in west Africa; so far, roughly 10,000 people have completed the Ebola course. Feerick is hopeful that crowdsourcing can be used to translate it into regional languages, and eventually all global languages.</p> <p>“We have a huge engagement on our platform,” he said. “It’s a crowdsourcing way to respond to a crisis like this, which I think is new to governments and health organisations. We have people lining up to translate this course.”</p> <p>Alison has already translated the programme into French with the help of the <a href="http://www.famsanet.org" title="">Federation of African Medical Students’ Associations</a>. It is hoped that an Arabic version can be produced soon.</p> <p>“It’s amazing the lack of information people have. We have been appalled,” Feerick said. He added that no major NGO had yet approached them to harness their reach and knowledge, a fact he found both frustrating and somewhat predictable.</p> <p>“We have the largest free learning platform in Africa, by a mile. Work with us. It’s almost cost-less for the likes of Alison to respond … They are dealing with the outbreak in a classic old-fashioned way that believes money is the answer. It’s not the answer. We have infrastructure now that was not there before. Ebola is containable. The response has to be information- and education-led.”</p> <p>Feerick says most users access the course through internet cafes, laptops or workplaces. The programme can also be completed using mobile phones, and Alison has provided pdfs for people to print out and use.</p> <p>For Gardy and others living on the frontline of this global health emergency, knowledge is powerful but fear remains a constant presence. It is not just the immediate worry of catching Ebola, but also concern about what the virus is doing to Liberia’s already fragile future prospects.</p> <p>“It is very worrisome. The Ebola virus has become an economic virus. There are no jobs, no investors,” he said.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/10/un-emergency-mission-chief-battle-ebola <p>Anthony Banbury is a man with an unprecedented, unenviable mission – and he knows it. The head of the first UN emergency health mission, which was created in September to fight Ebola, compares the task to fighting a raging blaze.</p> <p>“It’s like a forest fire, it keeps spreading and spreading. And when the firefighters come in, they get embers on their backs, which fly around as they try to put [the fire] out,” Banbury said in an interview in the Ghanaian capital Accra, where the UN Mission for Ebola Emergency Response (<a href="http://www.un.org/ebolaresponse/mission.shtml" title="">Unmeer)</a> is based.</p> <p>“The biggest challenge we have is to play the role of complex crisis manager. That’s one of the things that’s been lacking so far. There has been some really good work done by national governments, UN agencies, NGOs and – increasingly – foreign military, but they are all acting in their certain area,” he added.</p> <p>Announcing the creation of Unmeer in mid-September, the <a href="http://www.un.org/sg/statements/index.asp?nid=7999" title="">UN secretary general Ban Ki-moon said</a> the unprecedented situation required “unprecedented steps to save lives and safeguard peace and security”.</p> <p>Unmeer has five priorities: stopping the outbreak, treating the infected, ensuring essential services, preserving stability and preventing further outbreaks. To achieve these daunting goals, it needs to bring together the full range of UN actors and expertise to help the national efforts of countries struggling to control the disease. It will also work with the African Union and the Economic Community of West African States, (Ecowas).</p> <p>Ban has also warned that, as Ebola patients overwhelm poorly equipped health facilities, other people are dying from endemic diseases.</p> <p>“In the three most affected countries – Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone – the disease is destroying health systems. More people are now dying in Liberia from treatable ailments and common medical conditions than from Ebola,” he said.</p> <p>Banbury, an American who has worked for the White House National Security Council and the US defence department, as well as with the World Food Programme, is acutely aware of this ancillary demand. He also acknowledges that the crisis is affecting people’s ability to feed themselves: “We want to make sure that even as we are working to stop Ebola, people aren’t starving on the street.”</p> <p>According to the <a href="http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2014/10/08/ebola-new-world-bank-group-study-forecasts-billions-in-economic-loss-if-epidemic-lasts-longer-spreads-in-west-africa" title="">World Bank, the Ebola outbreak could cost the economies of west Africa $32.6bn (£20.1bn) by the end of 2015</a>, devastating fragile nations still recovering from decades of intertwined, resource-led wars.</p> <p>Unmeer will coordinate the arrival of protective gear, medical supplies, vehicles and generators to the region. It will also help develop existing healthcare facilities in the affected countries, including testing centres, community care facilities, treatment centres and training centres for healthcare workers.</p> <p>“The UN is uniquely positioned to help governments with the role of complex crisis manager and to do that across the region; Accra is the perfect place for us,” Banbury said.</p> <p>The UN has established a <a href="http://mptf.undp.org/factsheet/fund/EBO00" title="">$988m Ebola response multi-partner trust fund</a> to provide a common, coherent financing mechanism.</p> <p>Banbury has already visited the affected countries. He told reporters in Liberia last week that, despite “good results”, much remained to be done. He praised the work of district health officials and frontline NGO workers.</p> <p>With the scale of the crisis ever more apparent – already Ebola has claimed more than 3,800 lives – Banbury vowed Unmeer was in it for the long haul.</p> <p>“We will stay in place for 42 days – twice as long as the incubation period – after the last case, to make sure,” he said. “There is a lot of work to do. But we will not stop until Ebola is stopped.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/10/ebola-liberia-catastrophe-generation-poverty <p>The world is waking up to the shocking effects of the Ebola outbreak in west Africa. The US and the UK <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/07/ebola-us-troops-direct-contact-potential-sufferers-liberia" title="">have committed military forces</a>, and international organisations are similarly increasing funding and resources across the three affected countries. As cases appear in the US and Spain, it is obvious that this outbreak is no longer a localised west African problem, but a global emergency.</p> <p>If any more of a warning were needed, the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-patient-dies-texas-thomas-eric-duncan" title="">death of a Liberian in Texas</a> on Wednesday indicates the need for a unified global response, a call that was made by the Liberian government many months ago. Many have wished Ebola away, but the reality of our interconnected world has, despite our best efforts, meant the disease is now very real in countries far from the source of the outbreak.</p> <p>At the IMF and World Bank meetings this week, Ebola is being raised to the top of the agenda. This is because this crisis has ramifications far beyond public health. In short, the tragedy of Ebola does not lie just with the thousands of grieving families across the Mano River Union. It threatens an economic catastrophe that will affect a generation.</p> <p>All three affected west African nations already had fragile economies – in Liberia, we have emerged from a brutal civil war only 11 years previously. Similarly, Sierra Leone suffered a devastating civil conflict. Before this disease took hold, Liberia’s economic recovery was in full flow. Our economy was set to grow 5.9% this year. International investment was increasing. Major infrastructure projects were in the pipeline. Now with mining operations halted, harvests missed, regional trade suffocated and investors sheltering abroad, we are facing a possible recession within a year. This week, the World Bank estimated that west African economies will suffer a $36.2bn hit by the end of next year if Ebola is not brought under control. It is a dramatic, sudden and deeply frustrating turn of events.</p> <p>Our first priority to is to erect a robust economic safety net. The Liberian government has just signed a <a href="http://allafrica.com/stories/201409180760.html" title="">$52m grant with the World Bank</a>, $10m from the African Development Bank, and $5m from USAid to assist the government specifically with the Ebola fight. The IMF also approved our request for a special funding of $49m to support our budget.</p> <p>Yet this must be just the beginning. The Liberian economy has been all but paralysed. This will inevitably lead to a widening budget deficit and the curtailing of critical public investment projects. Budget-deficit estimates continue to pile up as the crisis drags on, with the latest figures as high as $130m. International financial institutions will have to continue to invest in vital health infrastructure, and support institutions that keep fundamental services intact. This must of course be in addition to the immediate need for medical supplies, health facilities and expertise.</p> <p>The government has already lost revenue equivalent to 25% of our annual receipts. While images of hospitals and dying patients saturate the international media, it is the hidden story of closed schools, unpaid teachers, underfunded security forces and absent local services that could threaten the very fabric of Liberian life.</p> <p>We will also need to unblock other critical arteries of our economy. The decimation of international air routes and the slow, grinding halt of cross-border trade must be resuscitated. This may not be possible at this stage of the outbreak, but the severing of Liberians from the outside world has destroyed livelihoods and driven many families into economic despair.</p> <p>The economic fallout from this crisis cannot be contained: our entire globalised economic system has a stake in this fight. Only this week, equity indexes have fallen in major cities and travel firms’ shares have dived with fears of further air-travel restrictions for holidaymakers and businesses. International financial institutions, resources companies and other large corporations have interests throughout the region. From cashews to cocoa to iron ore and oil, the ramifications of a west Africa cast adrift from the world economy are immense.</p> <p>For many young democracies in west Africa, the collective memory of political unrest, internal conflict and social upheaval is not far away. Over the past decade the region has, commendably, emerged from a history of conflict into a new era of vibrant and dynamic economic growth and cohesion. This is despite religious, ethnic and political division. Ebola risks marginalising and demotivating a whole generation of citizens through economic exclusion and poverty. The consequences for law and order and national unity are obvious. We simply cannot allow this to happen.</p> <p>Our financing must therefore be calculated and targeted. International financial institutions, private companies and donor countries must work together with the affected governments to ensure long-term economic damage is mitigated. In Liberia, this means filling an unexpected deficit quickly and keeping basic services online. Looking further ahead, planned infrastructure projects must not be allowed to dissolve away, and foreign investors must remain reassured and engaged. Support for community infrastructure and economic livelihood projects, particularly in Ebola-affected rural areas, should form a core of any post-Ebola strategy.</p> <p>The majority of Liberians have not contracted Ebola. But for every working family faced with ruined harvests, closed mines or empty markets, Ebola seems like a curse. It is a cruel fate for a people who in a single generation have already suffered immeasurably. This is why we are not just fighting a disease, but for the economic survival of a nation.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/business/marketforceslive/2014/oct/10/tui-travel-leads-ftse-100-lower-as-economy-and-ebola-fears-continue <p>After the recent market plunges, analysts believe it may be time to start looking for bargains among the beleagured.</p> <p>But there is no sign of that happening yet.</p> <p>The <strong>FTSE 100</strong> hit a twelve month low on Thursday and is down another 49.40 points at 6382.45 in early trading, following a 334 point slump on Wall Street overnight.</p> <p>Worries about the state of the global economy have been growing in recent days, with signs of a slowdown in China and Germany heading closer to a possible recession. The IMF did not help, by cutting its global growth forecasts, while the cheap money taps the central banks have been using to support the markets and economy are gradually being turned off.</p> <p>On top of that are the geo-political worries - air strikes in Syria, the situation in Ukraine, and the fallout of recent protests in Hong Kong.</p> <p>And of course, the spread of the Ebola virus.</p> <p>Mike McCudden at Interactive Investor said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The stuttering global economy continues to spook investors who appear to be on a mass exodus from equities to safer havens. Furthermore, with the German economy leading the euro zone from the frying pan in to the fire there are grave concerns for the future of the region.</p> <p>However, when fear grips, opportunities arise and both short and longer term investors will be lapping up opportunities as they come in droves.</p> </blockquote> <p>With Ebola possibly causing disruption, <strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/tuitravel">Tui Travel</a></strong> is down 14p at 342.9p and cruise company <strong><a href="http://theguardian.com/carnival">Carnival</a> </strong>has slipped 71p to £21.97. Analyst Charles Hall at Peel Hunt said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We are highly confident that the company will deliver our forecast of £63m in the current year, given the predictability of earnings, and we expect a significant increase in profits in H1, reflecting the increase in customers and the Npower deal. The company has announced that the interim dividend will be increased by 19%, reflecting the board’s confidence in the full year outcome. </p> </blockquote>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/cdc-health-ebola-inquiries-dallas-death <p>Since the first diagnosis of the disease in the US, the American public has become keenly aware of Ebola’s dangerous reach. <br /></p> <p>As concern rises, the nation’s public health agency said it receives hundreds of inquiries a day about possible Ebola cases, and all but one have been false alarms.<br /></p> <p>“Right now there is only one patient who’s ever been diagnosed with Ebola in the US and that individual tragically died,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) director Tom Frieden said on Wednesday, as news of a potential second patient – who ultimately tested negative for the virus – began to spread. </p> <p>He said the agency receives on average 800 inquiries a day about potential Ebola cases, up from about 50 before Thomas Eric Duncan, who died on Wednesday, was diagnosed with the disease at a hospital in Texas. Frieden said the added attention is positive because it means people are appropriately concerned about the virus that has killed nearly 4,000 people across Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.</p> <p>“We expect that we will see more rumors or concerns or possibilities of cases,” Frieden cautioned last week. “Until there is a positive laboratory test that is what they are: rumors and concerns.”<br /></p> <p>Those words looked prescient on Thursday, when the negative test results came back for deputy, Sgt <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-dallas-deputy-sheriff-hospital-symptoms-death">Michael Monnig</a> of the Dallas County Sheriff’s department, the subject of Wednesday’s reports about a possible second patient. Monnig had, in his official capacity, entered the apartment where Duncan had stayed before he was admitted to hospital.</p> <p>Responding to the growing concern that the virus might spread further, the US government announced on Wednesday that travelers from the three most affected west African countries will face enhanced screenings at five key American airports. </p> <p>But for a handful of lawmakers, these changes were not enough. Twenty-six members of the US House of Representatives, including three Democrats, signed a letter to President Barack Obama on Thursday imploring the administration to implement a travel ban on the three most affected west African nations, and impose visa restrictions on citizens from those countries. The administration, backed by public health officials, has previously said it will not ban travel from these countries.</p> <p>Speaking in Washington on Thursday, US Department of Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said he’d like more countries to implement Ebola screenings. </p> <p>“My goal is that we create internationally as many different checkpoints as possible for travelers to go through the system,” Reuters reported Johnson saying at Washington think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies.</p> <p>Meanwhile, about 200 airline cabin cleaners went on strike at New York’s LaGuardia airport on Thursday, to protest what they say are working conditions that do not protect against Ebola, among other diseases.</p> <p>“God forbid we get a disease like Ebola, Hepatitis, even AIDS, for $9 an hour it’s not worth it,” said Wendy Arellano, one of the strikers. “They’re not going to take care of us. They’re not going to take care of my kids if something happens to me,”</p> <p>Elsewhere in the US, there are two Americans undergoing treatment for Ebola: a freelance journalist and a World Health Organization (WHO) doctor.<br /></p> <p> Ashoka Mukpo, who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/04/us-ebola-patient-ashoka-mukpo-liberia">contracted the disease while covering the outbreak</a> in Liberia with NBC News, is undergoing treatment at the Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha. He received a blood transfusion from an American medical missionary who recovered from the disease. Doctors are hopeful that the blood of survivors could be used to help sick patients’ immune systems fight off the disease. <br /></p> <p>The other Ebola patient, who has not been identified for privacy reasons, contracted the disease in Sierra Leone and is still receiving treatment at Emory University hospital in Atlanta, the hospital confirmed on Thursday. </p> <p>Three other Americans, including the doctor who donated his blood, have survived the illness after treatment in the US, which included experimental drugs. One American has died in the current outbreak, a civil servant with dual American-Liberian citizenship and Nigeria’s Ebola patient zero.</p>

She runs a charity in Freetown, and has just returned from the epicentre of the outbreak in Kenema. See her earlier dispatches for this blog <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54367d0be4b04997e4a351a7">here</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54368deee4b04997e4a351c7">here</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-5436ece7e4b06ef687ff8f4d">here</a>.</em></p> <p>The two-month quarantine has had a dramatic effect on the economy, which was largely based on small businesses. Most people live hand-to-mouth, earning just enough money each day to feed their families and pay the rent. Shopkeepers buy in from Bo or Freetown, where prices are cheaper. Taxi drivers make their living doing the Bo to Kenema run. </p> <p><strong>“The vehicles are going nowhere</strong>,” says Amara, a driver:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p><em>They are just parked. We are just hanging around idle. All the families are suffering. Things are very difficult for me and my colleagues. There is no food in the house. Nothing.</em>” </p> </blockquote> <p>A shopkeeper named Sal said,<strong>“For now the business is really bad with us”:</strong></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p><em>Normally when people are traveling they come in to buy but since this sickness is around no-one can travel. Everything is difficult. I don’t understand what is going on because we don’t have help from anywhere.” </em></p> </blockquote> <p><strong>Widows who sold goods at the market</strong>, making just enough to put food on the table, have lost their own incomes in addition to their husband’s. Martha, a widow, said, “I have no money and no-one to pay the rent. The business came to an end and I have four children to feed.”</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436f5bee4b059d9478e08f0" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:48:06.869+01:00">9.48pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">US calls for more Ebola checkpoints worldwide</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>US Department of Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said on Thursday that he would like to expand screenings for the Ebola virus to airports outside the United States, Reuters reports: </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“My goal is that we create internationally as many different checkpoints as possible for travelers to go through the system,” said Johnson, speaking at Washington think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies. </p> <p>The Department announced on Wednesday that it would begin screening travelers arriving in five U.S. airports from three West African countries with high rates of Ebola. </p> <p>Johnson said most travelers entering the United States from the affected countries connect through other airports, often those in Europe.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436ece7e4b06ef687ff8f4d" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:34:52.158+01:00">9.34pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Kenema dispatch: A death in the family</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><em><strong>Hazel Chandler</strong> is a documentary maker who first went to Sierra Leone in 2004. She runs a charity in Freetown, and has just returned from the epicentre of the outbreak in Kenema. See her earlier dispatches for this blog <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54367d0be4b04997e4a351a7">here</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54368deee4b04997e4a351c7">here</a>.</em> </p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="848e892a5aeb025641dc437b46cb78c021493d59"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412886708667/92668640-483e-4931-96d8-f171843acfd2-280x420.jpeg" alt="Dr. Sheik Humarr Khan, left, pictured in July at an Ebola center in Kenema, later died from the virus, officials said." width="280" height="420" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Dr. Sheik Humarr Khan, left, pictured in July at an Ebola center in Kenema, later died from the virus, officials said.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>To people who are dealing with the trauma of loss – loss of children, loss of husband and bread winner, loss of parents – the trials of quarantine become less significant.</p> <p><strong>Death of a family member</strong> brings with it, not only grief, but fear and rejection and, in the early days, the destruction of your property. Now they use disinfectant but until recently mattresses, clothing and personal mementos were all burnt. </p> <p>Here is testimonial from a widow named Martha:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p><em>My husband was working in the Ebola hospital. When he died they took all our things and burnt them. There is nothing inside the house. I sat at home for 21 days and when quarantine ended my sister came with shoes and clothes for me</em>.” </p> </blockquote> <p>These are people who had very little to begin with and now have<strong> no incomes to replace what is lost.</strong> Martha continued,</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p><em>People shout at me and say my husband left me with Ebola. I wanted to take a picture of him for my children in the future but they would not allow me. So I went home and cried.”</em></p> </blockquote> <p>The number of children orphaned by Ebola is unknown. The NGO Street Child says that, in Kenema, the figure is at least 100. These children face very uncertain futures. Some have family in other cities who cannot help them because they simply cannot get through the road blocks. The <strong>numbers of children on the streets </strong>will swell if no-one comes to their aid.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:40:27.649+01:00">at 9.40pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436ed80e4b0cd82a095f15b" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:20:59.648+01:00">9.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Australian nurse cleared of Ebola</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>A Red Cross nurse in far north <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/queensland">Queensland</a>, Australia, who was undergoing tests in an isolation unit to see if she is <strong>suffering from Ebola, has been cleared,</strong> Queensland Health has reported. </p> <p>A <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2014/oct/09/ebola-fears-woman-observation-cairns-hospital-sierra-leone">Guardian report</a> from earlier today has details of her case:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The nurse, named in the media as Sue-Ellen Kovack, 57, returned to Australia on Tuesday after a month working in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/sierraleone">Sierra Leone</a>, one of the countries hardest hit by the epidemic which has so far claimed almost 3,900 lives across five west African countries.</p> <p>She was under observation in Cairns hospital, Queensland’s chief health officer, Jeanette Young, confirmed.</p> <p>She had been kept in home isolation and was admitted to hospital with a low-grade fever on Thursday.</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2014/oct/09/ebola-fears-woman-observation-cairns-hospital-sierra-leone">Read more here.</a></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:22:12.263+01:00">at 9.22pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436ea7ee4b0537810a48173" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:05:29.490+01:00">9.05pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Ebola aid: Who’s pledged what?</strong></p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/GdnDevelopment/statuses/520302927848943616">  <blockquote <a href="https://twitter.com/GdnDevelopment/status/520302927848943616">October 9, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436e855e4b0537810a48170" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:00:04.420+01:00">9.00pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Dallas county deputy tests negative for Ebola</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>The Texas Department of State Health Services announced Thursday a deputy sheriff in the Dallas suburb of Frisco who had entered the apartment where Ebola victim Thomas Eric Duncan had stayed <strong>has tested negative for Ebola.</strong></p> <p>It <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-dallas-deputy-sheriff-hospital-symptoms-death">had been feared</a> that the deputy, identified as <strong>Michael West Monnig,</strong> had contracted Ebola after he exhibited flu-like symptoms.</p> <p>The health services completed testing of a specimen submitted today by Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas, it said:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The result is negative for Ebola.</p> </blockquote> <p>Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas, which is treating the deputy, said his health is improving. “<strong>Mr Monnig’s condition is good with no fever, </strong>no vomiting, no diarrhea reported. His current condition is NOT consistent with an early stage ebola diagnosis,” the hospital said in a statement.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T21:07:38.701+01:00">at 9.07pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436e20be4b0537810a48169" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T20:46:09.534+01:00">8.46pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Foreign Office officials are investigating <strong>reports that a British national has died in Macedonia of suspected Ebola</strong>, Saska Cvetkovska (<a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=Saska%20Cvetkovska&amp;src=typd">@saskac</a>) reports for the Guardian from Skopje.</p> <p>If confirmed it would be the first death of a UK national from Ebola (British nurse Will Pooley was cured of the virus last month):</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The Macedonian government last night said it was investigating the death of a British national on its territory after an undiagnosed illness but stressed that the cause of death had not been confirmed.</p> <p>“It is a British citizen who has died. The health ministry is trying to find out what he died from and it needs some time to find out the reason,” a foreign ministry spokesman said. “We are following the protocols of what to do in such cases set out by the World Health Organisation.”</p> <p>The director of the commission for infectious disease at the ministry of health, Jovanka Kostovska, said the man, a 56-year-old, had traveled from London to Macedonia on 2 October with a colleague for business. He had been staying at a hotel in the centre of Skopje when he was taken ill with severe stomach ache and increased temperature. The man remained in his hotel room for three days, before an ambulance was called yesterday afternoon around 3pm local time. He was taken to hospital where he died around 90 minutes later.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>At this stage ebola is only suspected, </strong>and further tests are to be carried out by a laboratory in Germany to find out if it is ebola or not. Results are expected within 48 hours.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436dea1e4b06ef687ff8f3a" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T20:20:36.855+01:00">8.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The Guardian’s Lauren Gambino (<a href="https://twitter.com/LGamGam">@LGamGam</a>) has spoken with Wendy Arellano, one of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-5436aec9e4b059d9478e0885">about 200 maintenance staff</a> at La Guardia airport who have staged a walkout to protest what they say are unsafe working conditions that do not protect against potential Ebola contraction. </p> <p><strong>Wendy guides the water and lavatory trucks</strong> and on occasion she has to <strong>clean bathrooms in plane cabins</strong>, she told Lauren:<strong> </strong></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“When I do bathroom, I come in contact with tampons which I have to grab with my hand with a glove that is so cheap that it breaks easily. I come in contact with feces, a lot of feces and vomit. And we have to clean those bathrooms spotless because they audit those planes.</p> <p>They expect us, that if a little bit of feces stays on the toilet, that we remove it with our hands because [if not] they will say that bathroom is dirty. And I refuse to do it because I think it’s disgusting and I don’t have the appropriate attire, and because I don’t know what that person has. </p> <p>We come in contact with a lot of stuff that is dangerous for our health and obviously they don’t give us the appropriate tools to work with.</p> <p>God forbid we get a disease like Ebola, Hepatitis, even AIDS, for $9 an hour it’s not worth it. They’re not going to take care of us. They’re not going to take care of my kids if something happens to me.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>Air Serv, an employer of the people striking today,</strong> released the following statement in response to the walkout:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Air Serv trains its cabin cleaners in its long-standing safety procedures and cleaning protocols including for blood borne pathogens. These protocols include, but are not limited to, providing cleaners with protective equipment. We continually review our policies and procedures for updates and enhancements, and communicate updates to employees, as necessary – for example, including an update on protocols for Ebola just last week. As to the union’s organizing campaign, we have no comment.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T20:28:11.318+01:00">at 8.28pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436d7eee4b06ef687ff8f2e" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T20:12:53.812+01:00">8.12pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Live Q&amp;A: Ebola survivor Comfort Kollie answers your questions about what it's like to live with the virus</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="921405d91ac73641ddc2373f90d2266a3c416871"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412881244914/3bb0ccad-3a8a-46de-8861-e384bc68d05b-bestSizeAvailable.jpeg" alt="Comfort Kollie " width="240" height="360" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Comfort Kollie</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: IMC</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>When you got sick what were the most important things that helped you get through it?</strong><br /></p> <p>The encouragement I had was knowing the Lord was going to free me, because they told me that Ebola was something that had no cure. So when I got it I was very down. For me to walk, it was hard when I got that. So, I tried by all means. I drank my oral rehydration salts and the nurses helped me when I was weak. They gave me my medicine. Where I was, so many people died in my presence. In the morning, I would get on my knees and crawl. I was very sick when I got to the International Medical Corps centre. And the day that I left from there was a joyful day. So, I’m very happy.</p> <p><strong>What more do you think could be done to help people survive Ebola by organisations on the ground?</strong></p> <p>Bring personal protective equipment (PPE), because PPE is something that can only be used one time. And nurses go in there three times a day, and the patients are becoming more. So the thing I’m telling them to help us with is PPE, so that people will be able to go and take care of the patients. Without the PPE, you can’t go in there. Even if the patient is dying, you can’t go in there, because you have to protect yourself. So I’m asking them to please come in with more help like these International Medical Corps people have, more PPE and equipment--medicines, gloves, IV drips to help the other people there.</p> <p><strong>As a survivor you probably won’t get sick again, how does this change how you feel about being around the virus?</strong></p> <p>I feel alright. Even if I enter a place with people with Ebola, I know I cannot get Ebola. So I’m free now. I’m happy I will not get it. And if I enter in there, I will be happy talking with them, counselling them, telling them what to do to be safe like me. </p> <p><strong><strong>Will you return to nursing those with the disease?</strong></strong></p> <p> Yes, if I’m strong enough to walk, I will return to nursing, because I’m an Ebola-free patient now. I can never get Ebola in my life again.</p> <p><strong>Having seen other Ebola victims first hand and after suffering the disease yourself, what is the reality of suffering Ebola, and what sort of thoughts went through your mind when you were diagnosed and ill?</strong></p> <p>When I was at Phebe Hospital, there were five nurses that left to Monrovia for treatment. It was a day of so much crying. But none of them came back to Phebe. So when I got Ebola, when I suspected that I had Ebola, for all I knew, I was not going to come back. That was the only thing I could think. My friends, never came back. They tried by all means, but not one of them came back. Now, about eight of them have died. I survived. </p> <p>I was afraid. I was walking up and down, and I would sit in here, because I didn’t want anyone to come around me. So I stayed in the back of the house. In the night I would leave the room and come out here and lie on the ground, so nobody would come close. I told them, I am getting the virus they are all talking about. So I was very afraid. I told them the next place they would take me, I would not come back. I told them, take care of each other, because I’m not going to come back, because Ebola kills and there is no medicine for it. Only the International Medical Corps centre was able to save me.</p> <p><strong>Have you returned to your regular state of health or are you still suffering from any lingering symptoms? And have any of your symptoms caused permanent physical damage?</strong></p> <p>I still have pains in my joints. But when I try by all means, I can move around. The symptoms I had when I had Ebola, I don’t have those symptoms anymore. They have all gone away. I can eat.</p> <p>I’m improving. Sometimes in the morning, I take the broom and I start sweeping. They try to take the broom from me, but I say no, it’s small exercise. I also try to make the fire, and they try to tell me no, but I say I want to try to do things as I did before. I’m relearning how to do them.</p> <p><strong>Assuming you have been observing media coverage of the Ebola outbreak, is there some bit of information that has so far not been communicated, or perhaps not communicated prominently enough, that you think the public should be aware of?</strong></p> <p>Stigma. The people who used to pass by here, now they pass on the road. The journalists need to tell people not to stigmatize us. They stigmatize the children, they tell them, don’t go in that yard or you’ll get Ebola. When you pass, pass with speed, run! Run and pass them before Ebola gets you. So that’s what I want to tell them.</p> <p>Keep on telling people, Ebola is a real sickness. It’s no joke. People are still here denying it. </p> <p>Read an <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54368ea7e4b04997e4a351c8">interview with Ebola survivor Will Pooley</a>, and an<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54368617e4b09ceaddbcada9"> interview with Ebola survivor Harrison Sakilla </a></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T20:13:25.534+01:00">at 8.13pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436dc15e4b0cd82a095f148" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T20:05:39.324+01:00">8.05pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">France says Ebola not suspected in quarantine</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Kim Willsher (<a href="https://twitter.com/kimwillsher1">@kimwillsher1</a>) in Paris reports for the Guardian that an alert was lifted around a social services building in the Paris suburb of Cergy-Pontoise after two hours on Thursday evening after the French authorities said fears of Ebola amounted to a false alarm.</p> <p>French authorities sealed off a building near Paris on concerns about Ebola on Thursday after four people inside fell ill with headaches and fever, Reuters reported:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“The suspicion (of Ebola) is lifted,” said the official in the town of Cergy Pontoise, northwest of Paris. </p> <p>Police and interior ministry sources had said earlier the social services building was sealed off with 60 people inside after the four people, who arrived in France from Guinea in early October, fell ill. France has not reported any cases of the Ebola virus. </p> </blockquote> <p>An <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-5436cb4be4b0cd82a095f12f">earlier report</a> said four children in the building who had recently come to France from Guinea showed symptoms of the virus.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T20:09:31.951+01:00">at 8.09pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436d4fae4b06ef687ff8f29" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T19:36:29.874+01:00">7.36pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here’s a significant asterisk to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-5436c952e4b0537810a4814b">earlier report</a> that a House committee had agreed to release<strong> an additional $700m to fight Ebola.</strong> For that money to be released the proposal must pass the Senate as well, and an aide to Sen. James Inhofe, the top Republican on the Senate Armed Services panel, said <strong>Inhofe has not signed off on the money, </strong>the AP reports: </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>It takes the OK of the top Republican and Democrat on the House and Senate Armed Services and Appropriations panels to “reprogram” Pentagon funds. The Democrats have already agreed to the proposal.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436ce63e4b0537810a48150" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time Reuters reports:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A Health Ministry official said the man had arrived in the capital, Skopje, from Britain on Oct. 2 and had been rushed to hospital at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT) on Thursday, where he died several hours later. </p> <p>Dr. Jovanka Kostovska of the ministry’s commission for infectious diseases said the man had been suffering from fever, vomiting and internal bleeding, and that his condition deteriorated rapidly. </p> <p>“These are all symptoms of Ebola, which raises suspicions with this patient,” Kostovska told a news conference, adding that samples had been sent to Germany for tests to confirm the cause of death. </p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436c952e4b0537810a4814b" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:57:37.440+01:00">6.57pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Congress members ask Obama to impose travel ban</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>More than two dozen lawmakers want the US government to ban travelers from the West African countries hit hardest by the Ebola virus until the outbreak is under control, Reuters <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/09/us-health-ebola-usa-screening-idUSKCN0HY20B20141009">reports</a>:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Twenty-three Republican and three Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives signed a letter released on Thursday to President Barack Obama asking the State Department to impose a travel ban and restrict visas issued to citizens of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. </p> <p>In the letter, dated Oct. 8, they also asked U.S. health and border control officials to consider quarantine for anyone who arrives from the affected nations after being exposed to Ebola until 21 days have passed, the period in which they would show signs of the illness. </p> <p> The lawmakers said Obama should not wait for the World Health Organization to dictate how U.S. authorities should proceed. </p> <p>“The WHO is an organization of unelected bureaucrats and political appointees of foreign countries. It has no duty to protect the lives and well-being of Americans, as you do,” the letter said. </p> </blockquote> <p>Read the <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/09/us-health-ebola-usa-screening-idUSKCN0HY20B20141009">full report here</a>. Separately, Republicans in the US House of Representatives on Thursday agreed to <strong>release $700 million more to fight Ebola </strong>from the Defense Department’s request to shift $1 billion in war funds, bringing the total so far to $750 million, Reuters reports:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The additional funds were released following briefings from Pentagon officials this week after a handful of lawmakers had limited the funding shift to just $50 million until they received more information about plans to deploy up to 4,000 U.S. troops to West Africa to fight the disease </p> <p>“This week, the committee received briefings in which the DoD estimates, based upon prior humanitarian relief efforts they will require $750 million for the first six months of the mission,” said House Armed Services Committee Chairman Howard “Buck” McKeon said in a statement. </p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436cb4be4b0cd82a095f12f" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:52:08.032+01:00">6.52pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The Dallas hospital treating a sheriff’s deputy who went into the apartment where an Ebola victim was living says the <strong>deputy is showing no signs that he’s also infected, </strong>the Associated Press ambulance to the hospital.</p> <p>The hospital says Monnig does not have a fever, vomiting or diarrhea. Results of further testing are expected later Thursday.</p> <p> Monnig was one of the deputies who went inside the Dallas apartment where Thomas Eric Duncan was staying. Monnig did not have contact with Duncan, but did see some of Duncan’s family members now in isolation. </p> <p>Duncan died Wednesday.</p> <p> Officials say none of Duncan’s relatives have shown any signs that they are infected.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="00bfb70bc79ab7a005a34978ab53d4f6dd504e8c"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412877084134/b17fb947-3edb-4cc9-a105-a3eca9320ce7-460x276.jpeg" alt="Steve Oriabure, Eric Williams, a candidate for US Congress district 30, and Dr. Richard Nwachukwu hold a prayer vigil at The Ivy Apartments following the death of Liberian national Thomas Eric Duncan from Ebola, in Dallas, Texas October 8, 2014." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Steve Oriabure, Eric Williams, a candidate for US Congress district 30, and Dr. Richard Nwachukwu hold a prayer vigil at The Ivy Apartments following the death of Liberian national Thomas Eric Duncan from Ebola, in Dallas, Texas October 8, 2014.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: BRANDON WADE/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436c8b0e4b0537810a48148" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:42:39.907+01:00">6.42pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Reuters has <strong>more on the reported death of a Briton in Macedonia</strong>. The report, which refers to a second Briton said to have fallen ill with symptoms consistent with Ebola, quotes “a senior Macedonian government official who spoke on condition of anonymity”:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>He said the two had been staying at a hotel in the capital Skopje and that hotel staff and the ambulance crew that took them in for treatment had been put into isolation.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436c6c0e4b06ef687ff8f19" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:36:03.180+01:00">6.36pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Want to help? Here are some ways.</strong></p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/GdnDevelopment/statuses/520264118360473600">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Ebola outbreak: how can you help? <a href="http://t.co/FCimG9wtUb">http://t.co/FCimG9wtUb</a></p>&mdash; Global Development (@GdnDevelopment) <a href="https://twitter.com/GdnDevelopment/status/520264118360473600">October 9, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The death toll from the Ebola epidemic continues to rise – <a href="http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/136020/1/roadmapsitrep_8Oct2014_eng.pdf?ua=1">more than 3,800 cases have been confirmed</a>, the vast majority in west Africa – and on Wednesday the US and UK made another “urgent plea” for all nations to boost their efforts to combat the virus. So what is currently being done – and what can you do to help?</p> <h2>How to volunteer</h2> <p>• In the UK, <a href="http://uk-med.humanities.manchester.ac.uk/">more than 500 NHS workers have signed up to volunteer at a hospital in Sierra Leone</a>. NHS staff wishing to be considered for the UK response to Ebola in west Africa can <a href="https://eduqate.net/form-portlet/share/0690148788cf482899981f9d5df33d14#/0690148788cf482899981f9d5df33d14">register their interest</a>.</p> <p>• <a href="http://www.msf.org.uk/work-overseas">Médecins sans Frontières is recruiting field staff from both medical and non-medical backgrounds</a>.</p> <p>• <a href="http://www.usaid.gov/ebola/volunteers">USAid is inviting qualified medical professionals to volunteer.</a></p> <p>• The International Medical Corps is <a href="http://internationalmedicalcorps.org/ebola-emergency-response">recruiting qualified healthcare practitioners, water, sanitation and environmental experts, psychosocial staff and logistics, human resources and finance professionals</a> to work in Ebola treatment units in Sierra Leone and Liberia</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>For additional ways to help, including many suggestions for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-how-you-can-help">HOW TO DONATE</a> and how to stay informed, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-how-you-can-help">click here</a>.</strong></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:37:21.126+01:00">at 6.37pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436c5c3e4b0cd82a095f12b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:31:27.076+01:00">6.31pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Readers in Ebola outbreak zones have been sharing images,</strong> video and text with us via the <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41#contribute">GuardianWitness tool</a> (view submissions or <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41#contribute">contribute yourself here</a>).</p> <p>Here are two submissions from Sierra Leone:</p>  <figure class="element itemprop="contentURL"/></a>    <figcaption>  <h3 class="element-witness--title" itemprop="name"><a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41/1187268" itemprop="url">My parents are terrified, but I am committed to help others</a></h3>  <div itemprop="description"> <p>Edna Epelu, head of the World Food Programme sub-office in Makeni, Sierra Leone:“At the office we have a rule. Any person that comes in have their body temperature taken to make sure they don’t have fever. The rule stands for staff members and visitors alike.</p> <p>My parents, my siblings, my friends are all concerned. My parents are in East Africa. This Ebola outbreak does not relate to anything they have heard or experienced. We communicate through emails and phone calls. They are terrified with what they see in the news. They think that I am taking a big risk. But this is the work I like. I’m committed to helping others where I can, so eventually they are super supportive.”</p> </div>   </figcaption>  </div> <footer class="element-witness--footer"> <p class="element-witness--source">Sent via <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/" class="element-witness--brand" itemprop="provider">GuardianWitness</a></p> <div class="element-witness--metadata"> <p class="element-witness--author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">  By  <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/user/AlexisMasciarelli" class="element-witness--author-name" itemprop="name">AlexisMasciarelli</a> </p> <p class="element-witness--date"> <time itemprop="dateCreated" datetime="2014-10-09T13:00:53Z">9 October 2014, 9:00</time> </p> </div> </footer>  </figure>  <figure class="element element-witness element-witness-image" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" data-media-id="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41/1187440"> <div class="element-witness--main">  <a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41/1187440" itemprop="url"><img src="https://n0tice-static.s3.amazonaws.com/image/14128675603686c16bfbbd02172e362da683e1183bd96-mediumoriginalaspectdouble.jpg" alt="Information and awareness needed" itemprop="contentURL"/></a>    <figcaption>  <h3 class="element-witness--title" itemprop="name"><a href="https://witness.theguardian.com/assignment/541c1101e4b0e32cb9c53a41/1187440" itemprop="url">Information and awareness needed</a></h3>  <div itemprop="description"> <p>People of Sierra Leone keep on be suspicious, they don’t trust authorities and medical staff. One drug takes several months to produce, and so will not be widely available any time soon. But there are many everyday practical measure that are important to containing the outbreak. Watch for more:</p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2014/oct/09/ebola-virus-outbreak-stop-spreading-africa-video"                        data-show-ads="true"                data-video-id="2173123"                data-video-name="Ebola: how can we stop it spreading? - video report"                data-video-provider="guardian.co.uk"                data-video-poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/10/9/1412869349880/ebola-how-to-stop-it-010.jpg"> <video data-media-id="gu-video-449300715" class="gu-video" controls="controls" poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/10/9/1412869342002/ebola-how-to-stop-it-008.jpg"> <source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2014/10/09/141009EbolaSevenWays-16x9.mp4"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2014/10/09/141009EbolaSevenWays_3gpSml16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2014/10/09/141009EbolaSevenWays.webm"></source><source src="http://multimedia.guardianapis.com/interactivevideos/video.php?octopusid=9624162&amp;format=video/m3u8"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2014/10/09/141009EbolaSevenWays_3gpLg16x9.3gp"></source> </video> <figcaption>The Ebola virus has spread rapidly through West Africa, claiming thousands of lives. A Spanish priest and a US citizen have also died during the outbreak. Vaccines and experimental drugs are being developed but there are other measures that need to be put in place to halt the Ebola outbreak. What are they? </figcaption> </figure> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:25:41.337+01:00">at 6.25pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436c2bfe4b0537810a48140" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:20:01.170+01:00">6.20pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>For some diaspora west Africans,</strong> there is the twin distress of being thousands of miles away from relatives and communities who have succumbed to Ebola, as well as facing <strong>stigma in their adopted homeland</strong>, reports Guardian West Africa correspondent Monica Mark (<a href="https://twitter.com/nickswicks">@nickswicks</a>):<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Some say they have been told not to come into work on the back of a wave of negative publicity surrounding the death of Thomas Duncan, the Liberian who was diagnosed with Ebola in America. Duncan died Wednesday. </p> <p>Guinean-American Fatima Diallo, a 28-year-old living in New York, said she now fears going to the hospital if she falls sick. “They may treat me the same way [as a Guinean returnee] and it is really traumatising,” she said.</p> <p>Mohammed Jabadeh, 27, a New York City tour bus employee from Liberia, lost 14 members of his family. His brother was the latest to become infected. “It’s actually heartbreaking to me because that’s one of my brothers I love very much,” Jabadeh told Nigeria’s Nation newspaper.</p> <p>He said that he has been sending more money home to encourage his family to stay indoors. “You have to work extra hard in America and send them enough money so that they can have enough foodstuff.”</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>Apprehension is growing as the death toll rises,</strong> Monica writes:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“Nowadays, I’m afraid to answer the phone, because I think they’re going to tell me about another casualty -- someone has died,” Macdaniel Powell, a Liberian-born resident in Minnesota, recently told <a href="http://kstp.com/news/stories/S3578725.shtml">Five Eyewitness News</a>.</p> <p>Minnesota has one of the largest west African communities in the US, and some have banded together to raise awareness of the disease and fight back against ignorance. Since August, the Minnesota African Task Force has been recruiting health workers to volunteer in Liberia while distributing educational flyers.</p> <p>And a fundraising football match and prayer vigil recently held in Bronx was well attended by many from across the diaspora. “I know it’s in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone but at this point it doesn’t matter because it is West Africa,” said Usman Gaye, 34, from Gambia.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436c09be4b0537810a4813d" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T18:07:34.857+01:00">6.07pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Macedonia says Briton dies, Ebola suspected</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>A British national suspected of contracting the Ebola virus has died</strong> in Macedonia, a senior Macedonian government official said on Thursday, Reuters reports:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A second Briton had shown symptoms of the virus, the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time Britain is preparing to send 750 troops to Sierra Leone to assist with building new clinics and to train local staff.</figcaption> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436b775e4b0cd82a095f116" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T17:41:25.279+01:00">5.41pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Here is an update to accounts by <strong>aid workers in Sierra Leone of their work today</strong> (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54364fb5e4b0cd82a095f037">see earlier post</a>).<strong> </strong></p> <p><strong>From Freetown, Kelfa Kargbo, director of Street Child </strong>- <a href="http://www.street-child.co.uk/">a British charity that turned its 650-strong community workforce in Sierra Leone and Liberia to the Ebola effort two months ago </a>- says “the problem is far from solved”:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>This morning one member of Street Child staff passed a corpse in the centre of Freetown on his drive to work; the family had been calling the Ebola response team for days, but nobody had come. </p> <p>My morning meeting with Street Child senior management was extremely optimistic; our collective feeling is that our Ebola teaching training strategy will bring positive results. </p> <p>One of my Street Child staff members, Moses Kargbo, expressed his feelings of shock after his recent visit to Street Child-supported, quarantined families in Makeni. </p> <p>While collecting information for Street Child to disseminate to the media, Moses witnessed many untreated sick and countless families without food or humanitarian aid. </p> <p>Street Child initiatives, such as teacher training and providing humanitarian aid, are a major step in the fight against Ebola, but the problem is far from solved. </p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="8b938945be6a1923cee3a509148dd412286f4e96"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412873140171/914afe35-fc08-499e-b54c-2e3e41e87297-280x420.jpeg" alt="A poster about Ebola is displayed at the Hill Station community west of Freetown, Sierra Leone, 08 October 2014." width="280" height="420" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A poster about Ebola is displayed at the Hill Station community west of Freetown, Sierra Leone, 08 October 2014.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: STR/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>From Kenema, George Quaker, </strong><strong>deputy head of operations for Street Child, </strong>says “the orphan numbers are shocking”<strong>:</strong></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>I am just leaving the ministry of social welfare, gender and children’s affairs after a fruitful meeting. I received all the data Street Child needs on the number of orphaned children and post-quarantined families. </p> <p>The orphan numbers are shocking; in Kenema district alone 400 orphans have been identified. As part of Street Child’s campaign to support 1,000 Ebola orphans, it is our hope that we can provide immediate support for the majority of these orphans in the form of food, clothing and, where needed, medical support. Street Child will then undergo a reunification process to provide these orphans with the care of a relative or foster carer. </p> <p>In Kenema, everybody is greatly challenged, which makes the work of Street Child all the more important; we have identified 116 post-quarantined households who need support. This afternoon I will visit these families and assess how many children they have, and how best Street Child can support the primary breadwinner. Our aim is that these children are cared for and can return to school when schools are re-opened. </p> </blockquote> <p><strong>From Makeni, John Momodu Kargbo, head of operations for the rural Bombali</strong> district, passes on an account of a runaway grandmother and child:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>As Street Child staff conducted their morning visits to quarantined homes in Makeni we were told of an old grandmother who had run away with a baby believed to be suffering from Ebola; she had refused to take the child for treatment. </p> <p>This was two weeks ago and they are currently feared dead. In this remote cluster of seven houses, known as Masuba, losses have been great, tens of people have died and more are feared infected. </p> <p>Street Child is also stepping up our engagement with Street Children living permanently on the streets. Training for Street Child staff has given us a better platform to educate street children about Ebola prevention. </p> </blockquote> <p>Read what the aid workers told us <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/oct/09/ebola-disease-in-a-day-live#block-54364fb5e4b0cd82a095f037">earlier on Thursday here</a> (via <a href="https://twitter.com/lisaocarroll">@lisaocarroll</a>).</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T17:45:54.647+01:00">at 5.45pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436b5b6e4b06ef687ff8f00" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T17:21:55.902+01:00">5.21pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Liberia,</strong> where the healthcare system is still reeling from a devastating 1989-2003 civil war,<strong> is facing recession and may need more aid</strong> from the International Monetary Fund given the budgetary toll the virus has taken, its finance minister said Thursday. <a href="http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFW1N0S302X20141009">Reuters reports</a>:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“Our economy was projected to grow by 5.9 percent. That growth has been revised down to 1 percent,” Finance Minister Amara Konneh told Reuters late on Wednesday. “Technically, the economy is in recession.” </p> <p>Konneh said the nation’s service sector had taken the biggest blow with activity “declining significantly by some 10 percent.” He said the agricultural sector had shrunk by 12 percent, and cited mining and manufacturing as other areas under heavy pressure.</p> </blockquote> <p>Read the <a href="http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFW1N0S302X20141009">full piece here</a>. <br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T17:22:01.390+01:00">at 5.22pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436a84ee4b059d9478e087b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T17:10:44.271+01:00">5.10pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Two U.S. military flights were due to arrive in Liberia</strong> on Thursday, Army Capt. R. Carter Langston told The Associated Press in an email: </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“Two different flights of MV-22 Osprey and KC-130 aircraft, along with U.S. Marines, will arrive to support the whole-of-government effort to contain Ebola,” Carter said, noting they would land at Roberts Airfield outside Monrovia.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="e7f77b7e32ea4cb63b95c00135afa0fcf333b407"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412873476336/2d692d1f-3f1b-426f-93e5-6d58baa085af-460x259.jpeg" alt="A picture released by the US Marine Corps on 09 October 2014 shows US Marines and Sailors assigned to Special Purpose Marine Air-Ground Task Force-Crisis Response-Africa prepare to board an KC-130J Super Hercules as they deploy to West Africa in support of Operation United Assistance, at Moron Air Base, Spain, 08 October 2014." width="460" height="259" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A picture released by the US Marine Corps on 09 October 2014 shows US Marines and Sailors assigned to Special Purpose Marine Air-Ground Task Force-Crisis Response-Africa prepare to board an KC-130J Super Hercules as they deploy to West Africa in support of Operation United Assistance, at Moron Air Base, Spain, 08 October 2014.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: US Marine Corps/ Gerard Farao/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The announcement came as Sierra Leone President Koroma called the outbreak<strong> “a tragedy unforeseen in modern times”:</strong></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“Our people are dying,” Sierra Leone President Ernest Bai Koroma said by videoconference at a World Bank meeting in Washington on the Ebola response. He called the epidemic “a tragedy unforeseen in modern times,” saying the world is not responding fast enough as children are orphaned and doctors and nurses continue to die.</p> <p>A Uganda-born doctor, John Taban Dada, died early Thursday of Ebola at a treatment center on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia’s capital. Over ninety health workers, including nurses and physician assistants, have also died. Even people who live within reach of a medical clinic - and many do not - will often go to the healer as well. Research Richard Mallett and colleagues from the Overseas Development Institute studied healthcare provision in Sierra Leone a few months ago, which led to a report and <a href="http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/medical_examiner/2014/10/sierra_leone_plural_health_care_system_why_people_go_to_traditional_healers.html">photo essay</a>.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="3876a020aa06cfb18cb14c6d3b1a691e5fc91529"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412863602637/777a04ca-2254-49a2-b0db-6b155da8b52b-460x276.jpeg" alt="A traditional healer in the Kambia district of northern Sierra Leone." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A traditional healer in the Kambia district of northern Sierra Leone.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Richard Mallett/SLRC</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><br />Their work underlines how important it is for those trying to contain the Ebola epidemic in west Africa to engage with communities and traditional leaders. <br /></p> <p>The briefing paper says there is: <br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A high level of respect accorded to elders and traditional knowledge in Sierra Leone. Because traditional healers are venerated in society, even individuals who do not actually believe in their treatments take them seriously. This is particularly the case where the traditional healer is a religious leader, as their treatments are bound up with social norms about good behaviour<br /></p> </blockquote> <p>The healers are in a position to be able to educate and influence their communities - which means that though their medicines will not help, they can be part of the solution.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T16:54:51.896+01:00">at 4.54pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436aec9e4b059d9478e0885" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T16:51:07.086+01:00">4.51pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">New York City plane cabin cleaners walk out to protest Ebola risk</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>About 200 airplane cabin cleaners at La Guardia airport in Queens walked off the job Wednesday night, protesting that they were not provided with adequate protection to handle the blood, feces, hypodermic needles and other biohazards they encounter in their jobs. </p> <p>The New York Daily News <a href="http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/lga-cabin-cleanders-walk-job-claiming-unsafe-conditions-article-1.1968344">reports</a>:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>“I have to deal with vomit, feces and a lot of chemicals, without proper equipment,” cleaner Johanna Cruz, 33 and from Queens, told the Daily News. “They give us gloves, but they might as well be made of paper because they rip so easily.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Read the <a href="http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/lga-cabin-cleanders-walk-job-claiming-unsafe-conditions-article-1.1968344">full piece here</a>. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="2514aefe8960dd85f7db9d0e080435bb96060b36"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412869829791/e69f84d4-e834-44f8-98bc-e058580a8bed-460x307.jpeg" alt="Passengers wait in line at Transportation Security Administration (TSA) checkpoint at John F. Of the seven dead, four were medics. </p> <p>West Africa correspondent <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/-sp-ebola-west-africa-health-workers"><strong>Monica Mark</strong> reports on the heroism of doctors</a> including <strong>Sheikh Umar Khan</strong> in Sierra Leone and <strong>Ameyo Adadevoh</strong>, who treated Patrick Sawyer, Nigeria’s patient zero, in a small Lagos hospital. </p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Adadevoh set up aggressive barrier nursing, organised the disinfection of the hospital, and downloaded and distributed Ebola factsheets. For six days, the clinic’s staff effectively ran an Ebola isolation unit with no government help. When Liberian presidential officials called to insist Sawyer be released to attend a conference – he was a high-ranking civil servant – the hospital refused to let him go. And when an isolation ward was finally set up, Adadevoh visited even as other doctors refused to volunteer to staff it.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="cca2ce9da80191d34e8778fc8bb71a52b8d23da6"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412838303617/c9272a96-ed89-4517-ba9a-8dcd629897fb-460x276.jpeg" alt="Ameyo Adadevoh" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A candle light vigil in Abuja for Ameyo Adadevoh, who died treating Nigeria’s first Ebola patient.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Afolabi Sotunde / Reuters/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Read her full report on the impact of Ebola on West African
