<time datetime="2014-10-09T15:24:49.329+01:00">at 3.24pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54368ea7e4b04997e4a351c8" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:54:09.297+01:00">2.54pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Live Q&amp;A: Ebola survivor Will Pooley answers your questions about what it's like to live with the virus</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="f2117e46937ca10768feecac452c8972bc6c47cd"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412863098197/8fd5eaaa-f0dc-4aff-bb11-84549df95345-bestSizeAvailable.jpeg" alt="Will Pooley" width="240" height="360" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">British Ebola survivor and nurse Will Pooley.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: WILL OLIVER / POOL</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>As survivors you probably won’t get sick again, how does this change how you feel about being around the virus?</strong></p> <p>I have yet to re-encounter the virus. Will let you know when I do!</p> <p><strong>When you got sick what helped you get through it? </strong></p> <p>World class care, a wonderful family and Zmapp!</p> <p><strong>Having seen other Ebola victims firsthand and after suffering the disease yourself, what is the reality?</strong></p> <p>For me it was all about the fear of the symptoms. I was afraid of the vomiting, bleeding and mental disturbance. I was lucky that I didn’t develop any of these.</p> <p><strong>Have you returned to your regular state of health?</strong><br /></p> <p>I really felt fully recovered to 100 percent health before I was discharged or about 10 days after my diagnosis. I know of other survivors that suffer fatigue and weakness long after clearing the virus. Patients that get very sick before recovering may suffer longer term internal organ damage. Again I was fortunate enough to escape all this. </p> <p><strong>What’s the period of time is between someone beginning to recover, and being declared non-contagious?</strong><br /></p> <p>When someone recovers and symptoms (diarrhea, vomiting, bleeding etc) disappear people can be considered broadly non-contagious. At this point they will no longer be heavily shedding virus into the environment. Patients are officially declared virus free and can then be considered non-contagious when bodily fluids are tested and are negative. Semen is an exception and may be infectious long after all else is negative. Times scales vary for all of this from a few days from beginning to recover until virus negative (except semen) and a few weeks. <br /></p> <p><strong>Considering the presumable immunity of survivors, do you think it would be feasible to adopt a policy of recruiting and training volunteer survivors to carry out high-risk work on the ground as the epidemic grows?</strong></p> <p>I think training up immune survivors could be really helpful. The care required by an ebola patient in a resource-poor setting is generally very basic. Helping to keep them clean, assisting them with food and fluid and keeping them in the right place. Medication and IV fluids obviously need to be left to trained professionals but most care can be performed by minimally trained workers, providing they are kind and compassionate. </p> <p>However, it appears that many healthcare workers are being infected in the community as sick neighbours go to see the nurse, say, that lives next door. I encountered this scenario many times in Sierra Leone. So healthcare workers will continue to get infected whether they get onto the ward or not.</p> <p><strong>What more do you think could be done to help people survive Ebola by MSF and the the other organisations on the ground?</strong></p> <p>I think considerable improvements in care could be made by those acting on the ground currently. Aside from the obvious need for more beds, I would emphasise the need to give each Ebola patient the best chance possible. This means treating patients very proactively with IV fluids and appropriate medicines. Currently many think that the best we can do is isolate patients. I believe firmly in treating patients. More people survive if they receive more aggressive supportive therapy.</p> <p><em>Leave further questions for Pooley or Ebola survivors Harrison Sakilla or Comfort Kollie in the comments.</em></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T15:27:42.152+01:00">at 3.27pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436910ae4b01716247a0443" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:54:05.205+01:00">2.54pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>Airline bosses believe there is no significant change needed to protect passengers, and say wider travel has not been affected,<em> reports Guardian transport correspondent <strong>Gwyn Topham</strong></em> </p> <p><strong>Willie Walsh</strong>, the chief executive of IAG, which controls British Airways, spoke at length to the Guardian and others about Ebola last Friday. British Airways stopped flights to Liberia and Sierra Leone in August, but Walsh said: “The reason we stopped was that the demand was affected by the outbreak so it was very much a commercial decision first and foremost. <br /></p> <p>“All of the medical advice we received was that there was no risk to us. We were criticised by some government and health agencies for stopping flying because they felt it was an unnecessary decision.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="857c1732bca14e1f22bb8e108c09a72d11579520"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412863010415/05ec9204-9afe-4f8a-b143-b9ec89aa463e-460x276.jpeg" alt="Aerial view of an area of Freetown, Sierra Leone." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Aerial view of an area of Freetown, Sierra Leone.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Walsh said: “We take advice from the experts and we take measures to ensure our customers are aware of where there might be a risk. It’s clearly a tragedy for the countries involved ... but the experience that we’ve had flying into the region is that the risk is very low. This is a disease that only gets transmitted by direct contact with bodily fluids or secretions. </p> <p>Airlines have become sensitive to any suggestion that they are helping spread the disease, and Walsh said of Thomas Duncan, the Ebola patient who has since died in Dallas: “He hasn’t spread it to another continent. He [had] it. </p> <p>He said the airline would continue to evalutate whether additional measures need to be taken. </p> <p>Despite the confidence of airline bosses, airline and travel stocks have fallen in recent days as investors feared a perceived Ebola risk would deter the public from travelling abroad. <br /></p> <p>Walsh said there had been no impact on wider demand for flying away from directly affected areas. Walsh insisted there was “absolutely no impact on bookings other than on services to cities directly involved. We haven’t seen any changes to booking patterns and Europe has been aware of this for several months.”</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:58:04.142+01:00">at 2.58pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54368deee4b04997e4a351c7" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:39:50.054+01:00">2.39pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Kenema dispatch: Quarantined and hungry</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><em><strong>Hazel Chandler</strong> is a documentary maker returned from the epicentre of the outbreak in Kenema</em></p> <p>The Aruna Street community in Kenema was placed under a 21 day quarantine after five of its members died. <br /></p> <p>So many got sick that at the end of the 21 days a further 21 days was imposed. In all, 35 died. According to one survivor, Aminata:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>When it rains it becomes flooded. So when people became sick they were vomiting in the water and urinating in the water. We are all using the same bathroom so we all got sick. Thank God I survived. But my husband and two children died<em>.</em><br /></p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="76e0cfada7b95d4221e2848d263c12ca37e5c903"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412864267615/9f8fe47a-7c6e-44ff-9506-8956a8d1215a-460x276.jpeg" alt="World Food Programme depot in Kenema." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">World Food Programme depot in Kenema.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Ashley Hamer/Ashley Hamer</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Those quarantined complained of being hungry. One who lived through it said military police never came with promised supplies and only when challenged would deliver Bulgur wheat and beans. But, Fatu said, “Bulgur does not suit our stomachs because if you eat it it gives you a runny stomach and you need the toilet and if you go to the toilet a lot they will come and take you and say you have Ebola<em>.”</em></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T15:18:21.112+01:00">at 3.18pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54368617e4b09ceaddbcada9" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:12:08.569+01:00">2.12pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Live Q&amp;A: Ebola survivor Harrison Sakilla answers your questions about what it's like to live with the virus</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="76a9e3bcb02d0cbc74d628ebb6919070857f398f"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412859555522/dab2c68f-65b1-4ec6-a13b-86f150b67153-bestSizeAvailable.jpeg" alt="Harrison" width="240" height="360" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption"> </span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Martin Zinggl/MSF</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>What is the reality of suffering Ebola, and what sort of thoughts went through your mind when you were diagnosed and ill?</strong></p> <p>If you have Ebola you only feel sad and bad. It’s a disease that when you are infected with the virus, even your family cannot come close to you. Even the nurses can only be close to you if they have all the material to protect themselves when they touch you or feed you.</p> <p>You have weakness in the body. You are not even able to move and you have diarrhoea. As for me I never had vomiting, but I had a really strong headache and joint pains. I felt very, very weak.</p> <p>The major thing is the worry. Before people said Ebola has no treatment, so you have to worry. Most get worried, because of the way the disease is explained. Ebola has no treatment, so you think, “How will I live?”</p> <p>After I started being treated for the symptoms, I started to recover and to feel better, but plenty around me were dying. When I saw the people dying I felt scared. But I was given courage by the nurses that said even though some are dying, you can recover.</p> <p><strong>As survivors you probably won’t get sick again, how does this change how you feel about being around the virus?</strong></p> <p>Well, to the understanding that when you are cured from Ebola you will not easily get the disease again, I say, it depends if you are taking precautions, because the major thing is precaution. Then you can keep by the side of somebody who is contaminated with the virus. Even though some people say you are safe if you have recovered, but you don’t play with this disease. You have to keep up the precautions. The reason is – even if you cannot get it, but you touch the person who has the virus, you might simply pass it to somebody else who then may not survive from Ebola. So that’s why it’s best not to play with the virus.</p> <p><strong>When you got sick what were the most important things that helped you get through it?</strong></p> <p>You have to call for the ambulance, call the health worker. Then the second thing, they take you to the Ebola management centre. Then they will start to treat you. They take your blood, to test your blood. If you are positive they will help treat the symptoms you are showing. Then they feed you, give you food, give you clean clothes, plates, a spoon and cups to drink, as well as a bucket, water and soap for taking a bath.</p> <p>The nurses can give you courage and medication for the symptoms. There is no medication for the virus, but by reducing the symptoms that you are showing, it can help.</p> <p><strong>What more do you think could be done to help people survive Ebola by MSF and the the other organisations on the ground?</strong></p> <p>To my understanding, the best thing is to carry awareness to the community and the people in the area about Ebola. Also to tell them the facts about the disease as it is rare and people they don’t know. As mentioned before, we should take people like me who are survivors to be part of the awareness, to tell the people the truth. As MSF is doing so much of this already, others should also help and MSF should continue.</p> <p><strong>Considering the presumable immunity of survivors, do you think it would be feasible to adopt a policy of recruiting and training volunteer survivors to carry out high-risk work on the ground as the epidemic grows?</strong></p> <p>There is a lot we still don’t know about this disease. But as there is at least a theoretical and potential risk to survivors working in high-risk areas they will need to follow exactly the same procedures as anyone else. It is too early in the epidemic to say that those who have survived will never be at risk of reinfection. It is better to be cautious and to take full protective measures.</p> <p>Survivors can carry awareness messages for Ebola. Survivors understand the disease. They know the symptoms, they have suffered so much while they are recovering – it’s hard to cope with the bleeding and diarrhoea. It’s a hard task for you. Also, they will be able to tell people facts about the sickness. They know all about it including what Ebola does to you. For this reason it’s very good if survivors can work in health promotion.</p> <p><em>Leave further questions for Sakilla or Ebola survivors Will Pooley or Comfort Kollie in the comments.</em></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T15:21:50.893+01:00">at 3.21pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54368559e4b01716247a0425" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:01:14.408+01:00">2.01pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>The condition of the Spanish nurse infected with Ebola has worsened, <em>reports <strong>Ashifa Kassam</strong> in Madrid</em>.</p> <p>Her brother José Ramón Romero told reporters at the Carlos III hospital that her health had deteriorated and she was now <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intubation">intubated</a>. In a television interview with La Sexta he added she was having lung problems. <br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="5606e7334f98eaeb2efd1bd0c1927c47c46eb633"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412864446268/5fbbdff1-f84a-4a85-9d82-12990b36d2c5-460x276.jpeg" alt="Teresa Romero Ramos." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Teresa Romero Ramos.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: HANDOUT/REUTERS</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The nurse gave several phone interviews to Spanish media outlets on Wednesday, sounding exhausted as she gave answers that ranged from monosyllabic to a 12-minute conversation.</p> <p>Spanish health authorities on Thursday said that another person had been admitted to the Carlos III hospital. Seven people are now in quarantine and some 80 or so under observation in Spain, including health workers that treated Romero Ramos and two employees at a hair salon where the nurse went for an appointment last week. <br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T15:20:56.122+01:00">at 3.20pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543681ffe4b09ceaddbcad9b" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T13:50:19.328+01:00">1.50pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">CDC head: ‘The only thing I have seen like this is Aids’</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>At the ongoing World Bank meeting in Washington today, where global leaders are discussing the impact of Ebola, the director of the US <strong>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</strong> (CDC) has said that the epidemic has echoes of another.<br /></p> <p><strong>Larry Elliott</strong> quotes CDC head <strong>Tom Frieden</strong> telling the meeting:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>I have been in public health service for 30 years and the only thing I have seen like this is Aids. We will have to work hard to stop it being the next Aids.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:09:44.283+01:00">at 2.09pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-543682aee4b0cd82a095f0a5" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T13:49:32.130+01:00">1.49pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Ebola medic: Garth Thoms, Canadian Red Cross</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="e984d94151a3fbe5cb3650094e925b19cc41bae0"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412858901381/332996cd-6ea6-4379-8fe6-96a2f9aa4292-460x276.jpeg" alt="Garth Thoms" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Garth Thoms Canadian Red Cross</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Katherine Mueller/Red Cross</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We check each other out for breaches in our personal protective equipment and go one after the other into the high-risk zone. We pass by the patients. There isn’t much for them to do so they just sit in plastic chairs staring out. I always stop and say hello to them. <br /></p> <p>Sometimes, before I go in, I will tell them from the outside that I am coming in. I figure that way, they will know who is talking to them from behind the mask. I can’t imagine what it must be like for them, to be brought here and corralled into fenced areas surrounded by alien-like people walking around. I try to be funny so I do the moonwalk in my suit. Big mistake. The staff see me from the outside and many now call me “Jackson”. It is my cross to bear.<br /><br />It was a pretty uneventful entry today. Not like recently when I was working in the shower and felt a tug on my leg. When I looked down there was a patient lying naked on the floor next to me. <br /></p> <p>His eyes had the “Ebola look”. It is a look they get when they are certain to die from the disease. I turned the shower on to cool him, but he didn’t really react. I then called to Tina, our team lead who was doing the entry with me (we are that short of people that the manager of our centre had to come in with me) and we carried the patient to his bed. <br /></p> <p>He died four days later.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:10:54.564+01:00">at 2.10pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436775ae4b09ceaddbcad8b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T13:37:18.163+01:00">1.37pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>War game-style simulations</strong> to test Britain’s ability to cope with an outbreak of Ebola will be staged this weekend in hospitals in the north and south of England, report the Guardian’s <strong>Robert Booth</strong> and <strong>Matthew Weaver</strong>.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Officials at the Department of Health are today drawing up details of at least two simulations which will involve people posing as victims of the deadly virus to assess the real-time response of hospitals, the ambulance service and local authorities. The exercise will take place on either Saturday or Sunday and details of which hospitals will be chosen to handle the mock cases are being kept confidential to minimise disruption to the exercise, an official said. </p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:11:36.495+01:00">at 2.11pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54367d0be4b04997e4a351a7" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T13:25:17.819+01:00">1.25pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Kenema dispatch: a city under quarantine</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><em><strong>Hazel Chandler</strong> is a documentary maker who first went to Sierra Leone in 2004. She runs a charity in Freetown, and has just returned from the epicentre of the outbreak, in Kenema.</em></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="754085f7e3689fac2618d88a4b121c7c8c51af26"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412857210899/8f2c4eaf-4566-4e93-8cda-4481a01a006f-460x276.jpeg" alt="A healthcare worker sprays disinfectant in the area they found a man suspected of suffering from the Ebola virus in Kenema, Sierra Leone." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A healthcare worker sprays disinfectant in the area they found a man suspected of suffering from the Ebola virus in Kenema, Sierra Leone.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Tanya Bindra/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The road from Freetown to Kenema is peppered with road blocks manned by armed soldiers and police. Where once they were looking for weapons and diamonds, now they stop vehicles, check passes and request you get out, wash your hands and have your temperature taken. <br /></p> <p>Kenema is in the east of Sierra Leone and is one of the largest cities. It was put under quarantine on the 7 August 2014, which means that for two months the roads have been blocked. Without a pass, you cannot get in or out.</p> <p>It is estimated that more than 200 people have died there but the real figure is probably much higher. The district medical officer (DMO), Dr Mohamed Vandi, says that the infection rate has reduced as a result of the quarantine and that people in Kenema are better informed about Ebola than elsewhere in the country. <br /></p> <p>This may or may not be true but the impact of the quarantine is, as yet, unmeasurable. <br /></p> <p>Food shortages, failing businesses, rising prices, social isolation and surviving family members cut off from each other are just some of the problems. There are quarantines within the quarantine. Families or communities of people who have died of Ebola are isolated for 21 days. <br /></p> <p>They can walk in the compound just outside their houses but otherwise cannot leave to work, buy food or medicines or visit family members. There are no people in protective clothing wandering around or white tents, just a soldier with a gun and a variable number of police with only a stick to keep infected people away. Those quarantined sit silently and wait for an unknown outcome.<br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:11:00.949+01:00">at 2.11pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54365ccce4b04997e4a35165" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T13:13:16.676+01:00">1.13pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">The radio DJ battling Ebola myths</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Radio is playing an important role in the fight against Ebola. In Sierra Leone, thousands of people send text messages to <a href="https://twitter.com/Amarabangs">DJ Amara Bangura</a> with questions about the virus. Bangura, who is from Makeni, one of the areas most affected by the outbreak, puts the best questions to health experts and government officials on his show Kick Ebola Nar Salone (Kick Ebola out of Sierra Leone), which is broadcast on 35 stations across the country, three times a week.</p> <p>Bangura flew to the UK last week from Freetown. He spoke to <strong>Mark Anderson</strong>, from our global development desk, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-myths-sierra-leone-dj-tackles-rumours">about daily life in Sierra Leone at the moment</a>.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>If you go to Freetown or Sierra Leone generally, there is one slogan that everyone knows: no touching. Everybody says that: no touching, avoid body contact.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="057f919fe76f7a3135414ee8254ebaeea28b9596"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412849664932/62ee35a0-10d8-4785-871a-61daad79b915-460x276.jpeg" alt="Sierra Leone DJ Amara Bangura" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Sierra Leone DJ Amara Bangura uses his radio show to disseminate information about Ebola.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: BBC</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>People talk about hand washing a lot. Sometimes I touch something, I’ll go back and wash my hands. Also, if you’re using public transport, as soon as you get off you wash your hands. The number of passengers in each bus has been seriously reduced. People used to get crammed in the back of a bus, but now it’s just two. This is to avoid body contact.</p> <p>You go to offices, you meet a bucket full of water and soap. In most public areas there are lots of buckets full of water and soap. It’s the practice now.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T13:51:21.969+01:00">at 1.51pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54367557e4b01716247a03fb" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T12:49:27.981+01:00">12.49pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Heads of UN, IMF and World Bank meet on Ebola</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Jim Kim</strong>, the World Bank president is hosting a conference on Ebola in Washington and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-crisis-world-bank-president-jim-kim-failure">takes up the theme of his Guardian interview</a>, <em>reports <strong>Larry Elliott</strong>.</em></p> <p>“We are still way way behind the curve and we have to scale up the global response, there is a critical need for more trained health workers,” he said.<br /></p> <p><strong>Christine Lagarde</strong>, managing director of the IMF, said the fund was dropping its normal opposition to countries borrowing more. In the case of the three west African countries “it is good to increase the deficit. We don’t say that very often,” she said.<br /></p> <p>The UN secretary general, <strong>Ban Ki-Moon</strong>, said: “West Africans are scared. The best antidote to fear is an effective and speedy response.” He continued: “Cases are growing exponentially. We need a 20-fold surge in our response.”</p> <p><strong>Alpha Condé</strong>, the president of Guinea, said his country lacked the technical capacity and the financial resources to fight Ebola. </p> <p>Condé said the response needs to have four components: immediate intervention, the strengthening of health and education systems, massive budgetary support and a better explanation of what Ebola is so that investors return. “This is an international threat and it deserves an international response. All of the west African region is threatened,” he said.<br /></p> <p>Watch a live feed <a href="http://live.worldbank.org/impact-of-ebola-crisis">here</a></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T14:12:57.787+01:00">at 2.12pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54366f0ae4b01716247a03ec" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T12:31:25.392+01:00">12.31pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Live Q&amp;A: what’s it like to survive Ebola?</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Today between 2-3pm three Ebola survivors will join us live to answer your questions about what it’s like to live with the virus. Please leave your questions in the comment thread below: you can post individual questions, or general ones for the group.<br /></p> <p>We’ll embed the replies as posts in the live blog. You can also post questions on Twitter using the hashtag <strong>#guardianeboladay</strong>.</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="74d469bf3e314361d1e5a78f380668d0b2df783e"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412854046057/4b979851-d582-454b-905c-4ed1f1588586-460x276.jpeg" alt="Harrison Sakilla" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Harrison Sakilla MSF</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: MSF</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>Harrison Sakilla</strong> became infected when the disease reached his village, Wodu, in the north of the Liberia. The primary school teacher was admitted to the Ebola management centre in Foya where he became its first survivor. After losing seven members of his family to the virus he decided to stay and help others, and now works as a guard at the centre for MSF.</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="7e53a07999678199e93d09b4e58c82949c2cf84f"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412854265843/b5a00b16-0685-4f97-b9c4-7ce92f8d571d-460x276.jpeg" alt="Will Pooley" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Will Pooley Guardian</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>Will Pooley</strong> became the first known Briton to contract the virus after working in Sierra Leone. He was flown home where he made a full recovery. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/sep/09/william-pooley-ebola-sierra-leone-outbreak-epidemic">Pooley has said</a> he is happy to be alive but desperate to keep on helping the Ebola effort.<strong><br /></strong></p>  <figure class="element element-image element--thumbnail" data-media-id="d6ddbb66de65ffb37168fa80aea6cd4730b8f174"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412854166912/0086987d-4bcd-43f1-8918-e5a6166891d2-460x276.jpeg" alt="Comfort Kollie" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Comfort Kollie IMC</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: IMC</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>Comfort Kollie</strong> works at Phebe hospital in Bong county. Six other nurses contracted the virus in recent months, and Comfort believes it was transmitted to her while she was sitting on the bus with an infectious co-worker. Admitted to the International Medical Corps’ centre in Lofa in mid-September with Ebola, she was cured of the disease and discharged last week.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54366b52e4b01716247a03e2" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T12:05:03.434+01:00">12.05pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">'It's a sad story. It's so sad'</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O0oeHB0VQGs"                                                                                > <iframe width="460" height="259" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/O0oeHB0VQGs?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>  <p><strong>Douda Fullah</strong>’s life and family have been torn apart by Ebola. On 24 July he lost his father. Within two weeks, his stepmother and his two-year-old brother died. She was six months pregnant and miscarried in hospital.</p> <p>Douda, 17, then lost his sister and grandmother. He too was admitted to hospital, but survived. Orphaned, he is now left to care for himself and 12 year old brother and 15 year old sister. “I have lost five members of my family. I have no one to take care of me ... I’m begging. Come to our aid. We are suffering. There is no hope for us.” </p> <p><em>This film is supplied by <a href="http://www.street-child.co.uk/ebolaresponse">Street Child</a> was shot with Douda’s permission</em></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T12:05:44.083+01:00">at 12.05pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54366582e4b0cd82a095f059" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T12:04:48.064+01:00">12.04pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>An unidentified UN medic has become the latest healthcare worker to be sent to Europe for treatment after contracting the Ebola virus.<br /></p> <p>Reuters reports:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>A medical official with the U.N. Mission in Liberia who tested positive for Ebola arrived in the German city of Leipzig on Thursday to be treated at a local clinic with specialist facilities, authorities said. </p> <p>The unidentified medic infected in Liberia is the second member of the U.N. mission, known as UNMIL, to contract the virus. The first died on Sept. 25. He is the third Ebola patient to arrive in Germany for treatment. </p> <p>“The man will be treated on an isolation ward... with strict security measures,” said Dr Iris Minde, head of Leipzig’s St Georg clinic in a statement. “There is no danger of infection for other patients, relatives, visitors or the public.” </p> </blockquote> <p>In Australia, meanwhile, a 57-year old nurse in Cairns, north Queensland, is being tested for Ebola after returning on Tuesday from a month spent treating patients in Sierra Leone for the Red Cross. <strong>Bridie Jabour </strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2014/oct/09/ebola-fears-woman-observation-cairns-hospital-sierra-leone">writes that the nurse has been identified</a> as Sue-Ellen Kovack:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>She was under observation in Cairns hospital, Queensland’s chief health officer, Jeanette Young, confirmed.</p> <p> She had been kept in home isolation and was admitted to hospital with a low-grade fever on Thursday.</p> <p> Young emphasised there was zero risk to the Cairns community of infection as the nurse had followed protocols when returning to Australia.</p> <p> “She has not been out in the community in Cairns. She has been at home, isolated in her own home, testing herself,” she said.</p> <p> The head of the Australian Red Cross international program, Peter Walton, said the nurse remained upbeat despite her situation.</p> <p> “She’s doing well, but obviously she just has to play a bit of a waiting game at the moment,” he said.</p> <p>Walton said it was vital Red Cross aid workers were available to help combat the Ebola crisis, but everything possible was done to reduce the risk to them. </p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436666ee4b04997e4a3517a" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:44:29.764+01:00">11.44am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Ebola spreading fastest in Sierra Leone</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>In the past 21 days, Sierra Leone has reported 924 confirmed cases, or 40% of the total number of deaths in the country since the outbreak began. That’s also the biggest increase out of all three west African countries, <em>reports West Africa correspondent <strong>Monica Mark</strong></em>.<br /></p> <p>The new cases have come through a surge in infections in the western area, including the capital Freetown, which previously reported only sporadic cases.</p> <p>The country’s top officials are currently holding a closed door meeting in Freetown to discuss. “We can’t explain exactly why the numbers have gone up in the western area, but we’re going to discuss how to tackle it,” said Brima Kargbo, the chief medical officer.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="8b21d2e635675fe0da4f7d2b53dc6d05b3da906c"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412851586213/3378c3f2-7b3e-4410-8cd7-6e5984d0d0a6-460x276.jpeg" alt="Freetown body collectors " width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Volunteers arrive to pick up bodies of people who died of the Ebola virus in Freetown.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: FLORIAN PLAUCHEUR/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At the moment Sierra Leone has 304 beds, which is well short of the 1,100-odd beds the WHO estimates it needs. Two burial teams in the western area have also gone on strike over delayed payment. One worker, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: “We’re risking our lives and we’re not being paid for it. And since we started this work, people have been talking a lot – we’re not welcome in our community anymore.”</p> <p>One bright spot: there’s been a dramatic decrease in the eastern region bordering Guinea and Liberia, where the transmissions started and were initially highest. Health campaigns have been concentrated in this area for months now, and some districts are now going days without reporting any new cases.</p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:46:40.126+01:00">at 11.46am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54366639e4b0cd82a095f05b" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:41:21.353+01:00">11.41am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/guardian/statuses/520136636471201792">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Do you live in an Ebola zone? Tell us what it&#39;s like using <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/guardianeboladay?src=hash">#guardianeboladay</a> or submit your story to <a href="https://twitter.com/GuardianWitness">@GuardianWitness</a> <a href="http://t.co/8CGraCEERS">http://t.co/8CGraCEERS</a></p>&mdash; The Guardian (@guardian) <a href="https://twitter.com/guardian/status/520136636471201792">October 9, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54366139e4b01716247a03cc" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:26:20.365+01:00">11.26am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Nick Owen</strong>, one of a number of volunteers taking part in a six-month trial in the UK of an Ebola vaccine, has been speaking to the Guardian’s <strong>Ben Quinn</strong>.<br /><br /></p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n7pegRADe2Y"                                                                                > <iframe width="460" height="259" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/n7pegRADe2Y?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure>  <p>The vaccine he has been given is called ChAd3, which uses a single benign Ebola virus protein (one seventh of the whole virus) to generate an immune response.<br /><br />It’s carried into the body by a vector, in this case a chimpanzee adenovirus – or, a common cold. He was deliberately given a virus as it gets inside cells and produces a particular type of immunity. A chimp virus is being used as people are often immune to human common colds, meaning the vaccine wouldn’t have a chance to begin to work. Essentially, it’s a process of tricking the immune system into thinking it has an infection. <br /><br />He said: “The day after I had the vaccine I felt a bit fluey and had a sore arm but by the evening I was absolutely fine. I think it’s a really small price to pay for what we can potentially get out of this vaccine if it’s going to prevent outbreaks of the magnitude we have seen so far this year.”<br /><br />Owen, who works for MSF but has been taking part in the trials as a volunteer (the charity has no connection with the trials) has also <a href="http://blogs.msf.org/en/staff/blogs/msf-ebola-blog/subject-001016-the-vaccine-trial">written a blog about his experience</a>.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Friends and family have said I must be mad to want to take part, but I struggle to see the issue. As I write, 10 of my MSF colleagues have died treating this virus, along with hundreds of other healthcare workers in West Africa. To me, having a sore arm and potentially feeling a bit fluey is a very small sacrifice to make if it means lives will be saved in the future, and that my colleagues can work without putting themselves at even greater risk.</p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:47:14.989+01:00">at 11.47am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54365dcee4b01716247a03c7" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:14:07.142+01:00">11.14am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Ebola medic: Elvis Ogweno, Liberia</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><em><strong>Elvis Ogweno</strong> is a Kenyan nurse and ambulance coordinator, working at the <a href="http://www.internationalmedicalcorps.org.uk/">International Medical Corps</a> facility in Bong County Liberia. Today is a typical day.</em><br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="a6c1acb898cec92b68124b3674c33f08ed53e5ef"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412849516562/5062c630-56f3-46a9-bcd4-b0cd851ffab9-460x276.jpeg" alt="Elvis Ogweno" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Elvis Ogweno</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: International Medical Corps</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>5.30am</strong></p> <p>Elvis wakes up each morning at 5.30am. As a Christian, he always prays for protection. “I ask God to give me wisdom in making decisions.” In the context of Ebola, one decision could make the difference between life and death for the patient and for the health care worker, he explains. </p> <p>“I pray for the patients we carry, and my colleagues, who are doing great work. I pray for the country in general.”</p> <p>After his morning shower, Elvis dresses, gathers his laptop and first aid kit, and heads on over to the Ebola treatment unit to meet with the team.</p> <p><strong>7.30am – 9.30am</strong></p> <p>As soon as he arrives at the International Medical Corps Ebola treatment unit, Elvis meets with the night shift. He learns that one patient died late last night. The 28-year-old woman will be buried alongside her sister who died a few days earlier. </p> <p>Elvis meets with his ambulance team, which includes four other nurses and six sprayers, and informs them that they will be making a two-hour trek to Kakata in Margibi County. That sounds like a long journey, but they are actually relieved, because their last few pickups have been in Mawah, which is twice as far away.</p> <p>After briefing Elvis conducts a vehicle check. The tank is full and spare tires are in the bed of the truck. They’re ready to go.</p> <p><strong>12.16pm </strong><br /></p> <p>The two International Medical Corps ambulances, Rescue 1 and Rescue 2 arrive at the village in Kakata. Elvis rides in Rescue 1 with the nurses, where he used the journey time to review protocol and mentally prepare himself. “I always try to ask myself, ‘What is happening with the family? What is going through their minds?’ It helps me to understand their distress.”</p> <p> Donning a mask, gown and gloves with a pen and paper in hand, Elvis dismounts from the ambulance and walks up to the family. “Hello, my name is Elvis. I’m from the Ebola Treatment Unit. We’re here to help.”</p> <p>As he is talking with the family, the sprayers lay out the tarp and begin preparing the personal protective equipment that will keep his team safe. Three members of the family are showing symptoms of Ebola virus, with fever, diarrhoea, and vomiting. Five members of this family have died in recent weeks, of suspected Ebola. <br /></p> <p>There are another nine people living in the same home, including several children. Elvis is eager to get his three newest patients out of the house and back to the Ebola treatment unit where they can receive treatment.<br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T15:39:07.082+01:00">at 3.39pm BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-5436322ce4b01716247a0392" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:12:21.331+01:00">11.12am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Dallas, Texas: memorial for US victim</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Tom Dart</strong> reports from Dallas in the hours after Thomas Eric Duncan died and his family, now living in quarantine, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/family-ebola-victim-dallas-eric-duncan">were left to mourn in isolation</a>.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="ab6208c47936f681058a81d21d1d7da0d6ebe3e1"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412844746451/f286b425-a77b-4be4-8f9b-1b8ca652c1e9-460x276.jpeg" alt="Dallas memorial service" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Mamie Mangoe, a friend of the Duncan family, wipes a tear away during a memorial service.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Nathan Hunsinger/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>It had been planned as a vigil but the service quickly turned into a memorial once the news broke that Ebola had killed Eric Duncan, the first victim of the virus in the US.</p> <p>Before his condition worsened and he died in a Dallas hospital at 7.51am local time on Wednesday, eight days after his diagnosis was confirmed, Duncan’s last words were spoken to a nurse from the bed in his isolation room: a request to see Karsiah, the son he last saw sixteen years ago, when the boy was three.</p> <p>That final hope went unfulfilled. A student in San Angelo, 250 miles away, Karsiah was staying in Dallas and preparing to head to Texas Health Presbyterian hospital on Wednesday in the hope of seeing Duncan at about 9am when his mother called him to tell him his father was dead.</p> <p>The sense of disconnection and distance even from relatives in the same city was replicated at Wilshere Baptist Church on Wednesday evening at a service that was mainly for Duncan’s close friends and family but necessarily took place without them.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54363bc7e4b04997e4a35137" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T11:01:39.881+01:00">11.01am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Meliandou: the village where the outbreak began</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>A toddler, a fruit bat, and a village in southern Guinea.<br /></p> <p>That’s how <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-guinea-family-west-africa-crisis">the current Ebola outbreak found its origins</a>, writes <strong>Clar Ni Chonghaile:</strong><br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>In December last year, near the village of Meliandou in southern Guinea, two-year-old Emile was bitten by one of the fruit bats that fly through west Africa’s skies, often gathering at dusk to roost in trees.</p> </blockquote> <p>The village is reported as lying within a forested area close to three countries’ borders: Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The ease with which these borders can be crossed, due partly to years of conflict, has seen this region become the Ebola outbreak’s “hot zone”. From Meliandou, WHO researchers believe the virus was able to swiftly travel to neighbouring towns, to Guinea’s capital Conakry, and across the border to Sierra Leone.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>So began a chain of viral devastation, whose links represent individual lives cut short and ineluctable steps on Ebola’s path through west Africa.<strong><strong><br /></strong></strong></p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-map" data-canonical-url="https://www.google.co.uk/maps/place/Meliandou,+Guinea/@8.6160662,-10.061178,6z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0xfa9a35f789a2f39:0xa99ff0f9fc6be611"> <iframe width="460" height="379" src="https://maps.google.co.uk/maps?ll=8.6160662,-10.061178&z=6&q=Meliandou,+Guinea&dg=ntvb&output=embed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> </figure> </div>   </div> <div id="block-5436585de4b01716247a03be" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:50:21.970+01:00">10.50am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p>We’re getting a number of questions coming through about Ebola itself, and the ways people can contract the virus.<br /></p> <p><strong>Lauren Gambino </strong>has answered 10 commonly-asked questions on Ebola in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/03/ebola-answering-10-basic-questions">this explainer</a>.<br /></p> <p>They include:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p><strong>Can you get Ebola from sneezing?</strong></p> </blockquote> <p> It is possible to spread through coughing or sneezing, but health officials say it’s unlikely. Saliva or mucus from an infected person would have to get into a healthy person’s eyes, nose, mouth or open wound for the disease to spread.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p><strong>Can it spread through mosquitoes?</strong></p> </blockquote> <p> There is no evidence to support this. Humans, bats, monkeys and apes have the ability to spread the Ebola virus, but evidence so far indicates that mosquitoes and other insects can’t transmit it.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p><strong>Is it airborne?</strong></p> </blockquote> <p> Not currently.</p> <p>If you have a question that hasn’t been answered, let us know in the comments below.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54365871e4b01716247a03bf" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:49:58.089+01:00">10.49am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Lockdown in Sierra Leone – in pictures</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Njala<em> </em>Giema is a village in eastern Sierra Leone, set deep in the forest off the highway from Kenema to Kailahun. The hamlet had a population of about 200 people; at least 61 have died since Ebola struck in May. Locals say the disease was brought by relatives of a nurse infected in the nearest town, Daru. The village has been in lockdown as Sierra Leone quarantined a million people in an attempt to slow Ebola’s spread.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="9a65916587e5c2288c2008d76d795ddc78b89273"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848103736/c884b4bd-fedc-477c-8411-834ba0224885-460x276.jpeg" alt="Ambulance driver Shaka Koroma was recruited to transport suspected Ebola patients during the lockdown. He was given neither training nor adequate protective equipment." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Ambulance driver Shaka Koroma was recruited to transport suspected Ebola patients during the lockdown. He was given neither training nor adequate protective equipment.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Ashley Hamer</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Full set of pictures from Ashley Hamer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/gallery/2014/oct/09/ebola-sierra-leone-lockdown-food-queues-in-pictures">here</a><br /></p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54364c7fe4b0cd82a095f032" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:26:37.451+01:00">10.26am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">UK: government urges calm</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>In the UK, the government has today urged calm and indicated that it has no immediate plans to introduce screening for Ebola at UK border points.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>There’s no need for hysteria or panic of that kind,” Michael Fallon, the defence secretary, said in a round of broadcast interviews. “Every GP surgery, every hospital in the country knows how to handle this, how to check for symptoms. I think we need to be calm and measured about this and just make sure that if symptoms are identified that people get to be checked as quickly as possible.</p> </blockquote> <p>While the chairman of the home affairs committee, Keith Vaz, has called for testing measures to be put into place for people entering Britain, <strong>Mark Tran </strong>and <strong>Rowena Mason</strong> report that Fallon rejects these calls on the grounds that such screening should be carried out at their point of departure instead:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>The World Health Organisation advises that screening is best done when you leave a country, when you leave Sierra Leone or leave Liberia or Guinea, rather than the country you come into,” he said. “There are no direct flights at the moment from Sierra Leone to Britain so it’s not possible to be 100% sure of everybody who’s coming here.</p> </blockquote> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/british-troops-sent-fight-ebola-sierra-leone">Britain will send 750 military personnel</a> to West Africa in a bid to help halt the outbreak, it was reported on Wednesday. <br /></p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:51:43.552+01:00">at 10.51am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54364d58e4b04997e4a35149" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:18:21.448+01:00">10.18am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Spain: six now in quarantine</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Ashifa Kassam</strong> reports from Madrid, where six people are now in quarantine after a nurse became the first person in the current outbreak to be infected outside Africa.</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Six people are in quarantine in Madrid’s Carlos III Hospital and another 84 are being monitored for any signs of Ebola, health authorities said on Thursday.</p> <p>Those in isolation include Teresa Romero Ramos, the Spanish nurse who on Monday became the first known person to contract Ebola outside of west Africa. Her husband, who has not shown any symptoms, also remains in isolation as a precautionary measure.</p> <p>Two doctors were admitted to the hospital - a specialised hub for attending to potential Ebola patients in Madrid - on Wednesday evening. Both had treated the Spanish nurse when she arrived at the hospital in Alcorcón on Monday with a fever and fatigue. </p> <p>In a letter to his superiors published by several media outlets, one of the doctors detailed the 16 hours he spent on Monday treating the nurse. For much of that time, Juan Manuel Parra Ramírez and the nurses treating Romero Ramos wore just an impermeable gown, double gloves, a hat and a mask to protect themselves. </p> <p>As the nurse’s state worsened, the health workers changed into a more protective suit. The patient presented diarrhoea, vomiting and coughing, said Parra Ramírez, complaining that his protective equipment was ill-fitting. “The sleeves were too short,” he wrote.<br /></p> <p>Despite being on the frontlines of treating the nurse, he wasn’t updated when her test results proved positive, he said. “I learned of the results from journalists rather than the relevant authority.” </p> <p>On Wednesday, a nurse, who was part of the same team as Romero Ramos and treated the two Ebola patients repatriated to Spain, also was admitted to the Carlos III Hospital. </p> <p>She was placed in quarantine as three others were released from the hospital. Two of the nurses from the same team as Romero Ramos and an engineer, who had travelled from Nigeria to Spain, all tested negative for Ebola. </p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:51:26.086+01:00">at 10.51am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54364fb5e4b0cd82a095f037" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:13:51.777+01:00">10.13am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Sierra Leone: four aid workers tell us what they will do today</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>Kelfa Kargbo of Street Child - <a href="http://www.street-child.co.uk/">a British charity that turned its 650-strong community workforce in Sierra Leone and Liberia to the Ebola effort two months ago </a>- tells us that his biggest frustration in the fight against Ebola in Sierra Leone is the lack of “urgency” shown by “middle men” deployed by the government.</p> <p>“My biggest feeling about this fight against Ebola is frustration. Education of the population has created awareness, but people are still not following the guidelines. There are a lot of mountains to climb and maybe it is poverty and circumstances which causes people to disobey the rules.</p> <p>“My biggest frustration however, is that certain individuals within government institutions are not contributing to the fight against Ebola. The government is freeing up money and provisions but the middle men are not responding with urgency; they are dragging their feet.” </p> <p>Here, in four diaries he and three of his staff, tell us what they are doing today. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="93e18f009fb170a2bab0bd3793f130b344085868"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412846010652/642a025f-a8b2-4576-8cb9-0410a7430d32-460x276.jpeg" alt="Port Loko" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">In this photo taken on Friday, 3 October 2014, Ebola patients lie outside Port Loko district hospital in Sierra Leone.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Tanya Bindra/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><strong>Justin Sesay, Port Loko. Deputy regional manager rural projects</strong>:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>As I speak to you now I am very much scared for the district; the government institutions are no longer active here and there is a very real fear of famine.</p> <p>In one village, in the Masimra chiefdom, the whole population has practically been wiped out by the virus. </p> <p>This has greatly affected the community’s ability to generate food; those who have so far survived ran into the bush because their colleagues were dying so rapidly. </p> <p>They have been unable to complete the harvest. </p> <p>Even last week, as I spoke to the section Chief, there was a corpse lying nearby, waiting for a burial team to come.</p> <p>I fear for this district, it is an agricultural district, if the people are unable to have their rice, their ground nut and their crops, there will hunger, extreme hunger. </p> <p>This morning I am busy planning an Ebola training workshop for our teachers which will take place on Friday.</p> <p>It will be crucial in our fight against Ebola; the teachers will play a vital part in educating the community, as they are highly respected.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>John Momodu Kargbo, Makeni. Head of operations Bombali district</strong><br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>There is a family in an area of Makeni called New London, which has lost 21 members.</p> <p>The surviving elderly grandmother has been left to look after her grandchildren, 8 and 6, with just an older boy, himself an Ebola survivor, to help.</p> <p>This family has little support and they’re struggling to survive; the older boy is currently unable to continue working as a motorcycle taxi driver. Their situation is far from unique.</p> <p>This morning I am visiting quarantined homes along with ministry officials to collect information about orphan numbers.</p> <p>Secondly, I am meeting with the district Health and Medical Association to discuss and organise a programme to train Street Child teachers in Ebola prevention. Our plan is to use these teachers to broadcast critical information about the spread and containment of Ebola to rural villages</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>George Quaker, Kenema. Deputy head of operations for Street Child</strong><br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Kenema is in the quarantine zone.</p> <p>One child who we visited last week, Bettie Kargbo, aged 15, has lost her mother and is left to support her two younger siblings aged five and three. Her step-father is away with the military, peace keeping in Somalia.</p> <p>They are in desperate need of support and we, along with the World Food Programme are providing supplies while Bettie and her siblings are in quarantine.</p> <p>Normal people are finding it difficult to get basic food supplies such as bread; it is nearly impossible for orphans. </p> <p>What is good is that Bettie is increasingly receiving support from her neighbours; before, people were scared of helping families who had been in quarantine, but increased awareness and education has really helped to reduce the stigma.</p> <p>I start my work this morning by attending a meeting at the Sierra Leone ministry for social welfare, gender and children’s affairs to discuss data on orphans. We will then revisit communities to confirm the figures.</p> </blockquote> <p><strong>Kelfa Kargbo, Freetown. Director of Street Child of Sierra Leone</strong><br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Today I will be finalising a plan with another NGO, African Medical Mission, who we have contracted to train twenty teachers for us in Lungi just outside Freetown.</p> <p>This training will involve educating the teachers about the causes of Ebola and how the virus can be spread; each teacher will be assigned their own village, it is their responsibility to fully educate everybody in their village about Ebola.</p> <p>With 20 teachers we can reach 20 villages. We realise that people are not fully abreast of the Ebola issue and they have continued engaging in ritual practices, particularly during funerals, which carry a high risk of contamination. </p> <p>Our teachers are respected members of the community who we hope can spread the right messages about Ebola. </p> </blockquote> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T10:14:49.023+01:00">at 10.14am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54364539e4b01716247a03a2" class="block"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T09:22:18.474+01:00">9.22am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class="block-elements">  <p><strong>Lauren Gambino</strong> and <strong>Tom Dart </strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-dallas-deputy-sheriff-hospital-symptoms-death">report from the US</a> that a second man has been admitted to hospital in Dallas after exhibiting symptoms resembling Ebola, following the death of Thomas Eric Duncan on Wednesday:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Frisco fire chief Mark Piland said the man had visited the apartment where Duncan stayed <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/thomas-eric-duncan-liberia-ebola-war-texas-family-obituary">after he arrived in the US last week</a> and interacted with some of the people who live there, all of whom are under quarantine and not exhibiting symptoms. He was transported by ambulance to the hospital after going to an urgent care facility with “some” Ebola-like symptoms, which can also be symptoms of other illnesses. The ambulance crew who helped the sheriff into the vehicle wore protective suits and carried out decontamination procedures.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-1cb07b01-2cf1-48a3-b5e8-fe7791698bf7"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412842931830/f668aaa8-c173-4bdb-ad1a-dbc713a79d3e-460x276.jpeg" alt="A possible Ebola patient is brought to the Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in Dallas." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A possible Ebola patient is brought to the Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in Dallas.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Joe Raedle/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The risk of Ebola in this case is thought to be low because the man in question, a law enforcement official, reportedly never came into direct contact with Duncan – only visiting the apartment where Duncan was staying.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Right now, there are more questions than answers about this case,” the hospital said in a statement. The Ebola test takes about 48 hours to return results.</p> </blockquote> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54363ed7e4b04997e4a3513b" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T09:01:49.563+01:00">9.01am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Ebola discoverer: more European cases 'unavoidable'</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/04/ebola-zaire-peter-piot-outbreak"><strong>Peter Piot</strong></a>, who was part of the research team which discovered the Ebola virus in 1976, warned this morning that further cases of Ebola in Europe are “unavoidable”.<br /></p> <p>He told BBC Breakfast:<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>We will see other cases in Europe, this is unavoidable. People travel, people come back, people get infected in west Africa - volunteers. So we need to be prepared for more cases like this. </p> </blockquote> <p>Piot said, however, that he did not consider the UK to be at high risk.<br /></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>I’m not concerned about an outbreak in western Europe, in the UK, like we are seeing in west Africa. The highest risk is for the staff - nurses, doctors and so on, lab workers in the hospitals where someone would be admitted with Ebola infection.</p> </blockquote> <p>Other developments:</p> <p><strong>•The president of the World Bank, Jim Kim, said the global response to Ebola has “failed miserably”</strong>. He called for <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-crisis-world-bank-president-jim-kim-failure">a $20bn international fund</a> to react swiftly to health emergencies.</p> <p><strong>• The first person diagnosed with the disease outside Africa has died in a Texas hospital</strong>. Thomas Eric Duncan, 42, had <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/thomas-eric-duncan-liberia-ebola-war-texas-family-obituary">arrived in the US from Liberia</a> before he began to show symptoms. </p> </div>   <p class="block-time updated-time">Updated <time datetime="2014-10-09T09:22:32.105+01:00">at 9.22am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id="block-54353da2e4b0d098fa946d88" class="block is-key-event"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T08:42:38.470+01:00">8.42am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">The Guardian
