please do leave comments and questions below the line. You can read tweets from any of our team by clicking on their names. For tweets from volunteers, organisations and journalists covering the crisis worldwide, you could also follow <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/series/guardian-africa-network">Guardian Africa</a>’s Twitter list <a href="https://twitter.com/GuardianAfrica/lists/the-latest-on-ebola">here</a>.</p> </div>   </div> <div id="block-54353d4ce4b0cd82a095ef4f" class="block is-summary"> <p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2014-10-09T08:33:46.943+01:00">8.33am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p>   <h2 class="block-title">Ebola: the disease in a day</h2>  <div class="block-elements">  <p>The death toll from current outbreak of Ebola has now passed 3,800, with over 7000 infected. The UN <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/sep/18/ebola-outbreak-un-security-council-resolution">has called it</a> “likely the greatest peacetime challenge that the United Nations and its agencies have ever faced”. Since the first cases were reported in Guinea at the end of last year, it has ravaged healthcare systems and communities in West Africa and the first cases been diagnosed in Europe and North America.</p> <p>We’ll be spending the day reporting on the crisis, drawing together text, video and pictures to tell the story of Ebola and its effects wherever it has hit. We’ll be inviting you to join us in discussion and participate in a <strong>live Q&amp;A with three Ebola survivors </strong>and post any questions you have on the disease in the comments, which we will attempt to answer. </p> <p>Over the course of the day we will also be tracking health workers in the affected countries and meeting a Sierra Leone radio presenter trying to fulfil the information needs of his listeners. Later we’ll report live from Washington, where the presidents of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone are to meet the UN secretary general and the heads of the World Bank and IMF. The World Bank president, Jim Kim, on Wednesday <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-crisis-world-bank-president-jim-kim-failure">told the Guardian</a> the international community had “failed miserably” in its response to the disease.</p> </div>   </div>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/ebola-scare-race-frisco-dallas-texas-monnig-duncan <p>Frisco, a prosperous and bland modern suburb 25 miles north of downtown Dallas, is normally chiefly known as the home of Major League Soccer’s FC Dallas and the RoughRiders minor league baseball team.</p> <p>But for a time on Wednesday it was the epicentre of the rolling-news universe, as events at an urgent care centre prompted scenes reminiscent of a contagion disaster movie. Media <a href="http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/health/2014/10/08/patient-frisco-ebola-suspect/16922477/">rushed to provide live coverage</a> of a sheriff’s deputy in a surgical mask being taken to a hospital isolation room by men covered from head to toe in protective clothing.</p> <p>The deputy, Michael Monnig, did visit the apartment where Thomas Eric Duncan, who died from the virus on Wednesday, had stayed after arriving in the US from Liberia. But on Thursday afternoon, Texas officials said Monnig had tested negative for the virus.</p> <p>Still, on Wednesday no one was taking any chances; better to risk alarming the general population by responding urgently and forcefully with officials in hazmat gear than prompt fresh doubts about the competence of authorities by downplaying the drama, acting slowly and not wearing any protective clothes at all.</p> <p>The contrast in the speed and scale of the response in Frisco compared with events at the low-rent Ivy Apartments complex was jarring: despite confirmation on Tuesday last week that Duncan had Ebola, it was not until last Thursday that the authorities made a concerted effort to control who could enter and exit the apartment where he had stayed, and not until Saturday before the unit was cleaned and decontaminated by a professional crew. As various local and federal agencies appeared to debate and dawdle, the action achieved the rare feat of seeming at once chaotic and slow-moving.</p> <p>The 5,000- to 10,000-strong Liberian community in the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex has noted shortcomings in the way Duncan’s case was handled. Official accounts suggest he first developed symptoms on 24 September and went to nearby Texas Health Presbyterian hospital two days later, where staff failed to take his travel history into account and sent him away with antibiotics. By 28 September he was so ill that an ambulance was called to take him back.</p> <p>Without making any specific judgment on Duncan’s case, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) director Tom Frieden said at a media briefing on Wednesday that “the earlier someone is diagnosed, the more likely they will be able to survive.”</p> <p>Three other patients hospitalised in the US after contracting Ebola in west Africa, including one man from Fort Worth, received experimental treatments and survived. On Tuesday, Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, who is black, told a court meeting that “if a person who looks like me shows up without any insurance, they don’t get the same treatment … It’s historically what has happened in this community.”</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="888aaa17e1b1664aeeabaf29670753b0facc5307"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412886553885/1d171239-c62b-4bdf-9669-7646eb4218ad-460x276.jpeg" alt="Frisco emergency personnel cordon off Michael Monnig's vehicle" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Frisco emergency personnel cordoned off Michael Monnig’s vehicle. Treatment of Monnig’s case, some say, has proceeded in stark contrast to how Thomas Eric Duncan’s case was handled.</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Larry W. Smith/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Stanley Gaye, president of the Liberian Community Association of Dallas-Fort Worth, said that many people were raising questions about the standard of care Duncan received, but he is urging the community to keep anger in check and wait until Duncan’s fiancee, Louise Troh, and the rest of her quarantined family are given the all-clear.</p> <p>“They have questions about the hospital and how the family was treated and how he was treated. Those are all the concerns, but I told them this is not a time to talk about it, this is a time to grieve with the family and pray for the family,” he said. “The proper thing to do is to investigate and see if they did anything intentional.”</p> <p>“This is a city that lived through JFK. We don’t want any more of that happening,” said Troh’s pastor, George Mason. “We don’t want that sort of thing to reoccur. Anybody that’s lived in Dallas for a long period of time would tell you that that story haunts the city of Dallas. We believe we have come a long way since then and we have much more transparency,” he said.</p> <p>Apparently responding to these kinds of concerns, the hospital released a statement Thursday in which it said, “We’d like to correct some misconceptions that have been reported about Mr. Duncan’s first visit. Our care team provided Mr. Duncan with the same high level of attention and care that would be given [to] any patient, regardless of nationality or ability to pay for care. In this case that included a four-hour evaluation and numerous tests. We have a long history of treating a multicultural community in this area.”</p> <p>Allegations of official cover-ups and a lack of transparency cut deeper here than in many places. Texas is an independent-minded state with an innate distrust of the federal government and Dallas is still best known for some people as the site of the assassination of John F Kennedy, an event that inspired perhaps the most famous and enduring collection of conspiracy theories in Western culture.</p> <p>“We’re looking for moments to help correct the view of Dallas or to have some redemption about that, to be honest. This was a moment, and you realise we might have had another bobble as we began, but these public officials now are redoubling their efforts to see that we can do everything right in the wake of it.”</p> <p>The geography of Duncan’s sickness and death has also underlined that this is a city, like so many in America, with a stark racial and economic divide.</p> <p>On the north Dallas landscape, opulent shopping malls and the sprawling hospital campus act as a kind of bulwark separating the densely populated and deprived Vickery Meadow area – home to a diverse range of immigrants, including Troh – from some of the richest residents in America a short drive to the west across Highway 75. That area, Highland Park, almost entirely white and home to the George W Bush Presidential Library, was <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2011/12/highland-park-texas-gop-stronghold">described by Mother Jones</a> in 2011 as “the most enthusiastically Republican enclave in the country”.</p> <p>The Ebola scare has prompted a rare moment of crossover between the two communities. The Dallas Morning News <a href="http://www.dallasnews.com/news/metro/20141007-highland-park-isd-parents-told-jenkins-hasnt-created-risk.ece ">reported</a> that the Highland Park school district sent a note aiming to reassure parents that their children could not contract Ebola through contact with the daughter of Clay Jenkins, a judge who is in charge of emergency management for Dallas County and who drove Troh and her family from her apartment to a temporary home in an undisclosed location.</p> <p>Vickery Meadow is no longer invisible. “One of my own hopes is that out of all of this, at least people in Dallas could raise their awareness of the conditions in Vickery Meadow. It is not good and it has not been good for a long time,” said Mark Wingfield, associate pastor at Troh’s church. “There is substandard housing, it is in many places an urban ghetto and I think most people in Dallas if they don’t ever drive through there don’t even know it exists.”</p> <p>But so far the publicity and alarm appear to have made locals even more unwilling to circulate in the area. Attendance at schools near Troh’s apartment was down 10% in the wake of news that five area pupils may have come into contact with Duncan, according to Dallas school district figures.</p> <p>The Dallas Foundation, which links donors with non-profit agencies, said in a statement that it is focusing efforts on helping Vickery Meadow because “the backlash from this attention has had negative consequences for a neighborhood already plagued by poverty, affecting residents’ ability to work as well as the delivery of volunteer services within the community.”</p> <p>Alben Tarty, a Liberian community spokesman, said a fear of stigmatisation after the first diagnosed case of Ebola in the US has led to “rumours” that some Liberians’ jobs might be in jeopardy.</p> <p>Tarty said he has heard stories of home care workers and food handlers being sent home from their jobs because their employers feared they might have been exposed to the disease. He said he doesn’t know if the stories are true; nonetheless, their mere circulation has made some in the community very anxious.</p> <p>With Duncan the only confirmed case, Ebola’s capacity to frighten is so far greatly outpacing its ability to infect Texans. “The concern is the stress of this and the fear of this could be more damaging to the community than the virus itself,” Lakey said at a news conference on Monday.</p> <p>Dallas is waiting to discover whether any of the 10 people in Texas officials say had close contact with Duncan, as well as 38 others who may have had contact, will present Ebola symptoms. According to the CDC, the maximum incubation period is 21 days but symptoms usually start to show 8 to 10 days after exposure. If nothing develops by the end of the week, confidence will grow that, despite the missteps which delayed his move into isolation, Duncan will remain the city’s lone case, and Dallas’s affected communities can start rebuilding trust and repairing social fractures.</p> <p>“We are very hopeful and keep praying that it continues that way,” said Gaye.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/ebola-australian-nurse-returns-negative-blood-test <p>An Australian nurse who has just returned from west Africa has returned a negative test result for Ebola.<br /></p> <p>Sue Ellen Kovack was tested for the virus on Thursday after developing a low-grade fever upon her return to Australia after treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone. She was held in isolation at Cairns hospital and her blood samples were flown to Brisbane for testing.</p> <p>Queensland’s chief health officer, Jeannette Young, confirmed on Friday morning that the initial tests had returned a negative result. Kovack will continue to be held in hospital for at least 24 hours. She will be tested again at the weekend.</p> <p>“This is a necessary precaution given the patient has been to west Africa and has had a fever within the incubation period of 21 days,” Young said. “For the sake of her health and to follow due diligence, we want to be sure she is clear of Ebola virus disease as well as any other disease.”</p> <p>Young said even if Kovack had tested positive for Ebola the wider community had not been at risk. Kovack had been held in home isolation since her return from Sierra Leone on Tuesday and had not developed the symptoms of Ebola which make it contagious, such as vomiting and diarrhoea.</p> <p>Health minister Peter Dutton said 11 people across Australia had been tested for Ebola and all had returned negative results as he warned against community panic.</p> <p>“I want people to put things in perspective here, it’s not spread by people coughing … the chances of it being spread here are next to nil. We have the ability to deal with people and rapidly test,” he told reporters in Melbourne.<br /></p> <p>Dutton said he was “very satisfied” with the advice the government had received from Young, other health officials and immigration officials about how to best handle people coming back to Australia from Ebola-affected countries.<br /></p> <p>He dismissed independent MP Bob Katter’s comments that Australians should be held in official isolation for three weeks and humanitarian workers were putting all of Australia at risk.<br /></p> <p>“I’m happy for Mr Katter to be briefed and informed on these matters before he makes any further public comment so he’s properly informed about Ebola and [the] risk that it poses,” he said.<br /></p> <p>He said Kovack’s initial negative result was a “huge relief” for her, as well as the government.<br /></p> <p>Queensland will now hold health workers returning from west Africa in Brisbane, rather than their own homes in other parts of the state, so treatment can be swift if they are diagnosed with the virus, the state’s health minister Lawrence Springborg said.<br /></p> <p>“In the case of this nurse, she has been extremely responsible and followed all precautionary guidelines since she has returned from treating sick people in Africa,” he said.</p> <p>“We’re encouraged this … first test of this nurse has shown this is a negative result [but] there is an incubation period that goes for up to 21 days.”</p> <p>Young also dismissed Katter’s concerns, defending Australian health workers who have gone to west Africa to treat people with the virus.</p> <p>“I have every confidence that her and other people like her who have gone over to west Africa to give of their skills, which I admire tremendously, to do what they’ve done will not put any Australian at harm. They are genuine, true, fantastic health professionals who are practising their profession so I’m not concerned by it,” she said.</p> <p>The head of the Australian Red Cross international program, Peter Walton, said Kovack had an “anxious wait” on Friday morning but was in good spirits while in isolation at Cairns hospital. He said she was aware of the intense media speculation and the discussion her case had caused in the wider community, including questions about whether Australian aid workers should be travelling to west Africa.<br /></p> <p>“If we don’t make a contribution, the risk of this expanding and becoming much more than a regional concern is absolutely going to be the case,” he told ABC News 24. “So we should be doing more. And I think Australian aid workers like Sue Ellen are incredibly brave being at the frontline.”</p> <p>Walton said Kovack was a clinical nurse who had worked in a Red Cross Ebola treatment centre about 180km from Freetown.</p> <p>The Australian government has resisted calls to send health professionals to west Africa to help with the epidemic.</p> <p>“The worst-case scenarios are that it’s going to be keep doubling every three weeks [and] there will be over 1.4m people affected,” Walton said. “That is the worst-case scenario but more needs to be done. We certainly hope that won’t be the case.”</p> <p>Queensland’s premier, Campbell Newman, cautiously welcomed the news of Kovack’s initial negative result. “Let’s keep our fingers crossed for the patient involved,” he told reporters in Canberra, where he has travelled for a Council of Australian Governments meeting.</p> <p>Almost 4,000 people have died from Ebola in west Africa and Kovack was one of several Australians who have travelled to the region to help treat patients there.</p> <p>A doctor is in home isolation in south Brisbane after returning from treating Ebola patients overseas.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/train-immune-ebola-survivors-help-medics-uk-nurse-will-pooley <p>The British nurse who survived Ebola has said he believes immune survivors should be trained to assist healthcare workers in the fight against the disease.</p> <p>Will Pooley hopes to return to Sierra Leone after doctors advised him he would have antibodies to make him immune to the virus for months to come.</p> <p>About 50% of those who contract the disease survive, and Pooley says the public can contribute. “The care required by an Ebola patient in a resource-poor setting is generally very basic. Helping to keep them clean, assisting them with food and fluid, and keeping them in the right place.”</p> <p>He added: “Medication and IV fluids obviously need to be left to trained professionals but most care can be performed by minimally trained workers, providing they are kind and compassionate.”</p> <p>Pooley made his remarks as he recalled how helpful a 17-year-old survivor, Douda Fullah, had been in the Kenema hospital where he worked in an Ebola ward.</p> <p>Douda’s tragic story has been captured on film, with his consent, by the British charity <a href="http://www.street-child.co.uk/ebolaresponse/" title="">Street Child</a>, which is working to support those orphaned by the disease.</p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O0oeHB0VQGs"                                                                                > <iframe width="460" height="259" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/O0oeHB0VQGs?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed&start=26" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> <figcaption>Douda Fullah, 17, recounts how the loss of his parents left him looking after two younger siblings. </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In the film, he recalls how he lost his father, his stepmother, his two-year-old brother, his 13-year-old sister and his grandmother in just 37 days. His stepmother was six months pregnant but miscarried in hospital because of the Ebola virus.</p> <p>“It’s a sad story really, so sad,” said Douda. “I’ve lost five members of my family including my father,” he says as he drops his head into his hands, overcome by emotion. “Presently I am just left without my family and no one to take care of us. I am left with the younger ones.</p> <p>“I have lost five members of my family. I have no one to take care of me ... I’m begging. Come to our aid. We are suffering. There is no hope for us.” </p> <p>Pooley recalled: “I remember his stepmother; she was pregnant, she came in with a little boy ... that’s how I got to know Douda.</p> <p>“He was showing a lot of concern for his little brother. His mum had a really bad prognosis and died a couple of days after miscarrying. Douda was helping her. As a lot of patients do, she had fallen off her bed and died on the floor,” says Pooley.</p> <p>He remembers the other members of Douda’s family vividly, and said Douda played an important role in taking care of them: “It was a strange thing so see him so upset on the video because he was really one of the most helpful patients. He would help his grandmother get to the toilet and he would put on an apron and help others.</p> <p>“If we ever needed anything in the ward, we’d say ‘Douda, Douda’ and he’d get it. He was like an assistant.”</p> <p>“When he was tested again and tested negative, it was like a triumph and everyone cheered. He was so helpful. The last thing I heard was that he had come back to the ward to help,” Pooley said.</p> <p>Orphaned, Douda is now left to care for himself, his 12-year-old brother and 15-year-old sister.</p> <p>“Where am I going to get money to pay another rent, so that we continue to stay in the house. No hope. Let them help us. Let them see us as their children. We are suffering. We really need help, we really need help. Without help I don’t think we move further throughout our lives.</p> <p>“It is really a difficult situation. I am begging, come to our aid, we are suffering, let them come to our aid ... There’s no hope for us,” he says.</p> <p>His tragedy started on 24 July when his father contracted the disease and died a short time later.</p> <p>“Then after his burial, my stepmother, she also got sick. They [took] her to the hospital and the following day I also started feeling symptoms, having fever, headache, so I too decided to go to the hospital. So they took me in for admission with my stepmother and younger brother who was just about two years old.</p> <p>“I stayed to wait for my result. After two days they told me I was also positive, so I was also admitted to the hospital,” recalls Douda. He survived but two days later his 13-year-old sister died, followed by his grandmother eight days later.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/airline-cabin-cleaners-strike-over-ebola-fears-at-laguardia-airport <p>About 200 airline cabin cleaners walked off their jobs at New York’s LaGuardia airport on Thursday, to protest what they say are working conditions that do not protect against potential Ebola contraction.</p> <p>“When I do bathroom, I come in contact with tampons which I have to grab with my hand, with a glove that’s so cheap that it breaks easily. I come in contact with feces, a lot of feces and vomit. And we have to clean those bathrooms spotless because they audit those planes,”<em> </em>Wendy Arellano, one of the workers, told the Guardian.</p> <p>“They expect us, that if a little bit of feces stays on the toilet, that we remove it with our hands because [if not] they will say that bathroom is dirty. And I refuse to do it because I think it’s disgusting and I don’t have the appropriate attire, and because I don’t know what that person has.</p> <p>“We come in contact with a lot of stuff that is dangerous for our health and obviously they don’t give us the appropriate tools to work with.”</p> <p>Workers set up picket lines overnight, by non-unionized Air Serv cleaners near Terminal D. The one-day strike forces airline crews to clean planes themselves.</p> <p>Air Serv, an employer of the people striking today, released a statement in response to the walkout: “Air Serv trains its cabin cleaners in its long-standing safety procedures and cleaning protocols including for blood borne pathogens. These protocols include, but are not limited to, providing cleaners with protective equipment.”</p> <p> “We continually review our policies and procedures for updates and enhancements, and communicate updates to employees, as necessary – for example, including an update on protocols for Ebola just last week. As to the union’s organizing campaign, we have no comment.”</p> <p>Workers on strike, fearing the deadly virus and trying to join the union, briefly left the picket lines to attend an infectious disease training session organized by the union. </p> <p>The Obama administration announced it would step up screening for Ebola symptoms at five major airports, after<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-patient-dies-texas-thomas-eric-duncan"> one man died Wednesday in Dallas from the virus</a>, which he contracted in Liberia. LaGuardia, which does not service flights to west Africa – where more than 3,800 people have died due to outbreaks – is not among the airports with increased screenings.</p> <p>A Delta Air Lines spokesperson told Reuters that airline staffers who usually do other terminal jobs had to clean planes themselves, but that no flights were delayed or canceled as a consequence.</p> <p>The striking workers said in a statement that clean-up crews have recently been halved, and that the time to clean an entire plane reduced to as little as five minutes, rather than up to 45. They also protested that their employer does not provide them with face masks for dealing with strong cleaning chemicals.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/imf-ebola-outbreak-un-world-bank <p>The International Monetary Fund has changed its rules to allow the west African countries hit by the Ebola epidemic to borrow more and run up bigger deficits, as the head of the UN said 20 times more money was needed to fight the outbreak described as the biggest global health threat since Aids.</p> <p>Christine Lagarde, managing director of the IMF, said it was dropping its normal opposition to extra borrowing for the three worst-hit countries, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia. Lagarde said it was good to increase budget deficits at the current time, adding: “We don’t say that very often.”</p> <p>Ban Ki-moon, the UN secretary general, said the response to the outbreak that has left almost 4,000 dead had so far been inadequate. “For those who have yet to pledge, I say please do so soon,” he said. “This is an unforgiving disease.”</p> <p>The appeal came as the presidents of the three countries said they could not cope with the crisis and pleaded with the international community to send more help.</p> <p>The world’s response had not kept pace with the spread of Ebola, said Sierra Leone’s president, Ernst Bai Koroma, speaking by video to a summit held at the annual meeting of the IMF and the World Bank, and describing the disease as “a tragedy unforeseen in modern times”.</p> <p>Tom Frieden, director of the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, told the meeting that Ebola was comparable to Aids. “I have been in public health service for 30 years and the only thing I have seen like this is Aids. We will have to work hard to stop it being the next Aids.”</p> <p>Frieden’s comments came as new suspected cases of Ebola emerged in Australia and Spain and as the chancellor, George Osborne, said Britain would test people coming into the country if advised to do so by medical experts.</p> <p>Alpha Condé, president of Guinea, and Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, president of Liberia, – also spoke at the World Bank-organised summit, which pledged money, health professionals and hospital beds to help deal with the crisis.</p> <p>The US sent two military planes to Liberia, which has cancelled elections in the latest attempt to stop the spread of the virus.</p> <p>Critics say Liberian president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf’s handling of the crisis has been heavy-handed and ineffective. Police used batons and rattan whips to disperse 100 protesters outside the national assembly, where legislators were debating granting her even more powers beyond those contained in a state of emergency declared in August.</p> <p>Condé said: “This is an international threat and it deserves an international response. All of the West African region is threatened.”</p> <p>After Britain announced on Wednesday that it was scaling up its efforts to curb Ebola, the international development secretary, Justine Greening, called for other countries to do likewise.</p> <p>“If we wait a month the task will be twice as large. It will kill twice as many people and have twice the impact on economies,” she said.</p> <p>Jim Kim, the World Bank president, said: “We are still way, way behind the curve and we have to scale up the global response; there is a critical need for more trained health workers.”</p> <p>Kim also said that more hospitals and local health centres must be built quickly to ensure that west Africans had faith that they could get the care they needed in their own community, and no longer fear Ebola centres as places that people went only to die.</p> <p>Kim, a doctor who formerly led the World Health Organisation’s global Aids treatment programme, said studies of past disease outbreaks, such as the Sars virus, showed that 80-90% of the economic impact came from “the fear factor that surrounds the outbreak”.</p> <p>A World Bank study published on Wednesday said the cost of Ebola could be as high as $33bn (£20bn) for west Africa if it could not be contained. The bank has yet to do a broader assessment of its impact on the rest of the world.</p> <p>Kim said the most urgent humanitarian need was getting medical care to treat people in their own communities. That was also the best way to stop the spread of Ebola to other nations and counter the fear that magnified its economic damage.</p> <p>“Trying to block your borders or isolate those countries in some way is not going to work,” he said.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/09/guardian-view-on-ebola-fighting-fear-as-well-as-infection <p>The lay person is forever wary of being “blinded by science”. But to students of disease, the laws governing the natural world look far simpler than the chaotically unpredictable reaction that their work can often provoke. <a href="http://www.amazon.co.uk/Manias-Panics-Crashes-Financial-Investment/dp/0471389455" title="">Panics, manias and crashes attract the attention of economists</a>. There is less systematic study of the way in which crowds react, and over-react, to information in the non-financial realm.</p> <p>As the rich world belatedly grapples with the singularly nasty, but reasonably well-understood, outbreak of Ebola in Africa, fear itself is becoming the primary problem in Europe and America. The pressing need of the victims, who are almost exclusively in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, is plain. They don’t require Live Aid-style charity donations but many more medical workers. So, too, do the far greater number of potential victims in the region, whose contact with the stricken will leave them prone to the frequently fatal virus until sufficient quarantined facilities are up and running. The <a href="http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/ebola-what-europe-and-us-can-learn-from-nigeria-in-containing-the-virus-9780273.html" title="">contrast with Nigeria</a>, which is also poor but has – through more organised care – contained Ebola thus far, illustrates the importance of both the volume and the coordination of personnel. But as anxiety in Britain rises to the point where a nine-year-old <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2784698/British-school-bans-nine-year-old-Sierra-Leone-parents-feared-classmates-Ebola.html" title="">Sierra Leonean boy is banned from a Stockport school</a>, despite the headteacher being satisfied that he is not infected, volunteers may be put off from venturing overseas.</p> <p>Thursday saw a hasty refinement of the British approach. Initially, the UK had refused to follow America’s lead and <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/09/us/us-to-begin-ebola-screenings-at-5-airports.html?_r=0" title="">screen for raised temperatures at airports</a>. The UK’s immediate reservations were well-founded. Ebola’s <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs103/en/" title="">virology – non-airborne transmission</a>, incubation of up to 21 days, early symptoms indistinct from many infections – puts a premium on rooting out the problem at source. Quickfire border checks cannot be relied on to keep the virus at bay in Europe if it becomes more entrenched in Africa. Then there are more specific objections to temperature scanners: the countless “false positives” with other fevers that would be picked up, and the even more damaging false reassurance that would be produced if the all-clear were given to genuine Ebola cases where symptoms were still dormant. Subsequently, however, Downing Street signalled that – at selected entry points only – the UK would be running questionnaires about where travellers had been, and what contact they’d had. Checks of this form could be more useful, but they are certainly not failsafe. Thomas Duncan, who died of the virus in Dallas this week, had <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-crisis-world-bank-president-jim-kim-failure" title="">falsely responded</a> to such inquiries, denying he’d been in contact with anyone affected.</p> <p>If there is one cardinal “don’t” in navigating between the science of risk and public anxiety, it is running ahead of the available evidence about what it is, in fact, possible to guarantee. Recall <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/16/newsid_2913000/2913807.stm" title="">John Selwyn Gummer</a> feeding his daughter a beefburger to demonstrate that BSE posed no risk to humans to see why. What of the “dos”? Providing west Africa with the support it needs, including not only the troops already announced but medical practitioners too, is one. The overwhelming importance of on-the-ground resources vindicates David Cameron for, like Gordon Brown and Tony Blair before him, championing international aid. Like all the most important threats facing humanity, viruses are no respecter of borders, and so safety at home requires engagement and generosity overseas. At the same time as readying the NHS to deal with the worst possibility of Ebola’s arrival and transmission within the UK, it is also important to calm popular fears, and more particularly the anxieties of those who might be considering joining the relief effort. David Miliband, now <a href="http://www.rescue.org/david-miliband-biography" title="">president of the International Rescue Committee</a>, has shown the way. Simply by <a href="http://www.rescue.org/press-releases/irc-community-partnership-approach-helps-reduce-ebola-spread-targeted-west-african-co" title="">turning up in Freetown</a>, he makes the point that this is not an infection that lays waste every passing visitor, but rather a disease spread through direct contact, whose progress can be controlled by careful hygiene drills.</p> <p>The virulence of Ebola is not in doubt. No prescription to deal with it will do much good, unless honesty and calm are part of the mix.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/briton-dies-macedonia-suspected-ebola-reports <p>Foreign Office officials are investigating reports that a British national has died in Macedonia of suspected Ebola.</p> <p>If confirmed it would be the first death of a UK national from Ebola, although British nurse Will Pooley was cured of the virus last month.</p> <p>The Macedonian government says it is investigating the death of a British national on its territory after an undiagnosed illness but stressed that the cause of death had not been confirmed.</p> <p>“It is a British citizen who has died. The health ministry is trying to find out what he died from and it needs some time to find out the reason,” a spokesman for Macedonia’s foreign ministry said. “We are following the protocols of what to do in such cases set out by the World Health Organisation.”</p> <p>The director of the commission for infectious disease at the ministry of health, Jovanka Kostovska, said the man, a 56-year-old, had travelled from London to Macedonia on 2 October with a colleague for business. He had been staying at a hotel in the centre of Skopje when he was taken ill with severe stomach ache and increased temperature. The man remained in his hotel room for three days, before an ambulance was called on Thursday afternoon around 3pm local time. He was taken to hospital where he died around 90 minutes later.</p> <p>At this stage Ebola is only suspected, and further tests are to be carried out by a laboratory in Germany to find out if it is the virus or not. Results are expected within 48 hours.</p> <p>Officials said the man’s colleague said that he had not travelled to any country where Ebola was a risk, although the Macedonian health ministry suspected he had visited Nigeria. They gave no reason why this was suspected.</p> <p>Hotel staff and anyone who came into contact with the man have now been put in quarantine.</p> <p>In London, the Foreign Office said it was aware of the report of the Briton’s unexplained death and was urgently looking into it.</p> <p>Pooley, from Suffolk, became the first Briton to contract the virus after working as a volunteer nurse in Sierra Leone, which is one of the worst-hit countries of the current outbreak.</p> <p>He was flown back to Britain on 24 August and recovered after being treated in an isolation unit at London’s Royal Free hospital.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-how-you-can-help <p>The death toll from the Ebola epidemic continues to rise – <a href="http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/136020/1/roadmapsitrep_8Oct2014_eng.pdf?ua=1">more than 4400 cases have been confirmed</a>, the vast majority in west Africa – and on Wednesday the US and UK made another “urgent plea” for all nations to boost their efforts to combat the virus. So what is currently being done – and what can you do to help?</p> <h2>How to volunteer</h2> <p>• In the UK, <a href="http://uk-med.humanities.manchester.ac.uk/">more than 650 NHS workers have signed up to volunteer at a hospital in Sierra Leone</a>. NHS staff wishing to be considered for the UK response to Ebola in west Africa can <a href="https://eduqate.net/form-portlet/share/0690148788cf482899981f9d5df33d14#/0690148788cf482899981f9d5df33d14">register their interest</a>.</p> <p>• <a href="http://www.msf.org.uk/work-overseas">Médecins sans Frontières is recruiting field staff from both medical and non-medical backgrounds</a>.</p> <p>• <a href="http://www.usaid.gov/ebola/volunteers">USAid is inviting qualified medical professionals to volunteer.</a></p> <p>• The International Medical Corps is <a href="http://internationalmedicalcorps.org/ebola-emergency-response">recruiting qualified healthcare practitioners, water, sanitation and environmental experts, psychosocial staff and logistics, human resources and finance professionals</a> to work in Ebola treatment units in Sierra Leone and Liberia</p> <h2>How to donate to aid agencies and organisations tackling Ebola</h2> <p>USAid has collated a <a href="http://www.cidi.org/ebola-ngos/#.VDWi6xYgvOE">list of NGOs responding to Ebola</a>. In the UK, members of the <a href="http://www.dec.org.uk/blog/dec-statement-ebola-outbreak">Disasters Emergency Committee</a> appealing for support include: British Red Cross, Save the Children, ActionAid, Plan UK and Oxfam.</p> <p><strong>Médecins sans Frontières</strong> (MSF/Doctors without borders)</p> <p>MSF has led efforts to help those affected. Its teams in west Africa are seeing critical gaps in all aspects of the response, including medical care, training of health staff, infection control, contact tracing, epidemiological surveillance, alert and referral systems, community education and mobilisation. As well as directly providing medical care and training, MSF is continuing its advocacy to mobilise states to tackle the crisis.</p> <p><strong><em>How to donate:</em></strong> <a href="http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/support-us">International/US</a>, <a href="http://www.msf.org.uk/support-us">UK</a>, <a href="http://www.msf.org.au/donate.html">Australia</a></p> <p><strong>International Medical Corps (IMC)</strong></p> <p>IMC is operating a 70-bed treatment unit in Bong County, Liberia, where people with suspected and confirmed cases of Ebola are being cared for. Of the 58 patients admitted to the centre, 20 have died while four have recovered and been discharged. IMC’s ambulance team has picked up a total of 25 patients to date. In Sierra Leone, the organisation is about to open and manage a 50-bed Ebola treatment unit in Lunsar, Port Loko district. Staff have trained more than 120 healthcare workers in infection control standards to help control the risk when working with Ebola patients.<a href="www.internationalmedicalcorps.org.uk to donate."><strong><em><br /></em></strong></a></p> <p><a href="www.internationalmedicalcorps.org.uk to donate."><strong><em><br /></em></strong></a><strong><a href="http://www.internationalmedicalcorps.org.uk/about-us/emergencyresponse/ebola-crisis/"><em>How to donate</em></a></strong><br /></p> <p><strong>Oxfam</strong></p> <p>Oxfam is tripling its existing Ebola programme in Liberia and Sierra Leone: now worth a total of £22m, it will aim to help 3.5 million people in both countries. The funds will cover the construction and rehabilitaton of water supplies to treatment centres, providing bleach and materials such as personal protection equipment, as well as running mass media public health information campaigns. Training and support for community health workers will also be offered.</p> <p><strong><em>How to donate:</em></strong> <a href="https://donate.oxfam.org.uk/emergency/ebola?intcmp=hp_325ctrl_hero_ebola-donate_2014-10-08">UK</a>, <a href="http://www.oxfamamerica.org/take-action/save-lives/ebola-outbreak/">US</a>, <a href="http://www.oxfam.org">Oxfam international</a></p> <p><strong>World Food Programme (WFP)</strong></p> <p>The WFP has distributed food to 458,000 people in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. Food distribution takes place in both urban and rural areas, often house-to-house and one family at time. Besides food, WFP is providing transport and logistics support for the humanitarian response to the Ebola crisis. In the Liberian capital, Monrovia, WFP is building four Ebola treatment centres and has set up a dedicated warehouse storage hub for the entire humanitarian community. WFP also manages the UN’s humanitarian air service, which transports humanitarian workers and delivers light cargo between and within the three affected countries.</p> <p><a href="https://give.wfp.org/5126/?step=country&amp;lead_source=2014-media-theguardian-ebola&amp;form_tag=2014-media-theguardian-ebola"><strong><em>How to donate</em></strong></a></p> <p><strong>Save the Children</strong></p> <p>Save the Children is working with partners to support children and raise awareness of how to prevent infection and stop the disease spreading. They have trained more than 3,000 community health workers, who go from house to house explaining how to prevent infection. In Liberia, Save the Children has built a treatment centre and distributed essential supplies to hospitals. It is now building a network of 10 Ebola care units and providing specialist emotional support to children whose lives have been affected by the crisis. It is also working with the Sierra Leone and UK governments to build and run an Ebola treatment centre outside Freetown, and will manage the UK’s treatment centre once it is completed.</p> <p><strong><em>How to donate:</em></strong> <a href="http://www.savethechildren.org.uk/ebola">UK</a>, <a href="http://www.savethechildren.net">international</a></p> <p><strong>International Rescue Committee</strong></p> <p>The IRC has established a 100-bed treatment centre in Liberia – a quarter of the total number of available beds in the country – which is due to open in early November. It is providing treatment, a community-led approach to preventing the spread of the disease, and surveillance of potential cases, as well as leading on coordination with the UN, other NGOs and health ministries. In addition, medical care is being offered to people with treatable diseases, who would otherwise die as a result of being too scared to visit health centres, and to pregnant women. In Sierra Leone, the IRC is leading the Ebola Response Consortium, consisting of nine partner organisations. The IRC’s management and support of burial teams in Liberia has ensured that 70% of bodies in Montserrado County are now picked up within 24 hours (up from 38% in July).</p> <p><a href="https://engage.rescue.org/donate/ebola"><strong><em>How to donate</em></strong></a></p> <p><strong>Red Cross</strong></p> <p>The Red Cross is raising awareness about Ebola in communities and introducing measures to reduce further infection. A collaboration with the telecoms company Airtel has led to the creation of an mobile text message system that communicates messages about Ebola prevention and response. The Red Cross is coordinating the burial of infectious corpses and has also opened an Ebola treatment centre in Kenema, an area hit hard by the outbreak, expanding the number of local treatment beds available.</p> <p><strong><em>How to donate:</em></strong> <a href="http://www.redcross.org.uk/ebolavirus">UK</a>, <a href="https://www.icrc.org/en">international</a></p> <p><strong>Plan</strong></p> <p>Plan works in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. Frontline teams have been <a href="http://www.plan-uk.org/news/news-and-features/ebola-emergency-appeal/#sthash.Uq9B9aj5.dpuf">working in communities</a> for the past four months, helping people deal with local outbreaks, giving accurate public health information to prevent further infection, and providing materials to limit the spread of Ebola.</p> <p><strong><em>How to donate:</em></strong> <a href="http://www.plan-uk.org/news/news-and-features/ebola-emergency-appeal/">UK</a>, <a href="http://plan-international.org/what-you-can-do/emergency-appeals/ebola-outbreak-appeal">international</a>, <a href="http://www.plan.org.au/Donations/Our-Current-Appeals/Ebola-Crisis-Appeal.aspx">Australia</a></p> <p><strong>ActionAid</strong></p> <p>ActionAid is concentrating its efforts on prevention by training local women to talk to others about the disease. It is broadcasting safety messages on radio stations and in public areas, training local volunteers to raise awareness in their communities, providing food and oil for people in quarantine, giving medical and sanitation supplies to underfunded medical centres, and providing protective gear for health workers.</p> <p><strong><em>How to donate:</em></strong> <a href="http://www.actionaid.org.uk/ebola">UK</a>, <a href="https://support.actionaid.org.au/fightingebola">Australia</a></p> <p><strong>Unicef</strong></p> <p>Unicef, the UN children’s agency, is working with partners to control the Ebola outbreak. It has reached more than 5.5 million people with messages about the dangers of the disease, its symptoms and transmission, the importance of hygiene, and where to seek help.</p> <p><strong><em>How to donate:</em></strong> <a href="http://www.unicef.org.uk/ebola">UK</a>, <a href="http://www.unicef.org">international</a></p> <p><strong>Cafod</strong><br /></p> <p>Cafod church partners are training priests, parish volunteers, imams, spiritualists and traditional healers to spread the word about hand-washing, good hygiene and safe burial practices, as well as distributing hygiene kits. </p> <p><strong><em><a href="http://www.cafod.org.uk/Give/Donate-to-Emergencies/Ebola-crisis">How to donate</a></em></strong></p> <p><strong>Street Child</strong></p> <p>Street Child works with vulnerable children. It is supporting the day-to-day, essential needs of individuals and households whose lives and livelihoods have been affected either by ebola itself, or by the effect of quarantine, for example by supplying dry rations and water. As well as information and advice, Street Child is providing buckets, soap and chlorine to enable communities to reduce the spread of the virus in their area. </p> <p><em><a href="http://www.street-child.co.uk/donate/"><strong>How to donate</strong></a></em></p> <p><strong>Welbodi</strong></p> <p>Welbodi works to improve the quality of healthcare for children and mothers in Sierra Leone through education, training, infrastructure and management support.</p> <p><a href="http://welbodipartnership.org/home/how-you-can-help/"><strong><em>How to donate</em></strong></a></p> <p><strong>Educaid</strong></p> <p>Educaid runs a network of free schools for vulnerable youngsters in Sierra Leone.</p> <p><a href="http://www.educaid.org.uk/support-us/"><strong><em>How to donate</em></strong></a></p> <p><strong>American Jewish World Service (AJWS)</strong></p> <p>AJWS is working on the ground in Liberia to educate community members. AJWS provides money directly to local Liberian groups who are taking on the critical task of providing information and educational material to help stop further spreading of the disease. <br /></p> <p><strong><em><a href="https://secure.ajws.org/site/Donation2?df_id=7460&amp;7460.donation=form1">How to donate</a></em></strong></p> <p><strong>Mary’s Meals</strong></p> <p>In Liberia, the charity is distributing take-home food rations to about 69,000 of the almost 129,000 children it normally provides school feeding for.</p> <p><em><strong><a http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/liberia-suspends-elections-ebola-outbreak <p>Liberia has suspended senatorial elections due next week as the country grapples with an accelerating Ebola outbreak that health officials have said poses the biggest public health challenge since the Aids epidemic of the 1980s.</p> <p>At least two million voters, roughly half of the west African nation’s population, were due to elect half of the 30-member upper chamber next Tuesday, but organisers said a “mass movement, deployment and gathering of people” would endanger lives.</p> <p>Restricted numbers of polling staff and low voter turnout would make it impossible to conduct a credible election, the election commission said.</p> <p>The commission’s chairman, Jerome George Korkoya, said transporting and distributing equipment including ballot papers and polling kits had been hampered as international airlines had suspended flights in the wake of the outbreak.</p> <p>“The timely delivery of these materials, most of which are sensitive, cannot be guaranteed in the wake of the current wave of the suspension of flights to Liberia,” he said, adding that a new date would be set, before the end of the year if possible.</p> <p>President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf’s popularity has taken a battering at home over her handling of the Ebola outbreak. Liberia has recorded 2,200 deaths, more than half of the 3,865 total so far.</p> <p>A presidential request for sweeping emergency powers led to one newspaper running the headline “Flirting with dictatorship” on Thursday. Police used batons and whips to disperse around 100 protesters who had gathered outside the national assembly as politicians debated the request to extend the president’s powers beyond the state of emergency declared in August.</p> <p>On Thursday, Johnson Sirleaf addressed an International Monetary Fund meeting alongside her counterparts from Guinea and Sierra Leone. All three called for a greater international response to help stem the epidemic. “Our people are dying,” Sierra Leone’s president, Ernest Bai Koroma, said by video link.</p> <p>Tom Frieden, director the US Centre for Diseases Control and Prevention, told the meeting: “I have been in public health service for 30 years and the only thing I have seen like this is Aids. We will have to work hard to stop it being the next Aids.”</p> <p>A recent surge of international aid is intended to provide the 2,000-odd beds that are urgently needed. But efforts to recruit medics have been complicated as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/-sp-ebola-west-africa-health-workers" title="">many local health workers have succumbed to the disease</a>.</p> <p>On Thursday a Uganda-born doctor died at a treatment centre on the outskirts of the Liberian capital, Monrovia. He was the fourth doctor to die in the country since the start of the outbreak. A handful of international doctors have also been infected.</p> <p>Experts say many cases are going unreported. The largest number of infections in the past 21 days – a useful measure as it is the longest incubation period of the virus – have come from Sierra Leone. At least 924 cases have been confirmed.</p> <p>The rise has been concentrated in the west of the country, including the capital, Freetown, which previously was largely spared. “We can’t explain exactly why the numbers have gone up in the western area, but we’re going to discuss how to tackle it,” said Brima Kargbo, the chief medical officer.</p> <p>Sierra Leone has 304 beds, which is well short of the 1,100-odd the WHO estimates it needs. Two burial teams in the western area went on strike this week over delayed payment. One worker, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: “We’re risking our lives and we’re not being paid for it. And since we started this work, people have been talking a lot – we’re not welcome in our community any more.”</p> <p>There is one bright spot: new cases have all but stopped in the eastern region bordering Guinea and Liberia, where the transmissions started and were initially highest. Health campaigns and treatment centres are clustered there, and some districts are now going days without reporting any new cases.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2014/oct/09/ebola-crisis-worlds-celebrities-kim-kardashian-akon <p>Lost in Showbiz doesn’t know about you, but it’s barely slept a wink since the beginning of the Ebola crisis. There are so many different and terrible aspects of it that plague the mind: the thousands dead; the inadequacy of the response; the awful, helpless feeling that there really is no adequate response to an impossibly contagious virus with no effective cure.</p> <p>But one thought, more than any other, troubles Lost in Showbiz. Where are the celebrities in all this? It has long held that in any time of dire crisis, the people we should look to for guidance are the famous ones, selflessly willing to share with us their indispensable thoughts: on what should be done, on how people’s spirits should be lifted. Where, it asks, is Paul Daniels, who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2011/aug/11/judge-paul-daniels-condemns-looters" title="">gallantly came to Britain’s aid during the 2011 riots with his own inimitable brand of blue-sky thinking</a>, spitballing one idea after another that the nation may be saved further turmoil. Perhaps the rioters should be deported to Afghanistan, he mused. Perhaps we should douse them in petrol and threaten to set them on fire. Perhaps we should chop their hands off. Is there such a thing as a “wide-angle tazer” that could be deployed?</p> <p>Where is Chris Brown, who felt the best way to quell the situation would be for him to play his hit song Beautiful People to the rioters? LiS mourns the loss of the late Michael Winner, who rushed to social media in the wake of the Japanese tsunami to focus the world’s collective mind on the truly important issue: would it affect attendance figures for the American Cinematheque’s Tribute to Michael Winner event at the Aero Theatre Santa Monica? And it asks, where is Nicole Scherzinger, who noted that the 2010 Haiti earthquake may have been bad news for the 316,000 people who died, but that at least there had been one “miracle from Haiti’s disaster”: she’d met a producer at the recording of a charity single and together they’d made a “raw, soulful and funky” Nicole Scherzinger album.</p> <p>These were sage words; comforting words. But where are their equivalents in the face of the most severe public health emergency seen in modern times? The celebrity response started so well, with the appearance of Donald Trump – a man Lost in Showbiz has long come to think of as a lone voice of common sense in a world gone mad – fearlessly pinpointing the real culprits in all of this: the aid workers. “<a href="http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/whoopi-goldberg-to-donald-trump-on-ebola-virus-do-your-homework-201458" title="">The US cannot allow EBOLA infected people back</a>,” he tweeted. “People that go to far-away places to help are great – but must suffer the consequences!” At those words, Lost in Showbiz’s heart skipped a beat: thank Christ, the cavalry are here! It can only be a matter of time before Daniels rocks up with his wide-angle taser and his jerrycan of BP unleaded.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-79fa1a2b-9b34-4cb8-b409-4f48deee1a55"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412865603794/1b5b874c-1c07-46bc-8e75-60609f28ef71-460x276.jpeg" alt="Kim Kardashian and Kanye West … in danger?" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Kim Kardashian and Kanye West … in danger?</span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Sipa</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>LiS waited and it waited, but nothing. Its interest was momentarily pricked by a story that Kim Kardashian was “<a href="https://www.dishnation.com/kim-k-terrified-of-ebola-trading-in-her-designer-duds-for-hazmat-chic/" title="">trying to get her hands on a number of impermeable full body suits to protect herself and her family against Ebola</a>”. “These are the sorts of suits companies such as Doctors Without Borders or airport paramedics would be requesting. Not celebrities who don’t want to cut down their air travel,” claimed Lost in Showbiz’s old buddy An Unnamed Source. But the more it read of it – “Kardashian, hubby Kanye West, and their daughter North were most recently in Paris, France, but there’s no telling where the jet-setting family will end up next!”, it concluded, with the implicit suggestion they might all be “jet-setting” to Liberia – the more Lost in Showbiz began to suspect that the whole thing was made up, perhaps on the famous journalistic principle that if you think up the most idiotic thing you possibly can about Kim and Kanye, there’s a 75% chance it might actually happen.</p> <p>Next, Lost in Showbiz became hugely excited about the story that R’n’B star <a href="http://africasacountry.com/the-wisdom-of-akon/" title="">Akon</a> had played a charity concert in the Democratic Republic of the Congo encased in a giant plastic bubble to avoid coming into contact with the virus. It certainly seemed like the kind of thing Akon might do: he has variously told black Americans that they’re “blessed” not to be living in Africa, then changed his mind and told them they should all move to Africa and “live like kings” there and informed one journalist that women should always be monogamous, but men shouldn’t; and told another that there was <a href="http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/akon-so-what-if-i-own-a-diamond-mine-436472.html" title="">no such thing as a blood diamond</a> – the whole concept was apparently made up by Hollywood and people believed it. But, alas, no. He did indeed perform in a giant plastic bubble. Apparently he attempted to crowd surf in it but fell to the ground and had to be rescued by the UN – good to see them doing something useful for a change rather than just passing resolutions involving the trade in non-existent blood diamonds – but he also performed outside it.</p> <p>No giant plastic anti-Ebola bubble for Akon, no impermeable full-body suit for Kim: the only thing that celebrities appeared to have done in response to the Ebola outbreak was to <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/posttv/world/celebrities-team-up-to-fight-ebola/2014/10/08/c68d3c64-4f26-11e4-877c-335b53ffe736_video.html" title="">film a sober video asking for a calm and non-hysterical response</a> to the outbreak and soliciting donations for local relief efforts. Lost in Showbiz could barely contain its fury: a sober back-and-white video soliciting donations for local relief efforts? What’s wrong with doing something genuinely useful, more befitting your status as celebrities? Get a hashtag campaign going! Or something involving posting selfies to Facebook! Will none of you get yourselves on Twitter and start pontificating about the situation like a great berk? Seriously, this amounts to an absolute dereliction of duty. These are desperate times! People are being forced to make up stories about Akon having a giant plastic anti-Ebola bubble, simply because so-called “celebrities” are refusing to behave like celebrities. It’s absolutely terrible.</p> <p>So thank God for Katie Hopkins, who this week tweeted a load of idiotic old cack about how much <a href="https://twitter.com/KTHopkins/status/519759796241592320" title="">she “admired” the Ebola virus</a>. Teary with gratitude that at least someone is behaving in the manner they are supposed to, Lost in Showbiz is now counting down the days until Hopkins has herself deliberately infected with Ebola to prove that only thick, lazy poor people die of it.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/uk-screening-airports-ebola-symptoms <p>Travellers arriving at Heathrow and Gatwick from west Africa are to be screened for symptoms of Ebola, Downing Street announced on Thursday night after a day of confusion over the government’s response to the virus that has claimed more than 3,800 lives.</p> <p>People travelling from the worst-affected countries – Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea – will face a questionnaire about their recent travel history, who they have been in contact with and their onward travel arrangements.</p> <p>Medical staff will be deployed to check some travellers’ body temperature to ascertain if they have fever, one of the early symptoms of the illness. Rail passengers arriving in Kent and London on the Eurostar from Paris and Brussels will also be screened.</p> <p>Cases have already been reported in Spain and the US, where <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-dallas-deputy-sheriff-hospital-symptoms-death" title="">Thomas Eric Duncan died on Thursday</a> after flying in from Liberia with the disease.</p> <p>Washington has announced that travellers from the worst-hit countries will have their temperatures taken on arrival at five major airports in New York, Washington, Chicago and Atlanta.</p> <p>The UK border measures will be introduced “in the coming days”, Downing Street said, and the announcement came despite the British defence secretary, Michael Fallon, saying earlier on Thursday that airport screening was not in line with World Health Organisation advice that screening for fevers or temperature is better conducted in the exit country.</p> <p>The chief medical officer, Professor Dame Sally Davies, cited “concern about the growing number of cases” of the illness and recommended border checks to ensure “potential cases arriving in the UK are identified as quickly as possible”.</p> <p>Public Health England staff will work alongside border officers. No 10 was unable to say whether the system would catch travellers from west Africa who had transferred planes in other cities.</p> <p>The apparent U-turn comes before a war game-style test of Britain’s ability to cope with an outbreak being planned by the Department of Health this weekend. Doctors, the ambulance service, local authorities and the police will take part in the real-time simulation of Ebola cases at two or more hospitals to be selected in the north and south of England.</p> <p>No 10 said: “Advice from the chief medical officer today is that enhanced screening arrangements at the UK’s main ports of entry for people travelling from the affected regions – Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea – will offer an additional level of protection to the UK.</p> <p>“These measures will help to improve our ability to detect and isolate Ebola cases. However, it is important to stress that given the nature of this disease, no system could offer 100% protection from non-symptomatic cases.”</p> <p>The Foreign Office was last night investigating reports that a Briton had died of suspected Ebola in Macedonia. Tests were being carried out but the man’s colleague said he had not been in any country known to have Ebola outbreaks. A social services centre in Paris which was sealed off after four children recently arrived from Guinea showed symptoms of the illness, was later reopened after the French authorities said it was a false alarm.</p> <p>Pressure for airport screening grew yesterday when Keith Vaz, chairman of the Commons home affairs select committee, which scrutinises border controls, called for tests “to ensure that this deadly disease cannot take more lives”. Andy Burnham, the shadow health secretary, also urged the government to consider passenger screening “without delay”.</p> <p>Davies said: “Rapid access to healthcare services by someone infected with Ebola is not only important for their health but also key to reducing the risk of transmission to others. These measures could include a further UK-based package of measures to identify and assess the health status of passengers arriving from the affected countries and to ensure that those individuals know what to do should they be taken ill whilst in the UK.”</p> <p>Experts say airport screening may have limited effect. David Heymann, professor of infectious diseases at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, who is also chairman of Public Health England, said there was a danger of creating a false sense of security .</p> <p>“It is not a failsafe method mainly because people cross [borders] while they are still in the incubation period and you don’t know they are infected,” he said.</p> <p>“The most important response is better detection and rapid response. Borders cannot stop infectious diseases spreading. In Hong Kong and Singapore they set up thermal scanners during the Sars epidemic but I don’t think they identified more than one case that way.”</p> <p>Professor David Mabey, another physician specialising in infectious diseases at the London School of Hygiene &amp; Tropical Medicine, warned passengers will lie about their travel history to avoid the inconvenience and so would be “a waste of time”.</p> <p>“If last week your aunt died of Ebola but you feel fine, are you going to be honest when you get to the airport and risk being detained?” he said.</p> <p>Professor George Griffin, chairman of the advisory committee on dangerous pathogens, said screening just for body temperature was ineffectual and would have missed the case of the US death.</p> <p>Experts also moved to play down fears of a major UK outbreak. Peter Piot, a Belgian microbiologist who is part of the World Health Organisation’s Ebola science group, said: “I’m not concerned about an outbreak in western Europe, in the UK, like we are seeing in west Africa.”</p> <p>Heymann said British preparedness to cope with Ebola cases was “superb”.</p> <p>“The government and the NHS has access to all clinicians so messages can get out to all of them at once and that means it is much easier to achieve uniformity than in private systems,” he said.</p> <p>He added that the public health authorities in the UK has successfully stopped two outbreaks of the deadly Middle East respiratory syndrome, a virus which, unlike Ebola, can be transmitted through the air.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/ebola-outbreak-six-quarantined-in-spain-madrid-hospital-ramos <p>The condition of Teresa Romero Ramos – the Spanish nurse who is the first known person to contract Ebola outside west Africa – has worsened, according to relatives.</p> <p>On Thursday afternoon, her brother José Ramón Romero told reporters at the Carlos III hospital that her state had deteriorated and she was now intubated. Another 80 or so are under observation, including health workers who treated Romero Ramos, and two employees at the hair salon where the nurse went for an appointment a week and a half ago.</p> <p>Her husband, who has not shown any symptoms, remains in isolation as a precautionary measure.</p> <p>On Wednesday the nurse gave several phone interviews to Spanish media outlets, sounding exhausted as she offered answers that ranged from monosyllabic to a 12-minute conversation. The doctor attending to her told reporters that he had spoken to her in an effort to retrace her steps as part of the investigation into how she contracted the disease.</p> <p>The doctor, Germán Ramírez, said the nurse believed she might have touched her face with her gloves as she was taking off her protective equipment after attending to the second Ebola patient repatriated to Spain. Later in an interview with the Spanish television network Cuatro, the nurse said her training in how to get into and out of the suit had lasted “a short time”.</p> <p>On Thursday more details emerged regarding the handling of Romero Ramos’s case, reinforcing health workers’ claims that this was an improvised response, lacking in top-down guidance.</p> <p>One of the doctors who treated the nurse when she arrived at the hospital in Alcorcón on Monday described the 16 hours he spent treating the nurse in a report to his superiors. His protective equipment was ill-fitting. “At all times the sleeves were too short,” he wrote, leaving his skin exposed.</p> <p>Despite being on the frontline of treating the nurse, he was not updated when her test results proved positive, he said. “I learned of the results from journalists rather than the relevant authority.” The doctor is now one of the seven people in quarantine.</p> <p>Other lapses emerged, including the fact that the ambulance that initially brought Romero Ramos from her home to the Alcorcón hospital carried seven other patients after her before it was sterilised.</p> <p>Speaking to journalists at a conference on youth employment in Milan on Wednesday, the Spanish prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, said European colleagues thought Spain was managing the Ebola case “very well”.</p> <p>At a conference that included the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and the French president, François Hollande, Rajoy said many leaders had expressed interest in what was happening in Spain. “My colleagues are telling me that we’re doing things very well,” he assured the journalists.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/business/marketforceslive/2014/oct/09/ftse-lowest-for-year-economy-ebola <p>On 10 October 2013, the <strong>FTSE 100</strong> was sitting at 6430, before subsequently rising - albeit in a rather volatile way - to its recent peak of 6878 in May.</p><p>Now a year later the leading index has fallen all the way back, closing down 50.39 points at 6431.85.</p><p>It did not look like that at the start of the day, with markets enthused by the US Federal Reserve minutes which suggested fears of an early interest rate rise were misplaced.</p><p>But this optimism soon faded, as the current worries about global growth and geopolitical concerns reasserted themselves.</p><p>This week has seen a raft of poor data, from Germany in particular, and a 5.8% fall in exports reinforced fears about a possible recession in what is supposed to be the eurozone's powerhouse.
