http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/family-ebola-victim-dallas-eric-duncan <p>It had been planned as a vigil, but the service quickly turned into a memorial once the news broke that Ebola had killed Eric Duncan, the virus’s first victim in the US.</p> <p>Before his condition worsened and he died in a Dallas hospital at 7.51am local time on Wednesday, eight days after his diagnosis was confirmed, Duncan’s last words were spoken to a nurse from the bed in his isolation room: a request to see Karsiah, the son he last saw 16 years ago when the boy was three.</p> <p>That final hope went unfulfilled. A student in San Angelo, 250 miles away, Karsiah was staying in Dallas and preparing to head to Texas Health Presbyterian hospital in the hope of seeing Duncan at about 9am when his mother called him to tell him his father had died.</p> <p>The sense of disconnection and distance, even from relatives in the same city, was replicated at Wilshere Baptist church on Wednesday evening at a service that was mainly for Duncan’s close friends and family, but necessarily took place without them.</p> <p>If the virus no longer seems abstract and exotic but real and local for worried Dallasites,, for those nearest to Duncan their brush with Ebola has had a distancing effect, segregating them from each other and the wider community. Some barriers are temporary, but others will linger as the consequences of the 42-year-old’s decision to leave Liberia for Texas to start afresh with the woman he loved and a son he hardly knew.</p> <p>After Duncan became seriously ill at her apartment last week, Louise Troh, her 13-year-old son and two nephews were quarantined at a house somewhere in the Dallas area. They will remain there until around 19 October, when the 21-day incubation period for Ebola will be over. It meant they could not be among the 150 or so in the pews who sang hymns, listened to Bible readings, prayed and held candles that flickered, throwing dancing shadows on to the church walls.</p> <p>It was here that Troh was baptised last June, about eight months after she was introduced to the congregation by three nieces, and where she went to Bible study classes on Sunday mornings. The pastor, George Mason, and Clay Jenkins, a local judge, travelled to her temporary accommodation to tell the family about Duncan’s death, staying for several hours.</p> <p>The house has a common kitchen, living room and eating area but the occupants sleep in separate bedrooms. Mason and Jenkins gathered them together but they were forced to grieve apart, unwilling to risk hugging each other in case one of them is carrying the virus.</p> <p>“One of the most painful things in this process has been because of their isolation. They’ve not only been moved from everyone else, they are even supposed to keep away from each other in the house,” Mason said after the service.</p> <p>“The human instinct is to want to rush towards each other in moments like these and to touch each other and hold each other, to comfort each other … it was the most unnatural-feeling thing, as you might imagine.”</p> <p>During the ceremony, which was streamed live online, Mason described Duncan as a kind, respectful man who, Troh told him, “knew how to talk to ladies, he didn’t let anyone use bad language around women”. He said they planned to build a family together in the US and that he wanted to work hard and save up enough money for them to return to Liberia one day.</p> <p>Mason said Duncan’s spoke his last words around Friday, shortly before he became unresponsive and his condition was deteriorated.</p> <p>Troh and Duncan reportedly met at a refugee camp in Ivory Coast after fleeing war in Liberia, and she left for the US with Karsiah once they had secured visas. When Karsiah found out that his father had passed away, Mason said, it was “an eruption of grief”. He had hoped Duncan would be able to attend his high school graduation.</p> <p>Troh, a 54-year-old nursing assistant, issued a statement on Wednesday that said: “I trust a thorough examination will take place regarding all aspects of his care … I am now dealing with the sorrow and anger that his son was not able to see him before he died.”</p> <p>That appeared to be a reference to frustration at the hospital’s initial failure to diagnose him correctly, and a delay of several days before they treated him with experimental drugs. Mason said that Duncan’s deterioration and death took relatives by surprise, because they had put their faith in the new course of treatment.</p> <p>“This was part of the shock to the family, because the announcement that he was at long last receiving some sort of treatment protocol was an explosion of joy for them. When I was able to tell them that, [Troh] just sort of did a high-pitched scream, ‘glory to God, glory to God’. She left the phone for a second, I think she might have been dancing around,” Mason said.</p> <p>“She was very excited thinking her prayers were being answered and maybe this was just what they’d been praying for and hoping for. Honestly from the point of view of the family and the boys who were in quarantine there was now a great sense of hopefulness for the first time because up till now they were very frustrated by the lack of treatment available to him.”</p> <p>He downplayed <a href="http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/health/2014/10/08/ebola-jesse-jackson-dallas-tx-patient/16889201/" title="">suggestions that the family were angry at the hospital and believe Duncan’s care was inadequate compared with the treatment of other Ebola patients in the US</a>.</p> <p>“When people are in a situation like this they hear about others, they compare and they wonder. They don’t have all the information necessary to evaluate whether this is the same kind of situation or different. It only feels like the same to them. They can’t evaluate what differences might be and so it immediately makes your imagination go to, who was at fault here that he didn’t get that sort of thing? Those are natural human reactions and they’re not meant to be accusations, only frustrations of misunderstanding,” he said.</p> <p>With Troh confined to the house there is no funeral currently planned, but there may eventually be a service to bury Duncan’s ashes, Mason said. <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/hcp/guidance-safe-handling-human-remains-ebola-patients-us-hospitals-mortuaries.html" title="">Federal guidelines call for the remains of Ebola victims to be cremated</a>.</p> <p>Even after they are deemed not to be contagious, there is a risk the family will be treated as pariahs in the city. Mason said it would be impossible for them to return to their former apartment complex and that private donors have already stepped up to help find them a place to live and pay for their rent, furnishings and other expenses. The family had craved a new start – but not like this, not without the man who was supposed to be at the heart of it.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-sierra-leone <p><strong>Reports and presenters:</strong> <strong>LO’C</strong> Lisa O’Carroll; <strong>MM</strong> Monica Mark; <strong>HM</strong> Hugh Muir</p> <p><strong>Interviewees:</strong> <strong>EBK</strong> Ernest Bai Koroma; <strong>PP</strong> Professor Peter Piot; <strong>RP</strong> Robtel Pailey; <strong>MY</strong> Dr Mohammed Yilla; <strong>RM</strong> Roeland Monasch; <strong>MC</strong> Matthew Clark; <strong>TD</strong> Tom Dannatt</p> <p><strong>LO’C</strong> The first time I went to Sierra Leone a little over a year ago I was really hit by the extreme poverty of the country, lack of running water, lack of electricity, I know that’s a common feature in sub-Saharan Africa, but what was also extremely interesting was the overwhelming sense of optimism in the country, that this was a country 10 or 11 years after a civil war that was finally getting back on its feet. Things were moving and progressing in the right direction, foreign investment was returning, mines were opening and there were even green shoots of tourism with those wonderful, wonderful beaches on the western coast.</p> <p>So anyway, that was my first and only time in Sierra Leone and little did I know that a year or so later I was going to be inundated with emails from people I’d interviewed begging me to bring attention to the Ebola outbreak. So when I spoke to the director of operations at Médecins sans Frontières at the beginning of August and he told me that the world’s response was completely inadequate, I understood where he was coming from. Sierra Leone is one of the most vulnerable countries in the world, dependent on foreign aid, despite having natural resources such as diamonds and rare minerals.</p> <p>There’s been lots in the media about the crisis, there’s been hysterical reporting in the US about the threat to their own citizens, there’s been plenty of debate in the media, at the UN, about how to achieve the beginning of the end and how to contain the crisis, including the efficacy of a lockdown in Sierra Leone.</p> <p>Here’s the president of Sierra Leone, Ernest Bai Koroma, just before the lockdown began in September.</p> <p><strong>EBK</strong> Médecins Sans Frontières, they may be right in what they’re saying, but they’re only talking about it from the curative point of view, looking after the sick, they are caregivers. What we are more concerned about is the social mobilisation, 0.02% of the population, that is about just 1,000 people who have been affected by this, we still have five million, 999,000 people who have not been affected. These are the emergency, these are the ones that we must keep safe.</p> <p><strong>LO’C</strong> The number of dead had surpassed 3,000 at the start of October, more than the combined death toll of all previous outbreaks since 1976. Many are calling for more and more resources to be thrown at the crisis, like professor Peter Piot.</p> <p><strong>PP</strong> From my perspective what can we do, this is an enormously complicated logistics job and frankly the military are, together with DHL and so, are very good to do this. And then in addition …</p> <p><strong>LO’C</strong> With DHL did you say?</p> <p><strong>PP</strong> Yes, I mean all these companies that are into logistics and transport and delivery, I think they would be extremely useful but we also need doctors and so on and I think that the NHS and universities just coming back to the UK, we should make it possible for nurses and doctors who want to do this to volunteer and to work in an organised way through, for example, MSF and so on, I mean you need a structure there to work in.</p> <p><strong>LO’C</strong> But behind the headlines what is happening in Sierra Leone and neighbouring Liberia?</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> My name is Robtel Pailey, I’m Liberian, I’m a PhD candidate at the University of London School of Oriental and African Studies. I think there’s a lot of anxiety, a bit of hysteria because they don’t know what the next day holds. I remember having a conversation with my aunt when I was in Liberia in July and the question she asked me when we were sort of sitting at home trying to figure out what was going on was she was there during the course of the war and they dodged bullets from one county to another, from one city to another, now at this stage something like Ebola is going to kill them and she couldn’t understand how it could get to this level.</p> <p>But at least during the war you could see the moving targets, you could see the bullets, you could see where the destruction and where the possible danger was coming from. At this stage no one knows, and I think that level of uncertainty is what makes the situation so intense.</p> <p>I’m in touch with my family almost every single day and they’re trying to stay calm, they’re trying to stay prayerful and I think that’s pretty much what they’re holding on to, is this impeccable faith in God that at some point their prayers will be answered and this thing will go away.</p> <p><strong>LO’C </strong>For all the progress that has been made in West Africa what weaknesses has Ebola exposed in the development of countries like Sierra Leone and Liberia? How far will the disease hit the fragile and underfunded healthcare system?</p> <p>With civil war a recent memory how much trust do citizens have for national government and the West, and can anything come from the media’s renewed focus on the region?</p> <p>I’m Lisa O’Carroll, this is the Global Development podcast, stay with us.</p> <p>Let’s start with health and this report by Monica Mark who has recently been meeting doctors in Sierra Leone.</p> <p><strong>MM</strong> On the coast of west Africa Sierra Leone has suffered the second highest number of fatalities in the Ebola outbreak. By the end of September some 600 people had died out of the total of just over 3,000 recorded deaths across Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, but a recent quarantine here revealed dozens of undetected cases and health officials say the numbers may well have been underestimated all along.</p> <p>Although Ebola is deadly and contagious it’s also actually easily containable and so to understand how it’s been able to spread so far in Sierra Leone I spoke to Mohammed Yilla, a doctor in Freetown who runs a maternal health programme.</p> <p>Maternal and neonatal health statistics are a good beacon to gauge a country’s overall health system. Sierra Leone languishes at the bottom of every index for both maternal and neonatal health.</p> <p><strong>MY</strong> Before the Ebola crisis there have been challenges around making sure health facilities had the right stuff, for instance like a midwife. We’re not talking hi-tech, we’re not talking even doctors, we’re talking about nurses, we’re talking about midwives. The health facilities that did not have midwives, that did not have nurses, the health facilities that did not have drugs and in a country where water is so available many health facilities had very, very poor infrastructure relating to water availability and sanitation. And worse still, even electricity.</p> <p>So I think when we talk about that we’re talking about a country that probably haven’t turned around the issue of the civil war, a country that is faced with a very fragile health system.</p> <p><strong>MM</strong> Almost have of Sierra Leone’s population of six million is under the age of 18. I asked Roeland Monasch, country director of Unicef, what impact the outbreak is having on the country’s children.</p> <p><strong>RM</strong> It’s going up again. The impact on children is dramatic because the symptoms for Ebola, the first symptoms are very similar to preventable diseases like malaria, diarrhoea, and as a result of that because of the fear and anxiety parents are not taking their children anymore to a clinic. Well, we as Unicef have worked so hard to get anti malarias, anti diarrhoeas, pneumonia medicines to all clinics; we distribute to all 1,200 clinics, we supply them with medicines.</p> <p><strong>MM</strong> And unfortunately that impact goes far beyond the health sector.</p> <p><strong>RM</strong> Kids are not going to school so they’re missing their education at a very important phase in their lives, but secondly these schools are also a safe and protective environment for them, they’re overrun but it’s in the school compound and people are looking at them, now all these kids are out in communities which are all on high alert and anxiety so protection issues are there as well, child labour issues, so it’s not good, it’s very bad actually.</p> <p><strong>MM</strong> But even if schools do reopen and the outbreak slows down it’s likely to take a long time before Sierra Leone recovers completely.</p> <p><strong>RM</strong> The health system will take some more time I think, also people need to, and that’s also part of the work on social mobilisation we’re doing, people need to trust the system again, sort of confidence in the fact that they can go to a clinic. That might take a bit longer.</p> <p><strong>LO’C</strong> That was Roeland Monasch, country director for Unicef. So what are the long-term solutions for healthcare? Matthew Clark is the director of the Wellbodi Partnership in Sierra Leone. He spoke to the Guardian’s Hugh Muir.</p> <p><strong>MC</strong> Well I think that the solutions are complex and part of a very kind of chronic problem with the healthcare system, and I think that it takes a long time to train doctors, to train nurses, and build up a functioning healthcare system. And I think in Sierra Leone you have a good medical school that produces young doctors and you have several good nursing schools that produce good nurses, the challenge is that these healthcare professionals leave and qualify into a fairly dysfunctional system where there isn’t any senior doctors, senior nurses to support them, or there are very few because those people tend to have left, either during the war or to seek better professional opportunities overseas.</p> <p>So you have these very junior, very enthusiastic, very committed people start to work in a system that doesn’t function, they’ve got no one to refer to for advice, they’ve got no support. For themselves if they want to progress in their career they up until now have had to leave the country to seek specialist training.</p> <p>So I think until you build up a system where young doctors and nurses can qualify in Sierra Leone, can see an opportunity and a future for themselves and that the system supports them and nurtures them to become the kind of health leaders that they need to be, whether that’s in oncology, paediatrics, special psychiatry, it doesn’t really matter what speciality they’re doing, what you need is a system where people can leave medical school, leave nursing school and establish themselves as the senior doctors.</p> <p><strong>HM</strong> Presumably when people get to that stage they then start looking abroad because they can take themselves abroad and they can do well?</p> <p><strong>MC</strong> Exactly, and I think even before they get to that stage to actually get that training and that sort of experience, it’s almost impossible to get that in Sierra Leone, so very early on in their career they start to look, either within the west African sub-region or further afield and then, of course, like everyone else the incentives to come back to Sierra Leone at the time when they’d be most effective, which is probably in their mid-30s to mid-40s, then they have families and children and it’s very difficult then to suddenly relocate your life back to Sierra Leone.</p> <p>So I think until we address that central problem of not just thinking about we’ve got 20 doctors, 100 doctors in the country, but actually what are we doing with those doctors and how we can turn them into the leaders of the future it’s going to be very difficult to tackle any of these problems whatever the disease.</p> <p><strong>HM</strong> So that’s a problem that’s bigger than the health service in a way because to create the conditions so they would want to stay, that’s about the conditions in the country, that’s about the stability of the country isn’t it?</p> <p><strong>MC</strong> I think in part, but I don’t necessarily accept that it’s just about that, there will be some people who want to leave because of the system at large and there are some people who want to leave purely for professional reasons. And so I think you’re right, to create a utopia where every young doctor just wants to stay in Sierra Leone because it’s perfect I agree is a big challenge, but actually I don’t think it’s beyond the kind of commitment of the international community and other partners to actually say we’re going to look at this as a 10-year problem and we’re going to think about how do we strengthen the healthcare system over ten years, what expertise and what resources do we need to put in place to make sure that these young healthcare workers can train and be supported and then be remunerated appropriately.</p> <p><strong>LO’C </strong>That was Matthew Clark. We’ll be back straight after this.</p> <p>[advertisement break]</p> <p>You’re listening to the Global Development podcast, I’m Lisa O’Carroll. When you ask professionals working in Sierra Leone and Liberia what is causing the most problems they often cite lack of resources, ranging from lack of protective clothing or supplies of basics like paracetamol, ambulances, even open hospitals, but an underlying issue also identified early on is the lack of trust in authorities, a hangover from the civil war.</p> <p>We heard earlier from Robtel Pailey about the resonance the Ebola crisis has for those who lived through recent wars. Before we hear from her again this is Tom Dannatt, founder and director of the British charity, StreetChild, who work exclusively in Sierra Leone and Liberia.</p> <p><strong>TD</strong> Sierra Leone is a very suspicious society, the story is that the father tells the son to sit on a wall and turn his back to him. “I’ll stand behind you and just when you’re ready just rock back and I’ll catch you.” And the son does as his father tells him to and the father lets the son fall to the ground and hurt himself. And the son gets up and says, “Why did you do that, Dad?” And the dad says, “I’m teaching you the most important thing you’ll ever learn about life in Sierra Leone: trust nobody.”</p> <p>This is something I carry around with me and I see it in my regular life in Sierra Leone, trust is the commodity which is really at its lowest, the lack of trust which creates a vacuum through which rumour swirls and it makes it so hard for positive information to gain traction and it makes it very hard for businesses to operate, or even simple petty commerce on a local level.</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> I think a lot of investors are pulling out, or at least coming to a standstill. There have been issues with possible GDP growth slowing, I mean I remember AFD, the African Development Bank was saying that GDP growth this year was estimated at maybe 6% would probably go down to 3% for Liberia. I don’t remember what the estimates are for Sierra Leone.</p> <p><strong>TD</strong> For myself the problem that’s been really exposed is the chronic lack of education, under education of the population, particularly in the rural areas. We know that at least a quarter of a million children of primary school going age in Sierra Leone don’t go to school and that number, it’s nearer half a million in Liberia. As this disease has emerged it has spread predominantly in rural areas. These are the areas which are the hardest for the public health messages to penetrate.</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> I think in terms of the education system, I mean a few months ago the President said that the education system was in a mess which is a very damning evidence of her administration in terms of what it’s invested in in the education sector. Almost more than half of the entrants, the students who took the University of Liberia entrance exam, failed both the math and the English section.</p> <p>In terms of people’s morale, I think I’m more concerned about that than the infrastructure or the economic aspects, but people had a sense of hope I think immediately after the war ended, I think there’s a lot of despair and disillusionment at this stage. Even before Ebola I would say became a national health emergency, or international health emergency as the WHO says it is, I think people were suffering even before this Ebola outbreak came in and I think now that the prices of commodities have gone up people’s livelihoods are being threatened, they’re staying at home but again they don’t know what tomorrow holds, so it’s just a really trying time for the country.</p> <p><strong>TD</strong> Those that have received the least by way of services are those who are going to be the most sceptical and untrusting of messages that come from those that purport to serve them.</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> I think at the back of most people’s minds is yes, we’re still disillusioned, yes we’re still angry, but the fact of the matter is, we’re in the moment now, we have to deal with this now. But those questions of is the government really interested in my best interest are not going to go away, but right now I think it’s trust under duress if that makes any sense.</p> <p><strong>TD</strong> I think if we look specifically at what happened in West Point when overnight West Point was quarantined in an unexpected and aggressive fashion led by Liberian military and armed security forces, certain civilians, including one of our own beneficiaries were shot. Titus was shot by security forces. He turned up in our office in Monrovia heavily bleeding having tried to admit himself to two hospitals and being turned away. Our staff then helped him to be admitted to a third one.</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> I think that was a misstep from the very beginning, getting the armed forces of Liberia involved, you know, the government responded by saying that they’re going to have an internal probe and they will investigate the matter and if there’s anyone culpable they will find the culprit and he or she will be penalised.</p> <p><strong>TD</strong> It’s an indication of how potentially explosive this incident was viewed by the political authorities. We’ve had I believe two personal visits from the president of Liberia and they handed over some cash, I think $1,000 (£617). He’s saying he wants to be taken outside Liberia for proper medical care.</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> But I think using lethal force and using the armed forces, without any warning whatsoever I think was a really big misstep on the government’s part. And you know, the President, she’s sort of come back and said she apologised for the use of the AFL and realised that that was not the best course of action and I have to respect her for that, I think a leader who makes a mistake and is able to apologise and to acknowledge that that was a misstep is good I think in this particular instance, and sort of doubling back and saying okay what can we do to make the situation better.</p> <p>They lifted the quarantine on Dolo Town, they lifted the quarantine on West Point because they realised that that wasn’t helping the situation in any way because people didn’t have food to eat, they were scared that they couldn’t leave. The military was knocking on their doors and that just created more hysteria.</p> <p><strong>TD</strong> I think the sheer sort of desperation of the situation has forced the political authorities and everyone to think what can be done. Personally I think only really in recent weeks can I put my hand on my heart and say that I feel that the international response has started to be driven by a concern for West Africans.</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> People on the ground in Liberia are demanding that the $5m or $12m that’s been allotted to the Ebola Taskforce to contain the disease is not being managed properly. Now the National Taskforce leader, Dobo Jalla, came to I think a press conference at the end of August and he had an expenditures report and he was sort of telling us how the money had been expended and there were all these questions about where’s the money gone, they’ve eaten the money. No, that’s now what it’s been used for. And even the finance minister had to come and have another press conference to assure people that the money has not disappeared. And I thought that that was a great step, that they actually were being accountable to the citizenry and coming forward and saying this is how the money’s being spent, even though questions are still being raised.</p> <p>But I think for me a more telling accountability mechanism would also be for the international community to do the same thing. I mean we’re hearing pledges every day of these huge amounts of money but the question that I have as a Liberian citizen is how do we track this amount, I mean where is it going? How is it being used? Is it going on really expensive consultants, or is it going for much needed lifesaving medicine for the Liberian, Sierra Leonean, Guinean and Nigerian people. So I think there also need to be accountability mechanisms for donors as well so that they answer to their stakeholders as well as the people that they say they’re fighting this war on Ebola for.</p> <p><strong>TD</strong> I think a general concern for public hygiene might be a silver lining from this whole episode, people are washing their hands like never before across Liberia and Sierra Leone which is one of the ways or protecting oneself against Ebola but is also a good way of protecting yourself against a variety of other things. Long term the need to transform health provision is there, it’s clear, I hope that the need to transform education provision, people realise that these aren’t just bad things for those people but actually it presents a threat to everyone.</p> <p><strong>RP</strong> There’s a report that said more than 50% of the people who are contracting Ebola are women because they’re the natural care givers in homes. Where people are still, even though they know there’s eminent threat, that they’re still coming to the rescue of their fellow citizens, for me post-Ebola we need to sing these people’s praises and we need to tell their stories. I think that’s so important.</p> <p><strong>LO’C</strong> Matthew Clark again.</p> <p><strong>MC</strong> I think there is as I said a tremendous opportunity while we’re focused on what has caused Ebola to actually try and tackle some of the underlying problems and I think at the minute we’re sort of in a humanitarian phase of the response to Ebola, so that’s a lot about just going in and doing things, trying to treat patients, trying to isolate patients, trying to get the Ebola epidemic under control.</p> <p>I think that there’s a tension always between the humanitarian emergency response and the kind of more sustainable development response where you’re trying to strengthen the healthcare system for the future. And I think historically the international community hasn’t been very good at that, they’ve been good at the kind of big bang response which is effective at dealing with the humanitarian crisis but to a certain extent distorts the underlying health economy and then making sure that we transition from that back to a sustainable path for development. If we can get that transition right I think it’s an incredible opportunity to actually really strengthen the healthcare systems across West Africa and actually move forward the progress that we need.</p> <p><strong>LO’C</strong> And that brings us to the end of this edition of the Global Development podcast. Don’t forget you can have your say at <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development" title="">theguardian.com/global-development</a>. Just click the link to the podcast. My name is Lisa O’Carroll, the producer was Matt Hill. Until next time, goodbye.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/09/ebola-rayo-vallecano-lass-bangoura-guinea <p>The Rayo Vallecano forward Lass Bangoura has returned to Spain over fears he could catch the Ebola virus while on international duty with Guinea.</p> <p>Guinea are playing their Africa Cup of Nations home qualifier against Ghana in Morocco due to the outbreak, but Bangoura reportedly withdrew from the squad over concerns about being in contact with Guinea-based staff and officials.</p> <p>He has now returned to Madrid – where a nurse this week became the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/ebola-outbreak-six-quarantined-in-spain-madrid-hospital-ramos" title="">first person in Europe to be diagnosed with the disease</a>. Spanish authorities now have seven people in quarantine and another 84 under observation.</p> <p><a href="http://www.espnfc.com/rayo-vallecano/story/2078981/lass-bangoura-returns-to-rayo-vallecano-from-guinea-duty-due-to-ebola-fears" title="">ESPN quoted the player as telling local media</a>: “In Morocco I was there with my teammates. We were not talking about Ebola, just about football and the game against Ghana. I was not concerned about the people coming from Guinea, I was just there with the group. If you have a fever, or something else, you do not come with the national team … [But] I came back as I did not want problems with Rayo, and so that my teammates would trust in me.”</p> <p>Bangoura added: “I do not know if people in Guinea will understand why I left my national team to go back with my club. I am a bit worried for my family [in Guinea], because I might be attacked for this. I must talk with them to see what is happening.”</p> <p>Gabon, meanwhile, have <a href="http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2014/10/09/primera/1412857820_512101.html" title="">reportedly rejected a request from Celta Vigo</a> to release their midfielder Levy Madinda from international duty for the same reason.</p> <p>Celta Vigo’s president, Carlos Mouriño, said: “The club made contact with the FA to discuss the possibility of Levy returning to Vigo, but they have told us that it will not be possible.”</p> <p>Gabon are playing qualifiers against Burkina Faso at home in Libreville on Saturday and away in Ouagadougou on Wednesday.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2014/oct/09/ebola-infectious-disease-sustainability-concern-sxsw-eco-austin <p>When Ebola broke out in Liberia, 10,000 employees of Aecom Technology Corporation moved out of the country. Their work on new rail infrastructure and public housing in the nation of four million ground to a standstill. Many others <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2014/aug/15/mining-ebola-africa-nigeria-liberia-guinea-riotinto-vale">have done likewise</a>. As horrific as Ebola has proven to be, the risk of disease across the world’s tropical zone is often <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/oct/08/world-bank-warns-ebola-economic-impact-west-africa">considered alongside questions of resource availability, infrastructure conditions to move goods and services</a>, and political stability as businesses scout new overseas locations.</p> <p>It’s something that companies operating in the global north – including the Walt Disney World Resort in Orlando, Florida – need to start planning around, according to Gary Lawrence, Aecom’s vice president and chief sustainability officer. In fact, the public-health challenges of so many converging global threats are so daunting that addressing them will take much more dialogue and collaboration across sectors than is currently happening.</p> <p>Addressing an audience gathered Tuesday at the <a href="http://sxsweco.com/">SXSW Eco</a> conference in Austin, Texas, Lawrence said: “Communicable disease is one of the major risks all of us face when we’re thinking about these questions of water, food, energy.” </p> <h2>Deadly diseases are Disney’s problem, too</h2>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="97dcc7c58972fabbf85d074ccce2874d13c3b7a1"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/8/1412781163264/360eb79a-3223-4bcf-91f7-c1e5e1d8d056-460x276.jpeg" alt="panelist at sxsw eco 2014" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">‘We don’t normally talk about that as an engineering firm, but it is going to be a problem in terms of how you actually create an outdoor environment that protects people from this disease,’ Gary Lawrence, Aecom’s chief sustainability officer, said to a panel at SXSW Eco. </span> <span class="element-image__credit">Photograph: Greg Harman/the Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Lawrence told the SXSW audience that he recently had to warn the leadership of Disney that they must prepare against the possible threat of dengue fever, which has seen <a href="http://miami.cbslocal.com/2014/08/29/new-dengue-fever-cases-reported-in-miami-dade/">a recent outbreak in Florida</a>.</p> <p>“Disney World requires customers to be outside in order to make a profit,” Lawrence said. “How is Disney going to manage the risks of dengue if dengue moves that far up the panhandle and makes it almost impossible for anybody to go outside at dawn or dusk when the mosquitos are active? … There is no greater financial risk to Disney in Orlando than not having people able to come because of an infectious disease problem.</p> <p>“We don’t normally talk about that as an engineering firm, but it is going to be a problem in terms of how you actually create an outdoor environment that protects people from this disease.”</p> <p>Thanks to the increase in temperatures, in part due to global warming, mosquito-borne malaria, dengue fever, and West Nile virus are <a href="http://www.nrdc.org/health/climate/disease.asp">already marching north</a>. The same is true of <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/04/climate-change-disease/2623863/">Valley fever in the western US</a>. Dengue fever is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/aug/02/australia-risk-disease-climate-change">advancing on Australia</a> and public health officials in the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/may/05/uk-tropical-disease-malaria-threat">United Kingdom have been sounding the alarm about malaria</a>.</p> <h2>Collaboration is the only way forward</h2> <p>Lawrence’s sustainability credentials are impressive. In Seattle, he led the creation of the first municipal sustainability plan in the US (one of the first globally) and has served as an advisor to President Clinton’s Administration Council on Sustainable Development as well as similar bodies in South America and Europe, including the European Academy for the Urban Environment in Berlin and the Organization for Economic and Community Development in Paris.</p> <p>In the private sector, he worked as a sustainability leader at international consulting and engineering firm, Arup, before joining <a href="http://www.aecom.com/">Aecom Technology Corporation</a> more recently.</p> <p>In a session titled “Climate Change and the Bottom Line: Risk and Reward” at SXSW Eco, a three-day conference on matters of environmental sustainability from tech to policy to design and grassroots advocacy, Lawrence said the greatest challenge to responding to growing risk – from infectious disease to sea-level rise – involves communication and collaboration.</p> <p>The habit of thinking “in sectors” needs to change, he said.</p> <p>“The coasts are sinking faster than sea level is rising, but we don’t have conversations about that at all because it requires we get geologists involved in this discussion and what do geologists have to do with sustainability? Well, in that context they have everything to do with sustainability.”</p> <p>In another example of compartmentalized thinking, he credited the United Nations for its tremendous vision of poverty relief but claimed the intergovernmental organization simply doesn’t understand how money works. Worse: its bureaucrats have a generalized distrust of the private sector. For its part, the private sector has a jaded view of governments, which are often corrupt and in many ways function on bribes, Lawrence said.</p> <p>“The question for us and the UN is, can we both recognize we have aspects of evil within us that need to be curbed if we’re actually going to help optimize conditions for poor people in the world.”</p> <p>Attempting to put the climate challenge in perspective, he commented on the world’s obsession over the Malaysian jetliner that went missing in March with hundreds of passengers on board. If the planet reaches a six-degree Celsius rise in average temperatures in 100 years, <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/world-on-track-for-nearly-11-degree-temperature-rise-energy-expert-says/2011/11/28/gIQAi0lM6N_story.html">as is projected</a>, “the effect on human population will be as if 1000 airliners a day were crashing.”</p> <p>Those impacts are expected to come from a variety of sources, including heatwaves, extreme weather events, drought, and the spread of disease – potentially exacerbated by governmental inaction and resource disparities.</p> <p>How will such dire predictions impact Western development when it comes to infectious disease planning in the near-term?</p> <p>Despite his personal encouragements, Lawrence told the Guardian he is not optimistic.</p> <p>“Sadly, that’s because most of the people who are dying are poor. When a Western industrial society starts to collapse related to disease … someone is going to decide, ‘Ah, this is a problem that has to be solved.’ It’s not a problem that has to be solved yet.”</p> <p> <em>The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/values-led-business">values-led business</a> hub is funded by SC Johnson. All content is editorially independent except for pieces labelled advertisement feature. Find out more <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sponsored-content">here</a>.</em></p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/09/excalibur-ebola-dog-conspiracy-theories <p>Finally, the west has the first ebola victim it feels bad about. It was a dog.</p> <p>On Wednesday, Twitter was all aflutter with calls to <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/08/health/save-excalibur-ebola-dog/index.html">spare the life of Excalibur, a dog owned by a Spanish nurse’s assistant</a> from Madrid named Teresa Ramos. Ramos contracted Ebola, probably from caring for Spanish missionaries to Africa, and has been quarantined. Her husband was put in isolation to see if he had caught the disease via contact with her. So far, it looks like he has not. Still, despite <a href="https://www.change.org/p/no-al-sacrificio-de-excalibur-el-perro-de-la-auxiliar-de-enfermer%C3%ADa-contagiada-por-el-virus-del-%C3%A9bola">some 400,000 signatures on Change.org</a> and public protests, the Spanish government <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/excalibur-spanish-ebola-patient-dog-euthanised">opted to euthanize and cremate the dog</a>, based <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/ebola-virus-outbreak/madrid-will-kill-dog-woman-infected-ebola-n220361">on only one medical study of questionable accuracy</a> that says dogs can contract the virus and remain asymptomatic.</p> <p>That sucks. Spain doesn’t suck, but Dog Torquemada, whoever he is, definitely sucks.</p> <p>That the internet was upset makes a basic kind of internet sense. During horrible human and natural events, people post pictures of dogs to cheer themselves up. There are whole sites and Facebook feeds and Instagram accounts dedicated to the mediating images of dogs being happy in spite of everything.</p> <p>Dogs are even better in real life. They’re like people with all the stuff that sucks removed. It takes much less time to housebreak them. They don’t talk back. You are always the highlight of their day, and they’re always sad to see you leave. And almost any awful thing you can say or do will be forgiven and then forgotten within half an hour. You will spend the rest of your life remembering every time you ignored them or shooed them away because of some ephemeral distraction – some mean selfishness you will always wish you could retract – and your memory will repay you with the knowledge that your attitude was rewarded with unstinting loyalty. There’s even <a href="http://jezebel.com/commercial-uses-adorable-puppy-to-stop-you-from-drinkin-1637474377">a Budweiser ad about drinking and driving</a> that relies on making you think of some poor dog dying of a broken heart waiting for someone to come home who never will.</p> <p>The story of Ramos’s dog resonates with us so much for two reasons. One, many of us know what it’s like to lose a pet. Two, it’s hard to politicize dogs. As much as you might weep to think of those Soviet dogs strapped with explosives and trained to run under Wehrmacht tanks and blow them up from the underside, they weren’t really <em>Soviet</em> dogs. Hitler had dogs, but there was no way his dogs knew he was <em>Hitler</em>. There are no Maoist Third World dogs. And there’s no constitutional conservatism particular to an animal that can lick enthusiastically at its own anus, even if that metaphor is the first thing that leaps to mind watching <a href="https://twitter.com/Mobute/status/517071855149395968">Bill Kristol</a> or <a href="https://twitter.com/Mobute/status/491420613350031360">John Podhoretz</a>. Invariably someone <a href="https://twitter.com/femscreenwriter/status/498143176058609665">tweets a picture of a dog with pro-Israel swag</a>, and it’s always absurd. Often the dog looks irritated to have something on it, or curious what the hell its owner is doing. When it looks happy, it looks about as happy as it would be if some random Palestinian asked <em>who’s a good boy, </em>presumably in whatever language is used to determine good boys in that dog’s household.</p> <p>But people? You can politicize the hell out of them, to the point where you wipe all meaning they had off the face of the earth, long after Ebola does the same to them physically. Four thousand dead in Africa? They must have died because they’re <a href="http://mediamatters.org/video/2014/10/06/foxs-bernie-goldberg-many-africans-are-backward/201039">an intrinsically backward people who believe in magicks</a>. They probably don’t even believe in the constitution. Or they’re just an excuse for President Obama to <a href="http://www.salon.com/2014/09/26/laura_ingraham_obama_wants_to_expose_troops_to_ebola_to_make_up_for_colonialism/">poison our troops as a really confusing and abstract apology for colonialism</a>. Those 4,000 people must not even have had the honesty to die in some regular way; they died as <em>props</em>.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/Independent/statuses/519441477450354688">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>CNN is asking the stupid Ebola questions <a href="http://t.co/5awCkpl0Uy">http://t.co/5awCkpl0Uy</a> <a href="http://t.co/3flxvcQAnU">pic.twitter.com/3flxvcQAnU</a></p>&mdash; The Independent (@Independent) <a href="https://twitter.com/Independent/status/519441477450354688">October 7, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <p>About the only thing you can hang on a dog is a collar, but you can change the subject by engineering paranoia about people to such an extent that any people or fear will do. There were thousands of Honduran kids trying to come into the US, and <a href="http://www.newrepublic.com/article/118700/border-crisis-leads-conservatives-claim-child-migrants-are-diseased">they might have had infectious diseases</a>, and Ebola is an infectious disease, so this thing is just like the other thing. Speaking of illegal immigration, Isis could sneak into the US just like <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/26/james-okeefe-arrested-in-_n_437506.html">arrested phone-tap-fuckup</a>, <a href="http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/12/james-okeefe-accused-of-sexual-harassment/">accused sexual harasser</a> and “<a href="http://www.apple.com/">whey-faced little shit</a>” James O’Keefe did in the middle of a <a href="http://gawker.com/james-okeefe-is-getting-desperate-as-hell-part-mcmxvii-1619338668">staged cosplay exercise on the Texas border</a>. <a href="http://mediamatters.org/research/2014/09/05/conservative-media-echo-spurious-report-on-thre/200660">Isis could do that</a>! (There’s a <a href="http://gawker.com/breitbart-com-is-sure-this-adidas-shirts-an-islamo-mexi-1603045854">Muslim prayer soccer jersey</a> proving they may already have!) That’s important, because <a href="http://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/what-is-ebola">Ebola is the Isis of biological agents</a>. Once you think about it, <a href="http://mediamatters.org/video/2014/09/24/fox-analyst-obama-timed-syrian-airstrikes-to-av/200869">Obama is Isis</a>, because Isis is the Ebola of terroristisms, and <a href="http://talkingpointsmemo.com/livewire/dinesh-dsouza-ebola-obola-obama">Ebola is the Obola of Obama</a>. You know what <em>else</em> originated in Africa like Ebola? The president <em>and </em>anti-colonialism, from his father. <a href="http://www.mrdestructo.com/2013/04/the-sweet-smell-of-failure-dinesh.html"><em>The fever dreams are coming from inside his father</em></a><em>.</em></p> <p>You don’t even have to go as far as talking about people. You can just talk about one. US Ebola patient Thomas Duncan wasn’t actually <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/thomas-eric-duncan-liberia-ebola-war-texas-family-obituary">a human being who fled war</a> only to find himself on death’s door in his adopted country, suffering in agony and terror at the prospect of dying. He must have actually been <a href="http://mediamatters.org/video/2014/10/08/limbaugh-media-will-try-to-make-ebola-victim-th/201072">a trojan horse to get amnesty for illegal immigrants</a>. (Maybe he contracted Ebola from Isis agents hiding among all those Honduran kids. Who knows? Who cares!) <br /></p> <p>The fact is, it’s a lot harder to dehumanize a dog than it is to dehumanize a person. You can’t impute sinister motives to a dog. You can’t prove that the dog brought it on himself, via a rejection of modernity or liberty or due to elaborate subterfuge. You can’t make the dog an actor in an arcane and hateful agenda to rip the country apart from its innards on out. All you can do is think of the pity of the poor creature, isolated from his loved ones, dying alone.</p> <p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/08/ebola-patient-dies-texas-thomas-eric-duncan">Thomas Duncan did that on Wednesday, too</a>.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/09/ebola-outbreak-simulations-tested-uk-hospitals <p>War game-style simulations to test Britain’s ability to cope with an outbreak of Ebola will be staged this weekend in hospitals in the north and south of England.</p> <p>Officials at the Department of Health are drawing up details of at least two simulations which will involve people posing as victims of the deadly virus to assess the real-time response of hospitals, the ambulance service and local authorities. The exercise will take place on either Saturday or Sunday and details of which hospitals will be chosen to handle the mock cases are being kept confidential to minimise disruption to the exercise, an official said.</p> <p>They may include the Royal Free hospital in north London which has an isolation unit and a dedicated team of nurses, doctors and laboratory staff specialising in dealing with infectious diseases. The Royal Liverpool, Royal Hallamshire hospital in Sheffield and the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle upon Tyne also have infectious disease units that are expected to receive cases. Health secretary Jeremy Hunt has acknowledged that it was “entirely possible” Ebola could reach Britain.</p> <p>“We are planning as we speak,” said a Department of Health spokesperson. “It is going to test the emergency preparedness of the NHS and a number of hospitals are going to be involved. We will pretend there is an Ebola case in this country to test the response of the NHS, ambulance service, local authorities and police to make sure everything works in real time. There may be more exercises, but there will be at least one in the north and one in the south.”</p> <p>Details of the exercises came amid calls for new screening of passengers arriving at UK airports from west Africa where the virus has claimed at least 3,879 lives according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). Keith Vaz, chairman of the home affairs select committee, which scrutinises border controls, has called for tests at airports, railway stations and ports as well as greater support for immigration officers to make sure they have the training to deal with the outbreak.</p> <p>“Our immediate response should be to tighten regulation and introduce measures such as screenings at airports, train stations and ferry ports to ensure that this deadly disease cannot take more lives,” he said.</p> <p>On Thursday the government resisted such a move, pointing to WHO advice that suggests screening for people with fevers or temperature is better conducted in the exit country.</p> <p>“The World Health Organisation advice is that it is better to screen on exit from a country to make sure that people who are leaving are not infected, rather than trying to screen people who arrive,” said Michael Fallon, the defence secretary. “At the moment there are no direct flights from Sierra Leone to the United Kingdom. It is very hard to be able to track people who are changing planes and arriving by different means in the United Kingdom. It is particularly difficult because the symptoms may not be obvious for a number of weeks after you actually catch the disease. It is not straightforward.”</p> <p>A spokesman for Public Health England said it was important to recognise that the chances of infection increase as symptoms such as diarrhoea and vomiting worsen. Corpses are the most dangerous cause of transmission.</p> <p>“If you are symptomatic [of Ebola] and infectious you are not going to be in a position to be hopping on a plane,” he said.</p> <p>Earlier, one of the world’s leading experts on the virus played down the risks of a serious outbreak in the UK. Prof Peter Piot, a Belgian microbiologist who is part of the World Health Organisation’s Ebola science group and was part of the team that identified Ebola in 1976, told the BBC: “I’m not concerned about an outbreak in western Europe, in the UK, like we are seeing in west Africa.”</p> <p>But he added: “We will see other cases in Europe, this is unavoidable. People travel, people come back, people get infected in west Africa – volunteers. So we need to be prepared for more cases like this.”</p> <p>Public Health England has moved to quell concern among parents about the threat the virus poses to school children after it emerged on Wednesday that a school in Stockport had cancelled a planned school placement of a nine-year-old from Sierra Leone after complaints from parents. Public Health England stressed that the risk of Ebola arriving in the UK is “very low”. And it has told all education and childcare organisations not to restrict the teaching or activities of anyone who has travelled to affected countries if they show no symptoms of the deadly disease.</p> <p>It has urged school staff to look out for Ebola symptoms including fever, diarrhoea, vomiting, and weakness. Next, if such symptoms are apparent, teachers must establish whether students or children have spent time in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone or Nigeria in the last 21 days. If they have the student or child should be immediately separated from others and an ambulance called. Education staff are also urged to inform emergency staff that a case of Ebola is suspected to ensure that protective equipment is used.</p> <p>Universities UK, the body that campaigns for higher education organisations, said its members were “closely monitoring” students for signs of Ebola. It said latest advice has been circulated to heads of department, student services, accommodation staff, estate managers and student health centres. It said it was not aware that any restrictions being placed on students who had travelled to affected countries.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/from-the-archive-blog/2014/oct/09/ebola-outbreak-sudan-zaire-1976-archive <p>In 1976, a team at a lab in Antwerp discovered Ebola after a blood sample from a Belgian nun who had fallen mysteriously ill in Zaire was given to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/04/ebola-zaire-peter-piot-outbreak">Peter Piot</a>, one of the researchers. </p> <p>Reports of a ‘mystery epidemic’ in Sudan that was causing many deaths began to appear on the pages of the Guardian from 1 October 1976.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="a277052c960fe48b9dba2ca4ded2f02d33821ec2"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848724500/aee27765-f189-4df9-a454-4f22056f40d4-460x276.jpeg" alt="Ebola 1 October 1976" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">The Guardian, 1 October 1976. <a href="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848162261/Ebola-1-Oct-1976-001.jpg">Click to read full article</a>.</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>A week later health officials at <a href="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848217234/Ebola-8-Oct-1976-001.jpg">Heathrow airport had been alerted </a>to check on travellers from Sudan and Zaire. The World Health Organisation (WHO) admitted that it was having <a href="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848296655/Ebola-14-Oct-1976-001.jpg">difficulty identifying the virus</a>, although on the 14 October it claimed it was the Marburg virus disease. <br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="b961d1418575ffee5c0e85a56e2759372d739bb3"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848997013/312fad41-8411-47c9-864a-ea6b315bf733-460x276.jpeg" alt="Ebola 15 October 1976" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">The Guardian, 15 October 1976. <a href="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848346298/Ebola-15-Oct-1976-001.jpg">Click to read full article</a>.</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>By 23 October unofficial reports were putting the death toll in Zaire at anything up to 800. WHO announced that it had identified a new type of hepatitis unrelated to the A and B strains currently known. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="b8068a28c177fbed33f1b790a22393ca716c4b1c"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412849457342/dacdddf7-1df6-49a3-b775-43ace6a8020a-460x276.jpeg" alt="Ebola 23 October 1976." width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">The Guardian, 23 October 1976. <a href="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412848394016/Ebola-23-Oct-1976-001.jpg">Click to read full article.</a></span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>By the end of the month it was reported that the mysterious green monkey disease had disappeared.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="ecc730ce262029c89dbda7b628760b6c25f4a475"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412853841670/450b9511-a9b0-4df9-addb-c597c9d93b05-bestSizeAvailable.jpeg" alt="Ebola 30 October 1976" width="360" height="216" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">The Guardian, 30 October 1976</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>However, in mid-November there was a fear that workers at the Ministry of Defence biological research establishment at Porton Down may have contracted the disease.<br /></p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="804db7ef0349c08e877303e523b9a7f9e297a589"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412852586142/5bda0d1c-69bb-4d39-9ebb-01a895659945-460x276.jpeg" alt="porton 13 nov 1976" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">The Guardian, 13 November 1976. <a href="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/10/9/1412851968888/Porton-13-Nov-76-001.jpg">Click to read full article.</a></span> </figcaption> </figure>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/oct/09/ebola-myths-sierra-leone-dj-tackles-rumours <p>The Ebola outbreak was sparked by a bewitched aircraft that crashed in a remote part of Sierra Leone, casting a spell over three west African countries, but a heavily alcoholic drink called bitter Kola can cure the virus.</p> <p>These are just two of the rumours dispelled on <a href="https://twitter.com/Amarabangs">Amara Bangura</a>’s weekly radio show, which is networked through <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediaaction/">BBC Media Action</a> and broadcast on 35 stations across the country.</p> <p>“You have to deal with the issues of myth, you have to deal with the issues of religion, you have to answer questions about prevention and how to stay safe,” said Bangura.</p> <p>The presenter selects questions from thousands of text messages sent in from around the country and puts them to health experts and government officials. “Our radio programme has been very useful in helping people change their attitudes,” he said, noting that not all Sierra Leoneans are following guidelines aimed at preventing the spread of Ebola.</p> <p>Bangura, who is from one of Sierra Leone’s worst-hit districts, believes officials must engage with communities to alter deeply entrenched beliefs that lead people to seek religious counsel instead of medical treatment.</p> <p>“We’ve been telling them if you experience any signs or symptoms of Ebola, please go to the medical hospital,” he said. “Don’t go to the church or the mosque, you’re not going to get treatment there. You can pray as much as you can but go to the hospital for treatment.”</p> <p>Bangura added that his radio show is an integral part of the Ebola response: “Everybody listens to the radio and it’s the best way to communicate with people. You want to reach out to people in rural areas – they don’t have access to newspapers, they don’t have access to television – and you want to talk to people in a language they understand in a simple way.”</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/poll/2014/oct/09/uk-screen-ebola-airports-poll null
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/oct/09/ebola-response-diaspora-sierra-leone <p>When the government of Sierra Leone announced a three-day lockdown for the capital, Freetown, in September, boredom and cabin fever were not the only concerns for those forbidden to leave their homes. </p> <p>A vast majority of Sierra Leoneans live hand-to-mouth, and many do not have the means to store food and keep it fresh. How then would they cope without being able to go out and buy food each day? This question occurred to Memuna Janneh, a British-Sierra Leonean living in London. In response, she funded and coordinated an effort, implemented by family and friends in the country, to distribute meals to those caught up in the lockdown. </p> <p>“I live in Sierra Leone for part of the year so I know people who would struggle,” said Janneh. “I wanted to organise something for them but then I thought: ‘No, I have to help as many people as I can manage at the time.’”</p> <p>It took just over a week to organise the logistics: obtaining government passes to travel around, finding NGOs in country with the infrastructure they could work with, as well as shopping for food and organising the cooking. In the three days of the lockdown, <a href="http://www.lunchboxgift.com/">Lunchbox</a> fed approximately 2,600 people in seven different communities. </p> <p>But this has not been the only diaspora-led response to the Ebola crisis. Around the time of the outbreak, employees of the <a href="http://www.slwt.org/">Sierra Leone War Trust for Children</a> were on holiday in London. For various reasons, the group was unable to return home. Wanting to find a practical way to provide support, they bought and sent back 750 raincoats for okada (commercial motorbike) riders to wear, so they could continue to carry passengers without fear of transmission.</p> <p>“People aren’t sitting around waiting for governments to sort things out,” said Ade Daramy, chair and spokesperson for the <a href="http://www.engayde.org/">UK Sierra Leone Diaspora Ebola Task Force</a>. “Nobody had thought of that idea, even the okada riders hadn’t. They were just going to lose passengers as far as they were aware, but the initiative actually rescued their livelihoods in a major way.” </p> <p>It is not uncommon for the diaspora to lend their support when their home countries experience crisis, but Ebola has “concentrated minds” in a way that nothing has since the civil war. “Everybody seems to be directly related to somebody who has died, recovered, or been affected in another way, or knows somebody who knows somebody ... We’ve all been touched by it,” explained Daramy. </p> <p>But the diaspora’s involvement in Ebola relief efforts have not been without their challenges, and the absence of a coordinated response is one of the main concerns. </p> <p>“At the moment, there are too many pockets of people dotted around – there is no system in place,” said Nick Asgill, who <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jTbEtZLJbuY&amp;feature=youtu.be">took to YouTube</a> to express his opinions and experience of what is happening in Sierra Leone. “There needs to be a clear line of communication that reaches out to all of the diaspora.” </p> <p>This is the idea behind the UK Sierra Leone Diaspora Ebola Task Force, which attempts to galvanise the community towards a coordinated response. As well as organising fundraising events for <a href="http://www.advocaidsl.com/">AdvocAid</a>, the <a href="https://www.facebook.com/sierraleoneemergencyebolafund">Sierra Leone Ebola Emergency Response Fund</a>, and King’s College London’s <a href="http://kslp.org.uk/">Sierra Leone Partnership</a>, the task force have been involved in negotiations with Public Health England, the NHS and DfID to recruit people to staff the clinics being built in the country. </p> <p>“The initial call went out to Sierra Leoneans and people of Sierra Leonean descent, but it’s now gone wider,” explained Daramy. “We don’t just want doctors and nurses. The clinics being built in Sierra Leone will hopefully be run along NHS guidelines, so we want anyone who’s worked in the NHS – from surgeons to cleaners.” A website named <a href="http://www.engayde.org">EngAyde</a> (meaning “to put heads together”) has also been established in an effort to structure diaspora-led response.</p> <p>Despite complications with coordination, the diaspora’s contribution to the Ebola relief effort should not be disregarded.<br /></p> <p>In Sierra Leone, there are no formal arrangements for people to be fed in hospitals, so families cook food and take it to their relatives. But with Ebola, there’s no way this can happen. With authorisation from the <a href="http://health.gov.sl/">Ministry of Health and Sanitation</a>, Lunchbox now has plans to extend the initiative to medical centres, providing 50,000 meals over the next three months to people in three hospitals in Freetown. </p> <p>“While we have the big state players doing all the grand stuff there are little things that ordinary citizens like myself can actually do,” said Janneh. “I certainly don’t want to sit on the sidelines just watching. I want to be right at the forefront, trying to do my bit.”</p> <p><em>We want to hear from the diaspora – from Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and other affected countries – about how you’re responding to the Ebola crisis. http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/oct/09/diaspora-response-to-the-ebola-crisis-share-your-stories <p>As the Ebola crisis rages on governments, NGOs, multilateral organisations and private sector groups rush to lend their support; sending medical staff and equipment, pledging millions in donations through the United Nations or the World Health Organisation, and setting up clinics in affected countries. </p> <p>But the key players are not the only ones responding. During the lockdown in Freetown last month, members of the diaspora in London funded and coordinated an initiative that enabled a team of volunteers in the country to cook hot meals and distribute them to more than 2,500 people forbidden to leave their houses. </p> <p>That’s just one example of how the Sierra Leone diaspora are contributing to the Ebola effort. Many more expatriates in the UK and the rest of the world are fundraising, pooling resources and doing whatever they can.</p> <p>We want to hear from the diaspora – not just from Sierra Leone, but also from Liberia, Guinea and other affected countries – around the world.
