http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/aug/22/world-news-ebola-iraq-dead-elephants-humanitarian-day <h2><strong>Good week for</strong></h2> <p><strong>Arvind Subramanian</strong>, the economist who is <a href="http://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2014/08/22/meet-arvind-subramanian-the-man-who-could-be-indias-next-chief-economic-adviser/?mod=e2tw">front-runner in the race to become chief economic adviser</a> in India’s finance ministry.</p> <p><strong>Nian Bin</strong>, a grocery shop owner who, after six years on death row in China, <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-28892036">has been acquitted.</a></p> <h2><strong>Bad week for</strong></h2> <p><strong>Ebola-affected countries</strong>, whose economies are continue to suffer as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/17/ebola-kenya-bans-travel-west-africa-virus-fears">Kenya becomes the latest country</a> to declare a travel ban and <a href="http://rt.com/news/181544-air-france-ebola-petition/">Air France staff call for cancellations</a>.</p> <p><strong>Residents of Kerala</strong> as authorities in the southern Indian state outline plans to <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-28892073">ban the sale and consumption of alcohol</a>.</p> <h2><strong>Quote of the week</strong></h2> <p>This week a Youtube video showing <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HdIEm1s6yhY">Vian Dakheel, the only Yazidi female MP</a>, speaking out in parliament about the rape and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2014/aug/15/sexual-enslavement-iraq-minority-women-isis-slavery-rape">enslavement of Iraq’s minority women</a>, has been widely circulated. In an emotional appeal she is translated as saying:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Mr Speaker, our women are being taken as slaves and sold in the slave market. There is now a campaign of genocide being waged against the Yazidi constituent. Brothers, away from all political disputes we want humanitarian solidarity. I speak here in the name of humanity: save us!</p> </blockquote> <h2><strong>What you’re saying</strong></h2> <p>To mark World Humanitarian Day on Tuesday 19 August, we asked our Twitter followers who do relief work to complete this sentence: “I love being a humanitarian because...” This is what a few had to say:</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/So_Jo1/statuses/501696478310838272">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-conversation="none"><p><a href="https://twitter.com/GuardianGDP">@GuardianGDP</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/eu_echo">@eu_echo</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/theOFDA">@theOFDA</a> I love being a humanitarian b/c I meet ppl making a difference in their OWN lives They tell me their stories.</p>&mdash; Sophia Jones (@So_Jo1) <a href="https://twitter.com/So_Jo1/statuses/501696478310838272">August 19, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/TarikawiPeace/statuses/501698000746741760">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-conversation="none"><p><a href="https://twitter.com/GuardianGDP">@GuardianGDP</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/WHD2014?src=hash">#WHD2014</a> I was a hum. in DRC &amp; I loved it because I could immediately see the impact of my work. 2 old now but am still in dev</p>&mdash; Tarikua Getachew (@TarikawiPeace) <a href="https://twitter.com/TarikawiPeace/statuses/501698000746741760">August 19, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <h2>This week in numbers</h2> <p><strong>£6.5m</strong> <a href="http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/Media-office/Press-releases/2014/WTP057171.htm">Ebola research intiative</a> has been set up by the Wellcome Trust and DfID.</p> <p><strong>191,300 </strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/22/syria-civil-war-death-toll-191300-un">people killed in Syria’s civil war</a>, between March 2011 and April 2014.</p> <p><strong>42,000 acres</strong> of croplands in Gaza <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/22/gaza-economic-cost-war-factories-destroyed">has been destroyed.</a> The damage from the recent conflict is estimated at three times that of 2008-9 conflict.</p> <p><strong>$20,000</strong> the prize money for the <a href="http://www.gdn.int/html/feature_story.php?id=68">best idea to reinvent development</a></p> <p><strong>192</strong> elephant carcasses <a href="http://www.wwf.org.uk/wwf_articles.cfm?unewsid=7311">found in African Mara-Serengeti ecosystem</a>. </p> <p><strong>51</strong> people are still missing after a <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-28879401">landslide in Japan</a>.</p> <h2><strong>Picture of the week</strong> <br /></h2>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-6d3a1b14-a074-4223-ae71-be15d112b508"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/8/22/1408725808366/0ad71a2a-744a-4ff1-baae-6ae233eba828-460x306.jpeg" alt="tattooed man hong kong" width="460" height="306" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">A man displays his tattoo at the Hong Kong Tattoo Convention on August 22, 2014. http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/22/ebola-airlines-cancel-flights-guinea-liberia-sierra-leone <p><strong> </strong></p> <p>Airlines have cancelled more than a third of international flights to three west African countries over fears that an outbreak of the Ebola virus could spread, as more African countries introduce measures to block visitors from affected areas.</p> <p>Of 590 monthly flights scheduled to Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, 216 have been cancelled, according to OAG, an airline data provider. Although 14 cases of Ebola have been reported in Nigeria, flights to and from the country have not been affected.</p> <p>African countries are rolling out measures to stop Ebola from spreading: South Africa on Thursday banned travellers from Ebola-stricken countries from entering the country, and on Friday Senegal announced it was closing its border with Guinea as a preventative measure, while Chad said it had closed its border with Nigeria.</p> <p>Nigeria confirmed two new ebola cases on Friday – both spouses of medical workers who had direct contact with Liberian-American Patrick Sawyer, who flew into Nigeria last month with the virus and infected 11 others before he died in July. The male and female caregivers both subsequently died of Ebola, after infecting their spouses.</p> <p>The World Health Organisation (WHO) is concerned that the scale of the outbreak has been underestimated especially in Liberia and Sierra Leone, and that many people with Ebola symptoms have not been identified.</p> <p>Over the past two weeks new treatment centres in Liberia have been overwhelmed as soon as they opened by patients who had not previously been identified.</p> <p>In a situation assessment issued on Friday, WHO said this had “never before been seen in an Ebola outbreak”, and said that it suggested “an invisible caseload of patients” was going undetected by the government.</p> <p>Air Côte d’Ivoire, Nigeria’s Arik Air, Togo’s ASKY Airlines, British Airways, Emirates Airlines and Kenya Airways have together cancelled a combined 76 scheduled flights to Guinea, 70 to Liberia and 70 to Sierra Leone.</p> <p>Kenya Airways on Tuesday became the latest airline to freeze routes to Liberia and Sierra Leone after Kenya’s ministry of health recommended a temporary ban, <a href="http://www.health.go.ke/index.php/media-center/news-and-events/275-temporary-travel-suspension-for-all-passengers-travelling-transiting-to-kenya-from-liberia-guinea-and-sierra-leone" title="">calling the Ebola outbreak</a> “vastly underestimated” and saying it was “expected to continue for some time”.</p> <p>With fears growing that quarantining the affected countries will damage their economies and increase food shortages, <a href="http://www.iata.org/pressroom/pr/Pages/2014-08-18-02.aspx" title="">WHO has urged airlines to keep routes to west Africa operational</a>, saying it ”does not recommend any ban on international travel or trade”.</p> <p>It said: “Travel restrictions and active screening of passengers on arrival at sea ports, airports or ground crossings in non-affected countries that do not share borders with affected countries are not currently recommended by WHO.”</p> <p>Riots broke out in a slum in Liberia’s capital, Monrovia, on Wednesday as residents desperate for food rations battled police. The World Food Programme (WFP) said that about 1 million people are facing food shortages because of quarantines around the region.</p> <p>Air France, which has not suspended any flights, said it requires passengers in Conakry in Guinea, Freetown in Sierra Leone and Lagos in Nigeria to have their temperature taken before boarding an aircraft. “They are only given their boarding card if no medical symptoms are present,” a spokeswoman said. Other airlines have taken similar precautions.</p> <p><a href="http://www.afp.com/en/node/2743046" title="">Air France crews refused to board flights destined for Ebola-affected countries</a> this week, rasing concerns that it could scrap routes.</p> <p>Brussels Airlines, the only European carrier to serve all three affected countries, said it would continue flights, while <a href="http://news.klm.com/ebola-en/" title="">Dutch airline KLM said</a>, “travellers are highly unlikely to be infected with Ebola, which cannot be transmitted under normal hygiene conditions”.</p> <p>British Airways, which announced on 5 August that it would suspend its service to Sierra Leone and Liberia, has said it would review the severity of the Ebola outbreak at the end of this month.</p> <p>About 1,350 people are thought to have died from the Ebola outbreak since it began in March, <a href="http://www.who.int/csr/don/2014_08_20_ebola/en/" title="">according to WHO</a>.</p> <p>David Nabarro, the UN’s recently appointed system coordinator on Ebola, arrived in Monrovia this week as part of a trip to affected countries. He is also scheduled to visit Freetown, Conakry and Abuja in Nigeria.</p> <p>WHO said on Friday it was working on a six to nine-month plan designed to ease the Ebola outbreak.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/22/ebola-europe-spain-germany-ireland-risk-false-alarm <video data-media-id="gu-video-445261334" class="gu-video" controls="controls" poster="">\n        <source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2014/08/22/140822EbolaSurvivor-16x9.mp4"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2014/08/22/140822EbolaSurvivor/140822EbolaSurvivor.m3u8"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2014/08/22/140822EbolaSurvivor_3gpLg16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2014/08/22/140822EbolaSurvivor.webm"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2014/08/22/140822EbolaSurvivor_3gpSml16x9.3gp"></source>\n      </video><p>There has been only one confirmed <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/ebola" title="">Ebola</a> case in Europe since the epidemic broke out in Africa, but a string of false alarms has provoked jitters and charges of overreaction.</p><p>From Austria to Ireland, Spain to Germany, there have been at least a dozen cases of west Africans with mild flu symptoms being isolated until it was established that they were not suffering from Ebola. The only recorded case involved a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/12/ebola-spanish-missionary-dies-madrid-liberia" title="">Spanish missionary who contracted the virus in Liberia</a> and died after he had returned to Spain.</p><p>In Spain, worries over Ebola have resulted in three false alarms in as many days.</p><p>On Sunday, a hospital in Alicante said it was investigating a suspected case of Ebola after a man in his late 30s was admitted to the hospital suffering a fever as well as vomiting and bleeding. He had recently arrived from Nigeria, he reportedly told hospital staff. Later that day, health authorities said the man had tested negative for Ebola.</p><p>The next day there was panic at Madrid's Adolfo Suárez Madrid-Barajas airport after a man suffered spasms and vomiting. Airport authorities put in place the Ebola protocol, cordoning off an area around the man. Health officials, wearing a type of hazmat suit, were brought in to attend to him, according to El País. After an examination by a second set of medics, it was determined that the man did not have Ebola. He was transferred to hospital for treatment.</p><p>And on Monday evening, protocol against the disease was activated after a middle-aged man was admitted to a hospital in Bilbao with a fever. He had reportedly returned from a business trip to Sierra Leone. The regional health authority urged people to stay calm, saying it was activating the protocol as a precautionary measure. On Tuesday it announced that the test had come back negative.</p><p>In Germany, about 600 people were quarantined for two hours in a Berlin jobcentre after a false alarm about a suspected case of Ebola.</p><p>A 30-year-old woman from west Africa had collapsed at the jobcentre in the Pankow district on Tuesday afternoon. The centre was quarantined after the woman had told medics that she had been in direct contact with Ebola victims in her home country.</p><figure data-media-id='gu-image-445435962'><img src='http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/About/General/2014/8/22/1408719689185/German-police-officers-we-011.jpg' alt='German police officers wearing protective masks ' width='460' height='276' class='gu-image'/><figcaption>German police officers outside a jobcentre in Berlin that was quarantined after a woman from west Africa collapsed. Photograph: Fabrizio Bensch/Reuters</figcaption></figure><p>However, after the woman had been examined at an isolation ward at Berlin's Charité hospital, doctors said she had not visited an area affected by the virus and was suffering from an intestinal infection.</p><p>In Ireland, the body of an Irish engineer who had worked in west Africa was quarantined in hospital until Ebola tests could be carried out.</p><p>Dessie Quinn was found dead at his home in Mountcharles in Co Donegal and his body later taken to Letterkenny general hospital in the county where it was isolated. Tests for Ebola were carried out because he had been working in Sierra Leone a fortnight earlier.</p><p>His family said they were annoyed that the 44-year-old's body had been placed in a quarantined area of the hospital without their prior knowledge.</p><p>"In its own way, that is very hard to take when there is a sudden death," said family friend Fr Aidan Gavigan. "However, this was the first time they had heard of this news. He was a young man being treated for malaria for a number of weeks."</p>

http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2014/aug/22/ebola-liberia-monrovia-crisis-citizenship <p>“We dodged bullets during the war, now Ebola is going to kill us?” my aunt asked me in distress one evening in mid-July, as we sat commiserating at my house on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia’s capital.</p> <p>Back then, Ebola seemed like a looming threat in the way that armed conflict had 15 years earlier. But by the end of the month, the Liberian government had <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/jul/31/ebola-outbreak-state-of-emergency-liberia-sierra-leone" title="">declared a state of emergency</a> and, days later, the World Health Organisation designated the Ebola outbreak in west Africa <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/08/who-ebola-outbreak-international-public-health-emergency" title="">an international health emergency</a>. Ebola has now killed more than 1,000 people, with the number of deaths in Liberia surpassing those in Guinea and Sierra Leone.</p> <p>Yet before the highly infectious disease permeated Liberia’s borders from neighbouring Guinea in March, the country was plagued by a crisis of citizenship. Relations between the Liberian state and its citizens were already volatile.</p> <p>Before Ebola hit, a group of disaffected citizens <a href="http://www.tnrliberia.com/index.php/login/522-clashes-near-in-arcelor-mittal%E2%80%99s-mine.html" title="">clashed with riot police</a> at the Mittal Steel concession area in Nimba, north-central Liberia, in early July as they protested that an iron ore concession agreement had not benefitted local people. The government branded the assailants “thugs” and “unlawful”, making appeals to parent company ArcelorMittal before a formal investigation of the grievances.</p> <p>This was the beginning of the bubbling cauldron. Ebola simply tipped the pot over.</p> <p>When looters <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/17/ebola-liberia-clinic-raided" title="">invaded a treatment centre on 17 August</a>, declaring that Ebola was not real and that the government was using it as a ruse to shore up donor funding, this revealed a crisis of citizenship.</p> <p>When Liberians decide to hide suspected Ebola patients in their homes because they do not trust the healthcare system, this reveals a crisis of citizenship.</p> <p>When healthcare workers avoid going to work because their colleagues have died without the proper protective gear or training to safeguard them from infection, this reveals a crisis of citizenship.</p> <p>Those with money have the wherewithal to leave Liberia while others remain barricaded in their homes, shielding themselves from a silent killer with no cure. This also reveals a crisis of citizenship.</p> <p>These actions are not those of illiterate, unreasonable people, but indicative of the desperation of poor people who have seen the state fail them repeatedly.</p> <p>People in my country were angry before Ebola, and there was great cause for their ire. Liberia’s reintegration into the global capitalist system has placed profits above people and GDP growth above human development.</p> <p>On the surface, Liberia’s <a href="http://mof.gov.lr/doc/AfT%20document-%20April%2015,%202013.pdf" title="">postwar economic recovery</a> is laudable – steady growth rates of 5.3%, 6.1%, 7.9% and 8.3% in 2009-12, respectively; $1.3bn (£783m) in foreign direct investment between 2006 and 2010 in traditional sectors such as forestry, rubber and mining; and increases in export revenue from $175m in 2006 to $295.2m in 2011. But these developments have not rendered fundamental changes in the lives of most Liberians, <a href="http://www.emansion.gov.lr/doc/Final%20PRS.pdf" title="">64% of whom still live in abject poverty</a>.</p> <p>Liberia ranked 175th among 187 countries in the <a href="http://hdr.undp.org/en/2014-report" title="">2014 human development index</a> – admittedly an improvement from its 182nd ranking in 2011. Nevertheless, most people lack access to electricity, health facilities, access roads, quality education, finance and secure land tenure. According to the <a href="http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---dgreports/---stat/documents/presentation/wcms_156366.pdf" title="">2010 labour force survey</a>, 78% of Liberia’s workforce are engaged in “vulnerable employment” without a steady income, and <a href="http://www.lisgis.net/pg_img/LFS%20Presentation%20to%20EMT-Cabinet-170811.pdf" title="">68% are employed in the informal sector</a>.</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--supporting" data-media-id="gu-fc-9ff6589a-2211-403d-9b87-7ceaf287dcd4"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/8/22/1408699059101/0e445d12-39e4-43e8-8a0a-1eb917b6215b-460x276.jpeg" alt="MDG Liberia Battles Spreading Ebola Epidemic" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Residents cannot leave the West Point slum in Monrovia until the Ebola outbreak is contained. Photograph: John Moore/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Liberia is still reliant on donor aid – which accounts for more than half of overall spending on education and health – and exports of unprocessed raw materials and minerals. In the last fiscal year, there were several reported cases of <a href="http://allafrica.com/stories/201405151444.html" title="">budget shortfalls</a>. The current draft budget, which should have come into effect on 1 July, has yet to be passed by the legislature. Inflation has skyrocketed. In April, the exchange rate was 79 Liberian dollars to every US dollar; by July, it was almost 90.</p> <p>The lack of quality healthcare in Liberia is not from lack of financing, as most people have argued. It is from the mismanagement of funds. Contrary to what has been reported, Liberia is not poor; it is poorly managed.</p> <p>Liberia must take responsibility for containing the Ebola outbreak, and any in the future. We must think and plan ahead.</p> <p>We must devise a crisis response plan in emergency situations, such as an infectious disease outbreak, and create a contingency fund for this. We can do this by slashing by 10% the salaries of exorbitantly paid members of the executive and legislative branches of government, and placing those funds in an escrow account.</p> <p>Liberia must strengthen its healthcare infrastructure by increasing the percentage of the national budget allotted to health, which will enable the provision of insurance packages for healthcare workers, train more doctors and nurses, and expand health coverage to rural areas. The goodwill of Liberians abroad can also be leveraged.</p> <p>Liberian citizens must use the legislative elections postponed to next year and the presidential elections scheduled for 2017 to vote for leaders who have a track record in delivering public goods and supporting pro-poor development.</p> <p>Just as armed conflicts ended in Liberia, Ebola too will be overcome. But when the war on Ebola ends, Liberia and its people, domestically and transnationally, must begin an earnest conversation about how to solve the crisis of citizenship.</p>

http://www.theguardian.com/society/video/2014/aug/21/american-ebola-patient-released-from-atlanta-hospital-video <video data-media-id="gu-video-445187294" class="gu-video" controls="controls" poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/8/21/1408642560566/Emory-Hospital-Releases-A-007.jpg">\n        <source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2014/08/21/140821ebolasurvivor-16x9.mp4"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2014/08/21/140821ebolasurvivor.webm"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2014/08/21/140821ebolasurvivor_3gpSml16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2014/08/21/140821ebolasurvivor_3gpLg16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2014/08/21/140821ebolasurvivor/140821ebolasurvivor.m3u8"></source>\n      </video>
http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/21/ebola-americans-released-hopsital-recovery-doctors <p>Two US humanitarian workers <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/21/american-ebola-discharged-hospital-kent-brantly">who contracted Ebola</a> while working in Liberia have been released from Emory University hospital in Atlanta after receiving an experimental drug treatment which has yet to go through full clinical and human trials.</p> <p>Dr Kent Brantly of Texas and Nancy Writebol, a missionary from North Carolina, contracted Ebola while responding to the outbreak in Liberia. Brantly and Writebol were both treated in the hospital’s containment unit, which is specially equipped to care for patients with serious communicable diseases.<br /></p> <p>“Today is a miraculous day,” Brantly said at a press conference at Emory hospital on Thursday to announce his discharge from care. “I am thrilled to be alive, to be well and to be reunited with my family.”<br /></p> <p>The hospital said Writebol had been quietly released on Tuesday. </p> <p>The World Health Organization said earlier this month that unlicensed<br />drugs and vaccines can ethically be used to treat the outbreak which has so far claimed <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/12/world-health-organisation-allow-unlicensed-ebola-drugs-west-africa">at least 1,200 lives</a> in Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea and Nigeria.<br /><br />Doctors cautioned that it was too soon to hope that the treatment could hasten the end of the public health crisis: Dr Bruce Ribner, medical director of Emory hospital’s infectious disease unit said that it was unclear if the drug had contributed to the pair’s recovery and suggested it may have even delayed their return to health.<br /><br />Liberian officials have said that three African medics who have also been given the treatment are showing “remarkable signs of improvement”.</p> <p>But Ribner said there was no scientific basis to suggest the treatment was a cure. “They are very first ever to receive these agents. There are no prior experiments with this. We do not know if its improved them ... or even delayed their recovery,” cautioned Ribner.<br /></p> <p>Even if the treatment is effective, the California-based manufacturer of ZMapp, <a href="http://www.mappbio.com/">Mapp Biopharmaceutical</a>, said that “the available supply of ZMapp has been exhausted”. </p> <p>Brantly and Writebol were both treated in Emory hospital’s containment unit, which is specially equipped to care for patients with serious communicable diseases.<br /><br />Reinfection is not impossible, but Ebola survivors are highly unlikely to contract the virus a second time and the hospital said their release from hospital posed no risk to public health. “Limited knowledge of the Ebola virus, especially in our country, has created understandable anxiety and fear for some persons,” said Ribner, who said<br />he understood these concerns. “However, we cannot let our fears dictate our actions, we must all care.”<br /><br />Brantly and his wife held hands before he read from a written statement and he hugged members of his care team. He choked up several times while thanking his aid group, North Carolina-based Samaritan’s Purse, and the Emory medical team standing behind them.<br /><br />The hospital said Writebol had been discharged without publicity on Tuesday. Asked why the hospital did not announce her release from care, Ribner said the hospital decided to release the patients after a rigorous course of treatment and thorough testing.<br /><br />“The medical staff at Emory is confident that the discharge from the hospital of both these patients poses no public health threat,” said Ribner.<br /><br />It is five months since the first case of Ebola was confirmed in Guinea, spreading quickly into Sierra Leone, Liberia and Nigeria. According to the World Health Organization 2,473 people have so far contracted the disease which, once symptomatic, can kill within five days .<br /><br />Brantly said the virus was not on the radar when he and his family moved to west Africa two years ago, but he noticed a steady increase in Ebola patients in June and July. His wife and children returned to the US on 20 July, but Brantly stayed on to continue his work.<br /><br />Three days later, he fell ill. “I woke up feeling under the weather, and then my life took an unexpected turn as I was diagnosed with Ebola virus disease,” he said.<br /><br />Brantly, 33, was flown out of Liberia on 2 August on a private jet outfitted with a containment tent and was admitted to Emory, which is one of only four institutions in the US capable of properly handling patients with a disease of this nature, according to the hospital. Writebol, 59, arrived three days later.<br /><br />The two emphasized their desire to spend time with their families, since the nature of the disease requires isolation treatment.<br /><br />“My family and I will now be going away for a period of time to reconnect, decompress and recover,” Brantly said, after thanking all the people involved in his care and hugging many individually at the press conference. “For now, we need some time together, after a month apart.”<br /><br />Writebol has gone to “an undisclosed location”, said the North Carolina-based aid group SIM, for whom she had been working in Liberia.<br /><br />“Nancy is free of the virus, but the lingering effects of the battle have left her in a significantly weakened condition,” her husband, David, said in a statement. “Thus, we decided it would be best to leave the hospital privately to be able to give her the rest and recuperation she needs at this time.”<br /><br />Ribner warned that the fight against Ebola is “far from over”, as it continues to spread across west Africa. “What we learned in caring for them will help advance the world’s understanding of how to treat Ebola infections and hopefully improve,” said Ribner.<br /><br />The two missionaries’ survival has given fresh impetus to the search for a vaccine.<br /><br />US clinical trials for what scientists hope is a promising new vaccine have been brought forward, according to the US National Institutes of Health. Its researchers have been working on a vaccine with Okairos, a Swiss-Italian company owned by Britain’s GlaxoSmithKline for years. Dr Anthony Fauci, director of the NIH’s National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases told the Los Angeles Times: “We’re dealing with an urgent situation.”<br /><br />The disease is out of control in Sierra Leone and Liberia, the two worst-affected countries in west Africa, both of which have declared states of emergency.<br /><br />This week MSF director of operations Brice de la Vigne <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/19/western-leaders-ebola-outbreak-africa-medecins-sans-frontieres ">told the Guardian </a>the international community was paying “almost zero” interest in the crisis, saying the outbreak would not be contained unless western leaders implemented an emergency operation comparable with the response to a natural disaster.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/sport/video/2014/aug/21/uneku-atawodi-nigerias-polo-queen-on-race-and-ebola-video <video data-media-id="gu-video-445160283" class="gu-video" controls="controls" poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/8/21/1408627406205/Uneku-Atawodi-worlds-firs-008.jpg">\n        <source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2014/08/21/140821UnekoAtawodi-16x9.mp4"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2014/08/21/140821UnekoAtawodi_3gpLg16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2014/08/21/140821UnekoAtawodi.webm"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2014/08/21/140821UnekoAtawodi/140821UnekoAtawodi.m3u8"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2014/08/21/140821UnekoAtawodi_3gpSml16x9.3gp"></source>\n      </video>

http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/aug/21/ebola-how-to-prepare-epidemic <h2>Adam Ritchie, science and public policy lecturer, <a href="http://www.bsg.ox.ac.uk" title="">Blavatnik School of Government</a>, Oxford University, Oxford, UK, <a href="https://twitter.com/adamjohnritchie" title="">@adamjohnritchie</a></h2> <p><strong>Stop relying on Europe and the US to control epidemics:</strong> More African universities, scientists and doctors doing research and who drive their own agendas based on local needs, would help Africans deal with these issues directly.</p> <p><strong>Don’t neglect evaluation in the rush to deal with emergencies: </strong>To move forward we need to learn from each epidemic. The Independent Evaluation Group have produced <a href="http://ieg.worldbankgroup.org/blog/evaluation-action-responding-ebola" title="">10 tips for responding to Ebola and evaluation</a>.</p> <p><strong>Consider big data’s place in preparing for epidemics: </strong>We’ve all heard about Google being quicker to notice <a href="http://www.google.org/flutrends/" title="">flu outbreaks</a> than health authorities, due to people using the search engine to look up symptoms. However, but such concepts have failed to live up to their potential, eg <a href="http://www.gsma.com/mobilefordevelopment/is-there-potential-for-ehealth-and-mhealth-in-nigerias-saving-one-million-lives-initiative" title="">eHealth and mobile health</a>.</p> <h2>Pamela Steele, director and principal consultant, <a href="http://www.pamsteele.co.uk" title="">Pamela Steele Associates Ltd,</a> Oxford, UK</h2> <p><strong>Developing countries must create their own national preparedness strategies:</strong> African governments need to be working together with their health institutions and disaster risk reduction teams at all times. Countries not affected yet by Ebola should by now have tested their systems, processes, knowledge and understanding of them.</p> <p><strong>Encourage behaviour change before epidemics:</strong> The more we invest in behaviour change communication at a household and community level, the less overwhelmed hospitals will be during an epidemic. Advocacy for behaviour change has worked for HIV and Aids.</p> <p><strong>Stop supply issues becoming the issue during an epidemic:</strong> It is easy for fragile supply chain infrastructure to crumble during a disaster. No one seems to know what is required or where to get it from at the right quality. Make contingency plans for getting supplies.</p> <h2>Lisa Denney, research fellow, <a href="http://www.odi.org" title="">Overseas Development Institute</a>, London, UK <a href="https://twitter.com/odi_development" title="">@odi_development</a></h2> <p><strong>Local health workers should lead epidemic response teams:</strong> People don’t trust outsiders coming in. They fear they are either bringing the disease themselves or coming to take people away to treatment centres from which they won’t come back.</p> <p><strong>Different government departments must co-ordinate before epidemics:</strong> Too often diseases are considered the purview of health and not of the other sectors connected to this – like agriculture, infrastructure, security etc. Taskforces are set up in times of emergency response, but these parts of government need to interact more outside of crisis times, when the space for building resilience is more likely to exist.</p> <p><strong>Rethink training for community health workers:</strong> Currently training is carried out through cascade training models (eg one person trains 10 people, they in turn train 10 people, and so on). It is cost-effective, but often the information ends up at the end of the chain incomplete or inaccurate.</p> <p><strong>Engage traditional healers: </strong>Given that they are a trusted part of the health system from the perspective of service users, healers need to be engaged by governments in promoting appropriate health messages.</p> <h2>Carol Dunn, risk communication specialist, <a href="http://www.2resilience.com" title="">2resilience</a>, Seattle, US, <a href="http://www.twitter.com/caroldn" title="">@caroldn</a></h2> <p><strong>Encourage communication online or over the phone:</strong> Technology can help reduce factors that lead people to leave their house. People can get information and distractions that will help them relax, and can stay connected with loved ones.</p> <h2>Stella Anyangwe, global health expert and consultant, Pretoria, South Africa, <a href="https://twitter.com/SAnyangwe" title="">@SAnyangwe</a></h2> <p><strong>Name and shame those not prepared:</strong> Calling out countries on their mistakes at international forums has moved some countries to improve preparedness and response. Voicing concerns has also promoted quicker recovery from hard-hitting emergencies.</p> <p><strong>Allocate funding for training on disaster risk management: </strong>Without this training, epidemics and other emergencies are bound to recur.</p> <h2>Ruwan Ratnayake, epidemiologist and technical advisor, <a href="http://www.rescue.org/" title="">International Rescue Committee (IRC)</a>, New York, US, <a href="https://twitter.com/RuwanEPI" title="">@RuwanEPI</a></h2> <p><strong>Develop higher-quality surveillance systems for detecting epidemics earlier:</strong> <a href="http://www.ajtmh.org/content/89/4/688.long" title="">An alert and response system</a> was effectively used during the cholera outbreak in Haiti to rapidly detect emerging pockets of disease and launch rapid responses to control the disease at the source.</p> <h2>Genevieve Hutchinson, health advisor, <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediaaction/" title="">BBC Media Action</a>, London, UK, <a href="http://www.twitter.com/genevieveh77" title="">@genevieveh77</a></h2> <p><strong>More support is needed for communication in an epidemic:</strong> What to communicate, how to communicate, who to and when. Health workers, governments, and communities being able to give accurate, up-to-date and consistent information is absolutely key.</p> <p><strong>Connect local initiatives together to make communities more resilient:</strong> Coordinate complementary activities, working together with health workers and service providers in addition to local government and local leaders.</p> <h2>Kweku Ackom, health advisor, <a href="http://www.internationalmedicalcorps.org.uk" title="">International Medical Corps UK</a>, London, UK, <a href="http://www.twitter.com/kweku2007" title="">@kweku2007</a></h2> <p><strong>Have more stringent border controls from the start:</strong> Where people are coming from Ebola-declared countries they should be screened. Next, those that fit the case definition put in quarantine, observed and tested.</p> <p><strong>Build strong health systems:</strong> They must be built to handle all health challenges, and not just in response to one epidemic. Currently, the international community sees providing this infrastructure as too costly and the job of national governments – but it is the best deterrent against epidemics.</p> <p><em>Read the full Q&amp;A </em><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/aug/08/ebola-dengue-cholera-epidemics" title=""><em>here</em></a><em>.</em></p> <p><strong>Read more stories like this:</strong></p> <p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/aug/15/ebola-vaccine-outbreak-secret-serum?view=classic" title="">Ebola outbreak: the vaccine and ‘secret serum’ explained</a></p> <p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jul/14/ebola-epidemic-guinea-sierra-leone-liberia-msf-world-health-organisation?view=mobile#opt-in-message" title="">Ebola: voices from the epicentre of the epidemic</a></p> <p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jan/27/dengue-fever-vaccine-development-brazil" title="">Preparing for a dengue fever vaccine: why Brazil’s ahead of the game</a></p> <p><a href="https://register.theguardian.com/global-development/" title=""><strong>Join our community</strong></a><strong> of development professionals and humanitarians. Follow </strong><a href="https://twitter.com/GuardianGDP" title=""><strong>@GuardianGDP</strong></a><strong> on Twitter.</strong></p>
http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/20/uk-ebola-emergency-research <p>The international development secretary, Justine Greening, has launched an emergency research initiative to look into spread of Ebola, which has claimed more than 1,200 lives in west Africa.</p><p>The £6.5m programme co-funded by the Wellcome Trust was announced a day after a director of Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) accused western leaders of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/19/western-leaders-ebola-outbreak-africa-medecins-sans-frontieres" title="">taking "almost zero" interest in the crisis</a> in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia.</p><p>Greening said she hoped the research would "better equip those working on the ground so they can tackle the outbreak as effectively as possible".</p><p>Val Snewin, international activities manager at Wellcome Trust, said: "There's an urgency to this. We are not an emergency team, but what we can do is mobilise research. Unless someone is willing to commit to research you cannot learn to improve things either later in this outbreak or the next one."</p><p>The Department for International Development and the trust hope to have research commissioned and completed within two months, meaning it could have an impact on the current crisis, which is expected to last more than six months.</p><p>Among the projects they may look at are case detection systems in places such as Sierra Leone and Liberia where there is illiteracy and weak health infrastructure and where accurate data on the spread of the disease is difficult to come by. Snewin said they would also be prepared to fund clinical trials for prototype diagnostic&nbsp;tools.</p><p>This week the World Food Programme announced it was stepping up emergency food deliveries after reports of shortages in quarantined areas.</p><p>MSF has called for international leadership and resources to tackle Ebola. The UK's Disaster Emergency Committee has said it would support a transnational intervention if asked.</p><p>A DEC spokesman, responding to MSF's plea, said: "A regional monitoring and tracing programme would require leadership from national governments in the affected countries, probably with the support of the UN agencies. Were such a programme initiated, many DEC members might well be in a position to support it."</p><p>On Wednesday , police in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, fired teargas to disperse a crowd agitating to leave a neighbourhood placed under quarantine because of Ebola, witnesses said.</p><p>Liberia has the highest death toll of the four west African countries affected by the disease, with the fastest-rising number of cases. President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf ordered the quarantine and imposed a night-time curfew that began&nbsp;on Wednesday.</p><p>Snewin said a committee of experts was in place for the initiative, drawing on the UN, WHO and academia, who could approve research proposals. Among the areas that interest Wellcome are treatment-seeking behaviour, case detection systems and clinical management.</p><p>"What are the social reasons for seeking treatment? In some areas there is distrust of western medical centres and that then fuels potential transmission," she said. "WHO has various guidelines and practices that it feels are necessary to manage the crisis, are these working? Are these the best practices? Can we learn now and amend these practices?"</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/20/ebola-western-hysteria-health-workers-risking-lives <p>Last Friday, I spoke to my mother at her home in Freetown, Sierra Leone, to discuss my forthcoming trip. In light of the outbreak of Ebola in the country, should I still come? She thought I should reschedule – the mood in the country was low and people were staying home. Best wait for a better time. What we didn’t discuss was the chance of me catching Ebola, because we both knew the chances were minuscule.</p> <p>Our conversation may yet be entirely academic because British Airways, on which I am booked to fly, <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-28663833" title="">has cancelled all flights until the end of this month</a> and possibly beyond. The World Health Organisation gave the company a very public slap, issuing a statement to say there was no need to suspend flights as the disease was not airborne, and anyone in the infectious stages of Ebola would be incapable of flying. “<a href="https://twitter.com/WHO/status/499837549763121152" title="">Hard to save lives if we &amp; other health workers cannot get in</a>,” the WHO tweeted.</p> <p>Sadly, that didn’t stop other airlines following suit. Kenya Airways suspended flights to Freetown, and Korean Airlines suspended flights to Nairobi, even though Kenya is on the other side of the continent, 3,000 miles away. This week, a Brazilian delegation to a trade conference in Namibia cancelled its visit, citing fear of Ebola. “Do these people not have a map?” a spokesman for Namibia’s Chamber of Commerce asked. The Namibian capital, Windhoek, is closer to Rio de Janeiro than to Guinea, where the outbreak originated.</p> <p>Western reporting of the Ebola outbreak has been consistently overblown. Early reports claimed the virus was passed on to humans through the <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-26735118" title="">consumption of fruit bats</a>, an apparent delicacy of which I’d never heard. In a scientific paper I found a more convincing explanation: the bats hang in the rafters of buildings, dropping their <a href="http://web.stanford.edu/group/virus/filo/bats.html" title="">contaminated feces and urine</a> below. A friend in Freetown tells me of the greeting that has replaced the customary three kisses: people knock elbows and chant “Elbow, elbow-la!”.On the phone, my mother is pleased people are heeding government advice. This week, the New York Times reported <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/26/world/they-had-ebola-and-lived-to-tell-about-it.html" title="">Ebola survivors being shunne</a>d and treated as “untouchable” by neighbours. Much, in fact, as people in America refused to touch HIV-positive people a few decades back, only with better reason.</p> <p>In the US, Donald Trump <a href="https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/495415298808639488" title="">tweeted that American Ebola victims should not be brought home</a>. Yet international health experts agree that the failure to contain the outbreak is due to the broken health systems in the affected countries, which are among the poorest in the world, two of which are still rebuilding following a decade of war. Simply put, this would not happen in Britain or the US.</p> <p>In west Africa, those most at risk are the very poor, their carers and health workers. True, the disease has no cure, but reported death rates of 90% are wrong. The actual figure is 50%-55%. Agencies struggling to contain the outbreak took the international media to task for reporting an inflated figure, causing locals to view Ebola centres as no more than a place to die and therefore refuse to report symptoms.</p> <p>The US has begun evacuating its citizens from the area. Meanwhile, another friend, who heads an NGO in Freetown and has no plans to evacuate her staff, describes the courage of the doctors and nurses working 20-hour shifts, despite the loss of nearly 100 colleagues.</p> <p>Some years ago I met the Sierra Leonian expert in haemorrhagic fevers, Dr Aniru Conteh, who headed the country’s Lassa fever research unit. He had struggled on with his work for years despite a lack of proper equipment – reportedly at one point using a snorkel and mask while handling samples. He died after being accidentally contaminated by a patient.</p> <p>His successor, Dr Sheik Umar Khan, spearheaded initial efforts to combat the Ebola outbreak. He too died in the line of duty, as did most members of his unit: researchers, nurses and even a driver. Their loss will have enduring consequences in the world’s fight against the disease, yet their life’s work has received less coverage than an idiotic remark by Trump. Read reports in the western media of Ebola hysteria and you may well ask yourself to whom the hysteria belongs. Not, apparently, to those with the most to lose.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/aug/19/western-leaders-ebola-outbreak-africa-medecins-sans-frontieres <p>The international community has made "almost zero" response to the Ebola outbreak in west Africa, with western leaders more interested in protecting their own countries than helping contain the crisis that has now claimed more than 1,200 lives, a senior international aid worker said on Tuesday.</p><p>Brice de la Vigne, the operations director of Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), said politicians in industrialised countries urgently needed to take action, or risk the outbreak spreading much further. "Globally, the response of the international community is almost zero," he told the Guardian. "Leaders in the west are talking about their own safety and doing things like closing airlines – and not helping anyone else."</p><p>His comments came as the World Health Organisation announced that the death toll in the world's worst Ebola outbreak has now exceeded 1,200. The haemorrhagic disease, which kills up to 90% of those infected, is ravaging Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, and also has a toehold in Nigeria, Africa's biggest economy.</p><p>De la Vigne, who has just returned from a tour of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, said the scale of the outbreak was comparable to a catastrophe such as the 2010 Haitian earthquake, which killed 300,000 people.</p><p>"The solution is not that complicated but we need to have political will to do so. Time is running against us. But you need very senior people with high profiles, the kind of people who can co-ordinate a response to a million people affected by an earthquake," he said.</p><p>His words were echoed by Dr Gabriel Fitzpatrick, who is working at the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2014/jul/17/ebola-sierra-leone-epidemic" title="">MSF field hospital in Kailahun</a>, the epicentre of the crisis in Sierra Leone.</p><p>"If this Ebola outbreak happened in a western community, in London, you'd get a few cases and that would be it," he said. "The main objective here is not to dramatically increase the person's chance of survival, it's to contain the spread"</p><p>At least 810 cases of Ebola have been reported in Sierra Leone, and 348 people have died from the virus in the country, according to World Health Organisation figures. Since June  Fitzpatrick has been working in the MSF field hospital, processing patients through three stages with a "suspect tent", a "probably tent" and a "confirmed tent". Once in the final tent, their chances of coming out alive are slim.</p><p>He described one family of nine wiped out after a grandmother contracted the disease on August 4. Death is swift – usually within four or five days.</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/02/-sp-ebola-out-of-control-west-africa" title="">Fear, rumours and conspiracy theories have conspired with poverty and high illiteracy</a> to allow the disease to flourish in two countries whose infrastructure is already weak. "Both Sierra Leone and Liberia were at war 10 years ago and all the infrastructure was destroyed. It's the worst place on earth to have these epidemics," De la Vigne said.</p><p>Sierra Leone and Liberia have already declared a state of emergency, but health provision is reaching breaking point.</p><p>Sinead Walsh, who is working on the Sierra Leonean presidential Ebola task force, said the crisis was already causing deeper problems. She said more than 1 million people are in quarantine in Kailahun and neighbouring Kenema alone, businesses are closing, farmers are unable to trade and fears are rising about food shortages.</p><p>The disease is having a knock-on effect, with sick people afraid to go to hospital for fear of catching Ebola. Health workers fear deaths from malaria and in childbirth could now also escalate.</p><p>"We are gone beyond the stage of a health crisis. This is a humanitarian emergency now." said Walsh, Ireland's ambassador to the country and head of Irish Aid in Freetown. "We need to start working on the secondary crisis."</p><p>Fitzpatrick said the priority was to contain the disease, using local volunteers to find suspected cases and bring patients to hospitals where they can be isolated: "The second thing is to trace those who we know have been in contact and  keep them under observation. We are not doing any contact tracing at the moment," he said. "It's not rocket science to do on a large scale across west Africa. But it needs an organisational structure and good leadership." David Heymann, professor of infections disease epidemiology at the London school of hygiene and tropical medicine, who headed the global response to SARS while working for WHO said that oubtreak took three months to contain.</p><p>He also said containing ebola was "not rocket science" identifying "contact tracing" and public communications as the key factors.</p><p>One of the differences with SARS is the outbreak happened in industrialised countries where systems for "infection control" were in place, he said.</p>

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/17/ebola-kenya-bans-travel-west-africa-virus-fears <p>The World Health Organisation has urged governments not to impose blanket bans on trade and travel on Ebola-affected countries after Kenya joined a growing number of countries and airlines severing links to three west African states.</p><p>The WHO has already said that the <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/notes/2014/ebola-travel/en/" title="">risk of Ebola transmission from air travel is low</a>, but the level of fear is so high that several airlines have disregarded the UN agency's advice. The disease has already killed at least 1,145 people across west Africa this year.</p><p>"The scale of the outbreak is much larger than anything ever seen before," said Gregory Hartl, a WHO spokesman. "It is an obvious source of concern and it is not to be underestimated, but we must take measures commensurate with the risk. What you don't want to do is to take blanket measures to cut off travel and trade."</p><p>Despite such advice, Kenya is the latest country to jump on the bandwagon by declaring a travel ban on Saturday. From midnight on Tuesday, people travelling from or through Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia will not be allowed to enter the east African country, said Kenya's health ministry.</p><p>Nigeria, which allows entry to health professionals and Kenyans returning from those countries, was not included in the ban. The outbreak began in the forested zone on the borders of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia earlier this year, and spread to Nigeria last month.</p><figure data-media-id='gu-image-444767269'><img src='http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/8/17/1408301523250/EbolaTravelBansWEB2.png' alt='Ebola Travel Bans WEB2' width='460' height='525' class='gu-image'/><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>The WHO last week said the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/aug/15/ebola-outbreak-vastly-underestimated-world-health-organisation" title="">outbreak had been vastly underestimated</a> and will require "extraordinary measures, on a massive scale" to contain it. Médecins sans Frontières, the medical charity, said the disease was spreading "faster than we can respond to", and accused the WHO of being too slow to react.</p><p>Following the Kenyan government's decision, Kenya Airways said it would suspend flights to Liberia and Sierra Leone, abruptly reversing its announcement on Friday that it would continue flying to those countries. The airline had been accused by medical experts and Kenyan politicians of putting profits ahead of prudence amid fears that its flights would spread the virus. The airline flies more than 70 flights a week to west Africa.</p><p>The airline's chief executive, Titus Naikuni, had argued at a news conference on Friday that its flights actually helped to contain the Ebola outbreak by transporting medical staff, supplies and equipment to west Africa. But doctors representing the Kenya Medical Association had asked Kenya Airways to suspend flights to the four countries affected by Ebola "until things stabilise". MPs also called on the carrier to halt its west African operations.</p><p>Several airlines have already suspended flights to Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, including British Airways, Emirates Airlines, Arik Air and <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-28550906" title="">ASKY Airlines</a>. Nigeria became the fourth Ebola-affected country after a Liberian-American man <a href="https://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/top-news/165732-ncaa-suspends-asky-airline-for-flying-ebola-virus-victim-into-nigeria.html#sthash.l5Q1R24D.dpbs" title="">flew to Lagos on an ASKY flight</a> and infected several people in the city before he died.</p><p>Officials in Cameroon, which borders Nigeria, announced on Friday it would suspend all flights from all four Ebola-affected countries. Korean Air announced on Thursday it would temporarily halt its service to Kenya despite there being no cases of Ebola in the country.</p><p>Nigeria has withdrawn its athletes from the Youth Olympics in Nanjing, China, as a result of the outbreak; the games opened on Saturday. The International Olympic Committee has barred athletes from Ebola-hit countries from competing in pool events and combat sports, affecting three athletes.</p><p>Hartl said action commensurate with the risk of Ebola spreading through air travel has already been taken in the three most-affected countries: the screening of passengers.</p><p>"We know it's happening. It makes sense at the departure end and there is nothing to stop screening at the incoming end. These are much better measures. You do not need a sledgehammer to crack a nut."</p><p>Screening involves visual observations and asking passengers questions such as whether they have had known contact with Ebola cases and whether they feel ill or feverish. No one has been stopped from travelling since the screenings were introduced, said Hartl, who pointed out that the Liberian-American who died in quarantine in Lagos had left before screening was in place. But screening in his case might not have worked as he had left with no symptoms, and only reported feeling unwell on arrival in Lagos.</p><p>Ebola-affected countries are suffering economically as international airlines restrict flights, companies scale down regional operations and commercial trade is put on hold, <a href="http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/video/2014/07/25/ebola-tackling-the-outbreak-in-west-africa" title="">said the World Bank</a>. The bank, along with the International Monetary Fund, reduced this year's economic growth estimate for Guinea to 3.5%, down from their original projection of 4.5% growth.</p>
