http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2014/jul/17/ebola-sierra-leone-epidemic <p><em>Ane Bjøru Fjeldsæter is a 31-year-old psychologist from Trondheim, Norway. For the past month, she has been working for </em><a href="http://www.msf.org/" title=""><em>Médecins sans Frontières</em></a><em> (MSF) in Kailahun, Sierra Leone, helping to fight </em><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jul/14/ebola-epidemic-guinea-sierra-leone-liberia-msf-world-health-organisation" title=""><em>the largest ever outbreak of Ebola</em></a><em>, which has killed more than 600 people in three countries. She provides support and counselling to patients and their families, as well as to the staff whose job it is to deal with the dead bodies.  </em></p><p>I was expecting the Ebola epidemic to be quite gruesome and unlike anything I had seen before. But I really didn't expect its magnitude – this outbreak is enormous. In Sierra Leone, it killed off a lot of health workers before MSF even arrived. Not surprisingly, medical staff were reluctant to work with us at first. They'd never come across Ebola before – but at least they had previous experience of people suffering and people dying. But for the non-medical staff, like the hygienists – our hospital cleaners – it's been a new and disturbing experience, and a large part of my work involves helping them with counselling and support.</p><p>The hygienists have the hardest job of all because they are the ones dealing with the dead bodies. Since our Ebola centre opened two weeks ago, we've had 37 deaths: an average of two or three a day. A lot of the cleaners are young, unskilled workers. In an area with an unemployment rate of 95%, they jumped at this opportunity to get a job.</p><p>They are the ones who mop up the vomit, the stools and the blood. And when there's a death, they are the ones who retrieve the body from the isolation ward, put it in the morgue and disinfect it. In the final stages of the disease, the viral load increases massively, which means the dead bodies are extremely contagious and very dangerous to deal with.</p><figure data-media-id='gu-image-449195803'><img src='http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Environment/Pix/pictures/2014/7/16/1405525975590/MDG--MSF-Ebola-Treatment--007.jpg' alt='MDG : MSF Ebola Treatment Centre in Kailahun, Sierra Leone' width='460' height='276' class='gu-image'/><figcaption>Doctors try to feed a girl in the centre's high-contamination-risk zone. Photograph: Sylvain Cherkaoui/Cosmos for MSF </figcaption></figure><p>Dealing with the dead bodies is disturbing: the hygienists experience feelings of sadness and fear, but also disgust. When Ebola patients die, there's bleeding, vomiting and diarrhoea. The cleaners tell me they have flashbacks of the things they have seen and of things they have smelled. Even wearing a mask, you can't shut out all the smells.</p><p>Traditionally, in Sierra Leone, dead bodies are taken care of by the tribal elders. A lot of the hygienists feel they are too young to be dealing with the dead, so worry they're being disrespectful of their culture's traditions. We make sure that on each shift there is always one man and one woman, so that when someone dies, there will always be someone of the same sex to tend to them.</p><p>The local staff experience huge stigma from the community. The son of one of our workers recently died from malaria. People in his village immediately said he had caused his son's death because he was working with Ebola. It was very distressing for him.</p><p>The stigma makes it hard for the hygienists. We tell them: "You are heroes, you're doing a very important service for your community – it's absolutely vital that someone is doing this job." But although we see them as heroes, that isn't always how they are perceived by their families, their friends or their villages.</p><figure data-media-id='gu-image-449195804'><img src='http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Environment/Pix/pictures/2014/7/16/1405525722967/MDG--MSF-Ebola-Treatment--009.jpg' alt='MDG : MSF Ebola Treatment Centre in Kailahun. Sierra Leone' width='460' height='276' class='gu-image'/><figcaption>A patient attempts to rehydrate himself under the watchful eye of a nurse. Photograph: Sylvain Cherkaoui/Cosmos for MSF </figcaption></figure><p>When we discharge a patient who has survived Ebola, it makes an enormous difference to them. On Tuesday, three people who had been cured were discharged from the isolation ward, and all the cleaners were dancing, deliriously happy and taking photographs. They find ways to manage the stress: they take good care of each other; when someone is upset, they talk about it, and they are very open about voicing their concerns and difficulties.</p><p>Still, the local staff have had their lives turned upside down. But then throughout the entire district everything is upside down. Here in Kailahun, the banks are shut, the schools have been closed for more than a month, and the students are very upset that they are missing their exams. A lot of people are isolated by the fear that if they go near other people, they will get the disease. People are at a loss to understand what is happening to them.</p><p>Last week, a girl came out of the isolation ward. Her name was Bintu and she was almost two. Both her parents had tested positive for Ebola, but she tested negative, so we had to take her out of the ward because the risk of contamination was too high. That was a horrible day.</p><figure data-media-id='gu-image-449195805'><img src='http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Environment/Pix/pictures/2014/7/16/1405524312844/MDG--MSF-psychologist-Ane-009.jpg' alt='MDG : MSF psychologist Ane Bjøru Fjeldsæter at Ebola Treatment Centre in Kailahun, Sierra Leone ' width='460' height='276' class='gu-image'/><figcaption>Psychologist Ane Bjøru Fjeldsæter welcomes Tamba James, who has been tested negative for Ebola. Photograph: Sylvain Cherkaoui/Cosmos for MSF </figcaption></figure><p>The nurses told me she didn't know how to speak. For the two days she'd been in the ward, she'd been so shocked that she hadn't uttered a word. This can happen to children – it's called elective mutism. When she came out, she was in shock: she didn't make eye contact; she didn't speak to anyone. We put her in a chair and she turned around, with her back to the world.</p><p>It must have been a terribly disturbing experience for a child: to see someone come into the ward in a spacesuit; to hear them speaking to her mother in words she didn't understand; to see her mother start crying; and then to be handed over to the stranger in the spacesuit and carried off.</p><p>I sat with her for four hours, trying to talk to her in a calm and normal voice and singing her songs, to see if the shock would pass. By the end of the four hours she had turned around and was facing me. She made eye contact, she put her hand out for me to touch her, she tried to start a conversation with me. You could see that she was starting to warm up to me, and that she wasn't in the same condition.</p><p>Bintu became an orphan that day. She is in the care of our child protection partner and they will locate other family members who can take care of her. She will need to be monitored for 21 days to see that she does not develop the disease herself.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jul/15/immigration-myths-debunked-border-crisis <p>Just when you thought Washington was out to do something, the yellers pull you back in. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/14/obama-democrats-border-crisis-wilberforce-law-amendment">Bipartisan legislation from Texas lawmakers is set to be introduced</a> any moment now, in an effort (<a href="https://twitter.com/DanaBashCNN/status/489116264770842624">albeit a broad one</a>) to answer President Obama&apos;s call for &quot;an urgent humanitarian situation&quot; to the migrant crisis on the US border with Central America, and Republicans are <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2014/07/gop-border-crisis-obama-request-108919.html">reportedly interested in providing half of the emergency funding he has requested</a>. </p> <p>Yet this seems like the moment when so many immigration conspiracies – pumped for weeks by conservative websites, talk-radio hosts and Fox News – are just now ratcheting up. Somewhere (hint: national television), <a href="https://twitter.com/ErikWemple/status/489141630407311360">Dick Cheney is talking about &quot;integrity&quot; on the border</a>.</p> <p>From secret plots and diseases to the truth about Tuesday&apos;s new protests and life back in El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala, here is some sanity – with charts.</p> <h2><b><b>Theory No1: Obama is &apos;</b><b>secretly dispersing illegal immigrants around the country&apos;</b></b></h2> <p><i><b>The source:</b></i> Who else but former one-term Florida congressman Allen West, who took a break from <a href="http://www.breitbart.com/Breitbart-TV/2014/07/09/Allan-West-Obama-Would-Rather-Throw-Down-Beers-Than-Secure-Our-Border">accusing the president of drinking and smoking pot on the job</a> while <a href="http://mediamatters.org/blog/2014/07/11/conservatives-cash-in-on-impeachment-racket/200074">raising money off impeachment threats</a> to rise above &quot;all the pundits&quot; on his website. &quot;Hmm,&quot; <a href="http://allenbwest.com/2014/07/aliens-coming-neighborhood-white-house-secretly-dispersing-illegal-immigrants-around-country/">he wrote in a Monday blog post</a>, &quot;let&apos;s analyze this.&quot;</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Illegal immigrant children are being quietly dumped in states without the states’ knowledge or consent. ... Texas and Arizona have Republican Governors and are red states, and apparently President Obama has no interest in stemming the flow of illegals entering these two states. ... Nebraska is another red state – <b>could it be the liberal progressive objective is to begin altering the demographics</b> there as well? And mighty interesting that the other two places where these illegal immigrant children may be settled, Chicago and Delaware, are the home states of the president and vice president. Those are facts, not conjecture or hyperbole, and certainly not conspiracy theory.</p> </blockquote> <p><i><b>The ensuing hysterics:</b></i> &quot;If O gives amnesty to millions of illegal aliens,&quot; the conservative author Janie Johnson <a href="https://twitter.com/jjauthor/status/489046178185482241">tweeted to her nearly 79,000 followers on Tuesday morning</a>, &quot;will he also count them in the unemployment numbers? Just wondering!&quot;</p> <p><i><b>The reality: </b></i>As MSNBC&apos;s Benjy Sarlin <a href="https://twitter.com/BenjySarlin/status/486879453817999360">noted on Twitter</a> last week, &quot;[t]he &apos;fundamental transformation&apos; of America through immigration&quot; against which <a href="http://www.breitbart.com/Big-Government/2014/07/08/Exclusive-Sarah-Palin-Time-to-Impeach-President-Obama/">Sarah Palin</a> and West are pushing back &quot;is happening already.&quot; He cited <a href="http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/07/08/a-view-of-the-future-through-kindergarten-demographics/">this Census breakdown from the Pew Research Center</a>:</p>  <figure class="element element-image element--supporting" data-media-id="gu-fc-5eb47b47-332c-4c02-b528-cb7e54091ed0"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/7/15/1405452936814/a010acf5-a081-4e88-8fbe-155d41ecfe16-460x276.png" alt="hispanic children united states map" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">In 2012, one out of every American newborns were Hispanic. (<a href="http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/07/08/a-view-of-the-future-through-kindergarten-demographics/">Map via Pew Research Center</a>)</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>So, yes, Hispanic children are quietly entering states like Texas, Arizona, Nebraska and Illinois ... because they&apos;re being born there.</p> <p>The demographics of this country are altering, but <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/10/upshot/how-to-read-the-polls-in-this-years-midterms.html">that doesn&apos;t mean Democrats&apos; advantage among Hispanic voters are easy to measure</a>. And while <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/page/2010-2019/WashingtonPost/2014/07/15/National-Politics/Polling/release_357.xml">a new poll</a> shows that President Obama may <a href="http://hotair.com/archives/2014/07/15/about-that-poll-that-shows-obama-has-the-upper-hand-over-gop-on-border-crisis/">have the upper hand in favorability over Republicans</a> in dealing with the current immigration crisis, his administration is making no secret of its intentions: White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said on Tuesday afternoon that Monday&apos;s flight <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2014/07/14/migrants-returned-honduras/12656327/">carrying 40 migrant deportees back to Honduras</a> should <a href="https://twitter.com/carenbohan/status/489091462240669696">&quot;send a message&quot;</a>. Whether Allen West wants to hear it – hmm, we&apos;ll see. <b><i>—Matt Sullivan</i></b></p> <h2><b><b>Theory No2: Undocumented migrants are bringing Ebola and measles to America</b></b></h2>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-cc1254fe-0ffe-48c8-81c0-4242e310d817"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/7/15/1405453093571/a3724a91-11cc-4d33-8286-217d55d71c5d-460x276.png" alt="fox news diseases border" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">'Measles and chickenpox and leprosy?!' To which Fox's medical correspondent responded: 'Absolutely.'</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><i><b>The source:</b></i> Three weeks ago, <a href="http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2014/06/27/report-border-patrol-looking-to-house-immigrants-in-abandoned-buildings-along-rio-grande/">one local news story</a> out of South Texas led to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jul/02/border-patrol-diseases-anti-immigration-myth">a Drudge- and Fox News-fueled pile-on</a>: chicken pox, TB, even swine flu. Then, <a href="http://freebeacon.com/national-security/outbreak-on-the-border/">&quot;outbreak&quot;</a> – and now ...</p> <p><i><b>The ensuing hysterics: </b></i></p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Reports of illegal migrants carrying deadly diseases such as swine flu, dengue fever, <b>Ebola virus</b> and tuberculosis are particularly concerning. Many of the children who are coming across the border also lack basic vaccinations such as those to prevent chicken pox or <b>measles</b>. This makes those Americans that are not vaccinated – and especially young children and the elderly – particularly susceptible.</p> </blockquote> <p><i>—Rep Phil Gingrey (R - Georgia), </i><a href="http://thinkprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/gingrey_letter_to_cdc_on_public_health_crisis.pdf%20"><i>in a letter to the director of the Centers for Disease Control</i></a></p> <p><i><b>The reality:</b></i><br /></p> <p><b>EBOLA: </b>Ebola is a frightful virus, to be sure – an easy shorthand for a terrifying, exotic threat. It manifests as <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/pdf/fact-sheet.pdf">&quot;a severe, often fatal disease&quot;</a>, marked by fever, diarrhea, and, in some cases, bleeding. We don&apos;t know much about where Ebola comes from (there is no identified reservoir) and have only scratched the surface on how it spreads (human-to-human by direct contact or via infected objects, after a hypothesized first contact with an infected animal).</p> <p>But we do know this much: Ebola has never been reported in Latin America. Repeat: never. Not even in cases of laboratory contamination, <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/resources/outbreak-table.html">which have resulted</a> in human infection in Russia and England, and animal infection in the US. All naturally-occurring cases of &quot;human illness or death [due to Ebola] have occurred in Africa,&quot; <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/exposure/index.html">according to the CDC</a>. </p> <p>The largest Ebola outbreak on record is currently ravaging the west African nations of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, which may be why the disease has entered the popular imagination of US politicians looking for anti-immigrant scare tactics.<b><br /></b></p>  <figure class="element element-interactive interactive element--supporting" data-interactive="http://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js" data-canonical-url="http://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/2014/06/measles-intl/" data-alt="Measles: immunization rate by country – chart"> <a href="http://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/2014/06/measles-intl/">Measles: immunization rate by country – chart</a> <figcaption>Chart: Nadja Popovich / The Guardian</figcaption> </figure>  <p><b><b>MEASLES:</b></b> Ironically, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and Mexico – the four countries sending the largest numbers of unaccompanied minors to the US, <a href="http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/06/10/number-of-latino-children-caught-trying-to-enter-u-s-nearly-doubles-in-less-than-a-year/">according to Pew</a> – all have higher measles vaccination rates than the US.</p> <p>Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador have reported exactly zero cases of measles <a href="http://apps.who.int/immunization_monitoring/globalsummary/timeseries/tsincidencemeasles.html">each year since 2008</a> to the World Health Organization, while Mexico noted 3 in 2011. The US reports 50 to 225 annually. <b><i>—Nadja Popovich</i></b></p> <h2><b><b>Theory No3: &apos;v</b><b>iolence is likely not the primary cause of the surge of thousands of unaccompanied minors&apos;</b></b></h2> <p><b><i>The source: </i></b>On Monday, Brendan Darby of Breitbart <a href="http://www.breitbart.com/Breitbart-Texas/2014/07/14/Leaked-Intel-Report-Violence-in-Central-America-Likely-Not-Primary-Factor-in-Border-Crisis">published</a> unclassified but significantly redacted &quot;leaked documents&quot; from the El Paso Intelligence Center (Epic), a <a href="http://www.justice.gov/dea/ops/intel.shtml">DEA-run intelligence gathering and coordination group</a> focused on drug enforcement. They baldly state underage migrants are fleeing El Salvador, Honduras or Guatemala not so much because of drug- and gang-violence as they are influenced by &quot;traditional migration factors&quot; (i.e., economics) and misperceptions about their ability to remain in the US.</p> <p>The Epic analysis broadly mirrors <a href="http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/Latin-America-Monitor/2014/0710/Unaccompanied-children-not-fleeing-violence-says-Guatemala-s-first-lady-video">earlier statements by Guatemala&apos;s first lady</a> denying that there are no gangs in the municipalities from which children are fleeing (which were largely debunked).</p> <p><b><i>The ensuing hysterics:</i></b> While Darby&apos;s report got Drudged, it didn&apos;t see wide pick-up even on conservative outlets, possibly because it&apos;s so stupid.</p> <p><b><i>The reality:</i> </b>The Department of Homeland Security <a href="http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/07/01/dhs-violence-poverty-is-driving-children-to-flee-central-america-to-u-s/">reports</a> that the surge in minor refugees is due to widespread violence. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees <a href="http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/Latin-America-Monitor/2014/0710/Unaccompanied-children-not-fleeing-violence-says-Guatemala-s-first-lady-video">reports</a> that 50% of the minors it interviewed &quot;reported experiencing violence or having received threats from gangs, drug cartels, or state actors, such as the police.&quot; </p> <ul> <li>Guatemala has one of the highest violent crime rates and one of the highest murder rates in Latin America, <a href="https://www.osac.gov/pages/ContentReportDetails.aspx?cid=15656">according to the US State Department</a>.</li> <li>El Salvador&apos;s murder rate <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/27/us-elsavlador-violence-idUSBREA4Q00120140527">hit an all-time high</a> in May 2014, it&apos;s got <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/immigration-border-crisis/border-children-among-worlds-most-violent-countries-n145791">the second-highest murder rate in Latin America</a>, and the US State Department even <a href="http://travel.state.gov/content/passports/english/alertswarnings/el-salvador-travel-warning.html">issued a travel warning</a> for Americans considering going there.</li> <li>Honduras, <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/immigration-border-crisis/border-children-among-worlds-most-violent-countries-n145791">from where a significant proportion of the migrant children come</a>, has <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/07/10/child-immigrants-story/12426659/">the world&apos;s highest murder rate</a>, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/10/world/americas/fleeing-gangs-children-head-to-us-border.html?_r=0">child murders are up 77% from just a year ago</a>, and <a href="http://time.com/2984030/honduras-children-deported-us-san-pedro-sula-violence-gangs/">many child murders are thought to be gang-related</a>.</li> </ul> <p>Oh, and the crime reports Epic used to underscore its conclusions are from 2012 – before the current crisis of child migrants started, and while a gang truce was still in effect. That truce <a href="http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/ms13-expanding-after-truce-collapse-in-el-salvador">officially collapsed earlier this year</a>, but may never really have affected the murder rate – the <a href="http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2014/01/29/22491097-secret-mass-grave-threatens-el-salvadors-hard-won-gang-truce?lite">discovery of a mass grave in early 2014</a> indicated the increase in &quot;disappearances&quot; may have simply offset the supposed murder rate decline. </p> <p>And none of that takes into account Epic&apos;s long history of <a href="http://www.elpasotimes.com/ci_15304209?IADID=Search-www.elpasotimes.com-www.elpasotimes.com">distributing outdated &quot;intelligence&quot; information</a> or <a href="http://voices.washingtonpost.com/spy-talk/2010/06/audit_el_paso_intelligence_cen.html">its well-documented coordination and analysis problems</a> that have led law enforcement agencies to ignore its data for at least five years. <i><b>—Megan Carpentier</b></i><br /></p> <h2>Theory No4: <b><b>Citizens militias are more effective than the National Guard</b></b></h2>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-b8cd0d18-fc60-457e-b84f-9f8e8b0e4156"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/7/15/1405457512261/9cd9c880-c324-4bcb-9406-8221a33008a3-460x316.jpeg" alt="texas militia" width="460" height="316" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Truck driver Chris Davis was galvanizing a citizen militia before he disappeared from the spotlight. Photograph via Facebook</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p><i><b>The source:</b></i> Key players in the Republican party like Texas governor Rick Perry <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/04/us-usa-immigration-idUSKBN0F82HZ20140704">have been calling</a> for increased National Guard presence at the border, while the state&apos;s always-level-headed congressman Louie Gohmert declared that <a href="http://washington.cbslocal.com/2014/06/27/gop-lawmaker-we-are-under-invasion/">&quot;we are under invasion&quot;</a>.</p> <p>Meanwhile, other public figures like Paul Babeu, the controversial <a href="http://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/conservatives-to-block-bus">bus-blocking</a> sheriff of Pinal County, Arizona, have been highlighting criminals who cross the border. &quot;When the federal government fails to enforce our immigration laws, monsters like this get into our country,&quot; <a href="https://www.facebook.com/PaulBabeuAZ/posts/694339797305900">he wrote on Facebook</a>. &quot;Enough is enough. We MUST secure the border and deport those who are here illegally. Period.&quot;</p> <p><b><i>Ensuing hysterics: </i></b>So it&apos;s nosurprise that some citizens are … going there. In July, <a href="http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Anti-government-citizen-militia-groups-want-to-5604303.php">the San Antonio Express-News reported</a> that several anti-government groups were attempting to band together to form a citizen’s militia. The movement, known as Operation Secure Our Border, aimed to bring together armed groups committed to keeping undocumented immigrants from entering the country, and assist local law enforcement in doing so.</p> <p>Shockingly, this plan ran into trouble.</p> <p><b><i>The reality:</i> </b>First of all, the US Customs and Border Protection <a href="http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Militias-move-forward-on-border-with-Bundy-s-5612344.php">wanted nothing to do with these shenanigans</a>.</p> <p>Then, the purported leader, Chris Davis, a 37-year-old truck driver, <a href="http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Militias-move-forward-on-border-with-Bundy-s-5612344.php">was discovered to have been discharged from the Army in 2001</a> &quot;under other than honorable conditions&quot;. After word spread of Operation Secure Our Border&apos;s intent, Davis renounced the spotlight, according to the Express:</p> <blockquote class="quoted"> <p>Davis deleted his Facebook and YouTube accounts, including a 21-minute video in which he describes plans for &apos;securing the border:&apos; &apos;How?&apos; he asked on the video. ‘You see an illegal. You point your gun dead at him, right between his eyes, and you say, “Get back across the border or you will be shot.”</p> </blockquote> <p>Allies said Davis had &quot;gone black&quot;, and he <a href="http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2014/07/11/border-militia-plot-evaporates-into-cluster-coitus-as-doubts-arise-over-commander/#.U8HEGyy9u44.twitter">cancelled appearances</a> on Fox News and the Truth Broadcasting Network. While some who had rooted for Davis and his merry band were outraged that he decided to stand down, his natural allies were relieved: anti-government activist Mike Vanderboegh called Davis’s movement a <a href="http://sipseystreetirregulars.blogspot.com/2014/07/so-called-three-percenters-on-border.html">&quot;cluster-coitus in the making&quot;</a>. </p> <p>On Tuesday, even the head of the National Guard under George W Bush <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2014/07/15/sending-in-the-national-guard-isnt-the-answer/">admitted the current crisis was too complex</a> to determine &quot;whether this is an appropriate use of the Guard&quot; – the real one. <i>—<b>Kayla Epstein</b></i></p> <h2><b>Theory No5: Border residents don&apos;t want immigrants in their towns</b></h2> <p><i><b>The source: </b></i>Anti-illegal immigration activists are making a lot of noise with their bus-blocking protests – and the noise has echoed. Arrests <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/05/murrieta-california-immigration-demonstration-five-arrested">at a July 4th clash in Murrieta, California</a> became a kind of rallying cry: &quot;Who wants to be the next Murrieta?&quot; <a href="https://twitter.com/MaddowBlog/status/488779109728653312">asked Rachel Maddow</a>, rather facetiously, while pointing to forums calling for the emulation of <a href="http://seeingredaz.wordpress.com/2014/07/13/oracle-residents-mobilizing-against-feds-dump-of-illegals-update-contact-info/">&quot;the government&apos;s efforts to dump illegal aliens into their town&quot;</a> and for <a href="http://www.alipac.us/f8/protest-times-locations-july-18-19-national-protests-against-amnesty-307111/">rallies in more than 250 locations this weekend</a>.</p> <p><i><b>The ensuing hysterics:</b></i> On Tuesday, duelling protests kicked off in Oracle, Arizona, where Central American children are expected to be dropped off at a youth ranch in the area. The Drudge Report expected a <a href="https://twitter.com/Drudge_Siren/status/489084758698110976">NEW SHOWDOWN</a>. Fox News asked: <a href="http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2014/07/15/arizona-protesters-plan-to-block-bus-load-immigrant-children/">&quot;Another Murrieta?&quot;</a></p> <p><i><b>The reality: </b></i></p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/TucsonStar/statuses/489062237177643008">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Now more with &quot;welcome&quot; signs than protesters in Oracle. Live: <a href="http://t.co/N5JFZhDwkE">http://t.co/N5JFZhDwkE</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/immigration?src=hash">#immigration</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/busblockade?src=hash">#busblockade</a> <a href="http://t.co/ZqDM7lxngw">pic.twitter.com/ZqDM7lxngw</a></p>&mdash; Arizona Daily Star (@TucsonStar) <a href="https://twitter.com/TucsonStar/statuses/489062237177643008">July 15, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <p>The founding vice president of Somos America has organized a group of immigrants-rights supporters to oppose protesters in Oracle, Arizona, the <a href="http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/2014/07/15/arizona-illegal-immigration-protesters-oracle-inspired-murrieta/12660795/">Arizona Republic</a> reported.</p> <p>&quot;(We will) offer moral support to the children on the buses,&quot; Roberto Reveles told the paper. &quot;They will feel that the screaming protesters represent our nation. It does not.&quot;</p> <p>But it&apos;s not just activists who are turning out in support of the migrants.</p> <p>&quot;We view this as a refugee crisis, not an immigration issue,&quot; Oracle resident Frank C Pierson told the Arizona Republic. &quot;To treat these kids as pawns in immigration fights is seriously wrong-headed.&quot; <i><b>—</b></i><i><b>Lauren Gambino</b></i></p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jul/14/ebola-epidemic-guinea-sierra-leone-liberia-msf-world-health-organisation <p>The outbreak of Ebola in West Africa is unrelenting: according to the World Health Organisation there have now been <a href="http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/4220-ebola-virus-disease-west-africa-10-july-2014.html">888 cases and 539 deaths</a> across Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia since <a href="http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/4165-dashboard-ebola-virus-disease-evd-in-west-africa-16-june-2014.html">the virus</a> was first reported in March this year. The epidemic is unprecedented and the global health community has been left scrambling to contain the disease, for which there is no vaccine or cure. </p> <p>In a bid to boost the response to the disease, the World Health Organisation (WHO) convened a <a href="http://www.afro.who.int/en/media-centre/events/details/317-special-ministerial-meeting-on-ebola-accra.html">special meeting on 2-3 July</a> in Accra, Ghana, with health ministers from 11 West African countries and partners involved in tackling the disease.</p> <p>Here, professionals involved in fighting the deadly virus share their experiences of what it’s like to be at the epicentre of the epidemic.</p> <h2><b>Dr Ibrahim Bah, medical supervisor at the isolation centre of Hôpital National de Donka, Conakry, Guinea</b></h2> <p>I work in the department for infectious and tropical diseases so I am used to working on epidemics but this is the first time I have dealt with Ebola. It is a new disease in Guinea. Before Médecins Sans Frontières arrived, we had no specific training on dealing with the virus. At the beginning, I was scared: I saw people haemorrhaging to death. The experience is traumatising for patients too: they know we don’t have a vaccine or a cure, and they think: “I have Ebola, my life is over.”</p> <p>The earlier patients seek treatment however, the higher their chances of survival. We have had more recoveries than deaths on the ward. The first recovery was a real celebration – it gave us strength to continue working.</p> <p> Safety is paramount but working with the protective clothing is exhausting in the heat. On very hot days, you sweat so much that you can’t keep the equipment on in the ward for more than 30 to 45 minutes. </p> <p>It has been very hard for us: there is a lot of stigma attached to working with the virus and some people have been rejected by their families. But as people become more aware and realise Ebola need not be fatal, things will change.</p> <h2><b>Dr Jacob Mufunda, World Health Organisation representative, Freetown, Sierra Leone</b></h2> <p>One of the positive outcomes of the emergency ministerial meeting is that it aligned our actions. Until then, each country had been dealing with the disease individually. Yet the epicentre of the disease is the border area triangle between Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. The people living in this region are the Kissi. They speak the same language in each country and they move across borders along traditional routes.</p> <p>So WHO is very clear on this issue: closing borders would make no difference. What is crucial is that we keep focusing on surveillance and that we harmonise our approach across countries because if you use different languages and different practices to tackle the disease and approach these people, who should they believe?</p> <p>We want to encourage countries in West Africa to send their medical staff to affected countries so that they get hands-on experience. That way, if the virus spreads, they’ll be better equipped to tackle the epidemic.</p>  <figure class="element element-embed" data-alt="Map">  <iframe width='100%' height='520' frameborder='0' src='//rachelbanninglover.cartodb.com/viz/defafe84-0b3e-11e4-bac0-0e73339ffa50/embed_map?title=true&description=true&search=false&shareable=true&cartodb_logo=true&layer_selector=false&legends=true&scrollwheel=true&fullscreen=true&sublayer_options=1%7C1%7C1&sql=&sw_lat=1.7136116598836222&sw_lon=-21.741943359375&ne_lat=19.041348796589013&ne_lon=13.128662109375' allowfullscreen webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen oallowfullscreen msallowfullscreen></iframe> <figcaption> Credit: Rachel Banning-Lover</figcaption> </figure>  <h2><b>Mohamed Fofana, training manager with ActionAid, Kono District, Sierra Leone</b></h2> <p>We have just finished training 24 community outreach workers to raise awareness about Ebola. A key consideration in recruiting participants was that they are influential in their community so that when they go back, people listen to them.</p> <p>The training focused on the origins of the disease, its transmission, the signs and symptoms and what to do if you suspect a case of Ebola. We heavily emphasised the fact that transmission can happen through a dead body because in Sierra Leone, it is customary to pay your respect to the dead, to wash the body, touch it or keep clothes or sheets of the deceased, but these practices do not conform with Ebola prevention.</p> <p>If they suspect that someone is infected or has died from Ebola, outreach workers know that they should immediately notify the authorities. They must also refer the patient to the nearest health facility or make sure that no one comes into contact with the corpse if the person is dead. A specially-trained burial team will intervene instead.</p> <h2><b>Dr Bernice Dahn, deputy minister for health services, </b><b>Monrovia, </b><b>Liberia </b></h2> <p>Our biggest challenge is denial. People do not believe that Ebola is happening. There is a lot of fear and panic too and we’re struggling to get people to come into hospital when we suspect they are infected. The key for us is to align our traditional leaders with medical and health ministry officials: our society holds them in high esteem so if they are on board, they can educate their communities.</p> <p>Dealing with Ebola is labour intensive. Case detection is a door-to-door process; once identified, patients have to be taken to isolation wards; and then we need to trace all the people they have been in contact with. We also need special burial teams to handle dead bodies. Sorting out the logistics for all these interventions has stretched us.</p> <p>The difficulty is that the situation keeps evolving so we’ve had to modify our response needs: our initial strategy cost was $1.2 million but as the epidemic has progressed, we estimate we’ll now need $6.5 million. We���re still working within the constraints of the initial budget but the international community has been very supportive, so I am hopeful that we’ll be able to tackle this epidemic within the shortest possible timeframe.</p> <p><strong>Read more stories like this: </strong></p> <p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jun/19/ebola-multidisciplinary-approach-stop-epidemic">Tackling the Ebola epidemic in west Africa: why we need a holistic approach</a></p> <p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2013/feb/21/lassa-fever-sierra-leone">Lassa fever: why there are more public health questions than answers</a></p> <p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jun/24/sierra-leone-ntds-control-success">7 reasons why Sierra Leone is winning against neglected tropical diseases</a></p> <p><strong>Join the community of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development">global development</a> professionals and experts. </strong><a href="https://register.theguardian.com/global-development/"><strong>Become a GDPN member</strong></a><strong> to get more stories like this direct to your inbox</strong></p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/08/doctors-technology-ebola-africa <p>A Jeopardy-winning supercomputer is among technologies that could help prevent future Ebola epidemics such as the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/02/-sp-ebola-out-of-control-west-africa" title="">outbreak</a> that has killed more than 460 people in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia.</p><p>Doctors have called for greater use of emerging technologies to curb the outbreak, and said many cases were going undetected as victims opted for self-help or traditional cures.</p><p>"Emerging technologies can help early-warning systems, outbreak response and communication between healthcare providers, wildlife and veterinary professionals," four doctors at the Mercy hospital research laboratory in the Sierra Leone city of Bo <a href="http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2814%2961119-3/fulltext" title="">wrote in the Lancet</a>.</p><p>The team, headed by a US-based specialist, Karen Jacobsen, said smartphones should play a greater role in combating the disease.</p><p>"Our laboratory and others in the region have shown that routine syndromic surveillance systems can be designed to rely on mobile phones which have become ubiquitous in west Africa," they wrote. Researchers forecast that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/05/internet-use-mobile-phones-africa-predicted-increase-20-fold" title="">mobile internet use in Africa will increase 20-fold in the next five years</a> – double the rate of growth in the rest of the world.</p><p>Doctors – numbering as few as one per 10,000 patients in rural Guinea – have struggled to contain the spread of Ebola, which can have a fatality rate of up to 90%. Almost four decades after its discovery, the virus has no cure or vaccine.</p><p>This year IBM <a href="http://www.research.ibm.com/labs/africa/project-lucy.shtml" title="">announced</a> a $100m (£60m) project to use its Watson supercomputer to help solve African problems. Watson has been used to help treat cancer patients in the US and understands human language well enough that it was able to beat two champions on the US TV quiz show Jeopardy in 2011. Its ability to "learn" after rapidly analysing huge amounts of data sets it apart from conventional supercomputers that focus on number crunching.</p><p>IBM's west Africa director, Taiwo Otiti, said: "The beauty about Watson is it's a community computer. You could feed it information about Ebola cases, for instance, and then you could ask it questions, and it will give you a prognosis and suggest the best treatment for a particular patient based on that data."</p><p>Access to the system could enable poorer parts of Africa to "leapfrog" stages of development in much the same way that mobile phones took off across the continent in places lacking landline infrastructure, Michel Bézy, a Rwanda-based technology professor who helped develop the Watson system, told the Guardian at the project's launch.</p><p>Other technology is being adopted to help curb diseases such as measles and malaria still epidemic in Africa. Researchers in Burkina Faso use satellite data to track Saharan dust storms and their connection with meningitis, an airborne disease transmitted more easily in dusty conditions.</p><p>And simple text messages have played a vital role in health education. Fiona Mclysaght, Sierra Leone director of NGO Concern, said: "It's  a very useful medium to dispel myths and help change attitudes, and we've been using it a lot in urban areas."</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2014/jul/08/ebola-virus-west-africa-cured-preventable-sierra-leone <p>The role of the international community in current crises in the Central African Republic and northern Nigeria may be mired in confusion, but it can do something about the Ebola epidemic in west Africa.</p><p>The outbreak of the virus, which started in Guinea and has spread to Liberia and Sierra Leone, is the <a href="http://www.vox.com/2014/6/26/5839394/the-deadliest-ebola-outbreak-in-history-is-happening-right-now" title="">deadliest in recorded history</a>, with Médecins sans Frontières (MSF) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) declaring the situation <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/02/-sp-ebola-out-of-control-west-africa" title="">out of control</a>.</p><p>There are more than 759 cases across 60 sites since the first ones were confirmed in March – that's almost 50 known cases per week and a 20% increase in cases since 23 June. <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-28119365" title="">Almost 500 people have died</a> from the disease, which has spread across international borders.</p><p>Ebola has a <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs103/en/" title="">fatality rate of up to 90%</a> – once you have it, your chances of survival may be just one in 10. There is no vaccine and no cure; the only way to stop the virus is to prevent it or treat the symptoms if diagnosed early enough. It is primarily spread by contact with the blood or body fluids of an infected person and in some cases by contact with dead animals (primarily monkeys and bats) which are infected.</p><p>But here is where the international community can help. The health systems in west African countries are weak: three <a href="https://data.undp.org/dataset/Table-1-Human-Development-Index-and-its-components/wxub-qc5k" title="">countries ranked 174 (Liberia), 177 (Sierra Leone) and 178 (Guinea) out of 186 countries for human development</a>, according to the UN development programme. So, one of the world's most deadly viruses is plaguing three of the countries least equipped to cope with it.</p><p>In Sierra Leone, I have been involved in a two-year <a href="http://www.securelivelihoods.org/content/2265/Sierra-Leone" title="">research programme</a> to prevent malnutrition. This has involved spending time at some of the government-run peripheral health units (PHUs) in northern Sierra Leone, on the border with Guinea. The PHUs are the frontline of healthcare – assuming, of course, you can reach one of the 1,228 clinics across the country (one community we visited is a 6km walk from the nearest PHU). When access to state health services is limited; locals often turn to traditional healers, who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/02/-sp-ebola-out-of-control-west-africa" title="">sometimes misdiagnose Ebola and treat it as a curse</a>.</p><p>The PHUs are critical in providing immunisations, malaria treatment, delivering babies, providing free medical care to pregnant and lactating mothers and children under five – but they are not without serious problems. Staff often lack good-quality training, partly because they tend to learn through cascade models, where one person might train 10 others, who in turn train 10 more, and so on – operating like a system of Chinese whispers with all the <a href="http://www.securelivelihoods.org/publications_details.aspx?resourceid=290&amp;CategoryID=2265" title="">potential miscommunication this can involve</a>.</p><p>There is a high turnover of PHU staff owing to poor working conditions: for example, <a href="http://www.irinnews.org/report/95896/sierra-leone-drug-diversions-hamper-free-healthcare" title="">nurses earn just $55 (£32) per month</a> – roughly $1.80 per day – meaning that new, untrained staff are commonly found at the frontline of Sierra Leone's healthcare system. A lack of quality training means staff are <a href="http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2458/13/157" title="">not always equipped</a> to deliver appropriate healthcare messages or treatment. In fact, such professionals make up a large number of those who have died in the Ebola outbreak, having failed to take precautions in dealing with infected patients. The PHUs often face shortages of equipment and medicine.</p><p>To bring the virus under control, countries need more help from external partners. In the immediate term, emergency humanitarian support is needed to treat those infected and prevent further cases; MSF says it has <a href="http://www.msf.org/article/ebola-west-africa-epidemic-requires-massive-deployment-resources" title="">reached its limit</a> and that a <a href="http://www.msf.org/article/ebola-west-africa-epidemic-requires-massive-deployment-resources" title="">massive deployment of resources</a> is required. If donors and individuals want to support aid that shows tangible results in relatively short timeframes, supporting the response to the Ebola virus seems a good option that could save potentially thousands of lives.</p><p>In the longer term, support must focus on building the capacities of national health and sanitation systems to respond to emergencies and prevent such unnecessary loss of life. Ebola is not the first disease to wreak havoc in this region. Less than two years ago, Guinea and Sierra Leone faced a <a href="http://www.irinnews.org/report/96379/guinea-sierra-leone-cholera-outbreak-easing" title="">cholera outbreak that killed 392 people</a>.</p><p>Prevention might be better than cure, but it is also much harder to build capacity to do this. This is because preventative capacity is not only about technical knowledge, but about <a href="http://blogs.worldbank.org/futuredevelopment/beyond-stuff-capacity-relational-concept" title="">how well the different parts of health and sanitation systems work together</a> and interact with local dynamics, such as preference for tradition healers or stigma, for example.</p><p>Building this capacity to prevent future health emergencies is a long-term endeavour that becomes more critical with each epidemic in the region.</p><p><em>Lisa Denney is a research fellow in the politics and governance programme at the </em><a href="http://www.odi.org" title=""><em>Overseas Development Institute</em></a><em>. She leads the Secure Livelihoods Research Consortium's country programme in Sierra Leone</em></p><p>• This article was amended on 11 July 2014. An earlier version said Ebola could be spread through the water supply, ie if contaminated with infected <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/Fact_Sheets/humanitarian.pdf">urine</a>. However according to the World Health Organisation, human-to-human transmission of the virus arises from direct contact (through broken skin or mucous membranes) with the blood, secretions, organs or other bodily fluids of infected people, and indirect contact with environments contaminated with such fluids. Further information from <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/transmission/index.html"> the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> and the <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs103/en/">World Health Organisation</a>.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/02/-sp-ebola-out-of-control-west-africa <p>When ebola first struck Pujeh, a village deep in Sierra Leone’s forested interior region, residents did what they always do when a mysterious illness brings death: they consulted the traditional healer. But the elderly herbalist soon caught one of the world’s most contagious diseases, and then became a source for spreading it as visitors streamed in.<br /></p> <p>By the time officials had pinpointed Pujeh as a hotspot for the disease months later, dozens had died. “The people living in these areas said there’s no such thing as ebola,” said a district doctor who spoke on condition of anonymity. “They have their traditional beliefs and their traditional cures and they look up to their traditional leaders. Until we can bring the traditional leaders onside, it will be very difficult to convince them that ebola even exists.”</p> <p>As the death toll from the latest outbreak of the world’s deadliest virus climbed to 467 – far exceeding the previous most lethal outbreak which killed 254 people in Congo – officials and health workers are battling a surge of infections propelled by misinformation and doubt about the disease’s existence on one side, and mistrust of scandal-hit governments on the other.</p> <p>Following a Doctors Without Borders warning that the illness is “out of control” in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, west African health ministers on Wednesday began a two-day summit in Ghana’s capital of Accra to discuss ways to strengthen regional co-operation. The World Health Organisation has also warned four other west African countries – Ivory Coast, Senegal, Mali and Guinea Bissau – to prepare for the possible arrival of travellers carrying the virus.</p> <p>Some government officials have disputed the WHO’s statement, saying the increasing death toll is a sign of better surveillance. “We are not saying everything is okay but there are fewer people dying in silence now, which is a good thing – the more we can identify when and where there are fatalities, the better we can prevent further cases,” health ministry official Sakouba Keita said from Guinea’s capital of Conakry.</p> <p>The country has been the hardest hit by the virus, which first appeared there in February, before spreading through the tropical forests that sprawl into Liberia and Sierra Leone. More disturbingly, it has also jumped to all three countries’ densely-populated capitals.</p> <p>“This is different from other cases just by the fact it’s a cross-border epidemic. Previous outbreaks have been very localised, which makes them easier to isolate and contain. Now for the first time, it’s also affecting urban areas,” said Dr Nestor Ndayimirije, Liberia’s WHO representative who has handled epidemics in several other countries.</p> <p>Ebola was first identified in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Sudan in 1976, which suffered simultaneous outbreaks of different strains miles apart. </p> <p>It was named after Congo’s Ebola river, where its most lethal mutation – the Zaire strain – infected 318 people and killed 280. </p>  <figure class="element element-image element--supporting" data-media-id="gu-fc-a72943de-9e23-403c-8bfc-6121c5ac0464"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/7/2/1404303591744/f9124b54-6f90-42ab-9dbb-e1464404993d-280x420.jpeg" alt="A vendor holds up a fruit bat at a food market in Congo." width="280" height="420" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">Ebola is believed to be hosted by the fruit bat, a delicacy in Guinea and Liberia. Photograph: JIRO OSE/Reuters/Corbis</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Described by virologists as a “molecular shark”, ebola is believed to be hosted by the fruit bat, a delicacy in Guinea and Liberia. The current strain is at least the fifth mutation since its discovery in 1976. Diagnosis is often complicated by the fact symptoms mirror those of malaria, common in the region, including fever, vomiting and diarrhoea. Victims sometimes have horrific internal and external bleeding and most die of shock or multiple organ failure, although chances of survival increase dramatically if adequate treatment is received early on. No cure exists for ebola but confirmed cases are first quarantined before undergoing intensive rehydration therapy. Due to its high contagion rate, medical workers should wear head-to-toe biohazard suits even when dealing with dead patients.</p> <p>Weak public health systems have also undermined attempts to halt the disease. Sierra Leone and Liberia are both recovering from decades of back-to-back civil wars, while half a century of dictatorship in Guinea ended in 2010.</p> <p>Daily reports from Liberia’s ministry of health provide a glimpse of just how big the hurdles are. On the eve of the regional summit, two suspected cases from Voinjama had travelled to the capital Monrovia – but specimens hadn’t been collected because “the county laboratory supervisor could not be found,” internal notes said.</p> <p>The report also warned of an acute shortage of thermometers among a team dispatched to trace those who might have been in contact with suspects. Many of them feared taking temperatures in case they were exposed to the disease or attacked by locals, it added.</p> <p>But an alarmingly wide spread is partly down to geography. “The deaths have been increasing because of traditional burial rites in that region,” said Tolbert Nyenswah, Liberia’s deputy chief medical officer. The Kissi ethnicity, found in all three countries, traditionally keep their dead at home for several days, and mourners touch the deceased’s head frequently before burial.</p> <p>Ebola has a fatality rate of up to 90% and is transmitted through contact with fluids of infected people or animals, like urine, sweat, blood and saliva, even after death.</p> <p>A doctor in Sierra Leone said patients’ families often attempted to break them out of treatment centres – often successfully. “Some of them are in denial and that it is something they can treat at home, and faith healers are one of the problems for us. When you have patients disappearing like that, you don’t know where the virus will appear next.”</p> <p>When trader Fiya Lasana was diagnosed with suspected ebola in a clinic in Sierra Leone’s Kailahun district, he was put under quarantine. But convinced he had only malaria, he slipped out. Days later he returned, weak and dazed, for treatment. “My family tried prayers, but that didn’t work, so I returned,” said Lasana, who was declared ebola-free after eleven days.</p>  <figure class="element element-embed" data-alt="Map of the latest ebola outbreak in west Africa">  <iframe class="fenced" srcdoc="&lt;html&gt;&lt;head&gt;&lt;/head&gt;&lt;body&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://static.guim.co.uk/ni/1404317935763/Ebola_outbreak_map_WEB.svg&quot;style=&quot;width:100%;&quot;&gt;&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;"></iframe> </figure>  <p>Liberia’s president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, on Monday issued a warning on state radio that anyone suspected of holding ebola patients in homes or churches would be prosecuted.</p> <p>The disease has also revealed alarming mistrust between citizens and public office holders in a region with shocking corruption levels.</p> <p>Ebola was initially viewed as a government conspiracy to depopulate Sierra Leone’s Kailahun district, and fierce resistance to the arrival of health workers culminated in the stoning of a Doctors Without Borders vehicle. In Liberia, many remain adamant the outbreak is a hoax from government officials seeking to distract from a series of recent scandals, or for health officials to rake in public funds.</p> <p>“I will say this loud, the government of Liberia has come up with a new strategy to divert the Liberian people’s mind,” student Alfred Randall said. “We understand the issue of ebola, ebola is real, we agree the virus is a very terrible virus, but ebola is not in Liberia,” he said.</p> <p>Health workers at the frontline of the battle – often the first to die – face other challenges. Last week, riots broke out and an ambulance was attacked as family members fought to reclaim a victim’s corpse from a hospital in Kenema, Sierra Leone’s third largest city. On the same day, a three-man burial team was chased out of the Liberian town of Banjol where they went to bury a victim. “We need to find a special place to bury these corpses, if not, the bodies will keep piling up on us,” a member of the team said, adding that families often refused to come forward to identify dead relatives for fear of catching it.</p> <p>Officials and several hundred researchers who have poured into all three countries have scrambled to disseminate public information, seen as key to containment.</p> <p>But when the outbreak first began, popular text messages circulating in Guinea said an antidote could be found in a concoction of hot chocolate, coffee, milk, raw onions and sugar.</p> <p> “Ebola, ebola, ebola. I hear it everywhere,” said Adama Sherry from behind her market stall in Sierra Leone’s Tombo, a fishing village as yet unaffected by the virus. Sherry admitted she couldn’t list the symptoms, causes or precautions.</p> <p>Nearby, a local school had recently emptied out when word spread of routine blood tests being carried out – rumour had it that the needles would infect children with ebola.</p> <p>Liberia’s health ministry has begun putting images of ebola-ravaged corpses in newspapers and on television. “They are very graphic but it is working – people are starting to see that ebola is not just a spiritual thing that you can cure through going to church,” Nyenswah, the deputy chief medical officer, said.</p> <p>Ironically, survivors often face a “second disease” of stigmatisation. Aissata Bangoura’s family have refused to speak to her since her husband died in March, even though she has been declared virus-free.</p> <p>“During my husband’s wake, I was left standing by myself. People I have known my whole life didn’t want to approach me. As far as they’re concerned, I’m a widow and a leper,” she said.</p> <p>• Donal MacCrann in Tombo, Sierra Leone and Wade Williams in Monrovia, Liberia contributed to this report.<br /></p> <p>• This article was amended on 3 July 2014. An earlier version said it was the World Health Organisation that had issued a warning that ebola is “out of control” in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.</p>
