http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/jun/23/west-africa-ebola-epidemic-out-of-control <p>The Ebola epidemic in west Africa is "out of control" and will be contained only if politicians, religious leaders and aid agencies urgently improve their response to the unprecedented outbreak, <a href="http://www.msf.org/" title="">Médecins Sans Frontières</a> (MSF) has warned.</p><p>The disease, which is continuing to spread through Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, has so far claimed 350 lives, according to the World Health Organisation (<a href="http://www.who.int/en/" title="">WHO</a>). <a href="http://www.who.int/csr/don/2014_06_18_ebola/en/" title="">The total number of confirmed, probable or suspected cases stands at 567,</a> with the disease identified in more than 60 locations across the three countries. The disease, which can kill up to 90% of those who become infected, was first reported in Guinea in March.</p><p>Dr Bart Janssens, MSF's director of operations, said the charity had already treated 470 patients and was struggling to cope. "The epidemic is out of control," he said. "We have reached our limits. Despite the human resources and equipment deployed by MSF in the three affected countries, we are no longer able to send teams to the new outbreak sites."</p><p>MSF said that civil society and political and religious authorities were failing to recognise the scale of the epidemic, adding that prominent figures had to do more to promote the fight against the disease. Amid the panic, it said, key messages were not getting through and people were continuing to attend funerals where there were no infection-control measures in place.</p><p>Janssens said Ebola now had to be viewed as a public health issue throughout west Africa.</p><p>"The WHO, the affected countries and their neighbouring countries must deploy the resources necessary for an epidemic of this scale," he said. "In particular, qualified medical staff need to be made available, training in how to treat Ebola needs to be organised and, contact tracing and awareness-raising activities among the population need to be stepped up."</p><p>On Saturday, the WHO said a failure to gauge the severity of the initial outbreak and a subsequent relaxation of counter-measures had helped give rise to a "second wave" of the disease.</p><p>"When the epidemic started, it was a little underestimated, so that the states took a while to really prepare themselves," said Pierre Formenty, a WHO specialist.</p><p>"At the end of April, we started to see a decrease in the number of cases and we maybe saw a relaxation by the teams in the three countries, and this relaxation allowed things to restart. In addition, there were some problems with the affected populations which were sometimes not fully listened to."</p><p>In an interview with AFP, Formenty said that the WHO, MSF and others had mobilised dozens of experts but doctors alone would not be able to contain the epidemic.</p><p>"The most important things are monitoring and communication," he said. "States are getting better but the problems of communication continue. The medical corps on their own cannot stop this epidemic. It is only with the help of the population that we can fight this epidemic and stop it."</p><p>Formenty admitted that more needed to be done to explain the dangers of infection to those attending funerals or caring for the sick.</p><p>"One case can restart an entire epidemic," he said. "In an area where the quality of health services is not optimal, the populations have struggled to understand why we were asking them to make such an effort and probably we have not been able to explain both the disease and the means of control to the populations."</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jun/19/ebola-multidisciplinary-approach-stop-epidemic <p>As the <a href="http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2014/06/ebola-outbreak-spreads-as-toll-reaches-337-201461822534324796.html" title="">death toll from ebola</a> in west Africa continues to rise, there is a growing awareness of the threat of diseases transmitted from animals to people.</p><p>Ebola, a haemorrhagic fever that causes uncontrolled bleeding, is dramatic in its manifestation and has a <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs103/en/" title="">case fatality rate of up to 90%</a>. Its emergence can be sudden and unexplained, and, as the recent crisis shows, it can spread across communities and borders with alarming speed.</p><p>What the outbreak confirms is that if animal transmitted diseases such as Ebola – known as <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fen.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2FZoonosis&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEzfcoizjxSsDJjPp39mID4Biu4Mg" title="">zoonoses</a> – are to be tackled effectively, the response must go beyond media focus and immediate medical action when an epidemic hits. There is a crucial need for multidisciplinary working over the longer term to gain a holistic understanding of the <a href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DvqTT15Q-_Ds" title="">drivers of these diseases.</a></p><p>This so-called <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.onehealthinitiative.com%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNH0zJMcia1x0RE8kgwDZtWGapESRA" title="">one health</a> approach takes as its premise an understanding that human health, animal health and environmental health are all interlinked. It calls for collaborative efforts between natural and social scientists – including doctors, vets, environmental scientists, geographers and anthropologists – at local, national and international levels.</p><p>Such a holistic understanding of health is not new. It is however increasingly gaining <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.advanz.org%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNFlVhqVHYKh9itFkWZY6wJcyKfq-w" title="">traction</a> among those in the field, with the veterinary sector proving to be particularly <a href="http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/174/4/85.full" title="">quick to recognise the </a>benefits of one health.  A recent joint <a href="http://www.bbsrc.ac.uk/funding/opportunities/2012/zoonoses-emerging-livestock-systems.aspx" title="">research initiative </a> from the Department for International Development (DfID) and the social science, natural environment, medical and bioscience research councils, recognises the benefits of the approach. It aims to fund multidisciplinary research that would, among other benefits, reduce the impact of zoonoses on vulnerable people and their livestock.</p><p>When natural and social scientists work together – not just alongside each other, but meaningfully integrate their findings – it can be <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.nature.com%2Fsoapboxscience%2F2013%2F04%2F10%2Fhow-multidisciplinary-work-was-made-meaningful-for-me&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNG3sr_CTmC561yJbJODrrwfazP8YA" title="">very productive.</a> However, breaking down the barriers between researchers is one thing. The real challenge is to persuade those with the funds and the power to make <a href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ids.ac.uk%2Fpublication%2Fzoonoses-from-panic-to-planning&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNElirooojywVBfkkxMxFiGQKHYwuA" title="">cross-sector action happen</a>. One of the issues that urgently needs to be tackled is a reconsideration of funding models to help facilitate cross-sector working.</p><p>Over the past 40 years more than 60% of emerging infectious diseases affecting people have had their origin in wildlife or livestock. Many of these zoonoses may cause death more slowly than Ebola, and remain unnoticed by anybody outside the immediate populations affected by them, but their effects are often devastating.</p><p>An example is <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Ftrypanosomiasis_african%2Fen%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNHQBxXNjAEpOM6tgMXkMPwAfy2TyQ" title="">trypanosomiasis</a>, a disease caused by parasites transmitted by the tsetse fly, which affects both humans and animals and is widespread in large parts of Africa. This disease is one of four zoonoses being studied by the multidisciplinary research programme <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.driversofdisease.org%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGRliG9z2xPJp_3VyJR_yjGqi02JA" title="">Dynamic drivers of disease in Africa</a>, which is considering the complex links between ecosystems, zoonoses, health and wellbeing. While there were <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Fmediacentre%2Ffactsheets%2Ffs103%2Fen%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNE1E0c8e2dTP1addy1obh1Dl07o_A" title="">88 Ebola cases</a> reported in 2012, 50 of them fatal, there are an estimated <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.stampoutsleepingsickness.com%2Fabout-sos-%2Fsleeping-sickness-and-nagana.aspx&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNHkAit60Jo-LZ7xw9VKUkH4G9pNSQ" title="">30,000-50,000 new cases of trypanosomiasis</a> reported each year, with some 48,000 deaths recorded annually. In addition, the disease is likely to be misdiagnosed as in its early stages it is often confused with malaria and in its later stages with Aids.</p><p>Trypanosomiasis is fatal when left untreated and even when it is, it has a prolonged recovery period. As a result, it can ruin lives and livelihoods. The UN Food and Agricultural Organisation says the disease probably threatens rural development and poverty alleviation in sub-Saharan Africa <a href="http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/174/4/85.full" title="">more than any other disease</a>.</p><p>Like ebola, a multidisciplinary approach to understanding trypanosomiasis is essential if it is to be controlled. Take Zambia, where trypanosomiasis has historically acted as a limitation on human settlement, with families keeping away from fertile but highly tsetse-infested areas. Land pressure is increasingly leading to colonisation of these areas. Land clearance for cash crops such as cotton is also thought to be having an effect on tsetse populations, and thus the spread of the disease.</p><p>In addition, there are likely to be social differences in vulnerability to trypanosomiasis, based on gender roles, livelihood patterns and the different ways in which people interact with their environment. These points are aside from other, 'macro' changes, such as climate change and urbanisation, which may be having an effect on tsetse ecology and disease transmission. Thus, it can easily be seen how medical research on its own is insufficient to understand and tackle the disease.</p><p>The stories behind a host of other zoonoses – from <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.who.int%2Fmediacentre%2Ffactsheets%2Ffs207%2Fen%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEuHdf97WPr3PTwlDQPZy87w1RqzQ" title="">rift valley fever to ebola</a> – are just as complex. Only multidisciplinary research can help to reveal and unravel their complexity. Without a holistic understanding of all the inter-related factors affecting the emergence, transmission and spread of zoonoses, disease management or elimination will remain beyond our reach.</p><p><em>Naomi Marks works for the </em><a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.driversofdisease.org%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGRliG9z2xPJp_3VyJR_yjGqi02JA" title=""><em>Dynamic Drivers of Disease in Africa Consortium</em></a><em>. </em></p><p>Read more stories like this:</p><p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/may/23/dengue-fever-brazil-fifa-world-cup" title="">Football fans warned about dengue fever risk at Fifa World Cup in Brazil</a></p><p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2013/sep/16/blinding-trachoma-ethiopia-programme" title="">Blinding trachoma: why success depends on risk taking</a></p><p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2014/jan/09/ntds-diseases-disability-prevention" title="">NTDs: disease control is about much more than drugs</a></p><p><strong>Join the community of global development professionals and experts. </strong><a href="https://register.theguardian.com/global-development/" title=""><strong>Become a GDPN member</strong></a><strong> to get more stories like this direct to your inbox</strong></p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/28/relatives-sierra-leone-ebola-patients-clinic <p>Relatives of Ebola patients in Sierra Leone have been removing their loved ones from community health centres despite protests from medical staff, amid warnings from the World Health Organisation that the deadly and highly infectious disease is still spreading across west Africa nearly two months after an outbreak was first reported.</p><p>Guinea's capital, Conakry, has recorded its first new Ebola cases in more than a month, and five people have died in Sierra Leone's first confirmed outbreak of Ebola virus, according to the WHO.</p><p>"The situation is serious, you can't say it is under control as cases are continuing and it is spreading geographically," Dr Pierre Formenty, a WHO expert who recently returned from Guinea, told a news briefing in Geneva on Wednesday.</p><p>"There was no decline. In fact it is because we are not able to capture all the outbreak that we were under the impression there was a decline," he said.</p><p>In Sierra Leone, the family of one woman said they had removed her from a clinic in Koindu town, in the country's east, because they did not trust the medical system and feared she would die if a planned transfer to the general hospital in the town of Kenema went ahead, Amara Jambai, the health ministry's director of disease prevention and control, told Reuters.</p><p>On Wednesday, Jambai told the BBC that a total of six patients had been "aggressively" removed from care in Koindu, in defiance of medical staff.</p><p>When asked about the risk posed by the woman's removal from hospital in Kenema, Jambai said: "She can infect others, her family members and also those in the community. There is no news of her condition because she has been taken away so we need to search and find her and make sure that it [Ebola] doesn't spread."</p><p>Jambai said MPs and community leaders would try to talk to family members and persuade them to return her to hospital. She said there had been no news of the woman, whose identity has been kept secret, since she was taken from Koindu to her village nearby.</p><p>In Guinea, two districts north of Conakry previously untouched by the disease confirmed outbreaks through laboratory testing, the WHO said. Twelve cases, including four deaths, were reported in Telimele and Boffa between 23 and 26 May, while suspected Ebola infections were documented in the adjacent districts of Boke and Dubreka.</p><p>Aboubacar Sidiki Diakité, who heads the Guinean government's efforts to halt the virus's spread, said the origins of all the new outbreaks had been traced back to cases in Conakry. "The problem is that there are families that refuse to give information to health workers. They hid their sick to try to treat them through traditional methods," he told Reuters.</p><p>The WHO has documented a total of 281 clinical cases of Ebola, including 185 deaths in Guinea since the virus was first identified as Ebola in March. The disease is thought to have killed 11 people in Liberia, thought there have been no new cases there since 9 April.</p><p>Ebola is endemic to Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, Uganda and South Sudan. Researchers believe the west African outbreak was caused by a new strain of the virus.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/27/ebola-virus-outbreak-infectious-dance-tune <p>Few viruses can boast of being the inspiration for hit dance tunes. But then ebola – which can kill up to 90% of victims, has no vaccine or cure, and causes horrific internal and external bleeding – is not your average pathogen. When an epidemic struck west Africa's music-crazy nations of Guinea and Liberia, it spawned mass panic  – and the outbreak of a new dance accompanied to a infectious rap song.</p><p>"Ebola, Ebola in town. Don't touch your friend! No kissing, no eating something. It's dangerous!" warns the chorus of <a href="https://soundcloud.com/shadowmrgn/ebola-in-town-d-12-shadow-kuzzy-of-2kings" title="">Ebola in Town</a>, looped over a catchy, trippy electro-dance beat. At one point, the rapper describes an attempt to escape ebola by fleeing to neighbouring Guinea only to discover, in lyrics that suggest a stalking ex-lover, the disease lurking there too. Clubbers bitten by the musical bug have come up with a "no touching" jig in roadside bars of the capital, Monrovia.</p><p>"With such a high illiteracy rate, and such important messages to get across, sometimes a catchy or humorous song is the best way. I still remember ones that were made when I was a child in school here in Liberia," said bank manager Ethel Knuckles, in her 30s.</p><p>Such musical comic relief follows in the tradition of others such as Ivory Coast's <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EEFOaAtB_bg&amp;feature=player_embedded#!" title="">Crazy Chicken</a> dance, inspired by the bird flu virus. Aside from comic relief, in a region with weak public health systems, the ebola song also communicates vital information needed to curb the virus, which is spread through contact with fluids of infected people or animals, like urine, blood and saliva. This week, Sierra Leone confirmed four people had died in a district that borders southern Guinea, where the outbreak began.</p><p>Health workers have raced to contain ebola's transmission. When it appeared for the first time in Guinea this March – from where it later jumped to Liberia – popular text messages claimed an antidote could be found in of a concoction of hot chocolate, coffee, milk, sugar and raw onions. In Liberia, many initially dismissed ebola as a way for health officials to rake in money. Few took <a href="http://www.frontpageafricaonline.com/index.php/health-sci/1197-no-sex-liberia-s-ebola-epidemic-and-consequences" title="">official advice</a> to abstain from sex – coyly referred to as "no eating something" in the song – seriously.</p><p>Hosted by fruit bats, a local delicacy, the "molecular shark" has so far killed 145 people, around two thirds in Guinea.</p><p>"Timing and appropriate healthcare are crucial to whether ebola spreads, and whether victims survive. It needs to be taken very seriously but there's a tendency for people to develop a kind of paranoid psychosis about ebola," said Sakouba Keita of Guinea's health ministry.</p><p>For those who do beat the odds, Ebola in Town's call for "no touching" pre-empts the stigma that often awaits. Health workers say the terrified reactions towards survivors recalls the early days of the HIV epidemic, and can even affect relatives.</p><p>In Bakary's case, he went to the mosque to offer a thanksgiving prayer when his brother-in-law survived. "I was instantly left standing alone in the mosque. In broad daylight, people were treating me like a leper," the civil servant said by phone from Guinea's capital of Conakry. "My boss put me on forced sick leave and I haven't been called back yet." The family's children were pulled out of their private school after other parents told their classmates to avoid them.</p><p>An added complication is that medics on the frontline often face the greatest prejudice.</p><p>"You have to be scared of anyone who goes around dressed up like a cosmonaut," said Fanta Mamadou, a market trader in Nzérékoré, Guinea's second city, where residents initially refused to open their doors to health workers dressed head-to-toe <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/04/guinea-ebola-outbreak-sierra-leone-liberia" title="">biohazard suits</a>. Communities with little knowledge of the virus also <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/04/guinea-ebola-mali-idUSL5N0MW2AG20140404" title="">attacked a treatment clinic</a> at the epicentre of the epidemic, fearing relatives could catch the bug while being held in precautionary quarantine.</p><p>"Stigmatisation has now become the main challenge we are dealing with," said Marc Poncin, emergency co-ordinator of Doctors Without Borders, whose suspected or confirmed cases have dwindled to seven in Guinea. An epidemic is officially over once 42 days have passed with no new cases.</p><p>Medical workers make a point of accompanying recovered patients on their return home. "We always hug the patient in front of the family to show it is possible to live normally with a cured person," Poncin said.</p><p>For some survivors, being stigmatised is the least of their worries. "It feels miraculous to be given a second chance," said a former patient who gave only her first name, Rose. "The first thing on my mind when I got home was to hold my children, then give the house a good spring clean."</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/21/jean-marie-le-pen-ebola-population-explosion-europe-immigration <p>Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder of France's far-right Front National, has suggested the deadly virus Ebola could solve the global "population explosion" and by extension Europe's "immigration problem".</p><p>At a cocktail party before an election rally in Marseille on Tuesday evening, days before the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/european-elections" title="">European elections</a> in which the FN is leading the polls in France, Le Pen spoke of the "demographic explosion" in the world.</p><p>"Monseigneur Ebola could sort that out in three months," he said in front of journalists.</p><p>Later, addressing supporters, Le Pen, 85, said he feared the French population risked being "replaced … by immigrants".</p><p>"In our country and in all Europe, we have known a cataclysmic phenomenon – a migratory invasion that, my friends, we are seeing only the beginning of today."</p><p>Le Pen, who is standing as MEP for the south-east seat, added: "This massive immigration risks producing a real replacement of populations if we don't arrive in power soon enough to put an end to the politics of decadence that has been followed for decades."</p><p>He said that religion added an "aggravating factor" to this problem because many immigrants were Muslim and Islam had a "conquering vocation … and even more conquering when it feels strong and they feel numerous"</p><p>S.peaking in Marseille, which elected an FN mayor in one of its districts in recent elections, Le Pen was followed on stage by his daughter, party president Marine.</p><p>Once again, her father undermined her campaign to convince voters the FN has evolved from its days as a vehicle for the extreme right and Nazi apologists.</p><p>Taking the microphone, Marine Le Pen continued with the twin pillars of the party's manifesto: the anti-immigration and anti-Europe.</p><p>"That's enough. We wish to become masters in our own home once again," she told the cheering audience.</p><p>She added that France was caught between "two steel jaws", saying: "On one side we have the importing of foreign cultures by a wave of foreigners who, unlike those who came before wish to impose a change on our behaviour and our lives. On the other side, there are the European commissioners who force their crazy administration on every aspect of our daily lives."</p><p>Opinion polls have suggested that the FN could score between 23% and 25% of the vote in France this Sunday, beating the opposition centre-right UMP party and the ruling Socialists.</p><p>Jean-Marie Le Pen has been accused and convicted several times of xenophobia and antisemitism. In February 2005 a court in Paris ruled that his remarks about Muslims in an interview with Le Monde constituted an incitement to racial hatred and he was fined €10,000 (£8,100) plus €5,000 in damages. The conviction and fines were upheld on appeal. In 1987 Le Pen said he supported the forced isolation of those infected with the HIV virus. In June 1996 he complained that the French World Cup football team contained too many non-white players.</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/apr/26/mynypd-cliven-bundy-jo-becker-failure <p>As a journalist and citizen, I have always hated public relations. I believe it to be a fraudulent type of expression, a thinly veiled propaganda tool, a mercenary, French-Foreign-Legion form of communicating. So whenever a PR campaign crashes and burns – as three did this week, more spectacularly than a Bitcoin investment in Mt Gox – I couldn’t be happier.<br /></p> <p>To recap: first, an attempt by a police department to burnish its image on Twitter, <a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23MyNYPD&amp;src=typd">resulted in even more attention</a> to its officers’ inclination to beat the shit out of the very citizens they allegedly protect.<br /></p> <p>Next, a book on same-sex marriage compared a white, &quot;<a href="http://dish.andrewsullivan.com/2014/04/16/jo-beckers-troubling-travesty-of-gay-history/">handsome, bespectacled thirty-five-year-old political consultant</a>&quot; to Rosa Parks on its first page, and then went on to focus almost exclusively on rich, white men.<br /></p> <p>Finally, a white, law-breaking rancher made into a beloved folk hero by conservative media and embraced by leading Republicans, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/24/us/politics/rancher-proudly-breaks-the-law-becoming-a-hero-in-the-west.html">said &quot;the Negro&quot; is in trouble</a> because they &quot;abort their young children, they put their young men in jail, because they never learned how to pick cotton&quot;, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/apr/24/cliven-bundy-racist-comments-defenders">forcing his defenders to back-pedal wildly</a>.</p> <p>Each campaign was waged in different ways, targeting different demographics. But each shared three common, disdainful assumptions about the sector of the American public to which it was trying to &quot;relate&quot;:</p> <ol> <li>That the public would eat whatever shit was shoveled down its throat;</li> <li>That the public would stand for the systematic exclusion of the experiences of women, people of color and the economically marginalized; and</li> <li>That the public wouldn&apos;t use social media to respond in kind.</li> </ol> <p>For instance, the New York Police Department <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/23/mynypd-twitter-call-out-new-york-police-backfires">hilariously launched the #myNYPD hashtag</a>, in the misguided, bizarre belief that smiling people would tweet happy-go-lucky photos of themselves with police officers. The genius behind this campaign seemed oblivious that such images largely exist solely in Norman Rockwell paintings (and, occasionally, in the delusional imaginations of suburban white people who’ve never met the NYPD). </p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/NYPDnews/statuses/458665477409996800">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>Do you have a photo w/ a member of the NYPD? Tweet us &amp; tag it <a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23myNYPD&amp;src=hash">#myNYPD</a>. It may be featured on our Facebook. <a href="http://t.co/mE2c3oSmm6">pic.twitter.com/mE2c3oSmm6</a></p>&mdash; NYPD NEWS (@NYPDnews) <a href="https://twitter.com/NYPDnews/statuses/458665477409996800">April 22, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <p>They had clearly missed the memo that, in recent years, the major reason people use camera phones to record police interactions is because they or others are being profiled, harassed or physically assaulted by the cops.</p>  <figure class="element element-tweet" data-canonical-url="https://twitter.com/TheBardockObama/statuses/459067353540472832">  <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p>You might not have known this, but the NYPD can help you with that kink in your neck. <a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23myNYPD&amp;src=hash">#myNYPD</a> <a href="http://t.co/NTfCZstunT">pic.twitter.com/NTfCZstunT</a></p>&mdash; Bardock Obama (@TheBardockObama) <a href="https://twitter.com/TheBardockObama/statuses/459067353540472832">April 23, 2014</a></blockquote>  </figure>  <p>PR mercenaries always dream of their campaigns going viral. But as #myNYPD inspired people in cities worldwide to tweet photos of police violence, the viral contagion probably began to resemble an Ebola outbreak to whomever had unleashed the plague.</p> <p>Then there&apos;s Forcing the Spring, the new book from Becker, an investigative reporter. Her book was billed as an historic account of the same-sex marriage equality fight in the United States, replete with <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/20/magazine/how-the-president-got-to-i-do-on-same-sex-marriage.html">an excerpt in the New York Times Magazine</a>. Yet despite the gravitas of its launch, its takedown as pandering access journalism has been swift and relentless. </p> <p>Embarrassingly, Becker’s book is apparently <a href="http://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/the-new-book-about-the-marriage-equality-movement">part of a PR scheme by a small group of powerful white men</a> – the &quot;handsome, bespectacled&quot; and Rosa-Parks-esque Human Rights Campaign president Chad Griffin, and lawyers David Boies and former Bush Administration Solicitor General Ted Olsen – to cast themselves as the Great White (and largely straight!) Hope, who won over a black president and brought equality to the homosexuals of a savage nation.</p> <p>Like so much PR that comes out of Gay Inc, the book just reinforces a narrative that these rights were granted and won by a few Washington insiders. It nearly ignores decades of work by women, queer activists of color, and – most glaringly – unknown legions of grassroots activists around the country, who knocked on doors and lobbied state legislators to change hearts and minds – and then tweeted in outrage once they learned who Gay Inc said &quot;really&quot; won the war .</p> <p>And, finally, let’s look at the implosion of recently-crowned conservative folk hero Cliven Bundy. For years, Rancher Bundy has, repeatedly and flagrantly, broken the law by grazing his cattle on federal land and refusing to pay the fees owed to his government. Because he fits the narrative of a white cowboy colonizing the West (and any Native Americans, Mexicans or the Bureau of Land Management agents who get in his way, be damned!), Bundy had been given a series of wet and sloppy rhetorical kisses from many conservatives, including Senators Ted Cruz and Rand Paul.</p> <p>Bundy’s fight with the feds wasn’t a totally planned campaign. But, like John McCain embracing Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher (aka &quot;Joe the Plumber&quot;), the conservatives who rushed to embrace Bundy as an aggrieved white man with Barack Obama’s foot on his neck was a PR ploy too delicious for right-wingers to turn down. </p> <p>But as always happens whenever the establishment right embraces one of these guys, hoping their dog-whistle racism will stay stealth, it turned into a PR nightmare when their new hero start wondering aloud after ad hoc news conferences on a wooden stage on his ranch if blacks were &quot;better off as slaves, picking cotton and having a family life and doing things, or are they better off under government subsidy?&quot;</p> <p>Tellingly, this unholy trinity of major screw-ups in American spin showed not just that PR professionals consider the public to be morons – which they quite clearly do – but that the flacks are morons themselves. Social media is about social interaction, not just social persuasion; it is not, to the great consternation of flacks the world over, free PR that can always be controlled by a handful of powerful people.</p>

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/04/guinea-ebola-outbreak-sierra-leone-liberia <p>Late last month, villagers in Guinea's remote south-eastern region of Nzérékoré were greeted by a sight so alarming that many barricaded themselves indoors. A group of doctors dressed in protective suits and helmets were visiting the centre of an Ebola epidemic that has raged for six weeks.</p><p>"People were running away from the doctors who looked like cosmonauts on their way back from the moon. We have never seen anything like it. Some locked their doors, others hid themselves. It was frightening because there were all kinds of rumours about how this disease was spreading," said Bah Mamadou, a taxi driver.</p><p>It took two more days before his neighbours began to open their doors. Such reactions highlight the uphill battle facing officials and medics as they attempt to contain one of the world's rarest and most lethal viruses, which has claimed 84 lives in the outbreak and jumped borders to Sierra Leone, Liberia and Mali.</p><p>International organisations fear it could sweep across a region with weak public health services. "Prevention is the only way to contain the Ebola spread and we are desperately trying to get the message across. Posters, leaflets, radio, text messages and TV spots – we are resorting to every possible method to reach communities far and wide," said Berenger Berehoudougou, west Africa director of the aid organisation Plan International.</p><p>Officials from the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention travelled to Guinea this week to offer help, after a scare in Canada when a citizen returning from Liberia fell ill and was initially thought to have been infected.</p><p>There have been five suspected Ebola fatalities in Sierra Leone. In Liberia, where a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/31/guinea-ebola-epidemic-medecins-sans-frontieres" title="">state of emergency has closed the border with Guinea</a>, the government said this week that the latest of its nine victims had no known links to Guinea. "We have a case in Tapeta where a hunter who has not had any contact with anyone coming from Guinea got sick," the chief medical officer, Bernice Dahn, told AFP. "He was rushed to the hospital and died 30 minutes later. He never had any interaction with someone suspected to be a carrier of the virus and he has never gone to Guinea. This an a isolated case."</p><p>Described by virologists as a "molecular shark", Ebola is passed on through bodily fluids and causes extensive internal and external bleeding. The fruit bat, a delicacy in Guinea and Liberia, is a host of the virus. The World Health Organisation believes that the virus spread from Guinea's forested regions to the densely populated capital, Conakry, through one man who travelled 200 miles from the central town of Dobala.</p><p>"Unfortunately, this one person infected both family members and healthcare workers when he went to Conakry for medical attention and died," said a WHO spokesman, Gregory Hartl. Six of the man's relatives and two other people exposed to him are being kept in isolation at a hospital.</p><p>Already struggling with a measles epidemic that has infected 1,500 people since November, Guinea's health system – which ranked last in a 2011 World Bank study of beds per capita – has struggled to cope with the outbreak. Although Guinea is the world's top exporter of bauxite, mineral riches have failed to translate into prosperity. The government – recovering from almost five decades of dictatorship – took more than a month to identify the epidemic, which appeared in early February. The Brazilian mining firm <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/02/us-guinea-ebola-idUSBREA3125920140402" title="">Vale</a> has pulled its international staff from the country.</p><p>The latest infections have been passed on among family members or carers, said Sakouba Keita, a health ministry official. In one case, 10 people in one family died. "A lot of people are fleeing towns once they have any sign of a fever or headache. That's where we are psychologically today."</p><p>He said the government had a list of affected families and was placing them under 21 days' quarantine. "We also have to deal with a situation where people are using very crowded public transport from the interior to reach hospitals here. We're trying to make sure everybody hears the basic steps they can take to prevent the situation escalating," Keita said. Plan International said a co-ordinated multicountry emergency response was needed.</p><p>Last week the Senegalese music star Youssou N'Dour cancelled a concert in Conakry, fearing that a large crowd could spread the disease. Senegal's borders remain closed. Moussa Cissé, a rice trader in Senegal's southern town of Kédougou, said: "It has made things a bit difficult for us here because the weekly markets in [frontier towns] have completely shut down. People are just staying at home and trying to make ends meet."</p><p>Other countries have put in place preventive measures. Morocco has implemented strict travel controls, and Saudi Arabia has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/01/saudi-arabia-visas-guinea-liberia-ebola" title="">suspended visas</a> for an estimated 10,000 Muslim pilgrims from Guinea and Liberia. Dauda Souaré, who organises Mecca pilgrimages from Conakry, said: "It's really a massive disappointment to be placed under this kind of collective measure."</p>
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/01/guinea-ebola-outbreak-whats-being-done-explained <p>The medical aid charity Médecins sans Frontières <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/31/guinea-ebola-epidemic-medecins-sans-frontieres">warned this week</a> that Guinea faces an Ebola epidemic “of a magnitude never before seen” as the nation’s president appealed for calm amid a rising death toll. </p> <p>Since January, Guinea health authorities have reported more than 150 suspected cases and nearly 80 deaths, scattered far across the country. The outbreak has led to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/01/saudi-arabia-visas-guinea-liberia-ebola">travel alerts</a> and thrust one of the world’s most lethal infectious diseases back into the spotlight.</p> <h2>What is Ebola?</h2> <p>&quot;One of the most virulent viral diseases known to humankind&quot;, reads the WHO&apos;s alarming <a href="http://www.who.int/csr/disease/ebola/en/">first sentence on Ebola</a>, the group of five viruses with a case fatality ranging from <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs103/en/">25-90%</a> in humans. Ebola infects humans through direct contact with a sick person&apos;s (or animal&apos;s) blood or bodily fluids, or through contact with contaminated objects (such as needles and bedsheets). A &quot;viral haemorrhagic fever&quot;, symptoms at first resemble those of a normal fever, infections spread quickly among family and friends caring for sick people, and then among medical staff who haven&apos;t confirmed the cause of sickness.</p> <p>Unfortunately, the disease shares early symptoms with any number of other other illnesses, ranging from a passing fever to malaria, cholera and meningitis. Between two and 21 days, infected people might have red eyes and a rash, or <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/symptoms/index.html">suddenly experience</a> &quot;onset of fever, intense weakness, muscle pain and sore throat&quot;, &quot;followed by vomiting, diarrhea, rash, impaired kidney and liver function, and in some cases, both internal and external bleeding&quot;. </p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-1b033f75-7695-4733-91a4-75d7c0eca754"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/3/31/1396306285776/60418571-36b6-40c1-ab15-bfc1729a0a76-460x276.jpeg" alt="Ebola" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">The Ebola virus. Photograph: Frederick Murpy/CDC/EPA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Contagion survives so long as the virus is in people&apos;s blood and secretions, and with no vaccine or specialized treatment, victims must simply try to beat the disease with &quot;intensive supportive care&quot; to fight off near constant dehydration. Ebola <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/diagnosis/index.html">requires lab tests </a>to confirm, and usually appears around tropical rainforests.</p> <h2>Where is it?</h2> <p>Guinea, the west African country with a sliver of land reaching the Atlantic, is the broad center of March&apos;s outbreak. On 23 March, authorities <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/23/guinea-ebola-outbreak-conakry">confirmed infections nationwide</a>, from rural, southern towns to its capital, the port city of Conakry, where over two million people live. As doctors must quarantine the sick with extreme precaution, the wide range of infections could be disastrous. As of Monday, there have been 78 deaths from 122 suspected cases since January; the nation&apos;s health ministry has confirmed 22 of those deaths as due to Ebola. It took six weeks for the ministry to confirm Ebola since suspected cases first appeared.</p>  <figure class="element element-image" data-media-id="gu-fc-f91fe260-c733-441c-8ff9-0aa73f1bf387"> <img src="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2014/3/31/1396302247408/48cbc693-7c92-4459-8698-b7fb16405ae5-460x276.png" alt="guinea google maps" width="460" height="276" class="gu-image" /> <figcaption> <span class="element-image__caption">There has only been one other reported outbreak of Ebola in west Africa, in Ivory Coast in 1994. Photograph: /Google</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>On Tuesday, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/01/saudi-arabia-visas-guinea-liberia-ebola">Saudi Arabia suspended visas </a>for people from Guinea and Liberia. Senegal, to the north, has <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/31/guinea-ebola-epidemic-medecins-sans-frontieres">closed its borders</a>. Liberia, to the south, has reported four deaths among seven suspected and confirmed cases. Sierra Leone, almost surrounded by Guinea&apos;s borders, reports five suspected cases, and has begun screening anyone who wants to cross the border. Reuters reports that the regional airline Gambia Bird has delayed service to Conakry, the capital. A coordinator for Médecins sans Frontières <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-26825869">told the BBC</a> that this could be &quot;an epidemic of a magnitude never before seen&quot;. Liberia has <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-26825869">warned people to stop having sex</a>, kissing and shaking hands, and many people have taken to wearing gloves. </p> <h2>What&apos;s being done?</h2> <p>Without a vaccine or specific treatment, teams try to contain an outbreak immediately, meaning quarantine of sick people and the destruction or sterilization of anything that may be contaminated. Careful, standard practices – washing hands, wearing masks and gloves, clean gowns and safe injections – can mean the difference between life and death.</p> <p>Medical staff must often wear full-body protection when helping the sick, who may be placed in containment tents. Preventing further infection may also mean culling and burning infected animals, restricting movement from towns and quickly burying the dead. In short, everything possible is done to reduce and limit contact between infected people and animals. Doctors&apos; can treat infections that would complicate patient&apos;s condition, but they are otherwise limited to helping sick people stay <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/treatment/index.html">hydrated and breathe healthily</a>. The BBC reports that Guinea has <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-26735118">banned the sale and eating of bats</a>, which are often served in the country&apos;s southern forests.</p>  <figure class="element element-video" data-canonical-url="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2014/apr/01/guinea-ebola-epidemic-unprecedented-scale-video"                        data-show-ads="true"                data-video-id="2069455"                data-video-name="Guinea faces ebola epidemic on unprecedented scale – video"                data-video-provider="Reuters"                data-video-poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/4/1/1396350645265/Health-specialists-in-Gui-014.jpg"> <video data-media-id="gu-video-433487560" class="gu-video" controls="controls" poster="http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/audio/video/2014/4/1/1396350644084/Health-specialists-in-Gui-013.jpg"> <source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/mainwebsite/2014/04/01/140401Ebola-16x9.mp4"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/large/2014/04/01/140401Ebola_3gpLg16x9.3gp"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/HLS/2014/04/01/140401Ebola/140401Ebola.m3u8"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/webM/2014/04/01//140401Ebola.webm"></source><source src="http://cdn.theguardian.tv/3gp/small/2014/04/01/140401Ebola_3gpSml16x9.3gp"></source> </video> </figure>  <p>Besides efforts by national health ministries, several international groups, including the WHO and Doctors Without Borders, are helping investigate and respond. The CDC has issued<a href="http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/alert/ebola-guinea"> a travel alert</a> for Guinea, and the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/30/guinea-battles-spread-ebola-virus">EU pledged €500,000 </a>to fight the highly contagious disease.</p> <h2>Where did Ebola come from?</h2> <p>In 1976, the first known incidents of the disease broke out in two places simultaneously: one in Nzara, Sudan, and the other in the village of Yambuku, near the Ebola River in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Where the disease survives between outbreaks, called its &quot;reservoir&quot;,<a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/exposure/index.html"> is not known</a>, though fruit bats are a suspected &quot;natural host&quot;. Humans have contracted the disease through contact with chimpanzees, gorillas, monkeys, pigs, bats and other mammals, especially those found dead.</p> <p>Ebola has periodically broken out in remote villages, all in Africa, with outbreaks in the DRC and Uganda as recently as 2012, and with death tolls reaching 187 in the DRC in 2007 and 224 in Uganda in 2000. Monkeys, imported to the US from the Philippines in the 1990s, were found to have a similar species of virus, and though several people were infected, none fell ill. (The dangers of a virus like Ebola were explored in the 1995 film <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outbreak_(film)">Outbreak</a>, in which an infected monkey is set loose in America.)</p> <p> In labs in England and Russia there have been <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/exposure/index.html">three total cases </a>of contamination causing illness. </p>
